ULO1 - demonstrate an understanding of various forms of business organisation ULO2 - apply financial and management accounting principles in the preparation of financial statements ULO3 - measure and interpret information relating to financial performance, financial position, liquidity and risk indicators of businesses ULO4 - measure and interpret financial and non-financial information for managers to use in planning, decision making and control ULO5 - develop the ability to work effectively in a team and demonstrate the development of judgement, and skills in problem solving, critical thinking and analysis.

ULO1 - identify and analyse measurement systems and their relationship with the accounting Conceptual Framework ULO2 - apply the principles of double-entry and accrual accounting ULO3 - describe and apply definitions and recognition criteria for assets, liabilities, incomes and expenses as specified in the Conceptual Framework ULO4 - apply principles of selected Accounting Standards and prepare financial statements for business entities including service and retail organisations ULO5 - develop the ability to work effectively in a team; and demonstrate the development of skills in research, judgement and oral communication.

ULO1 - explain the nature and regulation of companies ULO2 - apply accounting standards and the framework in the preparation and presentation of financial statements for both single and consolidated entities ULO3 - demonstrate accounting knowledge in areas such as company operations, taxation, property, plant and equipment (acquisition and impairment), and group accounting ULO4 - examine contemporary financial accounting issues ULO5 - apply critical thinking, problem solving and presentation skills to individual and/or group activities dealing with company reporting and demonstrate in an individual summative assessment task the acquisition of a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered by ACW2120.

ULO1 - classify costs dependent on the context and purpose of related decisions ULO2 - analyse cost behaviour and estimate costs ULO3 - design, use and evaluate costing systems ULO4 - analyse and use cost information relevant to decision-making ULO5 - develop written communication skills; and apply critical thinking and problem solving skills to demonstrate the acquisition of a comprehensive knowledge of the topics covered in ACW2220.

ULO1 - examine the role of accounting information systems in analysing and providing decision support to managers ULO2 - explain the design of accounting information systems and financial models ULO3 - develop financial models to assist in decision making ULO4 - apply critical thinking, problem solving and presentation skills to individual and / or group activities dealing with accounting information systems and demonstrate in an individual summative assessment task the acquisition of a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered by ACW2420.

ULO1 - critically analyse how standard setting procedures and theories of regulation are formulated and their contribution to financial reporting globally ULO2 - apply the definition and recognition criteria for elements of financial statements and examine the associated issues ULO3 - apply accounting standards and the conceptual framework in the preparation and presentation of financial statements and the capital market ULO4 - examine contemporary financial accounting issues ULO5 - apply critical thinking, problem solving and presentation skills in dealing with advanced reporting issues and demonstrate in an individual summative assessment task the acquisition of a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered by ACW3120.

ULO1 - apply management accounting techniques to enable managers to measure and enhance organisational performance ULO2 - analyse and make recommendations regarding the design of management accounting systems ULO3 - evaluate management accounting systems in terms of their behavioural implications ULO4 - apply critical thinking, problem solving and communication skills to demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered in ACW3220.

ULO1 - demonstrate an understanding of the role, limitations and demand for audits in modern corporate society including the auditor's professional, ethical and legal obligations ULO2 - examine the auditor's role in corporate governance with particular emphasis on the detection and reporting of fraud and error ULO3 - describe the assurance framework, and apply planning processes and evidence gathering procedures that are used by auditors to form an audit opinion ULO4 - apply critical thinking, problem solving and presentation skills to individual and / or group activities dealing with auditing and assurance and demonstrate in an individual summative assessment task the acquisition of a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered by ACW3620.

ULO1 - critically evaluate the most common reporting frameworks used by organisations to report the sustainability implications of their operations ULO2 - critically evaluate the implications of government policy relating to the reporting of sustainability implications of corporate operations ULO3 - evaluate the factors effecting sustainability reporting by diverse organisations ULO4 - demonstrate an understanding of Environmental Management Systems and their implications for environmental performance measurement ULO5 - evaluate the factors effecting assurance of sustainability reports.

ULO1 - access and extract financial information from published financial reports and databases ULO2 - calculate and interpret relevant financial ratios concerned with the profitability, financial structure and solvency of listed public companies ULO3 - apply and critically assess approaches to valuation including discounted cash flow and residual income methods ULO4 - apply valuation methods to contexts such as security valuation, mergers and acquisitions and credit analysis ULO5 - apply critical thinking, problem solving and presentation skills to individual and/or group activities dealing with financial analysis and valuation.

ULO1 - demonstrate how management accounting systems can be designed to support strategy ULO2 - apply management accounting techniques to strategic business decisions ULO3 - critically assess strategic management accounting concepts and techniques ULO4 - analyse and make recommendations regarding the design of strategic management accounting systems ULO5 - apply critical thinking, problem solving and communication skills to individual and/or group activities to demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered in the unit.

ULO1 - understand the basic characteristics and applications of Big Data in the setting of business decision making ULO2 - apply SQL and relevant software to manage and analyse large data sets to obtain insights from accounting Big Data ULO3 - synthesise relevant information from academic research and industry practices to conceptualise predictive models ULO4 - employ accounting Big Data to produce predictions for corporate earnings, accounting fraud, and bankruptcy ULO5 - critically assess and test different models and select the optimal predictive models ULO6 - develop teamwork skills and present the insights from Big Data to the targeted audience.

ULO1 - compare and contrast accounting standard setting in various countries and discuss the convergence of accounting standards through an international study program ULO2 - develop a practical understanding and appreciation of culture in the development of national accounting regulations ULO3 - evaluate academic and professional papers in international accounting ULO4 - apply critical thinking, problem solving and presentation skills in individual and/or group activities dealing with international accounting.

ULO1 - explain the major steps in the development of a research project in accounting ULO2 - illustrate the key strengths and weaknesses of different accounting research designs and methods ULO3 - design and apply qualitative and quantitative data analysis techniques and interpret the output ULO4 - apply critical thinking, problem solving and presentation skills in individual and/or group activities.

ULO1 - implement a research proposal ULO2 - recognise practical problems of conducting scientific research and propose solutions ULO3 - complete a research dissertation ULO4 - develop the ability to conduct and manage a planned study ULO5 - apply critical thinking, problem solving and presentation skills in individual and/or group activities dealing with a research dissertation.

ULO1 - develop an understanding of key philosophical issues in Accounting Information Systems research, particularly the ontological foundations of the discipline ULO2 - articulate solutions to significant research problems using key paradigms in the Accounting Information Systems discipline ULO3 - critique research relating to the design and use of accounting and business information systems ULO4 - apply critical thinking, problem solving and presentation skills to individual and/or group activities dealing with issues in accounting information systems and demonstrate in an individual summative assessment tasks the acquisition of a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered by ACX4040.

ULO1 - evaluate and contrast research paradigms in auditing and assurance research ULO2 - describe and evaluate the range of methods of decision making in auditing ULO3 - critically evaluate empirical research and identify major research questions in auditing and assurance including audit quality, internal control, fraud and corporate governance ULO4 - apply critical thinking, problem solving and presentation skills in individual and/or group activities dealing with issues in auditing and assurance and demonstrate in individual summative assessment tasks the acquisition of a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered by ACX4050.

ULO1 - evaluate and contrast research paradigms and relevant theories in financial accounting research ULO2 - evaluate and contrast different research methods used in financial accounting research ULO3 - critically evaluate empirical research and develop an ability to identify major research questions in financial accounting research ULO4 - apply critical thinking, problem solving and presentation skills in individual and/or group activities dealing with issues in financial accounting research and demonstrate in individual summative assessment tasks, acquisition of a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered by ACX40

ULO1 - discuss research paradigms and relevant theories as they relate to management accounting research ULO2 - evaluate and contrast research paradigms and different research methods used in management accounting research ULO3 - critically evaluate empirical research and develop an ability to identify major research questions in management accounting research ULO4 - apply critical thinking, problem solving and presentation skills in individual and/or group activities dealing with issues in management accounting research.

ULO1 - develop an understanding the history of accounting standard setting in various countries and the international convergence of accounting standards ULO2 - develop a practical understanding and appreciation of cultural differences within the area of international accounting through an overseas visitation program ULO3 - develop a set of academic skills which include the ability to work independently, evaluate academic papers in terms of the application of theories to understand and explain differences in financial reporting, search the web and to submit assignments on time ULO4 - develop excellent oral and written communication skills to be able to analyse case studies and to lead/participate in groups from diverse cultural and social backgrounds.

ULO1 - Understand a range of opportunities for discipline-specific practitioners in interdisciplinary contexts; ULO2 - Apply collaboration, representation and communication skills for interdisciplinary engagement; ULO3 - Conduct critical enquiry relevant to an identified issue, and analyse and evaluate findings; ULO4 - Conceptualise, develop and present a creative response to a given interdisciplinary problem; ULO5 - Critically reflect on your own contributions to an interdisciplinary undertaking; ULO6 - Understand and apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the interdisciplinary study, in order to collaborate safely with peers.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding of design and design thinking, with a critical reconfiguration from an Indigenous positioning; ULO2 - Identify and discuss the major forms of Indigenous design, creative practices and ways of knowing; ULO3 - Critically examine and evaluate the changes to Indigenous creative practices, design, relationality and ways of knowing through colonisation; ULO4 - Examine how Indigenous design thinking and relational ways of knowing can provide solutions to complex issues, premised on their models of colonial resistance; ULO5 - Reflect on the value of Indigenous design thinking and relationality in your own situated experience and how to apply this to project-based problems.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate a discursive approach to the subject of your research and its field of enquiry; ULO2 - Demonstrate a critical understanding of methodologies in contemporary research, with particular emphasis on practice-based research; ULO3 - Demonstrate a critical understanding of the forms, languages and conventions (theoretical and practical) of your research and field of enquiry; ULO4 - Demonstrate a critical approach to the analysis of bibliographic and other empirical sources; ULO5 - Demonstrate an understanding of research ethics and research integrity; ULO6 - Demonstrate an appreciation of the difference between professional practice in your discipline and research in your discipline.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the principles of scientific thinking and apply them in the context of data science; ULO2 - Reflect upon how to create and deliver results in interdisciplinary teams; ULO3 - Critique the ethical and multicultural dimensions associated with data science decisions, use and quality and their possible impacts on organisations and society; ULO4 - Communicate outcomes effectively in a range of formats including orally, visually and in written form; ULO5 - Identify the various steps to perform data analysis and visualisation; ULO6 - Explore the importance of data in a variety of fields including science, IT and business.

ULO1 - Apply scientific thinking to data-oriented projects and tasks; ULO2 - Demonstrate the ability to work in a team to achieve a goal; ULO3 - Analyse the ethical issues associated with data science decisions ULO4 - Demonstrate a variety of approaches used to communicate complex ideas to potential stakeholders through a variety of techniques including role-play ULO5 - Perform a range tasks to analyse and visualise data ULO6 - Design approaches for collecting and analysing data for a range of industry problems

ULO1 - Apply scientific thinking to data-oriented projects and tasks; ULO2 - Demonstrate the ability to work in a team to achieve a goal; ULO3 - Analyse the ethical issues associated with data science decisions; ULO4 - Demonstrate a variety of approaches used to communicate complex ideas to potential stakeholders through a variety of techniques including role-play; ULO5 - Perform a range tasks to analyse and visualise data; ULO6 - Design approaches for collecting and analysing data for a range of industry problems.

ULO1 - Apply scientific thinking to data-oriented projects and tasks; ULO2 - Demonstrate the ability to work in a team to achieve a goal; ULO3 - Analyse the ethical issues associated with data science decisions; ULO4 - Demonstrate a variety of approaches used to communicate complex ideas to potential stakeholders through a variety of techniques including role-play; ULO5 - Perform a range tasks to analyse and visualise data; ULO6 - Design approaches for collecting and analysing data for a range of industry problems.

UNIT_TITLE: Introduction to the history and theory of art, design and architecture
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify works of art, design and architecture and place them in their social and historical contexts; ULO2 - Recognise relationships between art, design and architecture throughout their recent histories; ULO3 - Engage with key social, ethical, and cultural concerns in contemporary culture, as these relate to art, design and architecture; ULO4 - Critically analyse artworks, design objects and architectural structures from recent periods in the history of art, design and architecture; ULO5 - Critically discuss and reflect on the relevance of various historical style and movements in art, design and architecture to present day concerns in these fields.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Interpret the cultural significance of works of art and design by placing them in the appropriate social, cultural and artistic climate; ULO2 - Chart the aesthetic and semantic origins of works and identify their social role, engaging a structured combination of historical information and imaginative conjecture; ULO3 - Cultivate theoretical curiosity for the increasing alienation of design, art and craft in the industrial period; ULO4 - Produce a perceptive description of works and imaginatively connect such description with critical awareness; ULO5 - Present a combination of factual and subjective arguments in an articulate, critical and written manner; ULO6 - Recognise and champion critical values when conducting visual analysis and purposefully identify subjective habits and assumptions underlying attempts at historical or objective observation.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Define and understand the role of the curator within the ecology of the art world; ULO2 - Analyse and discuss the broader functions and institutions of the art industry; ULO3 - Critically analyse works of art or an exhibition and communicate findings in a variety of formats; ULO4 - Conduct curatorial research into artistic or cultural production; ULO5 - Identify socio-cultural concepts and issues in curatorial studies, including the ethical responsibilities of the profession.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate a detailed understanding of contemporary, experimental art and performance practice which centres on the body; ULO2 - Demonstrate a working knowledge of the key debates and theoretical dialogues that have occupied artists and critics in relation to performativity in art; ULO3 - Demonstrate skills in visual and critical analysis that can be applied to the investigation of the body and its performativity in art; ULO4 - Demonstrate the ability to research and write from an informed position about the body in contemporary art.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: World wide: art beyond the Western canon
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Recognise and discuss a wide variety of art from non-Western countries and regions; ULO2 - Employ, and critically engage with existing art historical methods to analyse art from non-Western countries and regions; ULO3 - Contextualise art from non-Western countries and regions, historically and culturally, within local and world contexts; ULO4 - Critically analyse the biases of Western art history and its relationship to the geo- and cultural politics informing art history; ULO5 - Situate both contemporary and historical Australian art within a wider world context.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify a number of major Western and non-Western artists and art movements after the War; ULO2 - Apply a range of methodological approaches to this art; ULO3 - Employ a critical perspective onto existing constructions of art history; ULO4 - Demonstrate an ability to thoughtfully and critically respond to images in one's own words.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the wider concerns of contemporary international art as they are played out in a local context; ULO2 - Demonstrate a detailed knowledge of contemporary Australian art and the various art institutions of Melbourne; ULO3 - Apply wider aesthetic, political and institutional concerns to particular art practices and institutions.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate an appreciation for the diverse ways in which artists have intervened in the social world since the modern period; ULO2 - Approach art history with an appreciation for the social and political forces that inform art practice; ULO3 - Analyse activist art critically in a manner that reveals the strengths and weaknesses of different artistic approaches; ULO4 - Demonstrate familiarity with the key political philosophies that have informed the production and reception of politically motivated art; ULO5 - Express verbally and in writing critical points of connection between art and social change; ULO6 - Understand the links between practice, theory and spectatorship in activist art.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: Renaissance to Baroque: Italian art and architecture in context
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the main characteristics of Renaissance, Mannerist and Baroque art and architecture; ULO2 - Understand the multiple historical, cultural, social and physical contexts of Italian art and architecture; ULO3 - Understand the principles of historical art and architectural theory, as well as their critical reception; ULO4 - Engage in on site analyses of works of visual art and architecture; ULO5 - Demonstrate your awareness of the historical precedents for, and dimensions of, your own practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: Contemporary art fieldwork: context and site
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Research and engage in on site analyses of works of visual art and architecture; ULO2 - Understand and evaluate the cultural, social and physical contexts of contemporary art exhibition; ULO3 - Engage in research fieldwork; ULO4 - Demonstrate your awareness of the precedents for, and dimensions of, your own exhibition practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the long historical debate between high and popular culture; ULO2 - Elaborate certain important interventions in this debate (Kant, Herder, Adorno, Bourdieu); ULO3 - Demonstrate an ability to use this knowledge to consider and discuss contemporary art.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: Indigenous Australian creative practice and ways of knowing
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate an appreciation, understanding and critical reconfiguration of the cultural value of Indigenous creative practices and ways of knowing; ULO2 - Recognise and discuss the major forms of Indigenous creative practices and ways of knowing; ULO3 - Critically examine and evaluate the changes to Indigenous creative practices and ways of knowing through colonisation; ULO4 - Examine the historical development and impact of Indigenous creative practices and ways of knowing on the broader Australian cultural context; ULO5 - Reflect on the value of Indigenous creative practices and knowledge in their own situated experience.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate a broad knowledge of the multi-disciplinary nature of photography; ULO2 - Demonstrate critical skills that enable you to analyse a broad range of photographic texts and contexts; ULO3 - Understand the critical and theoretical debates related to photography in society; ULO4 - Understand the two different modes of reproduction: the analogue and the digital; ULO5 - Understand the ways in which technologies of reproduction change modes of representation.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the main characteristics of Baroque and Neo-Baroque visual culture; ULO2 - Understand the historical, cultural, and social contexts of Baroque and Neo-Baroque art and media; ULO3 - Understand key aesthetic and theoretical concepts in Baroque and Neo-Baroque visual culture; ULO4 - Perform critical analyses of historical and contemporary works of visual art and architecture; ULO5 - Demonstrate your awareness of the historical and recent precedents for, and dimensions of, your own practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate a critical perspective of the selection of the voice, motives and bias of art critics and criticism; ULO2 - Appreciate criticism as a genre of writing, with the unique cultural and practical contingencies acting upon it, and understand the variety of art writing which it comprises; ULO3 - Understand the role of the curator as having a creative, political and active part in the production, mediation and dissemination of contemporary art; ULO4 - Identify and understand the developments specific to the rise of curator as an important cultural commentator, and the contemporary challenges faced by art criticism; ULO5 - Demonstrate your ability to think creatively and express your ideas clearly in written communication.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the key theoretical questions involved in the practice of art curating; ULO2 - Demonstrate a broad historical overview of the practice of curating; ULO3 - Elaborate key moments in the history of curating and of prominent historical and contemporary curators; ULO4 - Apply this knowledge to any practical act of curating you might undertake; ULO5 - Engage with the issues and theories of curating insofar as it applies to your art practice or study of art history.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Recognise and demonstrate respect for indigenous knowledge, culture, and values and their relationship to contemporary curatorial practice; ULO2 - Identify and evaluate theoretical questions relevant to contemporary curatorship; ULO3 - Outline and describe key roles, institutions and practices in the contemporary art ecology; ULO4 - Identify and apply key practical considerations involved in curating an exhibition; ULO5 - Critically analyse and interpret exhibitions verbally and in a written format; ULO6 - Apply historical and theoretical ideas in the justification of a curatorial project.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify a range of critical perspectives onto the history of Australian art; ULO2 - Show a broad familiarity with the major artists in the history of Australian art; ULO3 - Discuss a number of contemporary Australian artists and the methodological questions involved in the writing of Australian art history today; ULO4 - Demonstrate an ability to respond thoughtfully and critically to works of art in your own words.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand and articulate what a medium is both conceptually and practically; ULO2 - Analyse the debates surrounding the defence and criticism of medium specificity and the trans-disciplinary; ULO3 - Contextualise studio practice within the conceptual models explored in the unit; ULO4 - Reflect and engage in critical dialogue about the medium and its importance in twenty-first century art.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify, describe and critically analyse significant artworks, artists, curators, exhibitions and institutions within Asian modern and contemporary art histories; ULO2 - Discuss various artistic, cultural and political contexts from which modern and contemporary Asian art emerges; ULO3 - Critically analyse and evaluate the impact of key art historical scholarship and other art writing that has helped shape Asian modern and contemporary art histories; ULO4 - Apply and communicate critical research, analysis and feedback for interpreting Asian modern and contemporary art and its histories; ULO5 - Understand and be able to apply a range of theory for critically interpreting Asian modern and contemporary art, including Asia-based theoretical perspectives.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify and analyse the different places and formats in which the discussion of art takes place; ULO2 - Demonstrate practical mastery of the various genres and styles of art writing; ULO3 - Apply good work habits with regard to your own "art writing" practice; ULO4 - Develop new venues and opportunities for art writing in the 21st century; ULO5 - Employ new skills in online web publishing, graphic design and layout required to self- and other-publish online and in book and magazine production.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate a detailed understanding of contemporary, experimental art and performance practice which centres on the body; ULO2 - Demonstrate a working knowledge of the key debates and theoretical dialogues that have occupied artists and critics in relation to performativity in art; ULO3 - Demonstrate skills in visual and critical analysis that can be applied to the investigation of the body and its performativity in art; ULO4 - Demonstrate the ability to research and write from an informed position about the body in contemporary art.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: World wide: Art beyond the Western canon
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Recognise and discuss a wide variety of art from non-Western countries and regions; ULO2 - Employ, and critically engage with existing art historical methods to analyse art from non-Western countries and regions; ULO3 - Contextualise art from non-Western countries and regions, historically and culturally, within local and world contexts; ULO4 - Critically analyse the biases of Western art history and its relationship to the geo- and cultural politics informing art history; ULO5 - Situate both contemporary and historical Australian art within a wider world context.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the wider concerns of contemporary international art as they are played out in a local context; ULO2 - Demonstrate a detailed knowledge of contemporary Australian art and the various art institutions of Melbourne; ULO3 - Apply wider aesthetic, political and institutional concerns to particular art practices and institutions.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate an appreciation for the diverse ways in which artists have intervened in the social world since the modern period; ULO2 - Approach art history with an appreciation for the social and political forces that inform art practice; ULO3 - Analyse activist art critically in a manner that reveals the strengths and weaknesses of different artistic approaches; ULO4 - Demonstrate familiarity with the key political philosophies that have informed the production and reception of politically motivated art; ULO5 - Express verbally and in writing critical points of connection between art and social change; ULO6 - Understand the links between practice, theory and spectatorship in activist art.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: Renaissance to Baroque: Italian art and architecture in context
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the main characteristics of Renaissance, Mannerist and Baroque art and architecture; ULO2 - Understand the multiple historical, cultural, social and physical contexts of Italian art and architecture; ULO3 - Understand the principles of historical art and architectural theory, as well as their critical reception; ULO4 - Engage in on site analyses of works of visual art and architecture; ULO5 - Demonstrate your awareness of the historical precedents for, and dimensions of, your own practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate evidence of extensive research and independent, critical thinking; ULO2 - Appreciate the catalogue essay as a genre of writing, with the unique cultural and practical contingencies acting upon it, and understand the variety of art writing which it comprises; ULO3 - Consolidate your understanding of the role of the curator as having a creative part in the production, mediation and dissemination of contemporary art; ULO4 - Demonstrate your ability to think creatively and express your ideas clearly in written communication.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the long historical debate between high and popular culture; ULO2 - Elaborate certain important interventions in this debate (Kant, Herder, Adorno, Bourdieu); ULO3 - Demonstrate an ability to use this knowledge to consider and discuss contemporary art.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: Indigenous Australian creative practice and ways of knowing
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate an appreciation, understanding and critical reconfiguration of the cultural value of Indigenous creative practices and ways of knowing; ULO2 - Recognise and discuss the major forms of Indigenous creative practices and ways of knowing; ULO3 - Critically examine and evaluate the changes to Indigenous creative practices and ways of knowing through colonisation; ULO4 - Examine the historical development and impact of Indigenous creative practices and ways of knowing on the broader Australian cultural context; ULO5 - Reflect on the value of Indigenous creative practices and knowledge in their own situated experience.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate a broad knowledge of the history of international and Australian photography; ULO2 - Demonstrate critical skills that enable you to identify and analyse a broad range of photographs and contexts; ULO3 - Demonstrate an understanding of the critical and theoretical debates related to photography in society; ULO4 - Demonstrate an understanding of two different modes of reproduction: the analogue and the digital; ULO5 - Demonstrate an understanding of the ways in which technologies of reproduction change modes of representation.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the main characteristics of Baroque and Neo-Baroque visual culture; ULO2 - Understand the historical, cultural, and social contexts of Baroque and Neo-Baroque art and media; ULO3 - Understand key aesthetic and theoretical concepts in Baroque and Neo-Baroque visual culture; ULO4 - Perform critical analyses of historical and contemporary works of visual art and architecture; ULO5 - Demonstrate your awareness of the historical and recent precedents for, and dimensions of, your own practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate a critical perspective of the selection of the voice, motives and bias of art critics and criticism; ULO2 - Appreciate criticism as a genre of writing, with the unique cultural and practical contingencies acting upon it, and understand the variety of art writing which it comprises; ULO3 - Understand the role of the curator as having a creative, political and active part in the production, mediation and dissemination of contemporary art; ULO4 - Identify and understand the developments specific to the rise of curator as an important cultural commentator, and the contemporary challenges faced by art criticism; ULO5 - Demonstrate your ability to think creatively and express your ideas clearly in written communication.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify a range of critical perspectives onto the history of Australian art; ULO2 - Show a broad familiarity with the major artists in the history of Australian art; ULO3 - Discuss a number of contemporary Australian artists and the methodological questions involved in the writing of Australian art history today; ULO4 - Demonstrate an ability to respond thoughtfully and critically to works of art in your own words.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand and articulate what a medium is both conceptually and practically; ULO2 - Analyse the debates surrounding the defence and criticism of medium specificity and the trans-disciplinary; ULO3 - Contextualise studio practice within the conceptual models explored in the unit; ULO4 - Reflect and engage in critical dialogue about the medium and its importance in twenty-first century art.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify, describe and critically analyse significant artworks, artists, curators, exhibitions and institutions within Asian modern and contemporary art histories; ULO2 - Discuss various artistic, cultural and political contexts from which modern and contemporary Asian art emerges; ULO3 - Critically analyse and evaluate the impact of key art historical scholarship and other art writing that has helped shape Asian modern and contemporary art histories; ULO4 - Apply and communicate critical research, analysis and feedback for interpreting Asian modern and contemporary art and its histories; ULO5 - Understand and be able to apply a range of theory for critically interpreting Asian modern and contemporary art, including Asia-based theoretical perspectives.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: Project studies. Art history and theory honours
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify and critically evaluate current discourse in relation to an area of contemporary artistic production or curation; ULO2 - Advance sustained critical arguments in relation to a specialised topic; ULO3 - Use research methodology to conduct high level scholarly or curatorial research in your chosen field; ULO4 - Communicate fresh interpretations of the literature or curatorial practice in your chosen field.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: Major project - Art history and theory honours
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically reflect and respond to current discourse in relation to an area of contemporary artistic production or curation; ULO2 - Advance sustained critical arguments in relation to a specialised topic; ULO3 - Apply research methodology to conduct high level scholarly or curatorial research in your chosen field; ULO4 - Articulate interpretations of the literature or curatorial practice in yout chosen field.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: History of art in public space
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Examine the historical and theoretical constructions of the public and publicness through the lenses of politics, the digital, site specificity, and Indigenous perspectives; ULO2 - Explore the works of significant artists and industry figures working in public art in Australia and abroad; ULO3 - Critically discuss public art practice in a wider context, with consideration of the impact on local and international communities.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Work effectively in a professional environment; ULO2 - Understand the essential elements of museum and gallery administration; ULO3 - Apply and extend knowledge obtained through your degree in a professional setting; ULO4 - Work autonomously on a range of tasks, such as the installation of artworks and the marketing of exhibitions; ULO5 - Communicate the results of the internship through a reflexive journal.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate awareness of current discourses in a range of disciplines which bear on contemporary artistic production; ULO2 - Pursue critical arguments with a sense of their ideological relativity; ULO3 - Assess the bias of an investigative method, considering gender, class and ethnicity; ULO4 - Understand methodology as a critique of method and be able to practice criticism in your chosen field; ULO5 - Identify assumptions inherent in the formulation of critical questions and cultivate caution against prejudicing the outcomes of research by foreclosing on the terms of inquiry; ULO6 - Explain the basis of art works not merely as the outcome of practical constraints but the expression of cultural values.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate a grasp of key concepts in contemporary art theory relevant to the area of practice which you are pursuing; ULO2 - Relate the terms of your practice to the broader field of contemporary art; ULO3 - Practice criticism in small forums, identifying critical questions of other people's practice and considering and conjecturing how aesthetic standards are the expression of cultural values; ULO4 - Sustain an exegetical defence of your work and its placement in current visual production; ULO5 - Explain the senses in which your art practice involves research.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Analyse the complexities of internal and external communications in order to gain a leadership perspective of aprofessionally and socially diverse workplace; ULO2 - Produce reports, policy briefs, and other works that positively promotes a safer, more equitable, and ethical workingenvironment; ULO3 - Develop media strategies to productively engage with external stakeholders, the public, and the media particularly intimes of crisis; ULO4 - Collaborate with others to identify and utilize collective skills and expertise to maximize impact of media strategies, aswell as develop and utilize task management skills
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Analyse the complex forces surrounding policy questions pertaining to the rights of workers and detainees, intergovernmental institutions, media censorship, internet governance and digital piracy. ULO2 - Compare the reactions and responses to questions by different actors, for instance, governments, communities and groups directly affected by these shifts, other social groups including NGOs, firms and international organizations; ULO3 - Produce reports, policy briefs, position papers, essays and other works that reflect skills in interpreting texts, writing critically and persuasively, and crafting and defending sound arguments.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Global digital media: Issues in international and transnational communication
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain and demonstrate the implications of, and differences between, international and transnational communication; ULO2 - Explain and demonstrate the implications of, and differences between, digital and analogue media; ULO3 - Work in a team to plan and execute a project based on international communication; ULO4 - Use relevant theories and concepts to critically assess the place of digital media in the global context; ULO5 - Develop and execute academic research into historical, economic, and sociocultural aspects of global media.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Knowledge, skills and attributes necessary for understanding and engaging in advanced research; ULO2 - Increased understanding of the methods of communication research; ULO3 - Increased understanding of approaches to planning and designing research, and to writing and editing research; ULO4 - Increased knowledge, skills, and attributes necessary for independent research, enhanced capacity to formulate and research communication issues, to analyse and evaluate arguments, and to understand critical approaches to the planning, writing and editing of research; ULO5 - Enhanced intellectual independence, and greater self-reliance and critical distance in academic and professional research activity; ULO6 - Significantly increased capacity to design, manage, and carry out research projects.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Increased knowledge, skills, and attributes necessary for independent research; ULO2 - An enhanced capacity to formulate and research communication issues; ULO3 - An enhanced capacity to analyse and evaluate arguments, and to understand critical approaches to the planning, writing and editing of a research topic; ULO4 - A capacity to design, manage, and carry out a research project.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Knowledge, skills and attributes necessary for understanding and engaging in advanced research; ULO2 - An ability to design, write and edit a research thesis; ULO3 - An ability at advanced level to analyse and evaluate arguments, and to understand critical approaches relating to the communication industries and communication issues; ULO4 - The capacity to contribute advanced knowledge in the chosen area of research; ULO5 - An enhanced intellectual independence, and greater self-reliance and critical distance in intellectual and professional activity.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - To develop awareness of the range of social and professional contexts in which communication occurs; ULO2 - To develop an understanding of communication as a set of practices and to identify common features within these practices; ULO3 - To introduce some of the major ways in which communication and media have been understood at a theoretical level; ULO4 - To consider the relation between theory and practice in the field of communication and an appreciation of how they can productively inform each other; ULO5 - To introduce communications and media studies as a basis for further graduate study and professional practice in the field.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - To develop awareness of the range of social and professional contexts in which communication occurs; ULO2 - To develop an understanding of communication as a set of practices and to identify common features within these practices; ULO3 - To introduce some of the major ways in which communication and media have been understood at a theoretical level; ULO4 - To consider the relation between theory and practice in the field of communication and an appreciation of how they can productively inform each other; ULO5 - To introduce communications and media studies as a basis for further graduate study and professional practice in the field.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the function of public relations in a digitally-mediated world; ULO2 - Develop writing and communication skills required in the public relations industry; ULO3 - Write a report targeted at influencing external stakeholders; ULO4 - Develop research and analytical skills relevant to the public relations industry; ULO5 - Communicate perceptively, effectively and with cultural sensitivity; ULO6 - Demonstrate ethical values as responsible and effective global citizens in the public relations workplace.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate the ability to access, evaluate, interpret and use information appropriately from a variety of sources, especially within their disciplines; ULO2 - Employ skills and strategies for reading a variety of discipline-specific texts: textbooks, reports, research articles and others; ULO3 - Engage in critical and reflective thinking to respond to and construct academic discourses; ULO4 - Manage group dynamics and work effectively in teams to solve problems and generate desired outcomes; ULO5 - Make appropriate choices regarding context, purpose, rhetoric structure, strategies, form and style to communicate effectively for different audiences and academic communities; ULO6 - Revise and refine work in line with academic conventions, clarity and correctness; ULO7 - Demonstrate a degree of independence and integration of skills to produce a research paper in their discipline area.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate an appreciation of the centrality of skills development in academic excellence; ULO2 - Access and evaluate information needed appropriately; ULO3 - Use strategies and skills for effective, efficient and critical reading of academic texts; ULO4 - Produce essays that present a well-developed, coherent viewpoint and adhere to the conventions of academic writing; ULO5 - Effectively prepare for and deliver oral presentations; ULO6 - Maximise their learning from lectures, tutorials, reading materials and assessment tasks; ULO7 - Employ a range of skills, including academic reading, thinking and writing to academic tasks in this and other units; ULO8 - Apply teamwork, leadership and independent learning skills through various learning opportunities.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Film, Television and Screen Studies: Approaches
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the purpose and value of key film, television and screen studies approaches; ULO2 - Apply film, television and screen studies approaches to the analysis of selected moving image texts; ULO3 - Evaluate a range of critical approaches used within film, television and screen studies; ULO4 - Analyse the role played by key social, historical and political contexts in shaping the meanings of films and/or television shows; ULO5 - Plan and conduct written work that draws on film, television and screen studies approaches to critically analyse moving images
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Film, Television and Screen Studies: Forms
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the techniques used to create meaning in a range of moving image texts; ULO2 - Analyse films, television shows and other screen-based media, giving particular attention to their stylistic features and narrational strategies ULO3 - Interpret the themes and meanings of moving image texts through reference to their formal features and techniques; ULO4 - Evaluate critical debates on moving image analysis and interpretation, and on particular films and television shows; ULO5 - Plan and conduct written work exploring different aspects of narrative, style and form
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify and discuss the various economic, political and cultural forces which shape the practical work of media production; ULO2 - Explain the historical development of media industries; ULO3 - Recognise and use available frameworks for making sense of media texts; ULO4 - Analyse and evaluate the contribution of these frameworks to the production of dominant, or common sense, understandings of the world.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe and explain the development of communication technologies using theoretical frameworks and conceptual tools; ULO2 - Identify and explain the social and political uses of communications technologies; ULO3 - Recognise and discuss communication as an active production and negotiation of meanings, not just the transmission of information; ULO4 - Identify and analyse relations between media texts and technologies, the identities and capacities of producers and audiences, and the aspirations of governments and other powerful social actors; ULO5 - Use reading and note taking skills to develop critical perspectives on communication.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically analyse TV shows by drawing upon skills in textual analysis; ULO2 - Identify the main features of particular TV genres; ULO3 - Apply theories developed in Television Studies to the analysis of TV shows; ULO4 - Evaluate critical debates on television and on particular TV shows; ULO5 - Plan and conduct written work on how meaning is created in TV shows.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Analyse films with particular attention to their main formal and stylistic features; ULO2 - Identify techniques used to create meaning in films; ULO3 - Apply theories from Film Studies to facilitate the analysis of films; ULO4 - Evaluate critical debates on cinema and on particular films; ULO5 - Plan and conduct written work on how meaning is created in cinema.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify relevant resources and key issues; ULO2 - Relate key issues to different disciplinary contexts; ULO3 - Discuss key areas of inquiry within Sexuality Studies across disciplines; ULO4 - Examine the extent to which sexuality as a primary analytical category is useful; ULO5 - Formulate and structure a logical and coherent argument that is well supported by relevant evidence; ULO6 - Communicate perceptively, effectively and with cultural sensitivity; ULO7 - Demonstrate ethical values, cross-cultural competency as a responsible and effective global citizen.

OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the different types of creative writing and their related forms and techniques; ULO2 - Recognise form and techniques in the practice of creative writing to convey the meaning of a text; ULO3 - Identify the specific function of each creative writing type, and techniques unique to it (I.e. poetry); ULO4 - Utilise close reading skills to develop writing skills; ULO5 - Work independently and collaboratively (via peer reviewing) on short pieces of creative writing; ULO6 - Utilise technical aspects to enhance the quality of their creative writing.

UNIT_TITLE: Writing techniques: Forms and literary devices
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify and use a range of practices and techniques in contemporary writing through reading, analysis and practice; ULO2 - Communicate in a range literary and other forms and for a variety of audiences; ULO3 - Edit, proof and prepare copy for publication; ULO4 - Review and critique the work of peers as a member of an online writing group.

UNIT_TITLE: Introduction to world politics and history
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the major historical events and political conflicts of the twentieth century as studied in the unit; ULO2 - Identify and locate historical places on maps; ULO3 - Describe the main ideologies of the twentieth century; ULO4 - Explain the role played by these ideologies in the events and conflicts studied in the unit; ULO5 - Analyse the causes and consequences of major events and political conflicts of the twentieth century; ULO6 - Interpret primary and secondary documents through developing critical reading skills; ULO7 - Communicate ideas and arguments in verbal form; ULO8 - Write research reports and essays.

UNIT_TITLE: Transformation from above: Globalisation and the state
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the most important debates about globalization and its likely development; ULO2 - Explain the concept of the (nation)-state and evaluate the impact of globalization on the state; ULO3 - Explain why globalization has produced such a diverse group of opponents; ULO4 - Evaluate the causes and impacts of current global trends; ULO5 - Communicate ideas and arguments in verbal form; ULO6 - Write research reports and essays.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate an ability to identify and research a news story, conduct interviews and gather appropriate evidence in the print and online media; ULO2 - Demonstrate an ability to select an advantageous medium for presentation, and report in a clear, concise and factual way using news conventions in at least two media; ULO3 - Identify, observe key ethical and legal obligations associated with print and online journalism, and reflect critically on their own and others' performance in this regard; ULO4 - Work independently and collaboratively in learning and production processes, including online forums, to produce print and online journalism; ULO5 - Demonstrate an ability to set and meet deadlines, and report under pressure; ULO6 - Demonstrate an awareness of local, national and international people and events relevant to current affairs and media issues; ULO7 - Demonstrate a critical awareness of the capacities, limitations and socio-professional implications of journalistic practices in different media.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Create, manipulate and edit digital images using industry-relevant software; ULO2 - Recognise and assess the issues, constraints and potential of digital visual culture for industry and societies; ULO3 - Analyse and communicate the relevance of digital visual culture and the social, cultural and political implications it has for contemporary societies.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Situate the historical development of the internet and describe the fundamental features that distinguish the internet and digital media from earlier forms of media technology; ULO2 - Use examples to demonstrate the relevance of the internet and digital media to emerging local and global socioeconomic, cultural and political contexts; ULO3 - Critically evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of common scholarly explanations of the emergence and diffusion of the internet and digital media within society; ULO4 - Use the practical skills of reading, note taking and writing to formulate and structure a logical and coherent argument that is well supported by relevant evidence.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Analyse and explain the practical, infrastructural and socio-technological aspects of e-commerce; ULO2 - Assess the tensions between the needs of users, the competition between e-merchants, platform owners and governments; ULO3 - Explain and use online analytics of user traffic and behavior.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe and explain the main features that distinguish digital screen media from earlier types of screen production; ULO2 - Identify and describe the different genres of digital screen media; ULO3 - Apply theoretical frameworks to explain the historical, textual and critical significance of digital screen technologies; ULO4 - Critically evaluate scholarly perspectives of the impact of digital screens on moving image aesthetics, the media industries and society; ULO5 - Formulate and structure a logical and coherent argument that is well supported by relevant evidence.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify and assess a range of writing structures and techniques; ULO2 - Evaluate a range of experimental writing strategies; ULO3 - Utilise research and critical reflection skills in the exegetical stages of the creative writing process; ULO4 - Edit, proof and prepare copy for publication; ULO5 - Review and critique the work of peers as a member of an online writing group.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Malaysia School of Arts and Social Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain and demonstrate how the media influence society and culture; ULO2 - Explain and demonstrate the particular impacts of mobile media on youth; ULO3 - Critically evaluate and analyse academic sources in relation to relevant theories, concepts, and case studies; ULO4 - Independently identify, evaluate, and critically assess non-academic sources in relation to relevant theories, concepts, and case studies; ULO5 - Contextualise and explain how mobile media relate to diverse global cultural, social, political, and economic contexts.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the conventions associated with film genres; ULO2 - Evaluate the differences between Western and non-Western works classified under a particular genre; ULO3 - Interpret genre using concepts like intertextuality and hybridity, and how they are part of what constitute a genre; ULO4 - Write a detailed research into a specific genre; ULO5 - Explain the ways in that genres are socio-culturally and historically determined and often ambiguous and tend to encompass divergent, even contradictory; ULO6 - Evaluate the ambiguous nature of genres in terms of their apparently contradiction; i.e. being bound by certain conventions while simultaneously transgressing them.

UNIT_TITLE: Film histories: From 1895 to the present
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Discuss film form and style across a range of national contexts and in different periods of film history; ULO2 - Explain the main developments in the technological evolution of the cinematic apparatus and how this has shaped cinema's aesthetic and institutional agendas; ULO3 - Evaluate the key factors in shaping the evolution of cinema as a technology, as a business and as an art; ULO4 - Assess the impact of cinema's changing industrial structure on its cinematic output; ULO5 - Identify and explain the main ways in which cinema has been shaped by its changing social and political contexts from the late 19th to the early 21st centuries.

Students will meet the objectives of the unit by:  A. Participating actively in tutorial discussions;  B. Reading critically about the topics covered in lectures;  C. Demonstrating in the examination knowledge and understanding of key concepts and theoretical debates on global economic governance and their application to different case studies.

UNIT_TITLE: Advanced research methodologies in media, film and journalism
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate a sound understanding of the kinds of methodologies which can be applied in media, film and journalism; ULO2 - Analyse and expound the key ethical questions involved in scholarly or journalistic research; ULO3 - Participate effectively in collaborative learning activities at a sustained high level; ULO4 - Demonstrate a clear understanding of the relationship between theory, methodology and analysis in research; ULO5 - Demonstrate a clear understanding of the points of continuity and difference between scholarly research and research in journalism and other media fields; ULO6 - Identify the points of difference between journalistic and scholarly codes of ethics and prescribe when they respectively apply; ULO7 - Produce written work for assessment of a quality appropriate to doctoral studies.

UNIT_TITLE: Film, media and communication studies: The state of the fields
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate a broad understanding of the histories and disciplinary trajectories of film studies, communication studies, media studies, cultural studies and journalism ULO2 - Identify the major commonalities and differences between these fields ULO3 - Demonstrate an awareness of the intersection of the fields (as fields of scholarship) with fields of practice and with social and political movements beyond the academy. ULO4 - Provide a critical account of interdisciplinarity within the fields ULO5 - Outline the institutional location of the fields, their varying formation through teaching and research and their international influences and distribution ULO6 - Demonstrate awareness of the varying use of key concepts across the fields (for example, 'medium', 'audience', 'discourse', 'culture', 'genre' and 'power') ULO7 - Reflect critically on where their own doctoral or masters research project sits within larger intellectual and disciplinary contexts.
