UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Compare and contrast the biopsychosocial (BPS) model of addiction with other models of addiction. ULO2 - Critically evaluate factors related to the aetiology of addiction with reference to the research evidence base. ULO3 - Outline the neurobiological and genetic bases of addictive behaviours. ULO4 - Explain the psychological processes of addictive behaviours. ULO5 - Explain the sociocultural bases of addictive behaviours (dual diagnosis, Indigenous, youth, older adult, LGBTI, transcultural). ULO6 - Synthesise the implications of the harm minimisation approach for understanding public health policies and interventions. ULO7 - Identify concepts and methods used in the literature to determine whether process addictions should be grouped with substance addictions. ULO8 - Identify research evidence investigating how theories and models of addiction are used in the development of policies relevant to alcohol and other drugs and process addictions.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically analyse addiction models and discourses from a sociocultural perspective. ULO2 - Analyse ways in which addiction is discussed and framed in popular media, public dialogue and scientific inquiry, historically and today. ULO3 - Explain sociocultural and ethical considerations that converge with addiction science and policy. ULO4 - Evaluate the role of addictive behaviours in contemporary cultural practices, identities, meanings and values, including among specific groups (such as youth, sexual and gender minorities, Indigenous Australians). ULO5 - Examine the dynamic of physical, social and psychological landscapes in relation to addiction and the maintenance of health and well-being. ULO6 - Appraise the role of sociocultural factors in changing patterns and phenomenology of addictive behaviours, across the general population and within specific groups. ULO7 - Propose evidence-informed addiction interventions that account for sociocultural models and philosophies. ULO8 - Interpret and evaluate contemporary addiction research related to contextual factors, such as ethnography, autobiography and narrative analysis,?and its role in intervention and practice settings.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Addiction policies, prevention and public health
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically review the evidence-base of epidemiological and public health policy research in relation to licit and illicit addictive substances, gambling, and gaming. ULO2 - Synthesise ideas to effectively communicate with one another and academic experts around specific issues in addiction epidemiology, public policy and public health. ULO3 - Appraise public health strategies and policy processes in addiction, critiquing how individual, community and institutional forces can shape policy direction and focus. ULO4 - Compare and contrast policy responses to drug use across drug types and across different jurisdictions both within Australia and overseas. ULO5 - Determine the role and contribution of population-based prevention strategies and activities compared with individual-based prevention strategies and activities. ULO6 - Evaluate primary, secondary and tertiary public health measures across different aspects of addiction. ULO7 - Examine the crossover of individual public health prevention levels in the context of addictive behaviours. ULO8 - Identify evidence-based policy positions and responses relating to alcohol and other drugs and process addictions.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Addiction assessment and treatment: Practice and innovation
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Analyse the treatment system, including the various modalities of treatment in the AOD sector (including face-to-face, telephone and online-based treatments), and describe the social, economic and political influences on a treatment system planning. ULO2 - Critically evaluate the biopsychosocial framework for AOD screening and assessment, demonstrating an understanding of commonly used measures and diagnostic tools. ULO3 - Integrate information from screening and assessment into an individualised case formulation and treatment plan. ULO4 - Communicate evidence based psychosocial treatment approaches including Brief Interventions and Motivational Interviewing, Cognitive Behavioural Therapy, Dialectical Behavioural Therapy, Mindfulness, Acceptance and Commitment Therapy, Contingency Management and Family Therapy. ULO5 - Review the role of medication treatments in addictions, including withdrawal and maintenance pharmacotherapies, in accordance with current guidelines. ULO6 - Compare evidence based treatment approaches in gambling, including the use of psychological and pharmacological treatments. ULO7 - Determine how treatments can be adapted to the needs of special populations, such as youth, LGBTIQ communities, Indigenous populations and people with co-occurring disorders. ULO8 - Critically evaluate the evidence for mutual aid and peer-based models of aftercare and recovery.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Synthesise and critique the rationale and history of the recovery movement ULO2 - Synthesise the origins of the recovery movement across key countries (Australia, UK, US) and between addiction and mental health fields in each of these settings ULO3 - Critically review the definitions of recovery that have been advanced and summarise the strengths and weaknesses of each, from a practice and from a policy perspective ULO4 - Analyse the role of mutual aid and peer empowerment in the recovery movement and offer a critical analysis of the evidence for mutual aid groups, in particular 12-step groups ULO5 - Critically review the research methods and evidence models most appropriate within a recovery paradigm ULO6 - Critically appraise the appeal and risks of the recovery movement to policy makers and its potential role implications for specialist treatment service provision ULO7 - Summarise and critically appraise the strength of the evidence base for recovery as a viable paradigm and its implications for service delivery, and commissioning recovery-oriented systems of care. ULO8 - Summarise the innovations from the desistance movement in criminology and review its applicability to the addiction and mental health recovery movements.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Co-occurring disorders in mental health and addiction
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically review the limitations and assumptions of the various terminologies used to describe individuals with co-occurring disorders and how they are applied in different clinical and service settings. ULO2 - Discuss critically the prevalence of co-occurring disorders and common diagnostic combinations within a broader psychosocial context. ULO3 - Critique the major theoretical models on the aetiology of co-occurring disorders and how these determine priorities for clinical management and policy. ULO4 - Summarise and synthesise the unique challenges of supporting individuals and families with co-occurring disorders, relating to those with mental health or alcohol and other drug (AOD) disorders alone. ULO5 - Critically appraise common screening and assessment tools for cognitive impairment in this population and discuss how treatment approaches may need to be adapted. ULO6 - Critically review the treatment models of care for co-occurring disorders (e.g. parallel, sequential, integrated care, outreach etc), and evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of such models in improving outcomes for clients with co-occurring disorders. ULO7 - Evaluate gaps and limitations in translating evidence-based interventions and treatment models for co-occurring disorders into policy and into clinical practice. ULO8 - Formulate integrated assessment and treatment plans for clients with co-occurring disorders.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Developmental factors: Children and families, youth and early interventions
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify and contextualise developmental factors that contribute to addictive behaviours in young people ULO2 - Explain youth substance abuse in terms of family and social contexts such as trauma and youth disadvantage ULO3 - Synthesise the available information on the impact of addictive behaviours on young people and families in order to demonstrate an understanding of the complexity of this issue ULO4 - Reflect critically on psychological and sociological theories relevant to key contemporary issues in youth addiction ULO5 - Evaluate and critique current responses to addiction including school-based interventions ULO6 - Compare and contrast contemporary models of addiction behaviours among young people through an analysis of national and international research ULO7 - Critically review the effectiveness of family-based interventions including Family Inclusive Practice and Parents Under Pressure ULO8 - Critically appraise a range of youth-focused AOD treatment services and key elements of youth-focused service delivery ULO9 - Critically review policy issues relevant to youth including those pertaining to social media.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Gambling, gaming and other process addictions
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Recognise the prevalence and characteristics of gambling and gaming disorders and other emerging process addictions. ULO2 - Critique the differences and similarities between behavioural or process addictions and substance disorders. ULO3 - Contextualise issues regarding gambling and gaming addictions, among other process addictions, including precipitating, maintaining and relapsing factors on individuals, families, communities or social systems taking into consideration specific population (e.g., gender, age, culture, sex orientation including Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, and Intersex (LGBTI)). ULO4 - Discuss issues related to engagement, harm reduction, or early interventions to provide an evidence based assessment, treatment and relapse prevention plan for a person with one or multiple behavioural addictions. ULO5 - Compare and contrast the unique features associated with a range of behaviourally based addictive disorders on individuals, families, communities or social systems taking into consideration specific population (e.g., gender, age, culture, sex orientation). ULO6 - Critically analyse the research, available treatments and subclinical problems related to one or more behavioural addictions. ULO7 - Present an argument to potential policy makers that can contribute to behaviour change in the area of the process addictions. ULO8 - Critically analyse the contribution of the internet to gambling, gaming, and other process addictions concerning specific populations including individuals, families, communities or social systems (taking into consideration e.g., gender, age, culture, sex orientation). ULO9 - Compare and contrast the difference between biological (e.g. for food and reproduction) and non-biological needs (e.g., for gaming, shopping) in the consolidated and emerging process addictions.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the evolution and general properties of planets, solar systems, stars, and galaxies. ULO2 - Explain celestial and planetary motions across the night sky using naked eye observations and planetarium software. ULO3 - Reflect on the scale of the universe and earth's place in it. ULO4 - Execute experiments involving telescopes and other simple apparatus and analyse, interpret and evaluate the results arising from them. ULO5 - Demonstrate ability to analyse and solve problems using quantitative and qualitative analysis.

ULO1 - Explain modern theories of stellar and planetary formation and evolution ULO2 - Compare properties of our Solar system to that of extrasolar planetary systems ULO3 - Describe the necessary conditions for life and how species evolve ULO4 - Debate how development of life is dependent on the conditions in the physical universe ULO5 - Theorise on the possibilities of other life forms, interstellar communication and interstellar travel.

ULO1 - Use fundamental concepts in observational astronomy to model the motion of the planets and stars, to measure the brightness of celestial objects using astronomical images, and to determine astronomical distances. ULO2 - Explain the workings and limitations of telescopes and interferometers, to quantify their angular resolution and limitations, and describe how astronomers use these instruments to obtain images and spectra. ULO3 - Use optical, infrared and radio observations to measure stellar masses, stellar radii, astronomical distances, temperatures and the expansion of the Universe. ULO4 - Interpret astronomical observations and justify conclusions drawn via a concise and accurate written report.

ULO1 - Apply basic physical and mathematical principles, including dimensional analysis, to gain a quantitative and qualitative understanding of astrophysical processes. ULO2 - Explain how observational data may be exploited to infer the physical properties of cosmic objects. ULO3 - Solve astrophysical problems, and complete a range of problem solving tasks by drawing on physical principles. ULO4 - Use practical skills to computationally model astrophysical systems. ULO5 - Demonstrate a knowledge of stars, planets, and galaxies sufficient to undertake further astrophysics studies at Level 3.

ULO1 - Explain the nature of stellar structure and evolution, stellar life histories, and their ultimate fates;how they produce energy, how they synthesise the chemical elements, and their ultimate fates; ULO2 - Describe ?stellar nucleosythesis, the main nuclear processes, their products and sites within stars and the elements they produce; ULO3 - Build simple computer models of stars and galaxies; ULO4 - Distinguish and classify ?different types of galaxies; ULO5 - Explain ?the relationships between stellar evolution, galactic evolution, and the creation of the elements; ULO6 - Demonstrate ?the implications of the observed nature of galaxies for theories of the universe; ULO7 - Describe the morphology and kinematics of the Milky Way; ULO8 - Summarise ?the significance of dark matter to galactic structure; ULO9 - Illustrate the use of multi-wavelength data for understanding stars and galaxies; ULO10 - Write an observational research report.

ULO1 - Describe the reasons for supplanting Newtonian physics with relativity theory; ULO2 - Use special relativity to predict the behaviour of relativistic particles; ULO3 - Discuss the relativistic paradoxes in an informed way; ULO4 - Discuss the experimental and theoretical foundations of general relativity; ULO5 - Discuss our current understanding of the beginnings, nature, and fate of the Universe; ULO6 - Evaluate the current uncertainties in cosmology; ULO7 - Analyse physical problems geometrically, thinking logically in a theory at odds with common experience; ULO8 - Use mathematics to solve complex problems; ULO9 - Interpret complex mathematical results and communicate them in written form.

UNIT_TITLE: Computational astrophysics and the extreme universe
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate a basic understanding of astrophysical fluid dynamics, involving the physics of fluids at high Mach number, including sound waves and shocks. ULO2 - Demonstrate practical skills in scientific computing, computational modelling, data analysis and visualisation. ULO3 - Perform computer simulations of astrophysical flows using advanced astrophysical simulation codes, and demonstrate an understanding of the physics and mathematics behind modern large-scale astrophysical simulations. ULO4 - Obtain understanding of high-energy astrophysics phenomena such as supernovae and gamma-ray bursts, compact objects, and matter under extreme astrophysical conditions such in the interiors of stars.? This includes nuclear reactions and numerical modelling of simple nuclear reaction networks.

ULO1 - Students who have completed this unit will have an enhanced ability to critically analyse and evaluate the concepts employed in, and the doctrines accepted by, the world's religions, as well as to put forward ideas and arguments of their own in a clear and coherent way. ("Monash Graduates will be critical and creative scholars who apply research skills to a range of challenges, and communicate perceptively and effectively.") ULO2 - Students who have completed this unit will have an enhanced knowledge of theories of religion, and of key issues in contemporary studies of religion.

ULO1 - This unit contributes to the making of responsible and effective global citizens who: + engage in an internationalised world, + exhibit cross-cultural competence, and + demonstrate ethical values. (Cf. Monash Graduate Attributes). Having a basic grasp of the world's religions is part of cross-cultural competence (and is a basic requirement for responsible and effective global citizens). And the development of tolerance of diverse religious beliefs is a basic component of ethical maturity. ULO2 - Students who have completed this unit will have a deeper understanding of the history, core teachings and central practices of a wide range of religious traditions. They will be able to identify distinguishing features of these various religious traditions, and to compare points of similarity and difference among them. ULO3 - Students who have completed this unit will also have an enhanced ability to critically analyse and evaluate the concepts employed in, and the doctrines accepted by, the world's religions, as well as to put forward ideas and arguments of their own in a clear and coherent way. ("Monash Graduates will be critical and creative scholars who apply research skills to a range of challenges, and communicate perceptively and effectively.")

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - to formulate and critically evaluate concepts for understanding differences, similarities, connections and contestations between cultures; ULO2 - to perceive the ways in which knowledge about cultural comparisons enables us to be critically aware of our own cultural practices; ULO3 - to appreciate some of the important features of a number of Indigenous cultures in Australia; ULO4 - to discuss some of the key contemporary issues which exist in the relationship between Indigenous and Non-Indigenous cultures in Australia; and ULO5 - to write clear and well-supported responses to various questions posed through exercises and essays.

ULO1 - Identify and explain basic anthropological concepts and methods; ULO2 - Articulate key concepts and methods for understanding cultural difference; ULO3 - Recognise contemporary global issues and how understandings differ globally depending on perception; ULO4 - Recognise the significance of culture and difference in the development of solutions to problems affecting individuals, collectives and environments; ULO5 - Read, think and write reflectively and critically about basic anthropological concepts and issues; ULO6 - Use prescribed academic research skills to locate, analyse and communicate information.

ULO1 - An appropriate level of understanding of a range of theoretical orientations to human behaviour ULO2 - The ability to discriminate between evidence, interpretation, opinion and fact in evaluating these theories and concepts ULO3 - An ability to communicate, orally and in a written form, their understanding of these theories and concepts.

UNIT_TITLE: Extreme earth! Natural hazards and human vulnerability

UNIT_TITLE: Terrorism and political violence: An introduction
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - A. an introductory understanding of the cultural, economic, social and religious circumstances that lie behind the spread of politically motivated violence; b. how terrorism is a unique form of political violence, yet one that shares some features, objectives and tactics of guerrilla warfare, organized crime and political assassination. ULO2 - An introductory understanding of how politically motivated violence challenges established domestic and international political norms; especially in areas of citizenship, state surveillance and international cooperation between states; ULO3 - An introductory understanding of violent extremist networks and extremist groups and how these networks and groups impact upon national and international security; ULO4 - An ability to contribute in a constructive way to public debates in areas such as social alienation and its relationship to violence; the ethics of using violence to resolve conflicts; the limits of legal and acceptable political action. ULO5 - A solid grounding in a range of case-based examples of terrorist and other forms of political violence as perpetrated by various ideological and theological actors from different parts of the world, including Australia.

ULO1 - Weekly lecture/seminar on prescribed texts will provide basic concepts of issues in translation studies in general and text analysis in particular. The unit will focus on basic principles of text analysis and some popular theories relating to the translation of source texts into target language. Students are expected to improve their understanding of theories relating to the classification and identification of source texts and translation strategies; ULO2 - By applying some basic concepts relating to text analysis and translation strategy to weekly project-based translation practice and class discussion, students are also expected to improve their ability to determine correct translation strategies for specific professional purposes; ULO3 - Three supervised translation projects and one examination in a time controlled situation will be conducted during the semesters in order to test the progress of students.

ULO1 - Weekly lecture/seminar on prescribed texts will further provide concepts of issues in translation studies in general and text analysis in particular. The unit will further introduce principles of text analysis and theories relating to the translation of source texts into target language. Students will further develop their understanding of theories relating to the classification and identification of source texts and translation strategies; ULO2 - By applying basic concepts relating to text analysis and translation strategy to weekly project-based translation practice and class discussion, students will further improve their ability to determine correct translation strategies specific for professional purposes; ULO3 - Three supervised translation projects and one examination in a time controlled situation will be conducted during the semesters in order to test the progress of students.

UNIT_TITLE: The European Union from consensus to crisis

UNIT_TITLE: War and memory: Resistance, massacre and representation in second world war Italy

UNIT_TITLE: The Minotaur to the Trojan war: Aegean archaeology
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the major features of Minoan and Mycenaean societies, their interaction with each other and contemporary societies; ULO2 - Evaluate the methods of archaeological interpretation used to reconstruct the nature of these societies and the challenges posed in this; ULO3 - Critically appraise archaeological reports and interpretations; ULO4 - Discuss current archaeological methodologies and their application in the Aegean context; ULO5 - Assess how interpretation can be affected by the conditioning of the excavator/historian; ULO6 - Evaluate the use of textual sources and archaeological evidence to aid the reconstruction of ancient societies, focussing on the Minoan and Mycenaean cultures.

UNIT_TITLE: Asian imaginaries: Bollywood, Manga and other fictions in Asian worlds

UNIT_TITLE: Study tour in Italy: Etruscan and Roman archaeology
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Recognise the major sites and features of the Etruscan and Roman cultures; ULO2 - Identify key features of the art, architecture, beliefs, politics and histories of the Etruscan and Roman cultures; ULO3 - Evaluate the cultural exchange that operated between Etruscan and Roman cultures and their neighbours; ULO4 - Distinguish the advantages and limitations of different methods employed in reconstructing the past; ULO5 - Employ diverse approaches in the reconstruction of the past; ULO6 - Engage with debates surrounding the (re-)presentation of the past within the public domain.

ULO1 - Identify the historical context within which 5th century Athens flourished; ULO2 - Analyse the process by which Athens established an empire which, in turn, facilitated her innovative artistic and cultural achievements; ULO3 - Describe the principles of Greek art and architecture, major ideas and individuals in philosophy, history, and theatre, and the nature and ideological structure of Athenian radical democracy; ULO4 - Apply critical and analytical skills to the study of archaeological, textual, epigraphic, and numismatic evidence; ULO5 - Debate concepts and events related to the history, society, and material culture of 5th century Athens, through in-class discussion and a re-enactment meeting of the Athenian ekklesia (assembly).

UNIT_TITLE: The archaeology of death in ancient Egypt
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - identify and describe archaeological methods and theories to used in studying the customs and practices involved in death; ULO2 - analyse the main textual and archaeological sources for the reconstruction of Egyptian culture and critically assess the theories used to interpret them; ULO3 - describe the main features of Egyptian culture from the emergence of a unified state to the end of the Middle Kingdom; ULO4 - discuss elements of the ancient Egyptian world view and how this influences our interpretation of their culture and artefacts; ULO5 - communicate findings verbally and in writing.

UNIT_TITLE: Interrogating racism: Indigenous Australians and the state
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - The relationship between Indigenous Australians and social institutions ULO2 - How theories of race and experiences of racism continue to impact upon Indigenous people; ULO3 - In addition engaged with issues of research and research methodologies in relation to racism and prejudice in contemporary Australia.

UNIT_TITLE: Race and power: Imagining Indigenous Australia
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate, both orally and in writing an appreciation of the broad social, cultural and historical context in which contemporary dialogues between Indigenous people and white Australia operate. ULO2 - Demonstrate an understanding of the key theoretical frameworks through which white Australia claims knowledge about and power over Indigenous peoples and cultures. ULO3 - Describe and critically assess the central themes and issues that have shaped white Australian knowledge about Indigenous peoples and cultures. ULO4 - Acknowledge and critically examine the difference between white Australia's representational constructs of Indigenous people and the historic and contemporary realities of Australia's Indigenous peoples'. ULO5 - Acknowledge and critically examine the power and privilege of whiteness in contemporary Australian society. ULO6 - Demonstrate the various study skills and techniques necessary to successfully complete this unit and other Indigenous Studies units.

UNIT_TITLE: Contesting laws: Heritage, culture and land
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe and critically compare both orally and in writing the major shifts in approaches to native title and land rights. ULO2 - Evaluate the prevailing attitudes which dominate current thinking about native title from a range of disciplinary perspectives, including law, history, anthropology and archaeology. ULO3 - Understand the importance of native title and land rights to social justice and reconciliation. ULO4 - Critically analyse legal, political and historical representations of native title and understand their relationship to debates concerning the cultural politics of representation and self-determination. ULO5 - Demonstrate both orally and in writing an understanding of native title debates in terms of historical and contemporary relations between Indigenous peoples and the law.

UNIT_TITLE: Hearing the country: Studies in Indigenous Australian ethnoecology
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - To explore in depth the way in which people describe their relationship with country. ULO2 - To explore the way in which environmental and biological knowledge is encoded.? ULO3 - To study ecological and scientific systems within the context of a culture.? ULO4 - To explore how language, history, tradition, material culture, spirituality, kinship, emotion and politics are all ways in which people negotiate a relationship with the environment.? ULO5 - To study the anthropological discourse with landscape and how knowledge about landscapes are encoded. This will involve issues such as kinship and ceremony, language and understanding ethnobiological zoological/botanical taxonomy in comparison to western Linnaean zoological and botanical taxonomy. The course will use actual case studies and will involve manipulating original material collected by the lecturer and other researchers.? ULO6 - Address the academic debates in relation to ethnoecology from the school of thought which places cognition at the forefront of this discipline to those that believe other issues such as culture, time and concepts such as tradition and religion also influence people and their relationship to the environment.?

ULO1 - Describe and explain what magic, ritual and spiritual beliefs mean to people in the modern world; ULO2 - Appraise the contributions that anthropologists and sociologists of magic and religion have made to knowledge of human societies; ULO3 - Employ case studies of rituals and associated cosmologies in a variety of sociocultural settings to examine critically the cultural borders established between the fields of science and spiritual belief. ULO4 - Read, think and respond reflectively and critically to global issues and challenges; ULO5 - Utilise developing academic qualitative research skills to locate, link, critically analyse and communicate theory and evidence.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - design and develop an individual professional writing project; ULO2 - analyse communication needs in an organisational context; ULO3 - show an understanding of the principles of project design and documentation; ULO4 - demonstrate a detailed understanding of professional communication issues in the contemporary global context; ULO5 - present the key message of a project in various forms and situations such as an oral presentation, video presentation, text summary or media release.

UNIT_TITLE: Reading the Past: Shakespeare and Renaissance literature
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - have a familiarity with the various and changing intellectual contexts -- aesthetic, philosophical, religious, scientific, political and social -- of the pre-Romantic period and of the ways in which they form and inform its literature; ULO2 - have an understanding of the ways in which a variety of poetic and dramatic texts explore the concepts of power (political, social and sexual) and of desire (religious, courtly, neo-Platonic and sexual) in the pre-Romantic period; ULO3 - have the ability to respond imaginatively and critically to texts of a period of English literature whose traditions and conventions, though very different from those of the present, have had a significant influence on it; ULO4 - have some understanding of the complexity of gender- and race-representation in pre-Romantic literature; ULO5 - have the ability to apply different critical approaches to pre-Romantic texts and to the preoccupations and themes which they embody; ULO6 - have the ability to argue, interpret and analyse effectively both in written work and orally in seminar discussion.

ULO1 - Explain the historic context of the development of the main genres of children's literature, and of contemporary trends and issues; ULO2 - Discuss the ways in which different cultures construct different ideas of childhood, and of implied child readers; ULO3 - Critically analyse the ways in which adult and child readers learn to construct cultural paradigms, particularly relating to gender and race, through their reading; ULO4 - Apply skills pertaining to narratology, deconstruction and discourse analysis; ULO5 - Recognise and analyse the ideological significance of childhood reading; ULO6 - Explore the cultural contexts surrounding the production and reception of children's literature.

UNIT_TITLE: Australian film and television: Local and global
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Examine a range of film and television texts as representations of Australian national experience; ULO2 - Explain the place of the Australian film and television industries in relation to theories of globalization; ULO3 - Analyse the impact of government policy and further economic and political constraints on the national film and television industries; ULO4 - Analyse texts in relation to contemporary reformulations of nationalism; ULO5 - Critically engage with written and visual texts in a clear and confident manner in both written and oral presentation.

ULO1 - Recognise that meaning is not simply an intra-textual property of a particular text but an effect of historically specific inter- and extra-textual material technologies or institutions; ULO2 - Demonstrate an understanding of the concept of intertextuality in film and television studies and its relation to genre through the categories of quotation, allusion, translation and adaptation; ULO3 - Translate the in-principle concept of intertextuality into an understanding of the particular institutional structures that maintain the categories of film and television series, serials, remakes and sequels; ULO4 - Display an ability to critically engage with written and visual texts in a clear and confident manner in both written and oral presentation.

UNIT_TITLE: Screen storytelling: From classical narrative to multi-media world building
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding of narrative organisation of a variety of screen texts; ULO2 - Demonstrate an understanding of how other parameters of film, TV and other forms of screen communication (editing, mise en scene, cinematography, and sound as well as interactional and immersive techniques) relate to storytelling; ULO3 - Develop awareness of theoretical frameworks, current debates and research methods in narratology; ULO4 - Demonstrate an ability to formulate critical arguments and specific interpretations of screen texts informed by the theoretical and historical understanding of narrative.

UNIT_TITLE: Film and television industries and technologies: key contexts
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Recognise that meaning is not simply an intra-textual property of a particular text but an effect of historically specific extra-textual, material technologies or institutions; ULO2 - Demonstrate an understanding of historically specific material technologies of production, distribution, exhibition and reception, in relation to a range of contemporary and historical film and television examples; ULO3 - Develop a methodology for investigating the material - social, historical and political - difference of specific national film and television texts and industries.

ULO1 - Understand how environmental policy-making and management is positioned within governance structures and broader social and political contexts. ULO2 - Understand the main approaches to policy and management ULO3 - Understand the geographical relationship between environmental issues, policy and management across local, national, international, and global levels ULO4 - Understand the strengths and limitations of scientific knowledge in environmental policy and management

UNIT_TITLE: Writing resistance: Understanding the power of Indigenous story-telling through literature
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Discuss the development of Indigenous literary texts across different aesthetic/cultural/linguistic traditions and historical/geopolitical/national contexts; ULO2 - Discuss the ways in which knowledge about literary comparison enables us to be critically aware of our own literary assumptions, expectations, judgments and representational practices; ULO3 - Develop critical analytic written practice, in or about literary genres such as fiction, poetry, memoir with special reference to Indigenous literary traditions and practices; ULO4 - Undertake independent research in literary studies, using print and electronic sources; ULO5 - Apply a range of approaches and critical reading skills in the field of Indigenous literary studies in a comparative framework.

ULO1 - Explain the procedural dynamics of crime and criminal justice policy making; ULO2 - Identify and evaluate key obstacles to effective and human crime and justice policy making; ULO3 - Devise innovative solutions to policy related challenges ULO4 - Identify and evaluate the key challenges to effective policy implementation and evaluation

ULO1 - Recognise the ongoing significance of the criminal justice system in Indigenous justice and injustice; ULO2 - Critically engage with concepts vital to Indigenous justice and injustice concerning the operation and structure of the Australian criminal justice system; ULO3 - Communicate in respectful and culturally appropriate and sensitive ways; ULO4 - Reflect on their own connections to critical Indigenous issues; ULO5 - Generate and present respectful scholarship that is informed by Indigenous and non-Indigenous perspectives on racialised inequality within the criminal justice system.

ULO1 - Identify and explain key concepts in gender theory and contemporary feminist theories; ULO2 - Explain how patterns of gender operate in social structures and critically analyse the social and political effects that emerge; ULO3 - Critically read and analyse theoretical texts and apply this knowledge to everyday social contexts; ULO4 - Use evidence to develop and sustain theoretical arguments related to gender and sociological theory; ULO5 - Communicate theoretical concepts clearly and effectively.

ULO1 - A grounded working knowledge of the major theoretical and methodological approaches on sex and the media; ULO2 - An informed theoretical critique of how gender and sexuality is constituted in popular culture; ULO3 - An interdisciplinary approach to media analysis; ULO4 - Library-based research skills and a working knowledge of the major data-bases used in the field; ULO5 - The ability to think critically and analytically about gender representation in the world around them, and to articulate those thoughts in writing

UNIT_TITLE: Witches and depravity in the medieval and early modern world
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - be familiar with different approaches in the cultural history of the body and deviance ULO2 - know how to critically assess these approaches ULO3 - discuss their merit ULO4 - formulate their own positions on key issues based on a critical engagement with the historiography and relevant primary sources ULO5 - situate their own work within larger historiographical debates

ULO1 - Critically analyse relations between indigenes and Europeans in Australia; ULO2 - Evaluate the epistemological issues and problems evident in the study of Australian Aboriginal History; ULO3 - Interpret historical documents, placing them in their wider historical context and assessing their nature and value; ULO4 - Construct an original argument drawing evidence from a range of sources.

UNIT_TITLE: The rise and fall of Nazi Germany
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the major causes for the failure of the Weimar Republic; ULO2 - Recognize the complexity of social developments that characterized the Weimar and Nazi periods; ULO3 - Interpret primary source materials; ULO4 - Develop their own views on the relationship between modernity and Nazism; ULO5 - Critically assess the works of other historians; ULO6 - Communicate critical abilities in a written analytical exercise.

ULO1 - A knowledge of events leading to the Holocaust, its course and aftermath ULO2 - An understanding of Jewish responses to the Holocaust across Europe ULO3 - An understanding of the responses of perpetrators and bystanders across Europe ULO4 - An understanding of the issues involved in representations of the Holocaust, including testimony, museums, and memorials.

ULO1 - A knowledge of the city of Florence itself - including its churches, palaces, museums, piazzas, monuments and streets - as an artefact of its complex history ULO2 - The development of the requisite skills to interpret the Renaissance aspects of that artefact within an historical framework ULO3 - Enhanced skills in the critical and analytical reading of a variety of texts, including contemporary documents, religious and polemical literature, historical scholarship, physical monuments and visual representations ULO4 - An acquaintance with the considerable body of knowledge that has been built up about late medieval and Renaissance Florence (in the context of Italian history in general) ULO5 - A critical understanding of this fascinating society and its historiography ULO6 - The ability to use this knowledge (1, 3, 4, 5) and these skills (2) as a capital source for contributing to an understanding of the Renaissance city, its society and culture.

ULO1 - Identify and explain the nature of cultural diversity in contemporary Europe; ULO2 - Evaluate how dominant ideas and assumptions about cultural diversity are created and reinforced; ULO3 - Understand how sociological theories apply to cultural diversity; ULO4 - Utilise theoretical and methodological approaches to examine cultural diversity in the European context; ULO5 - Demonstrate developed written, research, and analytical skills.

UNIT_TITLE: Modern Japan: From Samurai to Pokemon
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify key political transformations across Japanese history as well as Japan's place in the wider region; ULO2 - Explain processes of identity formation and the power of national myths; ULO3 - Locate, assess, and analyse historical evidence; ULO4 - Develop effective communication, argumentation and critical reflection skills.

ULO1 - Discuss global governance, its origins and historical development; ULO2 - Critically engage with core theoretical and empirical debates on global governance; ULO3 - Analyse and evaluate the ongoing challenges facing global governance and its future trajectories; ULO4 - Communicate (in spoken and written form) the core issues and controversies in global governance; ULO5 - Collaborate effectively with peers in group learning tasks.

UNIT_TITLE: Mobile worlds: Borders, displacement and belonging
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify and discuss the diverse forms of human mobility in the contemporary world; ULO2 - Critically analyse perceptions, responses, representations and social categories of migrants and human mobilities; ULO3 - Identify and explain the ways refugees, asylum seekers, labour migrants and transnational communities pose challenges to the nation-state system; ULO4 - Engage and respond to the latest solutions offered by researchers and theorists to the challenges of human mobility and global migration; ULO5 - Read, think and respond reflectively and critically to global issues and challenges; ULO6 - Utilise developing academic qualitative research skills to locate, link, critically analyse and communicate theory and evidence.

UNIT_TITLE: Power and poverty: International development in a globalised world
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify and explain the key concepts of international development, with a focus on the existence of inequalities of wealth, poverty and power; ULO2 - Critically interpret competing theoretical explanations for global inequalities and disadvantage; ULO3 - Analyse and utilise text and other data to support research into inequalities of wealth, poverty and power; ULO4 - Critically assess institutional and other structures that exacerbate and reinforce uneven international development; ULO5 - Develop, justify and communicate strategies for the transformation of patterns of global inequality toward more socially just and sustainable outcomes.

UNIT_TITLE: Global cities: Past, present and future
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - describe the past, present and possible futures of a number of important world cities; ULO2 - explain the historical and contemporary role of cities as drivers of economic, social and cultural change, and as places of cultural interaction; ULO3 - identify and apply the research skills and methods of urban scholars, including urban historians; ULO4 - critically analyse a range of textual, visual and material urban research sources; ULO5 - communicate orally and in writing to specialist and lay audiences.

ULO1 - Familiarity with the range and nature of topics in global bioethics; ULO2 - Familiarity with the major ethical concepts and arguments used in discussing and resolving issues in global bioethics; ULO3 - Skills enabling them to critically analyse key ethical and policy issues related to topics in global bioethics; ULO4 - The ability to make informed judgments about these ethical and policy issues.

ULO1 - Have a high level of understanding of the central ideas of just war theory ULO2 - Appreciate a wide variety of criticisms of just war theory ULO3 - Understand the connections between human rights and war ULO4 - Have developed the ability to apply theories of justice in conflict to actual cases from recent history ULO5 - Be able to develop and critically assess arguments about the justification of violence in the pursuit of political ends ULO6 - Have improved their ability to effectively communicate about complex issues in international affairs ULO7 - Have developed their ability to conduct independent research on topics of international justice.

ULO1 - identify the key institutions and issues in contemporary Japan, and the historical context for their development; ULO2 - demonstrate a critical understanding of the concepts and terms used to describe and discuss contemporary Japanese society and culture beyond Japan; ULO3 - apply a range of disciplinary approaches to analyse major issues and debates in contemporary Japan; ULO4 - reflect on the relevance of Japanese experiences of social change to other national and individual circumstances; ULO5 - explore how contemporary Japanese social and cultural phenomena are reflected in, and shaped by, Japanese language use; ULO6 - read critically and engage with existing research on Japan; ULO7 - (For students of the Japanese language only:) utilize Japanese language skills in academic research and discussion of contemporary issues in Japan, as appropriate to proficiency level.

ULO1 - Apply theories and analytical methods to examine Japanese language use and practices; ULO2 - Discuss issues related to communication in Japanese, including intercultural communication; ULO3 - Critically reflect upon their own experiences of learning and using Japanese; ULO4 - Locate, summarise and critically review relevant research, both orally and in writing.

UNIT_TITLE: Structure in the langages of the world
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - identify and describe structural phenomena in a variety of different languages; ULO2 - identify cross-linguistic patterns in morpho-syntax and discuss claims of universality; ULO3 - apply different theoretical approaches to the analysis of language using the relevant terminology; ULO4 - assess evidence supporting various theories and thereby evaluate these theories; ULO5 - read and understand grammatical descriptions of languages and discussions of grammatical phenomena in the linguistic literature; ULO6 - use analytic and interpretive skills in dealing with language data

ULO1 - recognise inter-cultural differences in communication patterns and cultural expectations; ULO2 - ask questions about communication patterns in a culture with which they are not (very) familiar; ULO3 - analyse what goes wrong in communication breakdown; ? ULO4 - ?read and think critically; ULO5 - use analytic and interpretive skills in dealing with language data; ULO6 - present logical, coherent arguments both orally and in writing

ULO1 - Understand how texts are made accessible for computational analysis; ULO2 - Understand the nature of basic tools for the exploration and analysis of text corpora; ULO3 - Be able to apply such tools to specific analytic problems involving real data; ULO4 - Be able to interpret the analytic results and present them clearly both orally and in writing.

ULO1 - explain and apply key terms and concepts used for the study of language and society; ULO2 - identify and discuss how linguistic features intersect with society; ULO3 - articulate key differences between two or more approaches to the study of language and society; ULO4 - analyse the impact that ideologies and world-view have on inter- and intra-speaker variation; ULO5 - apply your knowledge in the collection and the analysis of sociolinguistic data.

ULO1 - explain and apply key notions used in the analysis of contemporary English grammar; ULO2 - discuss and analyse the patterns and structures that distinguish the main standard varieties of English from each other and from other important varieties; ULO3 - articulate the key features that distinguish formal and informal usage, and different occupational varieties; ULO4 - analyse the way the processes set in place by globalization and the electronic revolution have been shaping English structure; ULO5 - apply your knowledge to the analysis of 'real' texts, especially with the view to how information is structured in discourse.

ULO1 - Understand the political importance of 'coming to terms with the past'; ULO2 - Give an account of the conceptual tensions and ambiguities surrounding the theory and practice of dealing with past injustices; ULO3 - Understand the relative strengths and weaknesses of conventional institutional responses to injustice based in law and the more innovative institutional responses based in theories of political reconciliation; ULO4 - Think critically about the implications our struggles to come to terms with the past carry in terms of the relationship between politics and time; ULO5 - Undertake structured research tasks and demonstrate high level written communication skills.

ULO1 - Understand the relationship between the liberal democratic tradition, the media and elections; ULO2 - Understand the critical role served by elections in democratic society; ULO3 - Understand the legal and regulatory media framework that informs elections; ULO4 - Identify the ways in which ever-evolving media technologies affect parties, government and other political actors; ULO5 - Develop an argument, or to provide an opinion, and to do so clearly, accurately and concisely both in written and oral form; ULO6 - Develop skills of collaboration and team work by working on tasks as a member of a small group, providing and assimilating constructive critical commentary and feedback.

ULO1 - Deepened their understanding of the relationship between the great powers and Middle Eastern societies. ULO1 - to introduce students to contemporary US foreign policy - including its context, formulation, substance and consequences ULO2 - to enhance the ability of students to engage in critical reflection and produce reasoned, soundly structured and well presented debate on the role of Washington in the contemporary international system

ULO1 - An understanding of the strengths, limitations and appropriate applications of quantitative and qualitative approaches to research; ULO2 - Knowledge of methods commonly used in both quantitative and qualitative research; ULO3 - Understanding of the theoretical, practical and ethical considerations in research; ULO4 - Knowledge of issues related to the design and implementation of social science research.

ULO1 - Through daily surveys of news reports from major Chinese online and offline media, students are expected to keep in touch with the latest developments in world affairs and to improve their understanding of the social, political, cultural and economic contexts against which media terms and expressions are used in the Chinese-speaking world. ULO2 - By weekly readings in Chinese media studies and surveys of Chinese media content, students are expected to develop skills of analysis and critical thinking. ULO3 - Guided by appropriate theoretical frameworks and methods, students will acquire basic research skills and techniques to apply to their reading and understanding of Chinese media content.

UNIT_TITLE: War and memory: Resistance, massacre and representation in second world war Italy
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding of the history of the second world war in Italy and a detailed knowledge of the massacres on Monte Sole and their subsequent remembrance; ULO2 - Articulate an advanced understanding of the roles of literature, film, arts and other media in shaping dominant modes of remembering conflict; ULO3 - Demonstrate an informed understanding of the nature and functions of propaganda, how it has been employed to advance political and ideological imperatives and how it combines with specific media to frame the remembering of differing conflicts; ULO4 - Demonstrate a sophisticated grasp of how material forms of remembrance, monuments, memorials, cemeteries, places of commemoration, are informed by ideology and function as media; ULO5 - Apply an advanced understanding of theories of memory, histories of conflict and developments in the media to explore the complex inter-relations of media, memory and war in relation to the second world war in Italy and the massacres at Monte Sole. Students taking the unit at 3rd year level will be expected to demonstrate a greater theoretical fluency, a broader grasp of the relevant cultural background and to take a leading role in seminar and workshop discussions and activities.

UNIT_TITLE: Text and community in Medieval and Renaissance Italy
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Will have a thorough knowledge of the text(s) chosen for study. ULO2 - Will have gained an understanding of different genres of text circulating in Medieval and Renaissance Italy (chronicle, letter, diary, tract, sermon, poem, play, dialogue, treatise, monument, visual representation). ULO3 - Will have gained a grounding in core skills for Medieval and Renaissance Studies with respect to archives, manuscripts and palaeography. ULO4 - Will have developed a capacity to analyse the processes which underpinned the construction of particular texts. ULO5 - Will have developed the capacity to detect the resonances of language and code embedded in particular texts and their relationship to social context. ULO6 - Will have developed the capacity to read 'against the grain' in relation to the Medieval and Renaissance Italian social, political and social contexts. ULO7 - Will have had the opportunity to critique either an element of the historiography or a presentation by a scholar (or scholars) in the field. ULO8 - Will be able to engage in critical discussion of texts in relation to the urban context of Italian Medieval and Renaissance Society.

UNIT_TITLE: Seeking justice: South Africa and Rwanda
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - an understanding of the human impact of genocide and conflict on the communities that survive it ULO2 - an understanding of the modern historical contexts in which these conflicts emerged ULO3 - an appreciation of the issues and the agencies involved in rebuilding states and societies after genocide and conflict ULO4 - the capacity to describe and analyse questions of memory and justice using historical examples ULO5 - In addition, students undertaking this unit at fourth-year level will be expected to have the ability to analytically differentiate between the different forms genocide and conflict manifest themselves in.

ULO1 - Identify and explain the nature of cultural diversity in contemporary Europe; ULO2 - Evaluate how dominant ideas and assumptions about cultural diversity are created and reinforced; ULO3 - Understand how sociological theories apply to cultural diversity; ULO4 - Utilise theoretical and methodological approaches to examine cultural diversity in the European context; ULO5 - Demonstrate developed written, research, and analytical skills; ULO6 - Demonstrate wider reading and greater comprehension of relevant literature, and a greater degree of critical analysis.

UNIT_TITLE: Australia-Pacific Youth Engagement: understanding the Australia-Pacific partnership
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - recognise and analyse the strategic and geopolitical importance of the Pacific region ULO2 - critically evaluate contrasting perspectives and practitioner approaches to human security in different jurisdictions; ULO3 - synthesise, analyse and apply critical understandings of Australias role in the Pacific region? ULO4 - apply a range of skills within a team context, including team leadership, collaboration, problem-solving and decision-making and communication ULO5 - identify and utilise intercultural competency skills

ULO1 - Develop a research proposal and methodology ULO2 - Identify the key resources relevant to the topic through an analysis of different methodological frameworks and/or the completion of a literature review ULO3 - Critically analyse sources and/or data using relevant theoretical frameworks ULO4 - Produce a research essay, presentation (video or in-person) and/or translation ULO5 - Analyse vital aspects of Korean society and/or language

ULO1 - Explain lifestyle journalism, including PR/market orientation and the motivational aspects of lifestyle journalists, and its function in the media industry; ULO2 - Identify, research and edit a lifestyle journalism story for a magazine or website to a deadline; ULO3 - Conduct interviews and gather appropriate evidentiary material in the appropriate medium; ULO4 - Report on lifestyle journalism stories or events in a clear, concise, factual and meaningful way using a variety of elements in a coherent package; ULO5 - Identify and observe key ethical and legal obligations associated with lifestyle journalism and reflect this critically on their assignments; ULO6 - Identify local, national and international people and events relevant to current issues and media issues related to lifestyle journalism.

UNIT_TITLE: The archaeology of world rock art
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Discuss the earliest history of human symbolic behaviour and how it relates to the evolutionary beginnings of modern humans; ULO2 - Understand the chronology of early modern human visual art relative to their biological evolution; ULO3 - Explain the processes of dating and recording rock art; ULO4 - Interpret various aspects of rock art, including the production process, subject matter, location, cultural importance, and significance for understanding past social relationships; ULO5 - Explain the benefits of current digital technologies in the analysis of rock art; ULO6 - Evaluate contemporary perspectives on rock art, including those from the communities of the descendants of rock artists.

UNIT_TITLE: State sovereignty, human rights, and the responsibility to protect
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Acquire a detailed understanding of the theory and practice of the RtP doctrine, and the relevance of RtP and human rights theory in the contemporary European context; ULO2 - Deepen their understanding of theoretical issues that arise in contemporary human rights discourse; ULO3 - Further develop critical reading and writing skills relevant to work in human rights theory and politics more generally; ULO4 - Students taking the class at 3rd year level will deepen their cross-cultural competence, by learning about the impact of R2P on a particular country in Africa or the Middle East.

ULO1 - Understand the practice of music in diverse historical/social/cultural contexts; ULO2 - Evaluate practical and theoretical approaches to music performance, composition and research; ULO3 - Apply this knowledge to their personal music practice.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Sir Zelman Cowen School of Music

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand key elements of a specific cultural context including unique approaches to a particular stream of music study; ULO2 - Reflect upon their own musical practices and develop insights into newly acquired cultural knowledge about music; ULO3 - Apply concepts they learned to a specific stream of music study.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Sir Zelman Cowen School of Music

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically analyse the goals of various organisations and stakeholders involved with specific international policy issues; ULO2 - Interpret, critically analyse and synthesise a broad range of relevant primary documents and secondary research in the humanities and social sciences on a particular contemporary issue ULO3 - Propose practical, targeted and innovative solutions to contemporary challenges that are ethical and sensitive to diverse cultural considerations; ULO4 - Develop a professional report/policy brief and recommendations using appropriate language and presentation; ULO5 - Collaborate effectively in planning and contributing to team projects; ULO6 - Communicate ideas and arguments verbally.

ULO1 - Develop sophisticated understandings of the different approaches to International Political Economy (IPE); ULO2 - Explain the concepts and the relative power and influence of 'international regimes'; ULO3 - Employ IPE and regime approaches to understand global trade, investment and monetary arrangements; ULO4 - Present an overview of the structure and operation of important global institutions, including the WTO, IMF, the World Bank and the Bank for International Settlements; ULO5 - Analyse relevant case studies, including the global financial crisis, the Greek debt crisis and the Asian financial crisis; ULO6 - Encourage critical analysis of the political economy of globalisation.

UNIT_TITLE: Master class in archaeology and ancient history
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Recognise the historical development of relevant interpretive approaches applied to the record of the past; ULO2 - Apply different methodologies to problem solving; ULO3 - Engage with a variety of theoretical approaches to interpreting the record of the past; ULO4 - Evaluate different methodological approaches depending on the nature of the discipline involved; ULO5 - Appreciate and appraise key debates in the contemporary study of the past.

ULO1 - Identify and explain the theories of security and successfully apply them to contemporary global crises; ULO2 - Appraise several contemporary global security crises; ULO3 - Analyse the roles of states, global institutions (such as the UN Security Council), and non-state actors (such as NGOs or terrorist groups) in relation to questions of security; ULO4 - Utilise information and research skills to formulate and respond to essay questions; ULO5 - Critically assess the academic scholarship, including methods, assumptions and uses of evidence, and organise and defend a verbal and written argument based upon those assessments; ULO6 - Reflect upon and make critical use of a range of resources including, where relevant, on-line materials.

UNIT_TITLE: Study tour in Italy: Etruscan and Roman archaeology
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Recognise the major sites and features of the Etruscan and Roman cultures; ULO2 - Identify key features of the art, architecture, beliefs, politics and histories of the Etruscan and Roman cultures; ULO3 - Evaluate the cultural exchange that operated between Etruscan and Roman cultures and their neighbours; ULO4 - Distinguish the advantages and limitations of different methods employed in reconstructing the past; ULO5 - Employ diverse approaches in the reconstruction of the past; ULO6 - Engage with debates surrounding the (re-)presentation of the past within the public domain.

UNIT_TITLE: From Alexander to Kleopatra: The rise and fall of the Hellenistic world
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Discuss the nature of the rise of the Macedonian kingdom under Philip II and Alexander the Great, and the subsequent wars of succession; ULO2 - Explain the political situation in the eastern Mediterranean region from the late fourth century BCE to the first century CE; ULO3 - Analyse the literary, intellectual, and political culture emerging across the "Hellenistic" world; ULO4 - Evaluate the complex and changing nature of Egyptian culture as a result of the introduction of Hellenism and the development of the Ptolemaic state; ULO5 - Critically appraise ancient sources and modern scholarship and combine a variety of types of evidence in the analysis of ancient cultures; ULO6 - Use independent and group research skills to prepare and present a group project and an individual research project.

UNIT_TITLE: Interrogating racism: Indigenous Australians and the state
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - The relationship between Indigenous Australians and social institutions; ULO2 - How theories of race and experiences of racism continue to impact upon Indigenous people; ULO3 - Issues of research and research methodologies in relation to racism and prejudice in contemporary Australia.

UNIT_TITLE: Hearing the country: Studies in Indigenous Australian ethnoecology
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - To explore in depth the way in which people describe their relationship with country ULO2 - To explore the way in which environmental and biological knowledge is encoded.? ULO3 - To study ecological and scientific systems within the context of a culture. ULO4 - To explore how language, history, tradition, material culture, spirituality, kinship, emotion and politics are all ways in which people negotiate a relationship with the environment.? ULO5 - To study the anthropological discourse with landscape and how knowledge about landscapes are encoded. This will involve issues such as kinship and ceremony, language and understanding ethnobiological zoological/botanical taxonomy in comparison to western Linnaean zoological and botanical taxonomy. The course will use actual case studies and will involve manipulating original material collected by the lecturer and other researchers.? ULO6 - Address the academic debates in relation to ethnoecology from the school of thought which places cognition at the forefront of this discipline to those that believe other issues such as culture, time and concepts such as tradition and religion also influence people and their relationship to the environment.

ULO1 - Explain key concepts and debates in the anthropology of human rights; ULO2 - Recognise and analyse the importance, scope and distinctiveness of anthropology's contribution to the analysis of power and human rights in Western and non-Western countries; ULO3 - Critically appraise different theoretical approaches and methodological issues from the discipline of anthropology to the study of human rights; ULO4 - Express complex and independent analytical and critical thinking, and produce clear, original and coherent accounts of theories, knowledge and logical argument; ULO5 - Apply qualitative academic research methods and skills to identify, examine and evaluate data, texts and sources to reveal patterns, themes and meanings.

UNIT_TITLE: A world of sport: Business, politics and media
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding of sport as a cultural, economic and political phenomenon in a global context; ULO2 - Exhibit a critical understanding of key issues in the study of international sport, including the complex interplay between social ideals and aspirations and commercial, political, development and individual concerns; ULO3 - Have engaged with theoretical debates about the process of globalisation on Australian sporting economies and cultures; ULO4 - Exhibit a critical understanding of the role of the media in the development, representation and ownership of sport; ULO5 - Have built the capacity to research and critically evaluate topical and historiographical debates regarding sport; ULO6 - Have developed skills in constructing evidence-based arguments using a variety of primary and secondary sources and demonstrated their ability to reflect critically on what they have learnt; ULO7 - Have developed skills in written and oral presentation and communication

ULO1 - Discuss major theories of decolonisation, and the various interpretations informing historical and contemporary analysis of decolonisation; ULO2 - Explain the ongoing legacies of colonialism, including contemporary decolonisation movements, and the significance of decolonisation in world history; ULO3 - Critically analyse a variety of texts, including contemporary documents, polemical literature and historical scholarship; ULO4 - Conduct independent historical research; ULO5 - Communicate ideas orally and in writing.

ULO1 - Developed critical thinking skills in a variety of political, social and cultural theories on the nature of identity and human relationships at the start of the 21st century; ULO2 - Developed a detailed and extensive research skills for gathering knowledge about identity in the 21st century, and to demonstrate a capacity to work with these skills in a group work assessment context; ULO3 - Developed an ability to identify, explore and make judgments in finding innovative solutions to research problems related to the concepts learned in this unit; ULO4 - Developed an ability to critically use this literature to communicate perceptively and effectively in oral and written form, and in a logical, coherent and analytical manner about concepts learned in this unit.

ULO1 - Students will have acquired detailed knowledge of the main features of psychoanalytic theories; ULO2 - Students will have a good grasp of key texts reflecting the intellectual debates; ULO3 - They should have also developed an acute awareness of the formative historical forces which contributed to the development of psychoanalysis in the late 19th and 20th century; ULO4 - They will have developed their ability to analyse and interpret works of literature and art as well as social phenomena with reference to a psychoanalytic framework; ULO5 - Students will be capable of an informed discussion and they will be able to present the results of their own research in form of a class paper and in a more detailed written essay.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Languages, Literatures, Cultures and Linguistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - A critical understanding of the place and function of sensible form in art theory; ULO2 - An ability to use the terminology of aesthetic philosophy with confidence; ULO3 - An ability to situate the intersections between art and philosophy within their historical context; ULO4 - An ability to be able to articulate independent views on the topics covered in the unit.

ULO1 - A sophisticated understanding of modernist aesthetics and themes; ULO2 - The ability to assess and interpret the relationship between literary texts and their social and political context; ULO3 - An informed understanding of some key approaches to modernist literature; ULO4 - Developed an informed critical perspective on modernism as a term of periodisation; ULO5 - Advanced undergraduate-level skills in the reading and interpretation of literary texts.

ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding of the main ideas informing policy and media debates about communication ULO2 - Critically assess the arguments that justify freedom of expression, and the reasons this freedom may be limited ULO3 - Understand basic moral frameworks and identify moral issues ULO4 - Articulate a coherent position about a current issue relating to freedom of expression ULO5 - Explain their ideas and justify their conclusions in oral and written contexts.

ULO1 - Identify the major criminological and political approaches to global issues in crime and justice ULO2 - Construct an informed theoretical critique of issues related to global crime and justice ULO3 - Synthesis an interdisciplinary approach to the analysis of global crime and justice issues; ULO4 - Focus upon the production of scholarly research as the end point of a process of reading, discussion, drafting and debate; ULO5 - Work independently as scholars, and to give and receive constructive, critical feedback.

ULO1 - Appreciate the need for a comparative understanding of criminology in historical and current social perspectives; ULO2 - Find and generate information and data that can be used to facilitate a comparative understanding of criminology, and its relationship to other social and political systems; ULO3 - Critically evaluate contrasting perspectives and practitioner approaches to criminology in different jurisdictions; ULO4 - Consider understandings of criminology in both domestic and international settings and the impact of these; ULO5 - Synthesize, analyse and apply critical understandings of criminological comparisons to practices of national and international efforts to achieve justice; ULO6 - Communicate the key elements necessary for comparative work to be undertaken and critically evaluate the advantages and limitations of understanding crime and social control across cultures.

UNIT_TITLE: Human rights in the criminal justice sphere
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - The key human rights relevant to investigatory stages in criminal justice systems; ULO2 - The key human rights relevant to trial stages of criminal proceedings; ULO3 - The impact of human rights on national and international efforts to combat crime. The unit seeks to enhance the ability of students to undertake independent research under the guidance of supervision.

ULO1 - Determine the need for a critical understanding of the gender, sex and crime in historical and current social perspectives; ULO2 - Find and generate information and data that can be used to facilitate a critical understanding of how gender is constituted in society and the criminal justice system; ULO3 - Demonstrate a depth of knowledge and comprehension of methodological and theoretical analyses of gender, sex and crime; ULO4 - Organise and manage the collection of relevant research materials; ULO5 - Synthesize, analyse and apply critical understandings of historical and contemporary gender and crime research; ULO6 - Identify, evidence and communicate examples of how gender must be examined alongside other sites of power such as race, class and age.

ULO1 - Analyse fairy tales through cultural, ideological and historical frameworks. ULO1 - Articulate the key features of major developments in contemporary poetics ULO2 - Reflect critically on his/her writing practice in the light of these developments ULO3 - Demonstrate how a given text exemplifies or challenges contemporaneous theories of poetics ULO4 - Devise writing strategies which utilise in direct or modified ways (oppositional or ironic) aspects of a given poetics within their writing practice ULO5 - Demonstrate critical skills through the editorial commentary on works in progress presented in workshops ULO6 - Develop creative and professional skills through the drafting process ULO7 - Demonstrate an awareness of the relations between modern critical theory and creative practice

ULO1 - Been introduced to writing and reading in a variety of fictional sub-genres ULO2 - Become better acquainted with the publishing industry ULO3 - Developed their editing and revising skills ULO4 - Written short stories in the genres of their choice for possible publication ULO5 - Shared and responded to the writing of their colleagues ULO6 - Developed their critical reading skills ULO7 - Taken both inspiration and direction from prominent local writers ULO8 - Related current critical debates about writing to their own work

UNIT_TITLE: Gender and sexuality in film and television
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding the historical development of key theoretical approaches in feminist film theory; ULO2 - Analyse the formal and narrative codes of different screen media by employing and synthesizing multiple methods in feminist film theory; ULO3 - Compare and assess different theoretical approaches to gender, film, television or web media and evaluate their utility for critiquing gender politics; ULO4 - Critically analyse written and filmic texts in a clear and confident manner in both written and oral presentation.

ULO1 - An ability to discuss particular examples of Asian Cinema and Television texts in ways that show some understanding of generic considerations, cultural differences and historical specificity; ULO2 - A general theoretical awareness of the problematic of cross cultural readings; ULO3 - Some understanding of how cinema has developed across national and transnational film industries in different parts of the world.

UNIT_TITLE: Documentary and realism in film and television
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify and classify a range historical and contemporary documentary or realist codes in relation to different media such as cinema, television and digital media. ULO2 - Evaluate film and television studies methodologies as they pertain to examples of non-fiction. ULO3 - Apply film and television studies methodologies in order to compare and analyse different documentary or realist forms ULO4 - Apply library resources and communicate an understanding of research methods in written and oral form.

UNIT_TITLE: Australia's ancient Indigenous past: A 65,000 year archaeological odyssey
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Appreciate the broad range of techniques used by archaeologists to infer behaviour from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultural sites and material culture. ULO2 - Develop advanced skills in critically evaluating major debates and contentious theoretical issues in Australian Indigenous archaeology. ULO3 - Understand key cultural changes over the past 65,000 years of Australia's Indigenous past. ULO4 - Appreciate the diversity of Indigenous Australians who in different parts of the continent developed different cultures and lifeways. ULO5 - Appreciate debates concerning the origins of Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders from an archaeological perspective.

ULO1 - Appreciate the broad range of conceptual and practical skills required to find, record and excavate archaeological sites; ULO2 - Develop skills in community partnership research projects; ULO3 - Develop skills to critically evaluate archaeological evidence and assemble multidisciplinary research teams.

ULO1 - Identify the different types of environmental assessments and the decision-making contexts in which they are applied.
