ULO1 - analyse the theoretical and empirical bases of resource management issues; ULO2 - discuss the complex, intertwined nature of ecological, social, and political factors underlying resource management issues; ULO3 - explain and apply key theoretical concepts; ULO4 - construct analytical arguments relevant to resource management issues; ULO5 - communicate arguments effectively in writing.

ULO1 - Discuss critical debates in the area of global consumption with a focus on globalization, sex, race, and sustainability; ULO2 - Explain the changes in contemporary consuming practices being produced by globalization; ULO3 - Undertake critical sociological analysis of popular discourses, such as advertising, news production and other media and popular cultural forms that cross cultures and borders; ULO4 - Critically review, analyse, summarise and synthesise sociological scholarship and research; ULO5 - Formulate, conduct and present group research projects; ULO6 - Communicate complex ideas, principles and knowledge to non-specialist audiences.

ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding of the historical, ethnic and religious diversity of the Middle East upon which contemporary political complexity is based. ULO1 - Understand the competing narratives and claims of all parties to the conflict and how the past informs current perceptions of the conflict ULO2 - Be able to describe the historiographical debates about the history of the conflict ULO3 - Have a knowledge of the broader regional and global implications of the Arab-Israeli conflict ULO4 - Be able to analyse how key documents framing the conflict have been contested by different parties and political streams ULO5 - Have the ability to interpret the role of the media in shaping perceptions of the Arab-Israeli conflict. UNIT_TITLE: Modern Israel: History, politics and society
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - understand major topics in the political and social history of modern Israel; ULO2 - demonstrate skills in analysis of conceptual issues involved in the study of identity, social division and coherence; ULO3 - understand Israel's international standing and related issues in Middle East and international politics; ULO4 - understand the major ideologies and institutions at work in the development of modern Israeli society; ULO5 - discuss and analyse the major social and political facing the State of Israel; ULO6 - demonstrate an appreciation of the complexity of Israeli society through analysis of historical, religious, ethnic, national and political determinants.

UNIT_TITLE: Imagining God: The mystic quest in Judaism, Christianity and Islam
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate awareness of the major theoretical issues relating to mystical literature within a variety of religious traditions. ULO2 - Demonstrate awareness of the developments of mystical teaching in Judaism, Christianity and Islam, with particular attention to mysticism in medieval Christianity, Sufism, and Kabbalah in Judaism. ULO3 - Show understanding of the relationship between mystical literature and the religious tradition from which it emanates. ULO4 - Consider the historical context in which mystical teaching has emerged, and what social and political function it may play within a religious tradition. ULO5 - Demonstrate awareness of the major theoretical debates raised by the phenomenon of mysticism, and the question of whether or not it involves experiences common to different religious traditions.

ULO1 - A knowledge of the city of Florence itself - including its churches, palaces, museums, piazzas, monuments and streets - as an artefact of its complex history ULO2 - The development of the requisite skills to interpret the Renaissance aspects of that artefact within an historical framework ULO3 - Enhanced skills in the critical and analytical reading of a variety of texts, including contemporary documents, religious and polemical literature, historical scholarship, physical monuments and visual representations ULO4 - An acquaintance with the considerable body of knowledge that has been built up about late medieval and Renaissance Florence (in the context of Italian history in general) ULO5 - A critical understanding of this fascinating society and its historiography ULO6 - The ability to use this knowledge (1, 3, 4, 5) and these skills (2) as a capital source for contributing to an understanding of the Renaissance city, its society and culture. Students successfully completing ATS3612 will, in addition: ULO7 - Be capable of independently devising and executing an advanced research project in the above areas of study, based predominantly on primary sources.

ULO1 - Recognise the importance of debates and ideas about race, nationalism, ethnicity and conflict. ULO2 - Understand the importance of debate and discussion in the development of these ideas. ULO3 - Have sound oral and written communication skills and be able to utilise these in such debates. ULO4 - Understand the importance of critical analysis and be comfortable in challenging ideas and arguments.

UNIT_TITLE: Global disasters: Catastrophe and social change
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - A critical understanding of the role specific disasters and disasters in general have played in the development of global society; ULO2 - A thorough knowledge of how contested representations and understandings of disaster have explored issues of responsibility, mitigation, vulnerability and social change; ULO3 - A critical understanding of the various interpretations that inform the historical and contemporary analysis of these phenomena; ULO4 - A stronger understanding of the ethical challenges of disaster response; ULO5 - Enhanced skills in the critical and analytical reading of a variety of texts, including contemporary documents, polemical literature, historical scholarship visual representations and web-based evidence, and specifically the development of skills in source criticism, critical reading, the development of research and writing skills, especially the use of evidence and primary sources, analysing different interpretations of an event or issue, organising and defending an argument, and writing with precision and imagination; ULO6 - The capacity to independently develop an original research project.

UNIT_TITLE: Global cultures, media flows: Creating and consuming (popular) culture
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - A deeper knowledge of the concepts of modernity and tradition, and the problems of cultural ownership and authenticity, and an understanding of contemporary issues regarding copyright law; ULO2 - Acquired knowledge about the challenges to cultural nationalism by transnational cultural flows, and the role of electronic media, especially the Internet in this; ULO3 - Studied in depth some cases of cultural production and its local consumption, and critically analysed web-based and mass media material relating to these case studies; ULO4 - Improved their oral skills by participating in tutorial debate, both face-to-face and on-line cross-campus, on specific instances of cultural flows and local identities created through their consumption; ULO5 - Improved their written skills by producing a well-reasoned and well-documented essay on an aspect of the globalisation debate; ULO6 - Developed independent research skills; ULO7 - Developed the ability to critically assess the ideological implications of global cultural flows.

ULO1 - an understanding of the human impact of genocide and conflict on the communities that survive it ULO2 - an understanding of the modern historical contexts in which these conflicts emerged ULO3 - an appreciation of the issues and the agencies involved in rebuilding states and societies after genocide and conflict ULO4 - In addition, third-year students will develop the capacity to describe and analyse questions of memory and justice using historical examples.

UNIT_TITLE: Reflections on humanity: Truth, freedom and power

ULO1 - Demonstrate an improved understanding of the complexities involved in the formulation and implementation of public policy; ULO2 - Have gained an understanding of the role and influence of key players and institutions in the policy process; ULO3 - Be able to link theory and practice; ULO4 - Have developed the ability to present arguments (in oral and written form) relevant to the topic being analysed and debated.

ULO1 - Japanese literacy and communicative competence: Building on the competence in Japanese acquired through earlier studies, students will be able to identify and comprehend genre-specific features of Japanese evident in the popular culture genres studied and demonstrate an understanding of the ways in which they reflect and construct the social meanings embedded in the texts. ULO2 - English literacy and communication skills: students will express ideas about Japanese culture and society verbally and in writing in sophisticated and nuanced ways through tutorial discussions and essay writing. ULO3 - Knowledge about Japanese language, society and culture: through the study and critique of Japanese popular cultural representations, students will problematicise social concepts already learned and develop their own critical frameworks for understanding these genres. ULO4 - Cross-cultural and inter-cultural competence: through the study of Japanese popular culture, students will have the opportunity to reflect on meanings associated with their own popular culture and national identity. ULO5 - World view and ethical values: Through exploring social issues  (gender roles, personal identity, national identity, age hierarchy) in lectures, tutorials and written assignments students will reflect on their social values, respect for diversity and the ethical conduct and communication of research. ULO6 - Research skills: Students will develop and demonstrate independent research skills and critical thinking through their research projects, and further develop a personal voice in their understanding of the research literature.

UNIT_TITLE: Trauma and memory in the modern world
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - An understanding of the various individual, historical, cultural, and political factors that contribute to the shaping of traumatic memory. ULO2 - The ability to insightfully articulate and analyse the scholarly debates regarding differences between individual and collective experiences of trauma. ULO3 - The skills to critically assess the limitations and possibilities of employing Western conceptions of trauma to understanding non-Western contexts. ULO4 - An understanding of how trauma operates as both an internal psychological experience and as an external, social, and global phenomenon. ULO5 - A clear understanding of how traumatic memory shapes the representation of violence and suffering from an international perspective, through fiction and non-fiction writing (including novels, memoirs and works of historiography); film and television; museums and memorials; and photography, painting, and other media. ULO6 - The ability to critically analyse different kinds of historical sources including audiovisual testimonies. ULO7 - The development of skills for collaborative learning and group work. ULO8 - The acquisition of solid writing and oral presentation skills.

UNIT_TITLE: Professional screen pathways: Research, industry and practice
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify and understand a range of professional pathways extending from film and screen studies, including further research and professional work in the screen industries; ULO2 - Research and write for criticism and publication, developing a PhD or a conference proposal and creating a professional profile; ULO3 - Analyse the social, political and industrial contexts in which film and screen practices operate around the world; ULO4 - Evaluate and communicate film and screen practices within the contexts of social and community engagement; ULO5 - Contextualise various film and screen practices and research within broader industrial developments and demands.

ULO1 - describe and analyse the diversity of Jewish communal life and cultural expression in?modern Europe; ULO2 - discuss the significance of Yiddish as a literary and cultural phenomenon; ULO3 - explain the factors that create co-existence and conflict between different religious, ethnic and national groups in Europe; ULO4 - explain the rise?of modern antisemitism and its social function ULO5 - discuss the origins, implementation and impact of the Holocaust ULO6 - examine the politics that shape memory and memorialisation practices ULO7 - describe contemporary debates in Europe about diversity, migration, tolerance and religious freedom

UNIT_TITLE: Medieval dialogues: Reason, mysticism and society
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Have an understanding of the major intellectual currents within Judaism, Christianity and Islam in the twelfth and thirteenth centuries ULO2 - Have an understanding of the relationship between and mutual influences informing the various traditions ULO3 - Understand the role of classical thinkers and writers on the varied traditions ULO4 - Demonstrate familiarity with the major texts of the key religious figures of the period ULO5 - Appreciate the exegetical horizons facing interpreters of scripture ULO6 - Be able to engage in comparative analysis of philosophers and mystics from the different traditions ULO7 - Have applied the reading and interpretative skills they have learned to unseen texts ULO8 - Identify continuities and ruptures among the thinkers and writers examined

UNIT_TITLE: Text and community in Medieval and Renaissance Italy
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Will have a thorough knowledge of the text(s) chosen for study. ULO2 - Will have gained an understanding of different genres of text circulating in Medieval and Renaissance Italy (chronicle, letter, diary, tract, sermon, poem, play, dialogue, treatise, monument, visual representation). ULO3 - Will have gained a grounding in core skills for Medieval and Renaissance Studies with respect to archives, manuscripts and palaeography. ULO4 - Will have developed a capacity to analyse the processes which underpinned the construction of particular texts. ULO5 - Will have developed the capacity to detect the resonances of language and code embedded in particular texts and their relationship to social context. ULO6 - Will have developed the capacity to read 'against the grain' in relation to the Medieval and Renaissance Italian social, political and social contexts. ULO7 - Will have had the opportunity to critique either an element of the historiography or a presentation by a scholar (or scholars) in the field. ULO8 - Will be able to engage in critical discussion of texts in relation to the urban context of Italian Medieval and Renaissance Society.

UNIT_TITLE: Theories, concepts and controversies in Politics and International Relations

UNIT_TITLE: The globalisation of civil and human rights

ULO4 - Strong skills in the critical reading of a variety of texts, including contemporary documents, polemical literature and campaign material, the academic scholarship based upon those texts and the theoretical and conceptual debates about justice and rights; ULO5 - Strong skills in critical oral and written assessment of the academic scholarship, including methods, assumptions and uses of evidence, and in organising and defending a verbal and written argument based upon those assessments; ULO6 - A capacity to devise, plan and successfully complete a detailed case study, including significant documentary research, that evaluates the significance of a particular campaign, organisation or issue; and ULO7 - A capacity to reflect upon and make critical use of a range of resources including, where relevant, on-line materials, film and visual images.

UNIT_TITLE: Structure and function of cellular biomolecules
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe how the structure of biologically relevant molecules contributes to their function in cells and organisms; ULO2 - Define the molecular structure of biological membranes and their role in cellular metabolism; ULO3 - Explain the physical and biochemical properties of proteins and describe how proteins function as enzymes; ULO4 - Summarise the techniques and underpinning science that is exploited for the isolation, separation and characterisation of biological molecules; ULO5 - Demonstrate technical skills in basic laboratory techniques used for the separation and identification of biological molecules and for measuring enzymatic behaviour; ULO6 - Demonstrate the skills necessary to accurately interpret biochemical data; ULO7 - Demonstrate an ability to research original published scientific literature and effectively communicate your findings either orally or in writing.

ULO1 - Explain the various biochemical pathways used to generate energy, including their functions, interrelationships and regulation; ULO2 - Explain the various biochemical pathways involved in the biosynthesis of macro-molecules (lipids and carbohydrates);? including their functions, interrelationships and regulation; ULO3 - Apply knowledge of the biochemical basis of specific metabolic diseases to real life contexts and case studies; ULO4 - Discuss how micronutrients impact cellular metabolism; ULO5 - Communicate scientific information effectively through written and verbal communication; ULO6 - Apply scientific methodologies and laboratory techniques to collect, analyse, and draw conclusions from data.

UNIT_TITLE: Cellular organisation: Organelle structure and function in health and disease
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the structure of eukaryotic cells and explain the function of key organelles; ULO2 - Outline how different organelles are formed and positioned within cells and how these organelles respond to a changing environment; ULO3 - Explain the mechanisms that target and move proteins to the correct organelle and how protein mis-localisation and organelle dysfunction may lead to human disease; ULO4 - Discuss how the application of fluorescence-based imaging and other technologies enhances our understanding of cells, organelles and cellular proteins; ULO5 - Organise, plan and successfully execute laboratory experiments relevant to molecular cell biology, as well as analyse and report the results in a meaningful way; ULO6 - Conduct literature-based research, identify key knowledge and concepts and build coherent arguments and explanations either in writing or in oral presentations; ULO7 - Work effectively as a pair or in a group to achieve academic tasks collaboratively with respect for each other.

ULO1 - Describe the structure, organisation and functional rearrangement of eukaryotic genomes; ULO2 - Explain the mechanism of DNA replication in eukaryotic cells; ULO3 - Illustrate how gene expression is regulated in eukaryotes and how studies of DNA, RNA and protein levels contribute to our understanding of these processes; ULO4 - Discuss how cell and animal models are used to build our understanding of disease processes and to develop potential therapies; ULO5 - Describe how the application of genomic and other technologies is used to further our understanding of genomes and the treatment of disease; ULO6 - Demonstrate the ability to organise, plan and successfully execute laboratory experiments relevant to advanced molecular biology, as well as analyse and report the results in a meaningful way; ULO7 - Demonstrate the ability to undertake literature based research to collect and evaluate information relevant to current problems in biochemistry and molecular biology and to effectively communicate ideas in writing or orally.

UNIT_TITLE: Cell signal transduction: Role in cancer and human disease
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Discuss the basic mechanisms of cell signalling and how disordered intracellular signalling contributes to the development of cancer; ULO2 - Discuss the various aspects of the immune system in relation cell signalling and infectious disease; ULO3 - Explain how cell death contributes to differentiation and disease; ULO4 - Conduct literature-based research to critically evaluate how our evolving understanding of signal transduction contributes towards advances in biology, biotechnology and medicine and effectively communicate their research by both verbal and oral means; ULO5 - Discuss the importance of the discipline to current advances in biology, biotechnology and medicine; ULO6 - Illustrate how relevant laboratory techniques can be exploited to define essential steps in biochemical pathways; ULO7 - Plan and apply advanced biochemical laboratory methods to solve problems in cell signalling and demonstrate appropriate methods for data analysis and interpretation; ULO8 - Demonstrate technical and time management skills.

UNIT_TITLE: Protein biology: From sequence to structure and disease
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the relationship between protein sequence, structure and function and relate this to specific examples in human health and disease; ULO2 - Explain how proteins fold to their correct three dimensional shape and how this process may go wrong and cause disease; ULO3 - Illustrate how NMR and X-ray crystallography are used to determine the structure of a peptide or protein; ULO4 - Critically analyse how our understanding of proteins contributes to biotechnology and medicine, in particular comment on the contribution of protein engineering and proteomics to these fields; ULO5 - Describe the use of fluorescent proteins as tools for characterising the role of proteins in vivo; ULO6 - Apply experimental techniques and methodologies to determine the structure and function of an unknown protein.

ULO1 - Undertake a research project with regard to ethical and safety regulations; ULO2 - Demonstrate technical skills in experimental methods and the ability to collect, analyse and interpret data using methods relevant to the discipline of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology; ULO3 - Communicate appropriately and effectively with supervisors, laboratory staff and students; ULO4 - Maintain accurate and up-to-date records of experimental procedures, results and outcomes; ULO5 - Identify relevant published scientific literature and critically analyse and evaluate the content in the context of the discipline of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology; ULO6 - Construct written reports.

ULO1 - Discuss the different methods of knowledge acquisition and synthesis. ULO2 - Discuss the ethical, legal, and cultural responsibilities of scientific investigation. ULO3 - Describe the principles of "Good Clinical Research", as described by the NH&MRC, with an emphasis on research in community-based emergency health. ULO4 - Describe the phases of the research process. ULO5 - Discuss basic research concepts and methodology, in both quantitative and qualitative experimental designs. ULO6 - Critically review the scientific literature in community-based emergency health. ULO7 - Consult with both a statistician and a qualitative researcher to discuss the role of methodology consultants in the research process. ULO8 - Write up scientific work in a potentially publishable manner. ULO9 - Prepare and present suitable oral and written presentations for the emergency health academic, research and scientific community. ULO10 - Demonstrate a range of technical skills appropriate to community-based emergency health research. ULO11 - Demonstrate the ability to pursue higher studies in community based emergency health. ULO12 - Discuss the breadth and diversity of research in health sciences. ULO13 - Plan and implement a research project and prepare the associated report.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

ULO1 - Describe recent advances in genomics; ULO2 - Navigate genomic and proteomic databases in a variety of species; ULO3 - Use Linux, Python and R to query big data (DNA, RNA or amino acid sequences); ULO4 - Identify conserved features in nucleotide sequences and define functional domains; ULO5 - Identify sequences and data on mutations associated with human diseases; ULO6 - Interpret structural and functional effects of mutations and predict molecular mechanisms underlying the resulting disease; ULO7 - Construct and analyse sequence alignments, molecular phylogeny and molecular models using nucleotide or amino acid sequences.

ULO1 - Identify and describe the concepts, processes and practical applications of cell biology, biochemistry, genetics, molecular biology and microbiology in society and everyday human life; ULO2 - Demonstrate proficiency in communicating scientific results through a range of formats (written and oral); ULO3 - Formulate hypotheses, collect experimental data and demonstrate proficiency in interpreting their results; ULO4 - Demonstrate competence and precision in the use of common life sciences equipment and techniques; ULO5 - Utilise research skills including database searches to synthesise and interpret information related to scientific research, using appropriate conventions for scientific attribution; ULO6 - Work effectively, responsibly, safely and ethically, both individually and in peer or team contexts

ULO1 - Identify and describe the role of biological concepts and processes of evolution, plant and animal physiology, reproduction and life history strategies and core ecological concepts in society and everyday human life; ULO2 - Demonstrate proficiency in communicating scientific results through a range of formats (written and oral); ULO3 - Formulate hypotheses, collect experimental data and demonstrate proficiency in interpreting their results; ULO4 - Demonstrate competence and precision in the use of common life sciences equipment and techniques; ULO5 - Utilise research skills including database searches to synthesise and interpret information related to scientific research, using appropriate conventions for scientific attribution; ULO6 - Work effectively, responsibly, safely and ethically, both individually and in peer or team contexts.

ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding of biodiversity, evolutionary concepts and processes, aspects of the evolution of the Australian biota, the nature of biogeochemical cycles, and human impacts on the biosphere; ULO2 - Formulate hypotheses, collect experimental data and demonstrate proficiency in interpreting your own results; ULO3 - Demonstrate proficiency in communicating biological results through a range of formats (written, oral, multimedia); ULO4 - Self-evaluate and reflect upon the development of teamwork and communication skills; ULO5 - Apply practical techniques and tools to conduct an investigation in the laboratory, field or virtual environment; ULO6 - Work and learn independently and collaboratively while exercising personal, professional and social responsibility that recognises the importance of practising science sustainably, ethically and safely in society.

ULO1 - Construct, test, and evaluate scientific hypotheses in biology. ULO2 - Design and optimise sampling programs and experiments for answering biological questions. ULO3 - Select and justify the most appropriate analysis for a biological dataset and research question. ULO4 - Summarise, visualise and analyse datasets using the programming tools of R. ULO5 - Critically evaluate biological data and make inferences from analyses.

ULO1 - Describe the modern scope of scientific inquiry in the field of ecology; ULO2 - Describe the differences in the structure and function of different types of ecosystems; ULO3 - Identify and describe the fundamental drivers of patterns in diversity; ULO4 - Explain the main limitations on patterns of energy flow through natural food webs and ecosystems; ULO5 - Quantitatively describe patterns in populations and communities; ULO6 - Apply basic ecological sampling techniques in ecosystems and be proficient in summarising and reporting that data in the format of a scientific paper.

UNIT_TITLE: Food security in a changing world
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - List the sustainable development goals and discuss how they relate to and interconnect with food security ULO2 - Outline the ways in which plants detect and respond to changes in the environment and how this affects crop yield ULO3 - Analyse and compare the environmental, economic and social value of different types of agricultural practice ULO4 - Discuss how innovations in digital agriculture and biotechnology may impact future food production ULO5 - Understand how changing food composition alters behavioural, growth and health outcomes in consumers.

ULO1 - Identify and describe the key environmental issues facing humankind and outline the role that humans play in environmental degradation and species extinction; ULO2 - Evaluate and compare the conservation techniques that can be used to restore habitats and ecosystem function; ULO3 - Appraise the special problems involved in attempting to conserve endangered species; ULO4 - Integrate complex political, economic and social issues to formulate effective conservation outcomes; ULO5 - Present and communicate conservation issues to the general public and other stakeholders in written and oral formats.

ULO1 - Explain the evolutionary (i.e. phylogenetic) relationships among major plant lineages; ULO2 - Describe the major structural innovations of each group and how they function; ULO3 - Describe key physiological processes in plants and how they have evolved; ULO4 - Describe the influence of evolutionary history and of the environment on biogeographic patterns of species occurrence, from community to continental scales; ULO5 - Demonstrate a basic ability to use the command-line programming platform R to display phylogenetic trees and the use of phylogenetic information to analyse the evolution of traits and the formation of plant communities; ULO6 - Demonstrate a basic ability to identify species of the Australian flora with the aid of taxonomic keys.

ULO1 - Describe the origin of animals and how they differ from other living organisms; ULO2 - Explain the relationship between animal diversity and evolutionary derived changes in animal body plans; ULO3 - Identify major animal phyla; ULO4 - Demonstrate skills in library and field research, data and information gathering, collation and organisation suitable for the preparation of a scientific report; ULO5 - Demonstrate basic laboratory techniques associated with examining and handling zoological specimens.

ULO1 - Describe the relationships between functional anatomy, physiology and behaviour of animals that allow them to survive and reproduce; ULO2 - Explain the function of major biological systems in animals and their adaptations to different environments; ULO3 - Contrast the varying life history strategies of animals; ULO4 - Identify morphological features of animals and relate these features to their function; ULO5 - Demonstrate skills in research, data and information gathering, collation and organisation suitable for the preparation of a scientific report.

ULO1 - Explain the fundamental processes of evolution via natural selection, with particular reference to theories of life history evolution and speciation; ULO2 - Describe the genetic basis of evolution, and demonstrate how genetic data may be applied to investigating evolutionary and ecological processes in wild populations; ULO3 - Develop hypotheses, research questions, experimental designs, analyses and interpret data; ULO4 - Acquire, synthesise and critically analyse relevant primary research literature to answer questions in evolutionary ecology; ULO5 - Communicate complex ideas in evolutionary ecology in oral and/or written formats.

ULO1 - Describe the diversity and ecological importance of marine life; ULO2 - Explain the fundamental physiochemical and physiological processes underlying the productivity of marine environments; ULO3 - Explain the ecological dynamics of marine ecosystems; ULO4 - Discuss the impact of human activity on the sustainability of marine ecosystems; ULO5 - Demonstrate advanced scientific skills in project design, data collection, analysis and writing.

ULO1 - Explain and describe current topics in ecology and evolution, and their core concepts; ULO2 - Discuss the development of ecological and evolutionary ideas and current questions in the field; ULO3 - Gather, analyse, interpret and discuss primary data and research publications in the topics covered; ULO4 - Design experiments and develop hypotheses to test contextually-relevant research questions; ULO5 - Present and debate unanswered questions and controversial ideas in the field; ULO6 - Work effectively in individual and peer or team contexts.

ULO1 - Summarise the main anthropogenic pressures on biota, including climate change, land use change, pollution, and invasive species. ULO5 - Propose and evaluate strategies to prevent or mitigate environmental change and its impacts on biota. ULO6 - Demonstrate critical analytical approaches to scientific research and writing scientific reports.

ULO1 - Demonstrate knowledge of the diversity and ecology of freshwater and marine environments in the tropics with particular reference to the Malaysian region; ULO2 - Demonstrate understanding of the conservation and management issues relating to aquatic ecosystems; ULO3 - Design and analyse sampling programs to examine the flora and fauna of aquatic habitats and to assess changes; ULO4 - Demonstrate the ability to identify aquatic animals and plants from tropical Malaysian ecosystems; ULO5 - Demonstrate advanced scientific report writing skills; ULO6 - Make effective oral and visual presentations; ULO7 - Work collaboratively and effectively in the field in tropical environments.

UNIT_TITLE: Foundations of anatomy and physiology for health practice 1
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the importance of inorganic and organic compounds within the human body and apply the concept of homeostasis. ULO2 - Describe the cellular and tissue organisation of the body and explain their importance in relation to the integumentary system. ULO3 - Locate and identify the structural components of the musculoskeletal system and explain how it protects, supports and moves the body. ULO4 - Describe the major anatomical divisions of the central and peripheral nervous systems and relate the sensory, integrative and responsive functions to homeostatic imbalances. ULO5 - Explain the structural and neural mechanisms that underpin the special senses and their ability to perceive vision, hearing, smell, taste and balance. ULO6 - Interact with team-members and unit content in a thoughtful manner that facilitates the development of communication, reflection, research and problem solving skills.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Foundations of anatomy and physiology for health practice 2
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the interdependence of the cardiovascular and respiratory systems and how they maintain homeostasis. ULO2 - Discuss the components and functions of blood and the lymphatic system and how they maintain homeostasis. ULO3 - Explain how the endocrine system integrates various body functions. ULO4 - Outline the functions of the urinary system and explain how it contributes to maintaining pH, blood volume and the composition of body fluids. ULO5 - Identify the structures of the digestive system and explain their role in digestion, absorption and metabolism. ULO6 - Describe the structures of the male and female reproductive systems and explain how offspring are produced with respect to gametogenesis, fertilisation, embryonic and foetal development, maternal adaptations and patterns of inheritance.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand key principles in the organisation and funding of health systems. ULO2 - Be able to apply an understanding of health and health services in the context of the Australian health care system. ULO3 - Recognise the key elements determining health policy. ULO4 - Recognise key determinants and models of health. ULO5 - Understand the complexities of improving population health and the ways in which this is evaluated. ULO6 - Recognise the basis of human rights in health care. ULO7 - Develop important professional skills, including those in oral and written communication, critical analysis, and interpersonal proficiencies.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Contrast and compare the structure, development and function of body systems before and after birth. ULO2 - Explain the physiological changes that occur in the fetus during its transition to life after birth. ULO3 - Discuss and predict consequences of impaired transition at birth for postnatal survival, health and well-being. ULO4 - Evaluate research experiments in perinatology in regard to their contribution to evidence-based medicine. ULO5 - Synthesize and critically discuss the literature, then formulate and justify research methodology to address a knowledge gap in perinatology.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically review the scientific literature that underpins the area of the research project; ULO2 - Undertake a supervised research project and contribute to project design and management; ULO3 - Apply appropriate laboratory techniques, research methodologies and data analysis methods to collect, interpret and report research findings; ULO4 - Effectively present research and findings orally showing a firm grasp of the area; ULO5 - Analyse research undertaken in the context of the discipline area and report findings in an extended written report.

UNIT_TITLE: Advanced studies in biomedicine part-time A
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically review scientific literature in the discipline area of research; ULO2 - Apply knowledge of current methodologies and concepts to appraise scientific literature in the discipline area; ULO3 - Apply analytical and data analysis techniques relevant to the discipline area of research; ULO4 - Effectively communicate concepts in the discipline area of research both in writing and orally.

UNIT_TITLE: Advanced studies in biomedicine part-time B
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically review scientific literature in the discipline area of research; ULO2 - Apply knowledge of current methodologies and concepts to appraise scientific literature in the discipline area; ULO3 - Apply analytical and data analysis techniques relevant to the discipline area of research; ULO4 - Effectively communicate concepts in the discipline area of research both in writing and orally.

ULO1 - Identify the chemical and biochemical aspects of functional groups in biological molecules. ULO2 - Explain the common reactions found in metabolic systems such as oxidation-reduction, bond formation, bond breaking events and a knowledge of the role of water. ULO3 - Explain the role of equilibrium and kinetic processes in biology and apply these to the concepts of enzyme catalysis. ULO4 - Predict the thermodynamics of metabolic reactions. ULO5 - Describe how energy is generated and utilised from carbohydrates and lipids and integrate and translate this to different situations. ULO6 - Investigate and communicate, reactions of biomedical importance in normal and disease states
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the properties and function of cells and explain how the primary tissue types combine to form a complete organism; ULO2 - Describe the effects of cellular mechanisms and environmental impacts on human development, and identify how they are applied in health and biotechnology; ULO3 - Describe the ways in which organisms regulate their internal systems and environment; ULO4 - Explain the principles behind the development of an immune response and the role of microorganisms in health and disease; ULO5 - Implement basic laboratory techniques and associated research informed reports ULO6 - Effectively collaborate with peers in the communication of scientific information .
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain and apply relevant physics principles to human physiology and biomedical contexts ULO2 - Identify physical factors that should be considered when analysing physiological systems ULO3 - Perform basic experiments, conduct reliable measurements, analyse data and interpret results ULO4 - Accurately communicate scientific information in written and graphical forms ULO5 - Use critical thinking to apply physics principles and models to physiological problems
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate and show application of core public health principles including epidemiology, biostatistics and ethics in health research. ULO2 - Explain how disease is measured in populations and critically analyse the strengths and weaknesses of different epidemiological study designs which are used in public health research. ULO3 - Critically appraise the popular and biomedical literature in public health. ULO4 - Identify fundamental ethical considerations that underpin health research. ULO5 - Identify and apply the importance of statistical methods in the design, analysis and presentation of the results of research studies in health and biomedicine, and in reports of health-related matters in general. ULO6 - Interpret statistical results presented and identify limitations in the biomedical literature and other media and convey the interpretation in simple language.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the fundamental concepts of nervous system organisation and communication; ULO2 - Have gained some insight into how the brain enables us to sense our environment and to move, feel, think and communicate with others; ULO3 - Describe how the human brain and behaviour evolved; ULO4 - Explain how behaviour can be influenced by genetic makeup, environmental and social factors and drugs; and ULO5 - Acquire some basic skills in obtaining, interpreting and presenting scientific data.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the mechanisms of DNA replication and expression of genetic information. ULO2 - Evaluate the different levels of control of gene expression from DNA to protein. ULO3 - Apply the principles of relevant DNA technologies and bioinformatics to investigate problems in medicine, diagnostic or research. ULO4 - Demonstrate an understanding of DNA recombination, mutation and repair to interpret their role in normal biological processes and disease. ULO5 - Use molecular biology techniques and analytical skills to perform, interpret and critically analyse experiments addressing simple questions in research or medicine.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Structure of the human body: An evolutionary and functional perspective
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe and contrast the structures and spatial relationships of the tissues, organs, systems, and regions that make up the human body. ULO2 - Relate anatomical structures (tissues, organs, systems) to basic developmental processes and use comparative approaches to identify evolutionary and functional contexts. ULO3 - Interpret and extrapolate sectional anatomical images to topographic anatomy using various methods and techniques such as medical imaging, measurement, drawing, and 3D printing ULO4 - Integrate discrete anatomical knowledge into a comprehensive framework of body structures and systems ULO5 - Work collaboratively to collect and analyse anatomical data. ULO6 - Investigate and communicate, verbally and through writing, the developmental, evolutionary and functional aspects of human anatomy
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Discuss how energy and nutrients are supplied to mammalian cells and how metabolism is regulated and integrated. ULO2 - Discuss the mechanisms by which cells communicate to coordinate metabolism, cell growth, differentiation and cell death. ULO3 - Describe the mechanisms by which precursor and stem cells differentiate into mature cells. ULO4 - Explain the molecular and cellular basis of selected diseases and how they can be modulated by drugs. ULO5 - Demonstrate an ability to present, analyse and interpret data from molecular and cell biological experiments clearly and concisely in oral and written form. ULO6 - Demonstrate the ability to work in a team.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the functions and controls of the cardiovascular, renal, respiratory, endocrine, reproductive and digestive systems in the human body; ULO2 - Describe how the body systems integrate in order to maintain homeostasis following exercise or blood loss; ULO3 - Plan and conduct scientific experiments and analyse and interpret the associated experimental data related to the effects of ventricular filling on cardiac contraction, the effect of exercise on cardiovascular function, the effect of a water loading on urinary excretion and the effects of autonomic nerves on gut motility; ULO4 - Communicate experimental results in the format of scientific figures and written reports.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the central role of genes in the inheritance of traits and the complex variation in inheritance patterns that arise due to interactions of genes with each other and the environment; ULO2 - Explain how genetic variation is generated by mutation and the importance of this in phenotypic variation, evolution and disease; ULO3 - Describe the value of model organisms in studying human gene function in development and disease; ULO4 - Demonstrate understanding of the relevance and value of genetics to human society; ULO5 - Demonstrate skills in independent problem-solving and experimental design, and in data collection, analysis and interpretation; ULO6 - Demonstrate skills in written and oral communication through written reports and oral presentations of research findings by small groups.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the importance of micro-organisms in health and disease; ULO2 - Describe how host and pathogenic factors of micro-organisms affect the outcome of infection; ULO3 - Describe basic mechanisms of immunity to infection and the development and use of vaccines; ULO4 - Explain how infectious diseases are spread, tracked and controlled, and the susceptibility and resistance of microbial pathogens to antimicrobial agents; ULO5 - Describe some examples of microbial pathogens including bacteria, viruses, fungi and parasites, the diseases that they cause, their mechanisms of pathogenesis, and treatment; ULO6 - Demonstrate knowledge of microbiological methodology and laboratory skills that are used to study and diagnose microbial pathogens.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Analyse DNA and RNA sequences and predict gene products ULO2 - Identify conserved features in sequences and structures that define the function of macromolecules ULO3 - Navigate databases to identify sequences and data on mutations associated with disease. ULO4 - Construct and analyse sequence alignments, molecular phylogeny and molecular models of proteins and design strategies to assess gene function by reverse genetics. ULO5 - Interpret structural and functional effects of mutations and predict/state molecular mechanisms underlying the resulting disease. ULO6 - Investigate and communicate, verbally and through writing, the applications of bioinformatics to areas of biomedical science including the development of drugs and therapeutics
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Integrate, apply and build upon knowledge from previous core units in the study of the molecular mechanisms and defects that cause human disease, including how developmental errors and gene abnormalities may lead to abnormalities in protein structure and function. ULO2 - Discuss and evaluate the role of molecular techniques in the diagnosis of human diseases and the design of targeted therapies or specific treatments. ULO3 - Explain and predict the principles of pharmacokinetics and how these can influence the therapeutic use of drugs. ULO4 - Explore and analyse how patient factors (including genetics) can lead to interindividual variation in responses to drugs. ULO5 - Describe and apply skills required to undertake biomedical research activities and apply this to develop a career plan. ULO6 - Synthesise, integrate and summarise information from fundamental principles and techniques in biomedical sciences, then apply it to broader contexts. ULO7 - Work effectively and collaboratively in small teams and evaluate peer and self-performance. ULO8 - Present data and scientific ideas, in oral, written and visual forms using scientific language or plain English as appropriate.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Biomedical basis and epidemiology of human disease
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Integrate and apply their knowledge from previous core units in the study of specific human diseases; ULO2 - Describe and distinguish between the pathobiological processes related to disease; ULO3 - Recognise and cite evidence for how biomedical research, including cell biology, animal models of disease and human studies are important in defining the pathogenesis of disease and the optimal treatment of disease in a public health context; ULO4 - Demonstrate sophisticated interpretation and application of epidemiological methods and principles and discuss critically and cite evidence for the impact of disease on the individual and society; ULO5 - Identify and evaluate the contribution of the epidemiological studies involved in prevention, diagnosis and treatment of specific diseases and justify your reasoning; ULO6 - Critically assess the epidemiological quality of research in a range of studies outlining the basis of your methodological approach and criteria for determining the quality of the research; ULO7 - Synthesise and critically analyse medical literature to discover future challenges in disease pathogenesis and treatment; ULO8 - Further develop research skills including collaborative team work, clear communication and interpersonal skills as well as critical thinking and writing skills.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Action in biomedical science major research project
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Review scientific literature in the project area, including the ability to identify key information in this area; ULO2 - Access databases for provision of information; ULO3 - Present oral reports; ULO4 - Construct written reports; ULO5 - Manage workloads to meet deadlines; ULO6 - Work with a significant degree of independence; ULO7 - Plan a large project, including the ability to adjust planning as events and results dictate; ULO8 - Conduct appropriate statistical analysis of results; ULO9 - Perform routine laboratory measurements and manipulations; ULO10 - Maintain efficient and meaningful communication with a project supervisor; ULO11 - Use technical word processing packages and graphics software.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Major research project in biomedical science
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify relevant published scientific literature and critically analyse and evaluate the content in the context of  the research project ULO2 - Apply knowledge of experimental design with regard to ethical and safety regulations ULO3 - Demonstrate expertise in research methods relevant to the area of research ULO4 - Use appropriate data collection and analysis software to collect and analyse data ULO5 - Maintain accurate and up-to-date records of research procedures, results and outcomes ULO6 - Demonstrate the ability to critically evaluate research findings and how these fit with current knowledge ULO7 - Effectively present research plans and findings orally and via an extended written report ULO8 - Communicate appropriately and effectively with supervisors, laboratory staff and other research students
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Action in biomedical science minor research project
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Review scientific literature in the project area, including the ability to identify key information in this area; ULO2 - Access databases for provision of information; ULO3 - Present oral reports; ULO4 - Construct written reports; ULO5 - Manage workloads to meet deadlines; ULO6 - Work with a significant degree of independence; ULO7 - Plan a large project, including the ability to adjust planning as events and results dictate; ULO8 - Conduct appropriate statistical analysis of results; ULO9 - Perform routine laboratory measurements and manipulations; ULO10 - Maintain efficient and meaningful communication with a project supervisor; ULO11 - Use technical word processing packages and graphics software.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Be able to critically review the scientific literature in their discipline; ULO2 - Understand the processes involved in the design, development and implementation of a research project; ULO3 - Be able to execute and analyse an appropriate set of studies; ULO4 - Be proficient in computer-based data acquisition, analysis, presentation, and word processing; ULO5 - Be able to write up scientific work in a potentially publishable way; ULO6 - Show communication skills in both oral and written presentation to a scientific audience; ULO7 - Have acquired a range of technical skills appropriate to their discipline; ULO8 - Have the capability to perform a variety of scientific procedures and techniques that are essential to the satisfactory completion and reporting of a research project; ULO9 - Have the ability to pursue higher studies in selected disciplines of biomedical science; and ULO10 - Have gained insight into the breadth and diversity of the biomedical sciences.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically review the scientific literature in their discipline; ULO2 - Explain the processes involved in the design, development and implementation of a research project; ULO3 - Recognise the breadth of statistical tests and their applicability to common research methodologies; ULO4 - Apply simple statistical tests.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically review the scientific literature in their discipline; ULO2 - Explain the processes involved in the design, development and implementation of a research project; ULO3 - Assess the breadth of statistical tests and their applicability to common research methodologies; ULO4 - Identify and synthesize knowledge in specific areas of Biomedical Science other than that related to the assigned research project; ULO5 - Summarise research findings concisely, clearly and sequentially; ULO6 - Interpret experimental data with reference to the existing literature; ULO7 - Integrate theoretical knowledge with practice in a specific area of research; ULO8 - Evaluate the status of research progress within a particular research field ; ULO9 - Generate novel ideas to solve an existing problem or answer to an unknown question; ULO10 - Assess the risks in designing experimental strategies or identify the shortcomings in justifying the results; ULO11 - Integrate multidisciplinary components in an experimental design.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Validate the scientific literature to comprehend the progress within a specific research area; ULO2 - Identify and apply the processes involved in the design, development and implementation of a research project; ULO3 - Design, develop and implement a research project; ULO4 - Acquire and analyse computer based data for graphical and tabular summarisation of findings; ULO5 - Summarise research outcomes into scientific manuscripts in accordance with publication requirements; ULO6 - Effectively and clearly communicate scientific principles and research findings in verbal and written form to a broad audience; ULO7 - Identify and select techniques that are essential to the satisfactory completion and reporting of a research project ULO8 - Apprehend the significance of ethics, laboratory etiquette and adherence to OHS ULO9 - Recognize a critical problem and formulate a hypothesis to solve it; and ULO10 - Interpret the research findings with reference to the existing literature
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Research training: Critical thinking and communication skills
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Effectively communicate the basis of the scientific method from building a hypothesis, to testing the ideas through experimental methods; ULO2 - Interpret and summarise the purpose and outcomes of current biomedical research papers on studies at the level of tissues, organs and systems; ULO3 - Evaluate the different types of research designs used in the biomedical sciences at the level of tissues, organs and systems, and justify the use of particular research designs to address specific research questions; ULO4 - Analyse current, cutting-edge research in biomedical sciences, and effectively communicate these complex ideas to a diverse audience. ULO5 - Analyse the range of different biomedical science techniques used at the level of tissues, organs and systems, to create models pertinent to human health and disease ULO6 - Critically evaluate the advantages and limitations of different biomedical science techniques in providing information pertinent to human health and disease;
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Research techniques: Tissues, organs and systems
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Proficiently perform biomedical techniques for study at the level of tissues, organs and systems, and conduct research methods applicable to biology, biotechnology and biomedical science. ULO2 - Explain the basis of the scientific method from building a hypothesis, to the importance of testing scientific ideas through experimental methods and the need in science to gain experimental evidence to test a hypothesis. ULO3 - Independently design appropriate experimental protocols for use in biomedical research - at the level of tissues, organs and systems, by evaluating the advantages and disadvantages of different techniques for measurement and collection of data. ULO4 - Apply scientific concepts (such as controls, replication, reductionist and expansionist approaches, sources of error and error minimisation), and research ethics and integrity to scientific data collection and analysis. ULO5 - Critically analyse and organise research data and methodology, applying appropriate research methods to study design, collection and analysis of data at the level of tissues, organs and systems in the biomedical sciences. ULO6 - Work effectively in a collaborative environment as part of a team in a laboratory setting to address scientific questions.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply knowledge of some of the most important bacterial, viral and parasitic infectious diseases affecting humans (and animals) to assessment of their importance, impact and treatment and control, particularly in resource poor or low and middle income communities. ULO2 - Apply the concept of 'One Health' in the context of infectious diseases including vector-borne and zoonotic infections. ULO3 - Evaluate emerging and re-emerging pathogens and their implications on human health. ULO4 - Explain the application of recombinant DNA technology, molecular and cell biology and biochemical and biophysical techniques as research (and diagnostic) tools in infectious diseases. ULO5 - Evaluate the epidemiology and control of infectious diseases including chemoprophylaxis, Chemotherapy, drug resistance and vaccinology. ULO6 - Communicate complicated concepts, scientific data and results and current opinions accurately and effectively through oral presentations and reports.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Compile and recount advanced knowledge of relationships between brain processes and behaviour; ULO2 - Apply problem solving and decision-making methodologies to discuss and analyse contemporary research and theoretical issues in key defined areas of neuroscience; ULO3 - Explain the pathological mechanisms involved in specific neurological/neuropsychiatric disorders; ULO4 - Review, analyse and communicate on a range of research tools and paradigms used in different domains of neuroscientific research; ULO5 - Source, integrate and critically evaluate literature to synthesise the review necessary for a prototype application to study a particular problem; ULO6 - Present, analyse and interpret data from a range of experiment types and discuss this in the context of current scientific literature.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify, evaluate and effectively communicate key concepts and results and their implications from high impact recent publications in the field of stem cell and regenerative medicine research; ULO2 - Prepare a cohesive human ethics application covering a project focussed on research using human materials or for human clinical applications; ULO3 - Evaluate key future research directions for stem cell and regenerative medicine research, and develop scientific, clinical and/or commercial arguments to underpin funding applications; ULO4 - Identify, evaluate and justify appropriate approaches for stem cell-based therapeutics for specific disease states.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Analyse pathological mechanisms involved in specific cardiovascular diseases. ULO2 - Source, integrate and critically evaluate the scientific literature to address a defined problem relating to cardiovascular science. ULO3 - Analyse, interpret and present data from a range of experiment types and discuss this in the context of current scientific literature. ULO4 - Analyse contemporary research and theoretical issues in key areas of cardiovascular science, including epidemiological aspects. ULO5 - Evaluate a range of research tools and paradigms used within different domains of cardiovascular research, encompassing cellular through to in vivo through to the population. ULO6 - Effectively communicate complex concepts and scientific content in written or oral formats.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Interpret and critically evaluate the pathways from discovery science that lead to innovation and commercialisation of biotechnology innovations; ULO2 - Analyse and evaluate the critical role of intellectual property in the commercialisation of biotechnology; ULO3 - Apply advanced knowledge of how the major regulatory bodies [e.g. TGA (Therapeutic Goods Administration); FDA (Food & Drug Administration); CTN (Clinical Trial Notification Scheme)] deal with specific innovations in the biotech / medtech sectors; ULO4 - Evaluate and critically assess and predict the potential for commercial development and success of a specific biotechnology innovation; ULO5 - Systematically build and validate arguments and opinions by sourcing and critically deconstructing relevant material and information, working both independently and as part of a team; ULO6 - Effectively communicate complex concepts on scientific content and business processes in written or oral formats.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically review the scientific literature in their discipline; ULO2 - Identify the processes involved in the design, development and implementation of a research project; ULO3 - Design, execute and analyse an appropriate set of studies; ULO4 - Perform the variety of scientific procedures and techniques essential to the satisfactory completion and reporting of their specific research project; ULO5 - Proficiently acquire skills in data collection using computers or high-end biomedical devices ULO6 - Competently acquire the critical thinking and reasoning to analyse data from computers or high-end biomedical devices ULO7 - Critically evaluate, using appropriate statistical analyses, data from a scientific project to deduce appropriate interpretations ULO8 - Investigate, evaluate and select appropriate graphical and other formats for presentation of data ULO9 - Effectively communicate research outcomes in verbal and written form using appropriate tools to a scientific audience, including writing up scientific work in a potentially publishable way; ULO10 - Assemble from the breadth and diversity of the biomedical sciences thoughtful reasonings and interpretations of research findings to formulate a discussion
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Create a professional written portfolio for different types of positions within the biomedical or biotechnology industries. ULO2 - Evaluate explicit and implicit key selection criteria for different types of positions within the biomedical or biotechnology industries and formulate appropriate oral and written responses. ULO3 - Design and construct professional online portfolios to promote skills for self-employment in the biomedical and Biotech industries. ULO4 - Appraise and critique interview techniques for models of real world jobs in the biomedical or biotechnical industries. ULO5 - Apply professional biomedical science skills to generate a workplace -appropriate research report such as preparation of findings for publication or creating a pipeline of product marketing or evaluation. ULO6 - Appraise current trends in the biomedical and biotechnology sciences to Identify potential growth areas. ULO7 - Evaluate the impact of organisation culture upon ethical practise and approaches to problem solving. ULO8 - Formulate and apply a set of professional codes of conduct for a specific internship workplace.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify, evaluate and effectively communicate key concepts and results and their implications from high impact recent publications in the field of cancer biology and translational cancer research; ULO2 - Analyse, interpret and present data from a range of experiment types and discuss this in the context of current scientific literature. ULO3 - Review and critique scientific literature relevant to a specified scientific question to formulate a scientific hypothesis to underpin a research project in the field of cancer biology; ULO4 - Evaluate and integrate current knowledge on the genetic drivers of cancer to design trials to assess new cancer therapeutics; ULO5 - Review, evaluate and justify appropriate approaches for clinical trial design based on preclinical evidence.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Research training: Ethics and integrity, biostatistics and critical thinking
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Effectively communicate the basis of designing an experimental model to test a scientific hypothesis from building a hypothesis, to testing the ideas through experimental methods; ULO2 - Describe the different forms of statistical methods and analyses used in biomedical sciences and appraise the appropriate method to be applied to interpret different types of data; ULO3 - Identify and evaluate the different types of research designs used in the biomedical sciences, and justify the use of specific research designs to address specific research questions ULO4 - Analyse the ethical principles that inform the formulation of a scientific research question and the conduct of research to address that question ULO5 - Review and articulate the ethical framework that governs the conduct of science, in particular in regards to academic and research integrity. ULO6 - Analyse and effectively communicate, in written and oral formats, complex research integrity concepts relevant to the conduct of human and animal experimentation.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Research techniques: Molecular and cellular techniques
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Proficiently perform biomedical techniques for study at the molecular and cellular level, and conduct research methods applicable to biology, biotechnology and biomedical science. ULO2 - Explain the basis of the scientific method from building a hypothesis, to the importance of testing scientific ideas through experimental methods and the need in science to gain experimental evidence to test a hypothesis ULO3 - Independently design appropriate experimental protocols for use in biomedical research - at the molecular and cellular level, by evaluating the advantages and disadvantages of different techniques for measurement and collection of data. ULO4 - Apply scientific concepts on controls, replication, reductionist and expansionist approaches, sources of error and error minimisation, and the application of research ethics and integrity to molecular and cellular scientific data collection and analysis ULO5 - Critically analyse and organise research data and methodology, applying appropriate research methods to study design, collection of data and data analysis in molecular and cellular biomedical sciences ULO6 - Work effectively in a collaborative environment as part of a team in a laboratory setting to address a scientific question
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the nature of digestion, how nutrients are detected in the gut and signal to the brain to control body weight ULO2 - Create a model of the current understanding of the central processing of information that relates to appetite from both homeostatic and reward  based perspectives. ULO3 - Formulate a framework outlining the contribution of energy expenditure to control body weight and the amelioration of metabolic disorders. ULO4 - Generate a model for the brain's control of body weight, incorporating competing processes limiting the ability to maintain weight loss. ULO5 - Critically evaluate the evidence for the success of the treatment of overweight and obesity.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the relationships between DNA, RNA, and proteins and their roles in cell functioning. ULO2 - Explain the health data life cycle and the relevance of computation in modern life sciences research. ULO3 - Explain how nucleotide and protein sequence and structure data are represented and processed in computational biology. ULO4 - Evaluate the merits and limitations of the major bioinformatics databases to solve specific computational biomedical problems. ULO5 - Use bioinformatic tools and databases to analyse nucleotide or protein sequences. ULO6 - Perform elementary statistical analysis on biomolecular and omics datasets and represent the outcomes in informative graphical displays and data summaries.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Advanced bioinformatics: efficient genome, transcriptome and proteome analysis
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply modern approaches to rapid analysis of the genome, transcriptome and proteome and data integration. ULO2 - Explain the relevance of data integration and modelling in computational biology. ULO3 - Evaluate, rate and justify current research directions in computational biology. ULO4 - Analyse multiple data-types in computational biology and construct appropriate analytic solutions to large-scale datasets. ULO5 - Formulate and construct a multi-disciplinary solution for microbiome and metagenomics datasets and design informative graphical displays and data summaries to represent the data analytic outcomes. ULO6 - Assemble, appraise and judge the regulatory frame work for the acquisition and use of genomics data sets
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically review nutrition and dietetic practice, identifying gaps in knowledge and apply valid and relevant conclusions and recommendations for practice improvement. ULO2 - Utilise research, leadership, communication (including negotiation, advocacy and conflict resolution) and management principles and skills in approaching solutions to practice problems. ULO3 - Work effectively as a member of a team creating innovative solutions to nutrition and dietetics practice problems.
