UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate knowledge of the fundamental techniques and the basic principles of molecular biology and recombinant DNA technology that are required for biotechnology; ULO2 - Demonstrate an understanding of the applications and impact of biotechnology in the areas of agriculture, medicine, and industry; ULO3 - Assess and manage occupational health and safety issues related to biotechnology activities in the laboratory and in environmental and industrial settings; ULO4 - Demonstrate an understanding of the basic concepts of biotechnology business, intellectual property rights, and the regulatory framework governing the biotechnology industry; ULO5 - Apply knowledge of the fundamental ethical and regulatory issues surrounding the biotechnology field; ULO6 - Communicate biotechnology findings effectively in the form of oral and written scientific reports.

ULO1 - Discuss basic principles of recombinant DNA technology; ULO2 - Select and apply practical techniques to achieve a range of experimental outcomes in molecular biology; ULO3 - Give examples of the applications of recombinant DNA technology in medical and industrial settings; ULO4 - Describe the use of biological databases for data storage; ULO5 - Demonstrate skill in data mining; ULO6 - Present, analyse and interpret experimental data.

ULO1 - Discuss the buffering mechanisms that operate in biological systems; ULO2 - Recognise the role of non-covalent interactions in the maintenance of tertiary and quaternary conformation of biological macromolecules; ULO3 - Explain the connection between protein structure and function; ULO4 - Discuss strategies for the isolation and purification of proteins from biological samples; ULO5 - Discuss the principles of storage and transmission of genetic information and describe control mechanisms which operate at the level of gene expression; ULO6 - Use spectrophotometric methods to assay biological molecules in solution; ULO7 - Analyse and interpret laboratory data and present in an appropriate format.

ULO1 - Explain the mechanisms involved in the storage and processing of metabolic fuels; ULO2 - Discuss mechanisms for control of metabolic reaction sequences; ULO3 - Describe the specialised metabolic role of various tissues; ULO4 - Explain how metabolic processes are integrated and regulated; ULO5 - Demonstrate advanced laboratory skills; ULO6 - Collect, interpret and present experimental data in an accessible and appropriate format.

ULO1 - Demonstrate the ability to identify plant species of agricultural importance; ULO2 - Demonstrate good understanding of the principles involved in crop production and methods for crop improvement; ULO3 - Apply specialised knowledge on important factors affecting crop growth and yield to achieve sustainable production of important tropical crops; ULO4 - Analyse, interpret and present scientific data effectively.

ULO1 - Explain and describe the cell structure and function of viruses, prokaryotes and eukaryotes and how they differ from one another. ULO2 - Cite examples and describe the role of microorganisms in the fields of medicine, food science and in the environment. ULO3 - Explain how infections can spread and antibiotic resistance can be acquired, and be able to cite examples of important regional pathogens. ULO4 - List and describe requirements for growth and replication of these microorganisms as well as methods for controlling bacterial and viral growth. ULO5 - Perform aseptic techniques and be able to isolate and identify microorganisms using light/phase microscopy and a variety of media and staining procedures. ULO6 - Collect, interpret, and present microbiological data via written practical reports.

ULO1 - Explain how microbes cause disease, with particular emphasis on bacterial and viral pathogenicity; ULO2 - Discuss the epidemiology of infectious disease; ULO3 - Discuss the role of chemotherapy and the importance of drug resistance in the treatment of infectious disease; ULO4 - Describe the role of microorganisms in selected infectious diseases associated with the different organ systems; ULO5 - Discuss relevant diagnostic techniques used in clinical microbiology laboratories; ULO6 - Describe and perform techniques used in diagnostic serology; ULO7 - Demonstrate competence in laboratory procedures for handling and processing microbiological specimens.

ULO1 - Discuss principles of microbial ecology, recognising the role of microorganisms as a mixed flora; ULO2 - Diagram the role of microorganisms in biogeochemical nutrient cycles; ULO3 - Discuss the role of different microorganisms in air, water environments, and soils, predicting the effects of changes in environmental parameters; ULO4 - Describe how microorganisms can cause pollution and the use of microorganisms as indicators of pollution; ULO5 - Discuss the role of microorganisms in sewage treatment and composting; ULO6 - Explain how microorganisms can be exploited in bioremediation; ULO7 - Demonstrate the use of molecular and traditional methods for detection and identification of microorganisms.

ULO1 - Demonstrate a broad understanding of fundamental concepts, principles and theories relating to cell biology and the molecular basis of several major diseases. ULO2 - Recognise that our knowledge of complex cellular functions is based on observation and experiment ULO3 - Assess the importance of cell biology in modern technologies and medicine.

ULO1 - Discuss the molecular basis of a wide range of techniques for gene manipulation and genomic and proteomic analysis; ULO2 - Apply their knowledge to the pursuit of current scientific problems in industry, medicine, and research; ULO3 - Critically evaluate a variety of approaches to a particular scientific or industrial problem; ULO4 - Demonstrate proficiency in a wide range of techniques for gene manipulation and in the interpretation of data acquired by these techniques; ULO5 - Demonstrate advanced scientific writing skills.

ULO1 - Demonstrate knowledge of current issues and technologies in plant biotechnology; ULO2 - Demonstrate clear understanding of the techniques involved in plant tissue culture; ULO3 - Design constructs to alter the expression of specific genes; ULO4 - Demonstrate understanding of the various strategies involved in the creation of existing plant transgenic crops; ULO5 - Appreciate the potential role of genetic manipulation to produce novel plant products of potential economic importance; ULO6 - Exhibit skills in analysis, interpretation and presentation of scientific data.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Design and conduct experiments; ULO2 - Identify, use and critically evaluate research literature; ULO3 - Conduct interdisciplinary projects composed of chemistry and pharmacology; ULO4 - Implement safe working practices with chemicals, radio-isotopes, and biological materials; ULO5 - Make oral presentations and write reports covering both chemistry and pharmacology.

ULO1 - Critically review the scientific literature that underpins the selected area of biotechnology research; ULO2 - Undertake a supervised research project in an area of biotechnology and contribute to project design and management; ULO3 - Apply appropriate laboratory techniques, research methodologies and data analysis methods to collect, interpret and report the findings; ULO4 - Effectively present the research and findings orally showing a firm grasp of the area; ULO5 - Analyse the research in the context of the discipline area and report the findings in an extended written report.

ULO1 - Critically review scientific literature in an applied area of biotechnology; ULO2 - Research, analyse and report on the translation of basic research towards a commercial product; ULO3 - Recognise the breadth of analytical and data analysis techniques and their applicability to biotechnology research; ULO4 - Apply analytical and data analysis techniques relevant to the biotechnology industry; ULO5 - Effectively communicate concepts in biotechnology both in writing and orally.

ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding of experimental design and sampling methods that are relevant to their research project; ULO2 - Demonstrate an understanding of the impacts of resource limitation on experimental design and implementation; ULO3 - Critically analyse articles from the scientific literature and use this ability to enhance the quality of their own written work; ULO4 - Express themselves clearly and effectively to a scientific audience; ULO5 - Write and manage assessment tasks expeditiously and competently.

UNIT_TITLE: Grand challenges in chemical engineering: Delivering sustainable food, water and energy
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - describe key chemical engineering principles, such as heat and material transfer, thermodynamics, fluid dynamics, (bio)chemical reactions engineering and process design/control ULO2 - identify unit operations within chemical engineering processes and select suitable equipment for an operation ULO3 - investigate physical and chemical states of matter and delivery systems within industrial and practical lab settings ULO4 - apply creative problem-solving approaches using chemical engineering principles to contemporary examples ULO5 - engage and learn in both independent and collaborative ways with others to encompass diverse abilities and perspectives ULO6 - demonstrate effective communication within a range of settings, including oral presentations and written reports.

ULO1 - Determine and solve fluid flow problems by employing Bernoulli's equation and control volumes to predict fluid behaviour with particular regard to the principles of continuity and momentum. ULO2 - Use dimensional analysis and modelling to plan experiments, present results meaningfully and predict prototype performance. ULO3 - Determine lift and drag forces for bodies including vehicles subjected to fluid motion. ULO4 - Analyse and discern between laminar and turbulent flows, demonstrate an understanding of boundary layers and flow separation, and explain how these concepts impact on drag and fluid energy loss. ULO5 - Determine the appropriate sizes and operating parameters for turbo machines by employing knowledge of the typical operation, limitations, and applications of these devices.

ULO1 - Apply the basic concepts of conservation of mass and energy, including phase equilibrium, reaction equilibrium and non-ideal gas behaviour to mass and energy balances. ULO2 - Apply the concepts of unit operations to combine them into a block flow diagram and process flow diagram of a chemical process. ULO3 - Interpret physical property charts and diagrams to solve problems based on phase equilibrium, refrigeration and heat pump cycles. ULO4 - Analyse the mass and energy balances of any chemical process, for both steady and unsteady state situations. ULO5 - Simulate processes using a process simulation software to analyse the mass and energy balance of complex chemical processes and report the results in a technical report. ULO6 - Interpret experimental measurements of mass, energy and chemical composition and report the results in a lab report.

ULO1 - Determine which modes of heat transfer (conduction, convection and radiation) and/or mass transfer (diffusive and convective) are occurring in a given problem ULO2 - Identify key assumptions (e.g. steady state vs transient) that lead to a solution procedure. ULO3 - Formulate solutions for common engineering problem using a combination of analytical equations, dimensional analysis, and empirical correlations ULO4 - Critically analyse the solution with respect to clarity (communicating the solution to engineers and managers), effects of errors, validity of assumptions, and how the solution(s) can be used to provide operational advice. ULO5 - Conduct self-directed learning using common textbooks, online tools and reference texts, in order to prepare for laboratory sessions and assignments (including preparation for self-directed life-long learning beyond tertiary education).

ULO1 - Identify concepts of thermodynamic equilibrium and energy transfer. ULO2 - Determine the transfer of energy in ideal engineering devices using the First Law of Thermodynamics. ULO3 - Determine the performance and efficiency of ideal and practical engineering devices using the Second Law of Thermodynamics. ULO4 - Apply thermodynamics concepts to evaluate the performance of heat engines and refrigeration systems. ULO5 - Discern measurements required to evaluate the thermodynamic performance of real engineering systems.

ULO1 - Develop block flow diagrams and expand them into process flow diagrams via integration of open-ended design problem concepts to propose solutions for chemical engineering design problems. ULO2 - Solve problems using the computer simulation package for chemical processes. ULO3 - Integrate concepts of material and energy balances, unit operations and simulation methods and tools to solve complex design problems. ULO4 - Demonstrate the application of sustainable development, resource and energy efficiency concepts and principles to solve problems in existing and new process designs. ULO5 - Analyse the sustainability of chemical processes using simple environmental metrices. ULO6 - Work in teams and communicate their work effectively.

ULO1 - Use appropriate representation (one-dimensional beam theory) of structures and diagrams (Mohr circle) to describe forces and stresses acting in a system and perform analysis of such structures in relation to chemical engineering design. ULO2 - Solve the forces on solid structures in chemical engineering design problems. ULO3 - Describe properties of materials and the link between the properties and uses for different applications. ULO4 - Apply stress-strain relationships to determine elasticity of materials. ULO5 - Explain corrosion mechanisms that can occur in common materials of construction and describe measures to mitigate corrosion. ULO6 - Select materials of construction that are fit for purpose in design problems based on appropriate failure theories for engineering materials. ULO7 - Have an appreciation for the role of a chemical engineer in the safe design of structures and their link with other disciplines in the engineering profession (e.g. mechanical and materials).

ULO1 - Relate the importance of biochemistry in industry. ULO2 - Describe the role of basic cell components, the physical and biochemical properties of proteins especially in their roles as enzymes. ULO3 - Relate the major metabolic pathway and the biosynthesis of economic importance of primary and secondary metabolites. ULO4 - Relate the principles of storage and transmission of genetic information; the control mechanisms which operate at the level of gene expression; and their applications in industry. ULO5 - Demonstrate laboratory skills, including basic cell culture technique; spectophotometric methods to assay proteins; gel electrophoresis analysis for proteins and DNA.

ULO1 - Describe the major chemical processes in the petrochemical and oleochemical industry. ULO2 - Synthesise chemical processes by taking into consideration product quality, process safety, process economics, and sustainability. ULO3 - Address an open-ended problem by designing a solution and validate the solution using lab-scale equipment. ULO4 - Function effectively as an individual and as a team member, and demonstrate a commitment to professional ethics and norms of engineering practice.

ULO1 - Apply the principles of food engineering and food processing and relate the theory to the?practical (industrial) situation. ULO2 - Solve problems involving unit operations, water activity and food stability, food drying,?thermal processing, reaction kinetics, and rheological properties. ULO3 - Relate the principles and applications of material science in food product design,?development and packaging. ULO4 - Evaluate the kinetics of physicochemical changes in food during processing. ULO5 - Use instrumental techniques to measure the engineering principles as well as properties of?foods.

ULO1 - Apply mass, energy and entropy balances to flow processes. ULO2 - Determine the properties of ideal and real mixtures based on thermodynamic principles. ULO3 - Assess changes in the properties of gases, fluids and solids undergoing changes in temperature and volume. ULO4 - Interpret the underlying principles of phase equilibrium in binary and multi-component systems. ULO5 - Analyse the extent to which chemical reactions proceed, and determine the composition attained at equilibrium.

ULO1 - Discern the response to a set-point and disturbance change, including first order and second order responses. ULO2 - Interpret common control scenarios including feedback, feed forward, ratio and cascade systems. ULO3 - Interpret and model simple dynamic systems and understand the approach to modelling more complex systems. ULO4 - Execute basic and advanced control strategies including tuning of controllers, and model-based control. ULO5 - Discuss the issues associated with the use of computer control systems for the implementation of process control. ULO6 - Design a suitable control strategy for a given situation and process.

ULO1 - Apply the principles of cleaner production and sustainability in the design and evaluation of processes and products ULO2 - Design and evaluate processes with emphasis on resource and energy efficiency and waste minimisation ULO3 - Develop and draw a detailed process flow sheet ULO4 - Produce the life cycle block diagram of a product and determine the main environmental impacts of the life cycle ULO5 - Analyse a process or product using life cycle assessment methodology ULO6 - Analyse the benefits and burdens of materials recycling ULO7 - Evaluate and apply the principles of greenhouse gas (GHG) measurement and reporting under national and international schemes ULO8 - Examine and evaluate sustainable energy options

ULO1 - Appreciate the importance of chemical kinetics and reactor design in chemical industry. ULO2 - Apply the fundamentals of chemical kinetics for complicated reactions. ULO3 - Apply the fundamentals of kinetics of catalytic reactions, including some biochemical reactions. ULO4 - Describe the fundamentals of reactor design. ULO5 - Apply advanced mathematics to complicated problems of reactor design. ULO6 - Analyse the behaviour of complicated reactors. ULO7 - Apply the fundamental principles of reaction engineering to a wide range of problems, e.g. in traditional petrochemical and chemical industry, in pharmaceutical industry, in energy industry, in environmental protection. ULO8 - Analyse new reaction engineering problems and formulating original solutions.

ULO1 - Interpret the analysis of general equilibrium stage processes (co- and countercurrent). ULO2 - Describe the principles underlying the operation of a range of separation processes. ULO3 - Analyse the operation and performance of a range of separation processes and unit operations. ULO4 - Demonstrate skills in solving engineering problems related to design and operation of separation processes and unit operations. ULO5 - Demonstrate experimental skills in operating and analysing the performance of separation unit operations ULO6 - Generate strategies for solving complex, open-ended separation process problems.

ULO1 - Differentiate all the phases of a design project and explain the role of the chemical engineer in the detailed design stage and their relationship with the other design professionals. ULO2 - Select suitable containment materials, by explaining how chemicals are safely contained in a chemical process and corrosion mitigation. ULO3 - Assess potential hazards using an industry-accepted framework and mitigate these hazards as part of the detailed design process. ULO4 - Create engineering drawings used in the detailed design stage including P&I Diagrams, Equipment Datasheets, General Arrangement Drawings and a site Plot Plan. ULO5 - Compare different rotating equipment used in chemical processes. ULO6 - Apply design rules for the specification of static equipment such as process vessels and heat exchangers with application of inherent safety, hydraulic and operability considerations and mechanical integrity. ULO7 - Practice responsibility of a competent engineer to integrate individual design sections into a Design Project Report including the analysis and review of engineering drawings and calculations. Through this activity, continue to develop positive attitudes to teamwork and responsible engineering practice.

ULO1 - Select and describe mechanisms of transport phenomena present in given processes ULO2 - Design simple models relating the conservation of energy, species, or momentum to temperature, composition and velocity fields ULO3 - Demonstrate the ability to solve selected partial differential equations (one-dimensional and two-dimensional transport problems) by applying numerical methods such as finite element and finite difference ULO4 - Demonstrate the ability to develop approximate models of practical chemical engineering systems and solve problems based on them ULO5 - Generate complex problems commonly encountered in practice utilising commercial numerical software packages (MATLAB and COMSOL Multiphysics)

ULO1 - Describe biological systems and molecules and how these are harnessed in biotechnology. ULO2 - Analyse the performance of unit operations involved in bioprocessing. ULO3 - Generate a process flow diagram for a bioprocessing plant.

ULO1 - address an open-ended industrial problem by designing solutions that meet specified?objectives ULO2 - validate solutions using an in-house pilot plant facility and critically evaluate the process?operability, performance, economics, safety and sustainability ULO3 - function effectively as an individual and as a team member, and demonstrate a commitment to?professional ethics and norms of engineering practice.

ULO1 - Appraise the role of a professional engineer, Code of Conduct and Ethics. ULO2 - Deliberate the factors affecting the market for specific products and an understanding of market risks to industries involved in manufacturing businesses. ULO3 - Demonstrate teamwork skills for working in group projects. ULO4 - Design the normal project timeline using a GANNT chart, including the hurdles required for financing a new project. ULO5 - Appraise the approval process for government jurisdiction for environmental assessment and a plant safety case and have some understanding of the key points of environmental law, and occupational health and safety legislation. ULO6 - Demonstrate the ability to carry out the risk assessment and formulate the risk management for a process plant. ULO7 - Demonstrate the ability to produce an environmental improvement plan for a process and carry out a HAZOP of a part of a process and draw a fault-tree diagram. ULO8 - Demonstrate the ability to estimate the equipment costs for a process, the plant capital and operating costs, including a cash flow analysis and calculate the net present value of a project using discounted cash flow and determine its financial viability.

ULO1 - Appreciate the importance of professional industrial practice and the application of chemical engineering science in an industrial setting. ULO2 - Analyse an open ended industrial problem and develop a practical approach. ULO3 - Critically analyse data and develop a new theory or conclusion. ULO4 - Demonstrate interpersonal, oral presentation and technical report writing skills ULO5 - Function effectively and professionally in an industrial setting according to the principles of management, process economics and process safety

ULO1 - Appraise a design brief for a conceptual design study for a specific chemical product, feedstock and location and deliberate on the most appropriate technology for this brief. ULO2 - Synthesise a chemical process which reflects on efficiency, values inherent safety and mitigates environmental impacts, and demonstrates conservation of mass and energy. ULO3 - Design a specific area of the plant at a "detailed design level", by generating specification sheets of equipment and a detailed process design of a specific equipment item including detailed engineering drawings. ULO4 - Generate Piping & Instrumentation Diagrams for a specific design area and reflect on these drawings by assessing the safety of the process individually and as a part of a HAZOP team. ULO5 - Generate a plant layout that mitigates any risks associated with the process that has been designed and assesses the environmental impacts of the process at the plant level and over the whole product life cycle. ULO6 - Generate capital and operating cost estimates, and assess the financial viability of the project, and determine the sensitivity to various engineering and commercial factors, and appraise the project viability. ULO7 - Plan and prioritise the steps required in a conceptual design and monitor the performance of individuals and the team against these plans. ULO8 - Generate three major written design reports and justify the preparatory work for these reports through three individual interviews.

ULO1 - Apply principles of fluid flow, mixing, heat transfer and mass transfer to analyse bioreactors ULO2 - Assess the performance of bioreactors and troubleshoot operational problems ULO3 - Solve engineering problems related to the design and operation of bioreactors and bioprocesses ULO4 - Apply principles of biochemical engineering to analyse and assess special topics such as synthetic biology, animal and plant cell culture, and tissue engineering ULO5 - Solve technical and practical issues in commercial bioprocessing

ULO1 - The concepts of nanostructures and nanofabrication, including different synthesis methods ULO2 - The unique properties and applications of nanomaterials with emphasis on chemical engineering applications, including separation, absorption and corrosion ULO3 - New advances at the interface of engineering and biology ULO4 - The use of nanomaterials in medicine with examples in drug and gene delivery ULO5 - Bionanotechnology approaches to build nanostructures using self assembling peptides and DNA In addition, students will acquire skills in: ULO6 - Critical literature review ULO7 - Team work management ULO8 - Oral and written communication in scientific context

ULO1 - Understand and apply heat integration, water integration and process stream recycling in chemical engineering processes to achieve increased raw materials and energy efficiencies and waste reduction ULO2 - Understand the technologies for treatment and disposal of gaseous, liquid and solid wastes ULO3 - Understand the mechanisms and effects of natural cycles for water and carbon ULO4 - Understand the mechanisms and effects of various forms of pollution ULO5 - Explore the benefits of improved industrial ecology through integrated manufacture and improved industrial planning.

ULO1 - Synthesise outcomes from a literature review to identify specific research gaps. ULO2 - Apply engineering knowledge and judgement in experimental design, including the design and commissioning of experimental equipment ULO3 - Generate new knowledge based on the gathering, analysis and interpretation of experimental data. ULO4 - Generate and deliver effective oral and written reporting of the research work. ULO5 - Demonstrate the knowledge, skills and attitudes of a professional engineer.

ULO1 - Develop a research plan based on literature review, knowledge gap, scientific methodologies and methods that leads to a solution of an authentic engineering problem. ULO2 - Deploy an appropriate combination of knowledge, research, statistical and analytical methods, and creativity to conceive, design and develop solutions to complex engineering problems. ULO3 - Generate project findings, critically review project work and apply advanced communication skills to convey progress. ULO4 - Develop a project management plan that outlines objectives, activities, resources, timeline and risk assessment to demonstrate professional engineering skills.

ULO1 - Use an appropriate combination of knowledge, research, statistical and analytical methods, and creativity to conceive, design and validate solutions to complex engineering problems. ULO2 - Manage the continuation and completion of an engineering research project within some or all of the following constrains including technical, budgetary, risk and time. ULO3 - Identify, reflect upon and document possible solutions to professional, ethical, cultural and environmental issues that arise in an engineering project. ULO4 - Apply advanced written and oral communication and interpretative skills to communicate relevant outcomes, conclusions and recommendations against the research objectives and problem statement.

ULO1 - Apply the principles of thermodynamics to advanced chemical engineering processes,process safety, biological sciences, energy, and environmental sciences. ULO2 - Identify differences in thermodynamic properties using equations of state, charts, andtabulated data. ULO3 - Solve problems involving multi-phase chemical systems and reactive systems. ULO4 - Justify and apply the molecular basis of thermodynamics using the formalism of equilibriumstatistical mechanics.

ULO1 - Demonstrate use of advanced mathematical methods to analyse fluid flow. ULO2 - Demonstrate the use of mathematical and physical foundations of the continuum mechanics?of fluids, critically evaluate problems in advanced fluid dynamics and apply theory to analyse?the problems. ULO3 - Develop the capacity to formulate and simplify advanced equations of change, select the?appropriate boundary conditions for compressible and incompressible Newtonian fluids, write?the problem in dimensionless form, select the appropriate dimensionless numbers, and use?suitable numerical and analytical techniques to model the system. ULO4 - Analyse and utilise solution strategies for a variety of problems in incompressible flow,?inviscid flow, ideal fluid flow, boundary layer flow, irrotational flow, and potential flow. ULO5 - Critically evaluate and apply theoretical concepts in turbulence to analyse turbulent flows. ULO6 - Demonstrate an appreciation of how advanced fluid dynamics principles can be used?towards the solution of practical problems in technological contexts.

ULO1 - Analyse the thermodynamics, advanced mass transfer and diffusion theories underpinning?the multi-component separation processes. ULO2 - Combine the simulation tools and analysis methods for process flow-sheeting, column?dimension calculation, and determination of energy efficiency, cost-effectiveness and?sustainability of design solutions for complex separation processes. ULO3 - Apply conceptual procedures for the design of multi-component, extractive and/or azeotropic?distillation column, temperature-/pressure-swing adsorption column, advanced?chromatographic column, and ion-exchange adsorption column. ULO4 - Generate experimental skills in operating and analysing the performance of separation unit?operations. ULO5 - Appreciate through group-based assignments, an understanding of the design process?involving ethical conduct, teamwork spirits, leadership and the need for attention to detail.

ULO1 - Analyse and apply isothermal and non-isothermal kinetics ULO2 - Analyse the importance of catalysis in heterogeneous catalysis, photocatalysis and biocatalysis systems ULO3 - Design and analyse reactor systems using numerical methods and commercial software Aspen Plus ULO4 - Synthesize advanced reactor designs for selective industrial applications ULO5 - Critiquing contemporary journal articles in conventional industrial catalysis and emerging catalysis

ULO1 - Analyse new developments in fundamental aspects of biorefineries by identifying the main pathways of chemical conversion within biorefineries, the resulting products and their applications. ULO2 - Critically evaluate and critique new advances and applications for biorefineries from a technical perspective to devise a strategy based on the economic factors, safety considerations and environmental impacts and use them to inform engineering decision-making. ULO3 - Research. analyse and recommend an appropriate biorefining approach for various biomass feedstocks. ULO4 - Review and critique recent biorefinery research literature to systematically synthesise the finding and insights to design a solution to a problem and/or the project ULO5 - Create and analyse experimental data to produce an accurate and detailed report

UNIT_TITLE: Nanostructured membranes for separation and energy production
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Discern the functional difference between main membranes including polymeric, ceramic and nanocomposite membranes. ULO2 - Describe the synthesis and functionalisation of membranes. ULO3 - Describe the membrane transport of both porous and nonporous membranes in different applications. ULO4 - Reflect the key properties of membranes required for chemical engineering applications. ULO5 - Generate membranes and membrane processes suitable for specific applications, including gas separations, water treatment and desalination, fuel cells and etc. ULO6 - Reflect on and propose research on nanostructured membranes for energy production, water processing and gas separation.

ULO1 - Generate models of chemical and biological processes respecting conservation laws, applying suitable constraints and constitutive relations and determine an appropriate solution algorithm. ULO2 - Assess complex models of chemical processes with an understanding of the mathematical structure of the model and the convergence methods used to obtain the model solution. ULO3 - Assess the appropriate optimisation strategy for linear, non-linear, unconstrained, constrained and mixed integer models from a fundamental understanding of functional and constraint convexity, or determine the appropriate evolutionary solution strategy when convexity is not assured. ULO4 - Demonstrate both single objective and multi-objective optimisation of process models to improve the process objective(s), which assess the sustainability of chemical processes using the life cycle assessment methodology.

UNIT_TITLE: Principles and practices for sustainable development
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply ethical standards and sustainability principles in solving engineering problems ULO2 - Apply principles of sustainable development to develop sustainable designs of products or processes ULO3 - Analyse local legislations and schemes related to sustainable development and implementation of these schemes in sustainable design of products and processes ULO4 - Predict the environmental impacts involved in the lifecycle of a product or process using lifecycle assessment ULO5 - Conduct risk assessments and cost analysis to evaluate the sustainability of a process

ULO1 - Appraise the different types of naturally occurring biopolymers in terms of availability, morphology, composition and functionality to select the most appropriate manufacturing process. ULO2 - Analyse the strengths and weaknesses of different biopolymers. ULO3 - Assess the biomass composition balance of a mill and propose opportunities for business growth and development. ULO4 - Design a biopolymer product based on market needs and formulate the most effective composition and process to achieve the required properties.

ULO1 - Design products to meet recyclable eco-design. ULO2 - Research the most effective materials and processes to maximise sustainability. ULO3 - Synthesise and integrate a wide range of tools and best practices to evaluate product and process innovation sustainability. ULO4 - Design processes using concepts such as green chemistry, industrial ecology and cleaner production to minimise environmental impact. ULO5 - Utilise LCA to assess the sustainability of processes and materials.

ULO1 - Define the basic technological and commercial aspect of the food processing industry. ULO2 - Apply the latest engineering and scientific technology developments in food processing. ULO3 - Critically reflect on the ethical and societal aspects of food processing. ULO4 - Critically reflect the inter-relation between theory and practice in achieving unique innovations for the food industry.

ULO1 - Critically review scientific arguments to identify research questions, discern inductive arguments leading to hypotheses and deductive arguments leading to valid experimental tests. ULO2 - Generate a research proposal by applying the hypothetico-deductive framework to a research problem, formulating a research plan, assessing material and human resources required for the research, and justifying a research budget. ULO3 - Appreciate prevalent sociological perspectives of science and reflect on their consequences for publicly-funded scientific research, such as research quality assessment and metrics. ULO4 - Appreciate the steps involved in developing and commercialising technology and the value of scientific skills in this process.

ULO2 - Critically evaluate and critique new advances and applications for biorefineries from a technical perspective to devise a strategy based on the economic factors, safety considerations and environmental impacts and use them to inform engineering decision-making. ULO3 - Research, analyse and recommend an appropriate biorefining approach for various biomass feedstocks. ULO4 - Review and critique recent biorefinery research literature to systematically synthesise the findings and insights to design a solution to a problem and/or the project. ULO5 - Create and analyse experimental data to produce an accurate and detailed report

ULO1 - Appraise the different types of naturally occurring biopolymers in terms of availability, morphology, composition and functionality to select the most appropriate manufacturing process. ULO1 - Discuss the major trend that construct the periodic table of elements; ULO2 - Interpret relationships between electronic structure and bonding; ULO3 - Apply the theories of thermodynamics, dynamic equilibria and chemical kinetics; ULO4 - Recognise factors which impart polarity molecules; ULO5 - Foster the acquisition of practical skills by exploiting an inquiry-based approach to the chemistry laboratory experience; ULO6 - Communicate chemistry, and discuss the social and environmental responsibility of chemists in the global community.

ULO1 - Demonstrate a basic understanding of chemical nomenclature; ULO2 - Describe the classification, structure and properties of a wide range of organic compounds; ULO3 - Discuss the properties of transition elements; ULO4 - Describe a wide range of coordination compounds and their structures; ULO5 - Employ spectroscopy analysis to investigate molecular structure; ULO6 - Foster practical skills by exploiting an inquiry-based approach to the chemistry laboratory experience; ULO7 - Communicate chemistry, and discuss the social and environmental responsibility of chemists in the global community.

ULO1 - Discuss the major trends that construct the periodic table of elements; ULO2 - Interpret the relationships between electronic structure and bonding; ULO3 - Apply the theories of thermodynamics, dynamic equilibria and chemical kinetics; ULO4 - Recognise factors which impart polarity on molecules; ULO5 - Foster the acquisition of practical skills by exploiting an inquiry-based approach to the chemistry laboratory experience; ULO6 - Formulate hypotheses and design chemical experiments to synthesise and collect unique data using a range of sophisticated apparatus and technologies; ULO7 - Apply recognised methods for interpreting chemical data; ULO8 - Communicate chemistry, and discuss the social and environmental responsibility of chemists in the global community.

ULO1 - Demonstrate a basic understanding of chemical nomenclature; ULO2 - Describe the classification, bonding, structure, properties and reactions of a wide range of organic compounds; ULO3 - Discuss the properties of transition elements; ULO4 - Describe a wide range of coordination compounds and their structures; ULO5 - Apply recognised methods for interpreting chemical data; ULO6 - Formulate hypotheses and design chemical experiments to synthesise and collect unique data using a range of sophisticated apparatus and technologies; ULO7 - Foster the acquisition of practical skills by exploiting an inquiry-based approach to the chemistry laboratory experience; ULO8 - Communicate chemistry, and discuss the social and environmental responsibility of chemists in the global community.

ULO1 - Appreciate the tools used by chemists to design, prepare and study novel carbon based molecules and metal complexes; ULO2 - Apply the general principles of transition metal chemistry to industrial and environmental processes; ULO3 - Formulate the syntheses of a number of compounds using organic or inorganic chemistry processes; ULO4 - Appreciate and utilise a number of organic and inorganic reactions, including processes involving metal ions; ULO5 - Use common synthetic procedures and modern analytical and spectroscopic methods for the synthesis and analysis of chemical compounds; ULO6 - Demonstrate safe laboratory practices and apply OHSE principles; ULO7 - Communicate their chemistry in oral and written form and analyse how the material taught links to the social and environmental responsibility of chemists in the global community.

ULO1 - Comprehend concepts in instrumental analysis, including accuracy and precision, sensitivity, selectivity, detection limit and dynamic range; ULO2 - Describe the principles and applications of spectroscopic techniques such as infra-red, Raman, UV/Visible absorption and fluorescence, and atomic mass spectrometry; ULO3 - Demonstrate knowledge of electrochemical techniques for chemical analysis; ULO4 - Distinguish the need for, and uses of, separation techniques such as gas and liquid chromatography; ULO5 - Evaluate a range of instrumental methods and how different instruments operate; ULO6 - Compare and contrast a number of case studies illustrating the many and varied uses of chemical instrumentation for solving analytical and forensic problems; ULO7 - Use database searching and retrieval for compound identification; ULO8 - Demonstrate expertise in the manipulation of chemicals, the use of chemical analysis techniques, risk assessment and the use of modern information technologies and data analysis; ULO9 - Work in small groups and be competent in the written and oral presentation of scientific data, including in the context of a Moot-court scenario.

ULO1 - Add to their understanding of the chemical reactivity of organic molecules and the relationship between stereochemistry and biological activity; ULO2 - Understand the concept of a transition state in enzyme-catalyzed reactions and the difference between inverting and retaining mechanisms in carbohydrate processing enzymes; ULO3 - Apply the concept of protective groups in organic chemistry for the synthesis of carbohydrates and glycoconjugates; ULO4 - Understand and describe the physical and chemical behaviour of metal ions in aqueous solution, particularly in relation to formation, stability and ligand lability; ULO5 - Understand the role of metals in biology, and the development and application of metal-based therapeutics and diagnostics; ULO6 - Apply an understanding of the use of spectroscopic techniques for determining the structure and function of biomolecules; ULO7 - Understand the different types of bio-imaging techniques and the methods used to process bioimaging data.

ULO1 - Explain the physical and chemical characteristics of aquatic systems; ULO2 - Understand the fundamental physico-chemical processes operating in aquatic systems; ULO3 - Discuss, using appropriate local and international examples, current water pollution issues; ULO4 - Demonstrate proficiency in use of a range of water quality monitoring techniques; ULO5 - Access relevant data for comparative purposes using modern information technologies; ULO6 - Prepare, explain and undertake appropriate OHS Risk Assessments associated with laboratory and fieldwork activities; ULO7 - Prepare laboratory and field trip reports, using appropriate statistical analysis, incorporation of relevant lecture material and additional information from reputable sources.

ULO1 - Explore the chemical structure and functionality for the macronutrient categories of carbohydrates, lipids, and protein in food. ULO2 - Identify the important role of micronutrients (vitamins and minerals) and water activity in food. ULO3 - Formulate the links between food types and dietary energy content. ULO4 - Investigate the analytical techniques used for verifying food content and quality. ULO5 - Inspect the chemical changes that occur during the processing, storage and cooking of food. ULO6 - Design experiments through an inquiry-oriented, food chemistry focused laboratory program. ULO7 - Communicate via written and visual presentations the findings from a multistage laboratory program. ULO8 - Debate the benefits and potential drawbacks of genetic modification, organic agriculture, and the use herbicides and pesticides in global food production.

ULO1 - Demonstrate an ability to locate, synthesize and critically evaluate relevant scientific literature associated with the research project; ULO2 - Prepare, explain and undertake appropriate OHS Risk Assessments associated with laboratory (and if relevant, fieldwork) activities; ULO3 - Demonstrate the ability to work efficiently and safely within a research laboratory environment; ULO4 - Access relevant data for comparative purposes using modern information technologies; ULO5 - Synthesise and present in a format suitable for the discipline, experimental results and data analysis associated with the research project; ULO6 - Present scientific research findings to an appropriate expert audience; ULO7 - Integrate the research findings from the project into the larger context of research in that particular field, primarily through completion of the required report; ULO8 - Demonstrate the capability to learn new technical skills within the research project ambit and use these proficiently and safely.

ULO1 - Identify the link between polymer structure and physical properties; ULO2 - Understand the chemistry of ionic liquids; ULO3 - Demonstrate the connection between properties of conducting, magnetic and porous materials and their inorganic structure; ULO4 - Demonstrate a basic understanding of the theory of X-ray crystallography; ULO5 - Carry out organic and inorganic material synthesis in a laboratory environment; ULO6 - Apply characterisation techniques to both organic and inorganic materials; ULO7 - Demonstrate skills in the use of modern information technologies and data analysis, and in the written and oral presentation of scientific data.

ULO1 - Comprehend the basic concepts of computational chemistry and become proficient in the "hands-on" use of specific computational chemistry software. ULO2 - Develop assessment skills of reliability and accuracy of computational chemistry methods for a chemical problem at hand. ULO3 - Become proficient in the applications of the four laws of thermodynamics. ULO4 - Learn about the connections between kinetics and thermodynamics of chemical reactions. ULO5 - Understand how chemical rate analysis is performed, and analyse the kinetics of advanced chemical processes. ULO6 - Apply key concepts related to the fundamental physical chemistry of solids, liquids and gases. ULO7 - Develop an understanding of phase diagrams and phase behaviour, and how this is related to the interactions between atoms/molecules. ULO8 - Rationalise the key processes that occur at - and differences between - interfaces between solids, liquids and gases. ULO9 - Understand the wetting of solid surfaces, how this controls colloidal systems, and how kinetics of adsorption can be analysed. ULO10 - Explore colloidal systems involving solid particles, liquid droplets and gas bubbles. ULO11 - Rationalise the molecular basis for surfactant behaviour and the uses of surfactant-based systems including liquid crystals.

ULO1 - Identify and operate standard chemical laboratory apparatus to undertake and analyse routine organic transformations; ULO2 - Identify and design strategies that exploit conjugate addition reactions; ULO3 - Understand the rationale behind the design of strategies to assemble complex aromatic materials; ULO4 - Identify and describe common pericyclic reactions; ULO5 - Identify and understand routine transition metal catalysed and organocatalytic chemical reactions.

ULO1 - Understand traditional and modern methods used for drug discovery; ULO2 - Understand how molecules interact at the molecular level and how this relates to the activity of drugs; ULO3 - Demonstrate how crystallography and computational methods are used for drug development; ULO4 - Demonstrate a knowledge of reaction mechanisms and how they can aid in understanding the mode of action of a drug; ULO5 - Demonstrate practical skills through the practice of chemical synthesis in a laboratory; ULO6 - Demonstrate the capacity to work in small research groups, to solve problems and communicate science in both written and oral forms.

ULO1 - Derive the structural chemistry of transition metal complexes using various analytical techniques; ULO2 - Apply knowledge of chemical kinetics and thermodynamics to the stability of transition metal complexes; ULO3 - Describe and undertake the synthesis and characterisation of main group organometallic complexes; ULO4 - Understand and demonstrate the relationship between reactivity, selectivity and structure in main group organometallic complexes; ULO5 - Apply main group organometallic complexes in the asymmetric synthesis of bioactive molecules.

ULO1 - Operate analytical instruments competently and reliably; ULO2 - Understand the range of operational factors that lead to optimised performance of analytical instruments; ULO3 - Assimilate theoretical principles and practical aspects of analytical chemistry; ULO4 - Understand the range of application areas that analytical chemistry and analytical instrumentation are applied to; ULO5 - Appreciate the processes and limitations of different sampling methods.

ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding of the major components and processes in the atmosphere, soils and water; ULO2 - Show awareness of a range of environmental problems; ULO3 - Understand the major options for overcoming environmental problems confronting our planet; ULO4 - Assess environmental problems and design appropriate monitoring programs; ULO5 - Use modern analytical instrumentation; ULO6 - Solve problems in environmental chemistry; ULO7 - Work in small groups and communicate effectively through the written and oral presentation of scientific data.

ULO1 - Explore the social and environmental responsibility of chemists in the global community and debate their significance; ULO2 - Know the principles of green chemistry and green metrics such as atom economy and e-factors to recognise green chemistry criteria in the practice of chemistry; ULO3 - Identify reagents, reaction mechanisms and technologies that should be and realistically could be targeted for replacement by green alternatives; ULO4 - Research examples of successful and recent sustainable chemistry technologies which enable environmental benefits through process changes and product substitution; ULO5 - Explore chemical processes involved in new technologies for the transport, storage and conversion of energy; ULO6 - Apply technical skills for synthesising chemicals, interpreting chemical data, and collecting unique data using a range of sophisticated apparatus and technologies; ULO7 - Communicate the principles of?sustainable chemistry to a broad audience.

ULO1 - Demonstrate knowledge of modern laboratory practices and procedures; ULO2 - Practice an in depth understanding of one or several aspects of modern practical chemistry; ULO3 - Demonstrate safe laboratory practices and apply OHSE principles; ULO4 - Use chemical databases to aid in the design of a project strategy; ULO5 - Analyse data associated with a project and relate this to overall project goals; ULO6 - Present their data and conclusions to the broader chemistry community in both oral and written formats; ULO7 - Analyse how their project links to the social and environmental responsibility of chemists in the global community. ULO8 - Reflect on professional and technical skills development.

ULO1 - Demonstrate knowledge of modern laboratory practices and procedures; ULO2 - Practice an in depth understanding of one or several aspects of modern practical chemistry; ULO3 - Demonstrate safe laboratory practices and apply OHSE principles; ULO4 - Use chemical databases to aid in the design of a project strategy; ULO5 - Analyse data associated with a project and relate this to overall project goals; ULO6 - Present their data and conclusions to the broader chemistry community in both oral and written formats; ULO7 - Analyse how their project links to the social and environmental responsibility of chemists in the global community.

ULO1 - Critically review the scientific literature in their discipline; ULO2 - Understand, discuss and actively participate in the design, development and implementation of a research project; ULO3 - Execute, analyse and evaluate a set of laboratory-based exercises, showing an improved ability to work with minimal supervision and to implement their own ideas; ULO4 - Demonstrate proficiency in computer-based literature searching word processing and other computer programs commonly used in their chosen chemistry discipline; ULO5 - Experience then discuss the breadth and diversity of the chemical sciences, specifically through, but not limited to, attendance at seminars; ULO6 - Demonstrate proficiency in safe work practices for a chemical laboratory, including the use of MSDS and the performance of risk assessments; ULO7 - Synthesise and present in a format suitable for the discipline, experimental results and data analysis associated with the research project; ULO8 - Present orally the scientific research findings to an appropriate expert audience; ULO9 - Integrate the research findings from the project into the larger context of research in that particular field, primarily through completion of the required thesis; ULO10 - Demonstrate the capability to learn new technical skills within the research project ambit and use these proficiently and safely.

ULO1 - Develop a realistic experimental plan, including a timeline, for the research project undertaken in CHM4100; ULO2 - Appreciate and outline the key principles in Intellectual Property as it relates to the discipline and the CHM4100 research project; ULO3 - Use and critically evaluate the extant OHS software; ULO4 - Efficiently and competently use appropriate bibliographic software (eg. EndNote); ULO5 - Explain the operation of, and where relevant and appropriate, competently use, the equipment discussed in the workshops component of this course; ULO6 - Demonstrate an appropriate high level of understanding of the material presented in the selected lecture modules - this understanding is demonstrated through the relevant assessment tasks.

ULO1 - Develop a realistic experimental plan, including a timeline, for the research project undertaken in CHM4180; ULO2 - Appreciate and outline the key principles in Intellectual Property as it relates to the discipline and the CHM4180 research project; ULO3 - Efficiently and competently use appropriate bibliographic software (eg. EndNote); ULO4 - Explain the operation of, and where relevant and appropriate, competently use, the equipment discussed in the workshops component of this course; ULO5 - Demonstrate an appropriate high level of understanding of the material presented in the selected lecture modules - this understanding is demonstrated through the relevant assessment tasks.

ULO1 - Analyse structural behaviour (calculating reactions and bending moment diagrams and deflected shapes) of simple determinate and indeterminate beam and frame systems using qualitative and quantitative methods. ULO2 - Identify and determine elastic normal stresses, shearing stresses and shear flow in simple structures as a result of external (including thermal) loading producing internal actions of axial force, bending, torsion and shear. ULO3 - Determine the partial plastic and fully plastic section moment capacities of both symmetrical and asymmetrical steel sections. ULO4 - Determine deflections in linearly elastic determinate systems. ULO5 - Determine stresses and strains (and their relationship) in two dimensions utilising the concepts of principal stress and Mohr's circle, and select and use appropriate failure theories for engineering materials. ULO6 - Formulate technical reports and communicate effectively in team assignments, interpreting and analysing experimental data, utilising basic analysis software packages and relating results to the theory taught.

UNIT_TITLE: Design of steel and timber structures
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Determine dead and live loading on a building structure. ULO2 - Construct a model steel structure and predict its capacity in a team environment. ULO3 - Describe the properties of steel sections relevant to engineering design for strength. ULO4 - Determine steel and timber members considering strength and serviceability needs. ULO5 - Determine steel and timber joints for strength requirements. ULO6 - Identify issues related to timber durability following industry practice.

ULO1 - Describe types of cements, aggregates, and admixtures in concrete and their effect on the properties of fresh and hardened concrete. ULO2 - Design concrete mixes for various applications. ULO3 - Describe the properties and behaviour of structural steel under thermo-mechanical loading. ULO4 - Describe the properties and behaviour of timber for structural design, including durability. ULO5 - Describe the properties and behaviour of unreinforced masonry for structural design. ULO6 - Describe the main loads and load combinations relevant to structural design. ULO7 - Explore the structural behaviour of material specimens and communicate findings through team-based reporting.

ULO1 - Use knowledge of basic engineering geology in designing civil infrastructure on soils/rocks ULO2 - Plan and interpret results of geotechnical site investigations ULO3 - Classify soils and rocks including mineralogical compositions ULO4 - Identify different phases in soils and determine their densities, void ratios, porosities ULO5 - Determine total, effective and pore water pressures in soils/rocks including implications of loading on drainage behaviour of soils/rocks ULO6 - Identify and determine appropriate shear strength parameters of soils/rocks for engineering design ULO7 - Estimate incremental stresses in soils/rocks due to applied loads ULO8 - Use knowledge of soils/rocks in designing simple foundations

ULO1 - Apply fundamental principles to physical problems involving fluids in hydrostatic and dynamic conditions. ULO2 - Analyse fluid flow in closed and open conduits. ULO3 - Record and discuss findings from laboratory experiments.

ULO1 - Familiarity with the basic parameters and theories of traffic flow ULO2 - Knowledge of the role that advanced technology is playing, and will play, in the transport/traffic area ULO3 - Awareness of the importance of both safety and congestion reduction objectives as crucial design considerations in the transport/traffic field ULO4 - Appreciation of the relationship of transport/traffic engineering to the profession of civil engineering ULO5 - Ability to design, undertake and analyse traffic surveys ULO6 - Ability to apply basic traffic flow theory to the analysis of unsignalised intersection capacity ULO7 - Ability to design timing plans for isolated traffic signals ULO8 - Ability to work effectively in a team as a leader and/or a member ULO9 - Oral, written and drawing communication skills

ULO1 - Determine general civil road and bridge construction methodology sequencing including the selection of appropriate plant and material and analysis of crane load charts. ULO2 - Determine an appropriate civil construction cost estimate for a specific project through the identification of appropriate work activities and calculation of relevant productivities, quantities and rates. ULO3 - Construct a project schedule in Microsoft Project for a given construction project by applying principles around work breakdown structure and relevant productivities. ULO4 - Construct a Safe Work Method Statement (SWMS), Aspects and Impacts Register, Environmental Management plan and Quality Inspection Test plan; analyse and justify relevant hazards, risks and controls, and comply with relevant specifications. ULO5 - Analyse and justify the selection of a preferred subcontractor from the evaluation of two supplied quotes; formulate an appropriate letter of acceptance and contract documents for the recommended tenderer; execute contract management administration controls to mitigate dispute resolution with other parties. ULO6 - Appraise the use of HSQE and construction management systems in different working contexts and reflect on controls to minimise risks.

ULO1 - Apply statistical theory to problems frequently encountered by civil engineers. ULO2 - Analyse and interpret large data sets and present the summary. ULO3 - Design and conduct experiments using statistical methods. ULO4 - Formulate hypotheses and test them to come to a conclusion. ULO5 - Predict random processes through time series analysis.

ULO1 - Describe and apply the limit state design philosophy to calculate loads appropriate to each limit state. ULO2 - Determine the global structural behaviour of building frames, identifying the role of each component. ULO3 - Analyse structural behaviour using a combination of computer and hand analysis approaches. ULO4 - Design the members and connections for composite floor steel-framed building structures. ULO5 - Generate a high-quality technical report as part of a group to summarise the design of a building structure.

ULO1 - Determine soil consolidation time and associated settlements. ULO2 - Discern shear strength of soils and rocks. ULO3 - Analyse advanced soil strength testing and stress paths results considering drained and undrained behaviour. ULO4 - Apply various soil models to analyse soil/rock behaviour. ULO5 - Analyse stability of soil and rock slopes. ULO6 - Apply earth pressure theories to design basic retaining walls.

ULO1 - Give an engineering classification of soils, and on this basis predict how it will perform as an engineering lining material for waste containment facilities ULO2 - Calculate quantities of water flowing through the ground, and understand the effects that water flow has on the soil ULO3 - Identify the common situations when the soil becomes a factor in an engineering problem ULO4 - Explain the advantages and limitations of the different methods of seepage calculation ULO5 - Characterise contaminant migration through porous media ULO6 - Provide solutions to seepage problems based on the use of geosynthetics ULO7 - Use numerical and analytical procedures to analyse a geoenvironmental design problem

UNIT_TITLE: Design of concrete and masonry structures
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify types of cements, aggregates, and admixtures in concrete. ULO2 - Describe the properties of fresh and hardened concrete. ULO3 - Describe and decide concrete specifications. ULO4 - Design concrete mix and assess concrete mix proportions for various applications. ULO5 - Analyse loads and their representation on structures. ULO6 - Design reinforced concrete and masonry structures using relevant Australian Standards.

ULO1 - Undertake hydrological investigations of natural and urban catchments. ULO2 - Estimate floods for engineering design and planning. ULO3 - Conceptually design and estimate flows of a minor drainage network. ULO4 - Design gutters, swales, and pits. ULO5 - Produce technical reports developed by teams at the standard required by the engineering profession.

ULO1 - Determine the dead, live, and wind loads on a building structure, and the relevant load combinations. ULO2 - Analyse building structures for the load effects relevant for structural element design. ULO3 - Explore and predict the behaviour of physical specimens of steel and concrete elements. ULO4 - Design steel, concrete, timber, and masonry structural elements to the relevant Australian Standards. ULO5 - Communicate engineering designs through calculation, drawings, and reports as part of a team.

ULO1 - Describe the overall architecture of an autonomous vehicle (AV) system. ULO2 - Apply learned concepts to design algorithms for different functionalities of the AV system, such as localisation, perception, planning and control. ULO3 - Integrate and evaluate the AV system including testing and validation of algorithms and decision-making of the system. ULO4 - Critically appraise the different aspects of the AV system and its interactions in the urban networks. ULO5 - Effectively communicate findings, insights or professional recommendations to specialist and/or non-specialist audiences.

ULO1 - Conduct research on topics related to civil engineering within a given timeline ULO2 - Develop a sound research plan based on available scientific tools relevant to the project ULO3 - Undertake an extensive review of relevant literature ULO4 - Communicate to a professional audience via poster medium ULO5 - Analyse data and prepare i) a written progress report if taken with CIV4211 or ii) a written research paper and oral presentation if taken alone

ULO1 - Conduct research on topics related to civil engineering within a given timeline ULO2 - Develop a sound research plan based on available scientific tools relevant to the project ULO3 - Undertake an extensive review of relevant literature ULO4 - Analyse data and prepare a written research paper of high quality ULO5 - Communicate findings to a professional audience via oral presentation

ULO1 - Appraise a multidisciplinary engineering project brief as part of a design team. ULO2 - Generate concept designs that meet multidisciplinary criteria as part of a team. ULO3 - Design components of a multi-disciplinary engineering project. ULO4 - Construct construction-standard details and drawings of the design. ULO5 - Generate oral, written and visual communication skills suitable for professional practice.

ULO1 - Apply the stiffness method of matrix structural analysis. ULO2 - Apply the coordinate transformation method for matrix structural analysis. ULO3 - Identify the theoretical basis of finite element methods such as discretisation process, element formation, shape functions and Gaussian integration. ULO4 - Discern simple elements in the finite element method. ULO5 - Construct the framework of the finite element method. ULO6 - Generate high quality reports for assessing the behaviour of a multi-storey building under static, thermal and dynamic loading using a finite element computer package.

ULO1 - Generate team-work reports on the analysis/design of concrete slabs and steel frames using laboratory results and theoretical analysis. ULO4 - Design and analyse the steel reinforced concrete structures using the strut-and-tie model method. ULO5 - Describe the ultimate behaviour of basic structures and materials with reference to the theorems of plasticity. ULO6 - Determine the plastic collapse load of beams and simple frames using both hand- and computer-based methods.

ULO1 - Perform basic analytical procedures related to stability. ULO2 - Understand the importance of ethics and legal matters for geotechnical and geoenvironmental projects. ULO3 - Gain insight into the importance of minimising the likelihood of failures. ULO4 - Understand the concept of ground improvement. ULO5 - Provide solutions to ground improvement based on sound analytical methods.

ULO1 - Assess geotechnical investigation carried out for a civil infrastructure development project. ULO2 - Generate geological models for a development site based on the geotechnical investigation data. ULO3 - Predict design parameters for materials of interest from the geotechnical investigation results and existing correlations. ULO4 - Design shallow foundations on complex ground profiles using site specific material properties and satisfying limit states requirements. ULO5 - Design pile foundations for complex loads and ground conditions based on limit state and serviceability requirements. ULO6 - Generate quality reports for geotechnical investigation and design outputs.

ULO1 - Understand the components that make up the urban water cycle and urban water systems ULO2 - Understand the interactions between urban water cycle components and appreciate the complexities and conflicts involved in integrated management of urban water systems ULO3 - Understand the principles of, and methods for, integrated urban water management? ULO4 - Understand the basic ecological and social science perspectives of IUWM and the need for a multi-disciplinary perspective ULO5 - Develop and design IUWM strategies at a conceptual level ULO6 - Use software packages, such as MUSIC and Aquacycle, for IUWM design and assessment

ULO1 - Describe the major elements of the catchment water balance/cycle and the relationship with land-use and climate ULO2 - Appraise water quantity and quality by applying statistical methods and fundamental principles of water quantity and quality modelling ULO3 - Assess the demand for water, water availability and reliability of supply ULO4 - Design water quantity and quality management options according to environmental and society requirements ULO5 - Reflect the potential impacts of climate change on water resources management ULO6 - Generate technical reports at the standard required by the engineering profession

ULO1 - Formulate a conceptual design for a bridge considering various types of bridges, their components, and methods of construction. ULO1 - Describe advanced contemporary traffic flow theories and apply to solve practical traffic problems ULO2 - Perform traffic data analysis methodologically ULO3 - Apply analytical techniques in the design and operation of traffic systems ULO4 - Evaluate the role of Intelligent Transport Systems in Dynamic Traffic Management

ULO1 - Justify the relevance of quantitative data analysis skills for contemporary transport and traffic practice, ULO2 - Estimate and appraise suitable probabilistic models for transport and traffic problems, ULO3 - Infer the characteristics of a population based on a sample of that population drawing on appropriate statistical techniques, and ULO4 - Estimate and evaluate the robustness of statistical models for understanding current, or predicting/forecasting future, travel/traffic conditions.

ULO1 - Develop an understanding of the selected area/topic, ULO2 - Develop report writing and oral presentation skills , ULO3 - Strengthen ability to communicate information about a topic to readers/listeners who may have a limited background in the area, and ULO4 - Become aware of the importance of critical analysis of published material ULO5 - Develop capacity to provide effective peer feedback.

ULO1 - Design traffic and transport data collection initiatives with due consideration to manual and automatic data collection options.
