UNIT_TITLE: Intelligent transportation systems: engineering and management
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the role of the road system and the associated role of advanced technology or intelligent transport systems (ITS), in providing mobility and accessibility for the community ULO2 - Consider the needs of different road users (pedestrians and bicyclists, private motor vehicles, trucks and road-based public transport vehicles) and their interactions in the road system ULO3 - Design a traffic and road network heirarchy and the associated parking system to cater to the needs of different road users ULO4 - Differentiate the functional areas of ITS, the associated ITS applications in those functional areas and the component technologies which underlie those applications ULO5 - Appraise the technology building blocks employed by ITS and evaluate the ITS applications developed from them ULO6 - Critique information on ITS obtained from the world wide web ULO7 - Judge the need to manage the road system and critique the role of advanced technology in addressing broader transportation issues and challenges ULO8 - Demonstrate sound written and oral communication skills

ULO1 - critique the framework within which transport planning is conducted and the foundations upon which transport policy is formulated ULO2 - appraise the range of supply and demand-oriented solutions which can be used to address transport and associated environmental problems within a sustainability context ULO3 - judge the suitability of alternative methodologies for conducting transport surveys ULO4 - critique transport surveys on the basis of their sample design, questionnaire design and survey administration ULO5 - analyse contemporary issues in transportation planning and policy and assess the suitability of different policy options. ULO6 - demonstrate effective written and oral communication skills.

ULO1 - Critique the framework within which public transportation planning and management is conducted and the foundations of public transportation policy. ULO2 - Distinguish the nature and trends of urban public transportation markets, and the sensitivity of these markets to both external influences and public transportation service changes. ULO3 - Compare the performance, impacts and costs of various public transportation systems, services and modes and consider the factors influencing improvements to these systems. ULO4 - Design and critique demand and operational analyses in public transportation. ULO5 - Assess contemporary issues in public transportation through consideration of different policy perspectives. ULO6 - Demonstrate effective written and oral communications skills.

ULO1 - Assess the fundamental principles of risk management and relations to infrastructure projects. ULO2 - Analyse how risk management is enacted in diverse project contexts ULO3 - Synthesise risk management processes to undertake comprehensive risk analyses. ULO4 - Justify the determination of project risk. ULO5 - Communicate risk management outcomes to project stakeholders.

ULO1 - differentiate the component models used in transportation network modelling ULO2 - appraise various transport models to assess their strengths, weaknesses and suitability for particular modelling tasks ULO3 - formulate, calibrate, apply and interpret a range of transportation models ULO4 - justify the role of analytic modelling in transportation planning and traffic engineering.

ULO1 - Apply the knowledge of green materials and technology to the solution of complex problems involving buildings and structures. ULO2 - Relate the knowledge of physics and chemistry to green building concepts. ULO3 - Compute and assess the components of the Malaysian Green Building Index (GBI) and relate this to similar indices around the world. ULO4 - Conduct the necessary calculations for the assessment of sustainability measurements in green buildings.

ULO1 - Describe the fundamentals of subsurface flow and transport. ULO2 - Design hydraulic tests to obtain basic aquifer parameters. ULO3 - Derive analytical solutions for ground water flow and contaminant transport problems. ULO4 - Model ground water flow, solute transport and variable density flow numerically. ULO5 - Conduct model calibration, parameter estimation and sensitivity analysis. ULO6 - Work both independently and collaboratively on complex ground water problems.

ULO1 - Run operational hydrologic models. ULO2 - Parameterize models. ULO3 - Undertake flood frequency analysis. ULO4 - Analyse digital terrain models and outlines catchments. ULO5 - Understand hydraulics and apply hydraulic models. ULO6 - Understand runoff routing and apply operational routing models. ULO7 - Understand and apply state updating techniques. ULO8 - Work both independently and collaboratively on flood management problems.

ULO1 - compile time series data on precipitation and evapotranspiration ULO2 - model water flow processes in the unsaturated zone ULO3 - understand the process that control runoff and stream flow ULO4 - develop a conceptual hydrological model ULO5 - apply hydrological models to real-world problems ULO6 - work both independently and collaboratively on complex surface water problems.

ULO1 - Apply strategic planning principles for stormwater management. ULO2 - Operate within existing legislation in the development of urban drainage designs. ULO3 - Develop urban drainage designs, which employ best management practice principles in selection and operation of individual components. ULO4 - Select and design treatment sequences that provide acceptable outflows to receiving water. ULO5 - Work both independently and collaboratively on complex urban stormwater problems.

ULO1 - Calculate the dynamics structural response to various excitation types. ULO2 - Propose design solutions to mitigate vibration responses to acceptable limits. ULO3 - Explain, derive and use earthquake response spectra. ULO4 - Calculate ground-borne vibration levels from various sources and propose mitigation solutions. ULO5 - Use computer software to analyse dynamic effects and know the limitations of the numerical procedures used. ULO6 - Propose suitable instrumentation, and perform experimental tests, synthesizing the results.

ULO1 - Determine the properties of geomaterials and structural components relevant for the assessment of interaction. ULO2 - Assess the structural and geomechanical components available to address the expected interaction. ULO3 - Determine the interaction between structural and geomaterials using computational and analytical methods. ULO4 - Design appropriate solutions for infrastructure systems by incorporating governing interactions. ULO5 - Describe the limitations of developed solutions and prepare a formal report.

ULO1 - Assess the condition of existing infrastructure and noting the commonly observed problems. ULO2 - Design and interpret a smart monitoring strategy to assess the condition of ageing infrastructure. ULO3 - Describe and apply appropriate rehabilitation techniques for common infrastructure systems. ULO4 - Predict the remaining life of an infrastructure system, given condition assessments and monitoring results.

ULO1 - Explain the theoretical basis behind finite element and meshless methods. ULO2 - Select suitable constitutive models for different material types. ULO3 - Apply finite element and meshless methods to practical problems in structural, soil and rock mechanics. ULO4 - Present, explain, and interpret the results of a computational analysis to specialist and non-specialist audiences. ULO5 - Explain the suitable techniques for the management and visualisation of large quantities of data, typical of infrastructure systems.

ULO1 - Critically evaluate the selected area/topic and develop feasible project proposals. ULO2 - Demonstrate report writing and presentation skills. ULO3 - Demonstrate the ability to communicate information about a topic to readers/listeners who may have a limited background in the area. ULO4 - Conduct research and critical analysis on published material. ULO5 - Reflect and provide effective peer-to-peer feedback.

ULO1 - describe what innovation is and why innovation is important to the construction industry ULO2 - demonstrate an understanding of recent successful innovations in building and infrastructure sectors ULO3 - reflect on the enablers and barriers to innovation adoption from the perspectives of government, client, leadership and employee ULO4 - assess the benefits and limitations of innovative technologies and tools, such as BIM, laser scanning, UAS and VR/AR ULO5 - demonstrate the application of BIM tools and the BIM workflow for planning, construction and operation tasks in infrastructure projects ULO6 - critically reflect on professional practices to assess the pros and cons of technological innovations.

ULO1 - Investigate ground conditions based on various in-situ geotechnical measurements ULO2 - Determine physical and mechanical properties of soil and rock materials that can be used in geotechnical analysis and design ULO3 - Determine ground movements and settlements associated with various geotechnical structures in and on grounds ULO4 - Design and analyse geotechnical structures by computational and analytical methods design geotechnical structures by industry standards and codes of practice

ULO1 - Know features of different equipment and machinery used in geotechnical construction ULO2 - Understand construction contractual issues and procedures ULO3 - Acquire construction management skill including project planning and risk assessment ULO4 - Develop schemes for various geotechnical construction projects execute performance monitoring and appraisal of geotechnical structures

ULO1 - Appraise and apply the limit state design philosophy to calculate loads appropriate to each?limit state. ULO2 - Determine the global structural behaviour of building frames, identifying the role of each?component. ULO3 - Analyse structural behaviour using a combination of computer and hand analysis?approaches. ULO4 - Design the members and connections for composite floor steel-framed building structures. ULO5 - Communicate professional decisions to specialist and/or non-specialist audiences.

ULO1 - Apply the stiffness method of matrix structural analysis. ULO2 - Apply the coordinate transformation method for matrix structural analysis. ULO3 - Appraise the theoretical basis of finite element methods such as discretisation process,?element formation, shape functions and Gaussian integration. ULO4 - Discern simple elements in the finite element method. ULO5 - Draw on the framework of the finite element method. ULO6 - Communicate professional decisions to specialist and/or non-specialist audiences.

ULO1 - Identify the collapse mechanisms of reinforced concrete slabs and steel frames. ULO2 - Design and analyse plastically reinforced concrete slabs using Hillerborg method and yield?line theory. ULO3 - Design and analyse the steel-reinforced concrete structures using the strut-and-tie model?method. ULO4 - Appraise the ultimate behaviour of basic structures and materials with reference to the?theorems of plasticity. ULO5 - Assess the plastic collapse load of beams and simple frames using both hand- and?computer-based methods. ULO6 - Communicate professional decisions to specialist and/or non-specialist audiences.

ULO1 - Determine soil consolidation time and associated settlements. ULO2 - Appraise the shear strength of soils and rocks. ULO3 - Analyse advanced soil strength testing and stress paths results considering drained and?undrained behaviour. ULO4 - Draw on various soil models to analyse soil/rock behaviour. ULO5 - Analyse stability of soil and rock slopes. ULO6 - Draw on earth pressure theories to design basic retaining walls. ULO7 - Communicate professional decisions to specialist and/or non-specialist audiences.

ULO1 - Draw on analytical procedures to determine stability. ULO2 - Reflect on the importance of ethics and legal matters for geotechnical and?geoenvironmental projects. ULO3 - Prioritise the minimisation of the likelihood of failures. ULO4 - Draw on the concept of ground improvement. ULO5 - Design ground improvements using sound analytical methods. ULO6 - Communicate professional decisions to specialist and/or non-specialist audiences.

ULO1 - Assess geotechnical investigation carried out for a civil infrastructure development project. ULO2 - Generate geological models for a development site based on the geotechnical investigation?data. ULO3 - Predict design parameters for materials of interest from the geotechnical investigation results and existing correlations. ULO4 - Draw on site-specific material properties to design shallow foundations on complex ground?profiles satisfying limit states requirements. ULO5 - Design pile foundations for complex loads and ground conditions based on limit state and?serviceability requirements. ULO6 - Communicate professional decisions to specialist and/or non-specialist audiences.

ULO1 - Formulate a conceptual design for a bridge considering various types of bridges, their?components, and methods of construction. ULO2 - Identify and calculate the loads to which a bridge is subjected, according to first principles?and relevant codes of practice. ULO3 - Determine the structural behaviour of various bridge types quantitatively and qualitatively using?relevant hand- and computer-based methods. ULO4 - Design prestressed concrete beams for service and strength requirements. ULO5 - Assess the reliability basis for limit state design and its use in bridge assessment, including descriptions of the basic variables. ULO6 - Appraise bridge inspection and management procedures, including levels of assessment and?condition rating approaches. ULO7 - Work effectively in a bridge design team and communicate professional decisions to?specialist and/or non-specialist audiences.

ULO1 - Design road geometry with due consideration to horizontal and vertical alignment, cross-section?profile, earthworks and cost implications. ULO2 - Assess different components of a road project, within the context of a safe systems?approach to design, based on economic, social and environmental considerations. ULO3 - Design flexible and rigid road pavements giving consideration to economic, social and?environmental factors. ULO4 - Communicate professional decisions to specialist and/or non-specialist audiences.

ULO1 - Interpret components of the water treatment chain and explain the chemical processes for?water hardness removal. ULO2 - Design the various components of active and passive wastewater treatment plants. ULO3 - Determine potential quantities of recycled wastewater and recovered biosolids based on?designs of secondary wastewater treatment plants. ULO4 - Assess the components of advanced secondary wastewater treatment and energy recovery?processes and explain the biological processes for the anaerobic treatment of sludge. ULO5 - Decide between various wastewater treatment systems for differing problems given space,?economic, and environmental constraints. ULO6 - Communicate professional decisions to specialist and/or non-specialist audiences.

ULO1 - Describe advanced contemporary traffic flow theories and apply to solve practical traffic problems ULO2 - Perform traffic data analysis methodologically ULO3 - Apply analytical technques in the design and operation of traffic systems ULO4 - Evaluate the role of Intelligent Transport Systems in Dynamic Traffic Management

ULO1 - describe and critique the principles and practice of traffic management ULO2 - design and conduct an assessment of a local traffic network ULO3 - demonstrate skills in the critical assessment of alternative solutions and trade-offs in the traffic system ULO4 - discuss the role of the community and stakeholders in contemporary traffic management ULO5 - critically reflect on contemporary issues and challenges in transport management ULO6 - interpret collected and pre-existing traffic survey data.

ULO1 - appraise the framework used to undertake urban transport planning and its capacity to deliver sustainable transport outcomes ULO2 - discuss the factors influencing the level, pattern and trends in travel demand ULO3 - appraise the characteristics of a range of passenger and freight modes ULO4 - assess the potential impacts of policy options designed to enhance urban transport systems

ULO1 - Critically review scientific arguments to identify research questions, discern inductive arguments leading to hypotheses and deductive arguments leading to valid experimental tests. ULO2 - Generate a research proposal by applying the hypothetico-deductive framework to a research problem, formulating a research plan, assessing material and human resources required for the research, justifying a research budget. ULO3 - Appreciate prevalent sociological perspectives of science and reflect on their consequences for publicly-funded scientific research, such as research quality assessment and metrics. ULO4 - Appreciate the steps involved in developing and commercialising technology and the value of scientific skills in this process.

ULO4 - develop a conceptual hydrological model. ULO5 - apply hydrological models to real-world problems. ULO6 - work both independently and collaboratively on complex surface water problems.

ULO4 - Select and design treatment sequences that provide acceptable outflows to receiving water. ULO5 - Work both independently and collaboratively on complex urban stormwater problems.

UNIT_TITLE: The context for mental health practice
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify major contextual influences on mental health service delivery in Australia ULO2 - Demonstrate a knowledge of the major components of the community-based framework of mental health services in Australia ULO3 - Integrate their knowledge of policy frameworks and epidemiology with the design of service systems in mental health services ULO4 - Demonstrate a knowledge of the range of perspectives of stakeholders actively engaged in mental health care delivery ULO5 - Identify the special needs of people from an indigenous and culturally diverse backgrounds ULO6 - Critically appraise the reform of mental health service delivery in Australia through the case study of Victoria.

ULO4 - Be able to describe various mental health care systems and models of service. ULO5 - Be able to integrate all concepts in the mental health practice with the systems and model of service delivery.

That accounts for the indications or contra-indications for child psychotherapy and other treatment options.

ULO5 - Identify and appraise the importance of termination - the process of bringing the therapy to a conclusion; and ULO6 - Determine the impact of working with the disturbed child including the disturbed child in special situations and advance an ?understanding of the child and the therapeutic process.

UNIT_TITLE: Early human development from cells to tissues
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the diverse structures of eukaryotic cells; ULO2 - Explain how cells and extracellular matrix are arranged in primary tissues; ULO3 - Outline the key features and stages of early human and animal development; ULO4 - Identify specialised cell types, primary tissues and the cellular processes that produce diverse tissues; ULO5 - Explain the origin of major tissue types and how stem cells contribute to tissue renewal; ULO6 - Outline strategies to experimentally analyse gene and tissue function; ULO7 - Demonstrate an ability to research published scientific literature and effectively communicate their findings either orally or in writing.

UNIT_TITLE: Human anatomy and development: Tissues and body systems
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the basic anatomical structure of the human body and some of the major body systems; ULO2 - Describe the microscopic structure of the human body and how the primary tissue types combine to form a complete organism; ULO3 - Explain how the general body plan is established in the embryo, and the processes of organogenesis and how major congenital abnormalities arise; ULO4 - Demonstrate practical laboratory skills in anatomy & developmental biology; ULO5 - Collaborate effectively as a pair or in a group to complete academic tasks; ULO6 - Discuss and critically analyse anatomical and developmental biology studies.

ULO1 - Describe the molecular and cellular mechanisms that regulate animal development; ULO2 - Outline the strategies used to study mechanisms of development; ULO3 - Compare and contrast different developmental model systems; ULO4 - Demonstrate practical laboratory skills integral to the study of developmental biology including obtaining, documenting and interpreting data; ULO5 - Discuss and critically analyse developmental biology research papers; ULO6 - Collaborate effectively as a pair or in a group to complete academic tasks; ULO7 - Demonstrate effective communication by oral, visual and written means.

UNIT_TITLE: Developmental and anatomical basis of human health and disease
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the basic anatomy and development of the major organs and organ systems; ULO2 - Analyse the genetic and environmental regulation of organogenesis in the major organ systems; ULO3 - Explain how errors or perturbations in genetic and/or environmental regulation of development can lead to birth defects and outline how suboptimal development can result in or predispose to adult chronic disease; ULO4 - Relate the relative contributions of endoderm, mesoderm and ectoderm in the formation of the tissues and organs of the adult body; ULO5 - Demonstrate familiarity with experimental strategies and techniques used to identify and study organogenesis and the regulation of organogenesis; ULO6 - Demonstrate an ability to interpret, discuss and present studies in anatomy and developmental biology research.

UNIT_TITLE: Stem cells and the foundations of life
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the basic biology of embryonic and induced pluripotential stem cells; ULO2 - Describe the basic biology of newborn, adult and tissue-specific stem cells and the status of research into their characterisation and role in health and disease; ULO3 - Explain current and potential future applications of stem cell therapies for the regeneration of diseased organs and how stem cells can be combined with factors and materials and nanotechnology to engineer replacement tissues; ULO4 - Demonstrate practical laboratory skills and interpretation of scientific data in contemporary reproductive biology and/or stem cell research; ULO5 - Discuss controversies surrounding the commercialisation and ethics of stem cell research and advances and requirements for clinical treatments; ULO6 - Demonstrate critical and independent thinking in the synthesis of research reports and scientific presentation.

UNIT_TITLE: Action in anatomy and developmental biology research project
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Undertake a research project with regard to ethical and safety regulations; ULO2 - Demonstrate technical skills in experimental methods and the ability to collect, analyse and interpret data using methods relevant to the discipline of Anatomy and Developmental biology; ULO3 - Communicate appropriately and effectively with supervisors, laboratory staff and students; ULO4 - Maintain accurate and up-to-date records of experimental procedures, results and outcomes; ULO5 - Identify relevant published scientific literature and critically analyse and evaluate the content in the context of the discipline Anatomy and Developmental biology; ULO6 - Construct written reports.
