UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Undertake a major project with effective resolution of technical detail at a level sufficient to brief specialists; ULO2 - Develop a brief; analyse client and user requirements; research and resolve technical requirements; specify materials, finishes; and construction concepts; ULO3 - Communicate and present the project design to client and constructors; ULO4 - Explain analytically the cultural sources of the inspiration for the design; ULO5 - Express persuasively the aesthetic and symbolic values embedded in the design; ULO6 - Relate the design to historical and contemporary precedents, not only for the sake of explaining its technical and cultural virtues but for potential refinements and the development of vision in your future career; ULO7 - Observe and employ occupational health and safety practices appropriate to studio practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Engage with practice-based processes to coordinate project outcomes from initial research and concept development to final resolution and evaluation; ULO2 - Apply an appropriate range of discipline knowledge and interdisciplinary processes to generate prototype solutions to complex problems; ULO3 - Exercise judgment involving a combination of creative, design led, critically informed and self-reflective considerations as part of an iterative process of producing new or novel understandings, interpretations and applications; ULO4 - Apply design processes and methods with an open attitude to inquiry and experimentation; ULO5 - Apply strategic and cognitive knowledge, problem-solving and communication skills that demonstrate capacity to generate, plan, produce, and critique a self-directed project; ULO6 - Plan and produce a project to a high standard with a degree of independence, originality, accountability and (if relevant) collaboration with other parties and stakeholders; ULO7 - Communicate in a manner that is effective for the stated purpose, intended audience and designated context of the project; ULO8 - Understand and apply the occupational health and safety requirements appropriate to the discipline practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify ways design contributes critically, ethically and responsibly to the preservation and promotion of culture and heritage in the Galleries, Libraries, Archives and Museums (GLAM) sector; ULO2 - Identify, conceive and create design solutions for communicating tangible and intangible cultural heritage, with consideration to collaboration and inter-disciplinary processes; ULO3 - Apply investigative methods and conceptual, visualisation and prototyping skills as part of the design process involved in culture and heritage interpretation; ULO4 - Produce design prototypes or other creative outcomes in response to directed briefs related to museum work, exhibition-making and cultural heritage practices; ULO5 - Understand and apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the discipline.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand advanced aspects of design research; ULO2 - Critically analyse and evaluate dimensions of design (as cultural practice, studio research, applied research); ULO3 - Apply advanced methods and strategies involved in practice-based design research (including disciplinary, interdisciplinary, transdisciplinary); ULO4 - Apply designerly processes that result in the creation and communication of design research outcomes; ULO5 - Plan and produce a project with a high degree of independence, originality, accountability and (if relevant) collaboration with other parties and stakeholders; ULO6 - Communicate in an effective manner for the stated purpose, intended audience and designated context of the project; ULO7 - Understand and apply the occupational health and safety requirements appropriate to the discipline practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Evaluate and communicate the potential of design as a means for preserving and promoting culture and heritage; ULO2 - Propose and present ethical and responsible design concepts specific to culture and heritage; ULO3 - Understand the significance of collaboration as part of inter-disciplinary teamwork in co-creating complex design solutions for communicating and promoting culture and heritage; ULO4 - Demonstrate ethnographic research methods as part of the design process for culture and heritage productions; ULO5 - Demonstrate conceptualising, visualising and prototyping skills for complex design solutions in the area of culture and heritage; ULO6 - Critically analyse and evaluate cultural/heritage design productions or prototypes as a response to a specific brief; ULO7 - Understand and apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the unit.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Evaluate and communicate the potential of design as an agent for social change; ULO2 - Propose and present ethical and responsible design concepts; ULO3 - Understand the significance of collaboration as part of inter-disciplinary teamwork in co-creating complex design solutions for social enterprise or innovation; ULO4 - Demonstrate ethnographic research approaches as part of the design process for social enterprise or innovation; ULO5 - Demonstrate skills for visualising and prototyping complex design solutions in the area of social design; ULO6 - Critically analyse and evaluate the social impact of design solutions; ULO7 - Understand and apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the unit.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: Digital processes for art and design 1
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate a basic practical and critical understanding of digital imaging and its links with other media; ULO2 - Access the Faculty computing resources, including access facilities with a clear understanding of appropriate health and safety studio procedures and implement these procedures within your work practice; ULO3 - Competently operate a computer, familiarising yourself with operation system basics and file management; ULO4 - Use peripheral devices (ie. scanners, printers) to acquire, compose and output images; ULO5 - Use image editing software to skilfully create, adapt, edit, manipulate and compose images; ULO6 - Apply digital imaging techniques towards the realisation of conceptualised, communicative works; ULO7 - Demonstrate the foundation necessary to undertake further units in digital imaging with a view towards either specialisation or application of the media within other studio disciplines.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Prepare multimedia documents suited to online delivery; ULO2 - Identify the different technologies for web design, including mark-up languages, interactive multimedia formats, video/sound streaming, and database systems; ULO3 - Understand web page construction and principles, file and site management, and web design for accessibility and usability; ULO4 - Use text, images, animation, sound and digital video as multimedia elements in electronic documents; ULO5 - Demonstrate familiarity with colour mode and resolution requirements for a range of electronic media; ULO6 - Demonstrate awareness of a variety of file formats, and be able to optimise a media file for a particular application; ULO7 - Understand the role of web design in multimedia.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Skillfully and insightfully create, edit, manipulate, compose and output digital images; ULO2 - Explore the range of options and controls available through vector and pixel-based software applications and use peripheral devices with increasing confidence and proficiency; ULO3 - Produce creative digital images with an increased conceptual understanding of representational issues, visual language and communication; ULO4 - Demonstrate increased technical understanding of demands required across the development, acquisition, creation and production of digital media; ULO5 - Display an increasingly personalised artistic expression and sophisticated creative digital imaging approach which can be pursued at an advanced stage in subsequent digital imaging studios; ULO6 - Understand and be able to apply the rules of occupational health and safety and environment appropriate to this unit of study, particularly those applying to use of computing equipment, access to facilities, and the environment of healthy and safe studio practices.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand design conventions and narrative concepts common to cinema; ULO2 - Identify tools and features of digital video cameras and digital audio and video software; ULO3 - Utilise script and storyboard to illustrate concepts; ULO4 - Plan and manage an audio recording session; ULO5 - Plan and manage a video capture session; ULO6 - Acquire footage, incorporate graphics and manage a variety of media sources into a video sequence; ULO7 - Explore nonlinear editing techniques, including editing effects, transition and wipes; ULO8 - Collaboratively contribute to planning and management of a digital audio/video production; ULO9 - Address appropriate output considerations for the assembly and preparation a digital video/audio production; ULO10 - Understand and be able to apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the unit of study.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Skillfully and insightfully create, edit, manipulate, compose and output digital 3-Dimensional elements (ie. photorealistic renderings, surface models); ULO2 - Explore the range of options and controls available through polygon and NURBS-based software applications and production issues associated with output (ie. rendering, rapid-prototyping, multimedia, etc) with increasing confidence and proficiency; ULO3 - Produce 3D models with an increased design intention and creative application; ULO4 - Demonstrate increased technical understanding of demands required across the development, application, creation and production of 3D computer-generated models; ULO5 - Display an increasingly personalised expression and sophisticated creative 3D design approach which can be pursued at an advanced stage in subsequent 3D imaging studios; ULO6 - Observe and employ occupational health and safety principles and rules appropriate to studio practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Recognise the basic set-up and components of a graphics workstation and peripheral devices and display an understanding of industry-standard publishing software; ULO2 - Understand the relationship of various software applications for electronic publishing to the design and production of printed material; ULO3 - Manage a variety of digital assets associated with an electronic publication (ie. translating and importing native image/graphic files created in other digital imaging applications, format text files, colour management, use typographic style sheets and document specifications); ULO4 - Demonstrate efficient organisation of text, image assets and the preparation and files for presentation of digital artwork to a bureau; ULO5 - Apply visual communication, graphic design and page layout skills to publication projects that emulate advertising industry standards; ULO6 - Understand and be able to apply the rules of occupational health and safety environment appropriate to this unit of study, particularly those applying to use of computing equipment, access to facilities, and the employment of healthy and safety studio practices.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Skillfully and insightfully conceive, develop, create, compose and output digital publications; ULO2 - Explore digital workflow through a variety of software applications and range of delivery options for digital publishing with increasing confidence and proficiency; ULO3 - Produce creative digital publications with an increased conceptual understanding of hypertext forms and visual communication; ULO4 - Demonstrate increased technical understanding of demands required across the development, creation and realisation of networked publishing outcomes; ULO5 - Display an increasingly personalised artistic expression and sophisticated creative digital media approach which can be applied to self-promotion and publishing strategies for marketing and visual communication; ULO6 - Observe and employ occupational health and safety principles and rules appropriate to studio practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Use 3D imaging software to create environments and objects; ULO2 - Demonstrate an understanding of the principles of designing objects and spaces in three dimensions; ULO3 - Apply surface qualities, lighting, textures, and imported graphic files to elements in a three dimensional composition; ULO4 - Demonstrate capability in exploring the range of options and controls available through 3D imaging and modelling software applications; ULO5 - Understand and manipulate camera properties and viewer perspectives; ULO6 - Demonstrate knowledge of the various tools and techniques used for realtime 3D computer graphic applications.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand digital video and audio concepts; ULO2 - Plan, acquire and digitise a video source; ULO3 - Trim and edit a video source; ULO4 - Plan and manage an audio recording session; ULO5 - Acquire and incorporate audio and music tracks within a video source; ULO6 - Assemble and output a complete digital audio/video production; ULO7 - Understand the various applications of digital audio/video in multimedia; ULO8 - Demonstrate knowledge of the various tools and techniques used for digital video effects and sound composition.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Use 3D imaging software to create 3D animations; ULO2 - Demonstrate an understanding of the principles of designing for animation in three dimensions; ULO3 - Apply surface qualities, lighting, textures, and imported graphic files to elements in a three dimensional animation; ULO4 - Understand and manipulate camera properties and viewer perspectives; ULO5 - Prepare animation sequences for inclusion in multimedia presentations; ULO6 - Understand the various applications of 3D animation and virtual space in multimedia; ULO7 - Demonstrate knowledge of the various tools and techniques used for realtime 3D computer graphic applications; ULO8 - Analyse the effective use of 3D animation in multimedia; ULO9 - Demonstrate an individual understanding of an aspect of a specific application of 3D animation and virtual space in multimedia; ULO10 - Observe and apply the OHSE requirements of the working environment.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand digital video and audio concepts; ULO2 - Plan, acquire and digitise a video source; ULO3 - Trim and edit a video source; ULO4 - Plan and manage an audio recording session; ULO5 - Acquire and incorporate audio and music tracks within a video source; ULO6 - Assemble and output a complete digital audio/video production; ULO7 - Understand the various applications of digital audio/video in multimedia; ULO8 - Demonstrate knowledge of the various tools and techniques used for digital video effects and sound composition; ULO9 - Analyse the effective use of digital video/audio in multimedia; ULO10 - Demonstrate an individual understanding of an aspect of a specific application of digital audio and/or video in multimedia.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: Doctor of public health: Public health practice
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - demonstrate a thorough understanding of quantative research methods in public health; ULO2 - design, develop and present an original research protocol; ULO3 - prepare an application for approval by an Ethics Committee; ULO4 - design and outline methods for validating a questionnaire suitable for data entry; and ULO5 - write a paper suitable for publication in a peer reviewed journal.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Conduct a clinical interview with a client, incorporating a mental status examination. ULO2 - Complete a thorough and accurate written evaluation of a client. ULO3 - Be familiar with major classes of psychiatric illness. ULO4 - Feel competent in the formulation and diagnosis of a wide variety of psychiatric problems. ULO5 - Effectively and appropriately contribute to case discussions regarding formulation and diagnoses and reflect upon and evaluate own and others' assessment/clinical interviewing skills
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand the principles and processes of psychological, behavioural, and personality measurement and their application; ULO2 - Have become proficient in the administration, scoring, interpretation and integration of assessment results utilising some of the most commonly used psychological tests, including cognitive and personality techniques; and ULO3 - Have developed skills in behavioural assessment including development, implementation, and evaluation of behavioural assessments. ULO4 - Show competency in evaluating psychometric instruments for research purposes and in screening referrals for psychometric assessment, selecting appropriate tests, integrating results and providing oral and written communication of results to interested parties.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - This unit equips students with the necessary skills they need to design research and analyse data for their thesis, placements, and employment. After completing this unit successfully, students should be able to undertake a comprehensive program evaluation as well as a single subject design, and complete their thesis, confidently, competently, and independently. Specifically, students should be able to: + Understand and design the main phases of the key research approaches, including program evaluations, single subject designs, experiments, quasi-experiments, and qualitative projects; + Accommodate the considerations and complications of these approaches, such as sampling biases, spurious variables, common method variance, suppressors, non-recursive relationships, confounds, consequential validity, asymmetric transfer, mediators, moderators, stakeholder needs, economic evaluation, family wise errors, power, autocorrelation, and nonlinear dynamics; + Apply multivariate statistics techniques to address some of these complications, such as ANCOVA, discriminant function analysis, logistic regression analysis, multiple regression analysis, canonical correlation, and factor analysis; + Recognize the fundamental principles of more advanced concepts, which can then be explored through additional reading, including HLM, grounded theory, survival analyses, meta-analyses, catastrophe theory, signal detection theory, ARIMA, interim designs, Bayesian theory, and structural equation modelling; + Develop creative and insightful methods to maximise the utility of research; and + Justify and report the procedures and techniques that were utilised.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Equip students with knowledge of the laws and ethical principles which govern research and professional practice in psychology and understand how to apply their knowledge of relevant legislation and codes of professional conduct to such issues as confidentiality, informed consent, freedom of information, intra and inter professional relationships, responsibilities, and professional conduct. ULO2 - Have an understanding of the intercultural and ethnic issues that impact on their practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand the diagnosis, classification, and aetiology of the major disorders occurring in childhood and adolescence; ULO2 - Understand the principles of interviewing and assessing children and adolescents; ULO3 - Be competent in the administration of the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children (WISC-IV); ULO4 - Be familiar with the major forms of treatment and management based; ULO5 - Be competent in writing a clinical case formulation for a child presenting with a clinical developmental disorder; and ULO6 - Understand clinical developmental issues using a biopsychosocial frame-work.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Ethics and professional practice in neuropsychology
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Be familiar with the legal and ethical principles which govern research and professional practice in psychology and understand how to apply their knowledge of relevant legislation and codes of professional conduct to such issues as confidentiality, informed consent, freedom of information, intra and inter professional relationships, responsibilities, and professional conduct; ULO2 - Be able to define the professional role/s of the Clinical Neuropsychologist; ULO3 - Understand the relationship between the Clinical Neuropsychologist and other health professionals; ULO4 - Have an understanding of the importance of teamwork and the skills necessary to implement this understanding; ULO5 - Have acquired the practical skills necessary to conduct a clinical interview, develop an understanding of the history preceding the development of a neuropsychological problem and write a comprehensive case report; and ULO6 - Have an understanding of the intercultural and ethnic issues that impact on neuropsychological practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the major components of pathways associated with smell, vision, hearing, touch, balance, taste, movement, memory, emotion, and language. ULO2 - Be familiar with the external anatomy of the brain, to be able to name and identify each part and describe its contribution to behavioural and cognitive function. ULO3 - Be able to identify the main subcortical nuclei and their functions. ULO4 - Be able to identify the fibre tracts in the brain and spinal cord and describe their function. ULO5 - Be able to identify each major blood vessel in the brain and describe the functional consequences of infarction for each vessel. ULO6 - Be fluent in the terminology used to navigate the brain and describe brain structures. ULO7 - Be familiar with neurogenetic disorders and their manifestation in brain anatomy. ULO8 - Be knowledgeable about the clinical neurological examination and how neurologists denote and interpret their findings. ULO9 - Be familiar with the most common forms of imaging relevant to clinical neurology and neuropsychology. ULO10 - Have a view of how cognition and behaviour are implemented in neural tissues from the cellular to systems levels of analysis.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Conduct a psychiatric interview with a client; incorporating a mental status examination; ULO2 - Complete a thorough and accurate written evaluation of a client; and ULO3 - Be familiar with major classes of psychiatric illness. ULO4 - Understand the basic concepts of psychopharmacology with particular reference to recent advances in the fields of psychiatric medication, cognitive enhancers and neuroprotective agents, and substance abuse; and ULO5 - Effectively and appropriately contribute to case analyses regarding formulation and diagnoses and reflect upon and evaluate own and others' assessment/clinical interviewing skills
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Theories and techniques of intervention part 1
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Knowledge of mental health problems, ethical and professional guidelines, and a model of therapy (and the ability to draw on and apply this knowledge when providing psychological interventions)? ULO2 - Ability to engage the client, foster and maintain a good therapeutic alliance, and to grasp the client's perspective and 'world view' ULO3 - Ability to deal with emotional content of sessions ULO4 - Ability to manage endings ULO5 - Ability to undertake an assessment ULO6 - Knowledge of basic principles of CBT and rationale for treatment, common cognitive biases relevant to CBT, and the role of safety-seeking behaviours ULO7 - Ability to explain and demonstrate rationale for CBT to client ULO8 - Ability to agree goals for intervention ULO9 - Ability to structure sessions ULO10 - Ability to use measures and self-monitoring to guide therapy and to monitor outcome ULO11 - Ability to devise a maintenance cycle and use this to this set targets ULO12 - Problem solving ULO13 - Relapse prevention ULO14 - Exposure techniques ULO15 - Applied relaxation? ULO16 - Activity monitoring and scheduling ULO17 - Guided discovery and Socratic questioning ULO18 - Ability to develop a formulation with the client
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Neuropsychological models of cognition and behaviour part 1
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Have knowledge of neural bases of attention, language, visuospatial functions, memory, executive functions, emotion processing, and complex adaptive behaviours, in both in normality and pathology; ULO2 - Understand the current theoretical models proposed to account for neuropsychological impairments.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Case analysis and professional practice in neuropsychology 1
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - be familiar with the format of oral presentations suitable for a number of different audiences, ranging from the medico-legal forum and other colleagues to lay persons; ULO2 - participate confidently in case discussions; ULO3 - be informed about current issues in the field of clinical neuropsychology; ULO4 - have developed sufficient rapport with staff members to seek assistance when it is required during later years of the course; and ULO5 - have developed their ability to read and evaluate journal papers relevant to clinical neuropsychology.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Be able to critically evaluate a wide range of neuropsychological tests and scales designed to assess numerous aspects of cognitive, behavioural and emotional functioning. ULO2 - Be able to plan neuropsychological assessments, including both qualitative and quantitative methods, appropriate to specific clinical contexts and referrals (eg; across the lifespan, cross-cultural assessment etc.). ULO3 - Be able to interpret and integrate information obtained during neuropsychological assessment to formulate a comprehensive analysis of an individual's neuropsychological function. ULO4 - To be able to disseminate neuropsychological assessment findings across a range of formats (reports, verbal feedback) and audiences (other clinicians, clients, family).
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - be able to provide a verbal description of the neuropsychological deficits associated with common inherited and acquired neurpsychological disorders; ULO2 - be able to recognise and differentiate between common syndromes on the basis of the patient's history, presentation and assessment results; ULO3 - feel confident in planning and executing a formal assessment of a patient presenting with each syndrome; and ULO4 - be aware of psychosocial and treatment issues associated with each disorder.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - expected to have gained an appreciation of the professional role a psychologist in practice and to have an understanding of the delivery of a service to patients, clients and other interested parties; ULO2 - to have acquired an understanding of the context of the delivery of the service and the particular function it serves to the individual and the community at large; ULO3 - to have developed an appreciation of the competing demands on service delivery and the range of issues which impact on service delivery; ULO4 - expected to become proficient in establishing rapport with patients, administering and scoring the commonly used intellectual, diagnostic and personality tests, integrating the results and providing appropriate oral and written reports; ULO5 - expected to have developed an understanding of the functioning of a multi-disciplinary team and the role of its various members.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Theories and techniques of intervention part 2
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - To further develop skills in cognitive behaviour therapy ULO2 - To develop the knowledge and skills to apply CBT and other integrative treatments to a variety of disorders under supervision ULO3 - To develop knowledge and skills to design a CBT-focused treatment plan ULO4 - To provide an awareness of some other modes of therapy and related underlying theory ULO5 - To engage in and develop self-reflective practice
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand the basic concepts of psychopharmacology with particular reference to recent advances in the fields of psychiatric medication, cognitive enhancers and neuroprotective agents, and substance abuse; ULO2 - Have a broad understanding of commonly prescribed psychoactive drugs, legal and illegal drugs and other commonly abused substances. ULO3 - Be able to comment on the likely physiological and psychological effects in a particular individual of a specific drug (together with possible drug interactions), and to prepare a written report on the topic. ULO4 - Be exposed to current issues in clinical psychopharmacology and in research concerning treatment approaches. ULO5 - Gain a broad understanding of the advanced psychopathology topics of delirium, mental health in older adults, and bereavement.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand the scope of the related fields of health psychology and behavioural medicine, and their history. ULO2 - Understand the systems of the body that underlie health and disease. ULO3 - Comprehend the prevalence of different chronic diseases and factors that affect prevalence rates. ULO4 - Understand how behaviour and lifestyle relates to health. ULO5 - Understand the main models of health behaviour and behaviour change. ULO6 - Understand the goals and methods of health promotion and the prevention of disease. ULO7 - Understand how to develop conceptual models of patient problems, and how to plan and implement interventions based on the model and the relevant empirical literature. ULO8 - Understand the major chronic diseases that affect morbidity and mortality, that is, cancer and cardiovascular disease, from a behavioural perspective. ULO9 - Understand how to assess and manage, or contribute to the management, of a number of exemplar disorders/problems (e.g., drug and alcohol abuse,overweight and obesity, sleep problems, cancer and cardiovascular disease). ULO10 - Understand how to increase patient adherence with advice from health professionals. ULO11 - Understand models of stress and the stress-moderating variables of coping and social support; how to measure these constructs; and methods of stress management.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Case analysis and professional practice in neuropsychology 2
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - be proficient in summarising and presenting case material in an oral format suitable for a number of different audiences, ranging from a hospital or rehabilitation setting through to a medico-legal forum, to other colleagues and to lay persons, ULO2 - participate confidently and productively in case discussions; ULO3 - be informed about current issues in the field of Clinical Neuropsychology.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - developed skill and confidence in applying their theoretical knowledge to the psychological treatment of individuals with relatively uncomplicated emotional and/or behavioural problems and to the assessment of treatment outcomes. ULO2 - developed an awareness of the intricacy of the therapeutic relationship and of the contribution of their personal qualities to it. Their contribution to service delivery should reflect the principles of best practice and their role within an agency should be equivalent to that of a junior employee.? ULO3 - the ability to demonstrate an understanding of the complexities of the agency's role in service delivery and to service delivery and to independently contribute to the development of strategies for improved service delivery.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Be familiar with basic functions of key neuroanatomical brain regions and be able to apply this to brain-behaviour relationships ULO2 - Understand key principles underlying neuropsychological assessment and formulation ULO3 - Have a understanding of key neuropsychological syndromes that are regularly encountered in clinical psychology practice ULO4 - Be able to interpret neuropsychological reports and apply recommendations relevant to clinical psychology
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Be familiar with the main stages of central nervous system development, and the impact of these stages on normal cognitive functioning; ULO2 - Be fully aware of the impact that various neurodevelopmental disorders, various neuropsychiatric disorders or several kinds of acquired brain injury might be expected to have on the development of cognitive skills; ULO3 - Be familiar with theories of recovery function during childhood and adolescence, and appropriate rehabilitation and management strategies; ULO4 - Be competent in taking a comprehensive case history, in selecting and administering neuropsychological tests suitable for each developmental period, and interpreting the results of these; ULO5 - Be able to effectively impart their neuropsychological findings and recommendations to non-professionals such as parents and teachers; and ULO6 - Feel confident working with children, parents, teachers and professional childcare workers.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Case analysis and professional practice in neuropsychology 3
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - be proficient in summarising and presenting case material relative to assessment and management in an oral format suitable for a number of different audiences, ranging from hospital to rehabilitative settings, through to the medico-legal forum to other colleagues to lay persons; ULO2 - participate confidently and productively in case discussions; ULO3 - be informed about current issues in the field of Clinical neuropsychology; ULO4 - be familiar with case material drawn from a number of different settings.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Recovery of function and rehabilitation after brain injury
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - have acquired a good understanding of current theories and models of recovery of brain function after neurological damage; ULO2 - be familiar with recent research examining plasticity and reorganisation in the primate brain; ULO3 - be informed about the current World Health Organisation (WHO) framework for conceptualising disability in terms of impairment of function, activity limitation and participation restriction; ULO4 - know how clinical neuropsychologists and other allied health professionals assess impairment following neurological damage; ULO5 - be familiar with current rehabilitative interventions for specific neuropsychological disorders, and the methods commonly used to assess the effectiveness of these interventions; ULO6 - be well informed about strategies used in the management of those with neurological damage.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - include management of individuals identified with serious and difficult problems;? ULO2 - independently develop and deliver intervention strategies across a range of areas which reflect an understanding of the current psychological principles and how these can be implemented within service delivery systems.? ULO3 - utilise a full understanding of the complexities of provision of services should be apparent with evidence of appreciation of the wider context in which the client operates and in which the service is provided.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - be able to develop and deliver assessment and intervention strategies which reflect an understanding of the current knowledge of best practice in clinical psychology. ULO2 - be able to provide input at the organisational level. ULO3 - demonstrate a sound understanding of clinical psychological principles and how these are implemented within service delivery systems. ULO4 - understand fully the role of a clinical psychologist at an organisational level, and the contributions that a clinical psychologist makes to a service delivery system. ULO5 - be able to recognise when input from a senior member of staff is required and be able to seek out this input in a timely and professional manner.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Organize features of cases to construct problem focused, disorder specific, and comprehensive case conceptualizations for complex case presentations; ULO2 - Assess client strengths and aspects that require special consideration when engaging clients, tailoring therapeutic relationships and interventions; ULO3 - Create therapeutic environments that foster client engagement during sessions, and that maximize client engagement with between session work; ULO4 - Construct, deliver, and evaluate comprehensive case presentations including comprehensive case conceptualizations and treatment plans; ULO5 - Plan tailored therapeutic intervention for clients with severe personality disorders and multiple diagnoses; ULO6 - Contribute to constructive case consultation;
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Advanced clinical psychology: Child, adolescent and family
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Create a comprehensive case formulation for a young person drawing together developmental history, and construct an appropriate treatment plan; ULO2 - Construct, deliver, and contribute to case presentations, including case conceptualizations and treatment planning; ULO3 - Prepare and conduct role-plays utilizing relevant Dialectical Behavior Therapy Skills with mock clients and appraise their performance; ULO4 - Plan and critically evaluate the existing literature for the implementation of a group therapy program for a relevant child or adolescent clinical presentation; ULO5 - Contribute to constructive case consultation.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - be able to independently develop and deliver assessment and intervention strategies which reflect an understanding of the current knowledge of best practice; ULO2 - be able to provide input at the organisational level;? ULO3 - be able to demonstrate a sound understanding of neuropsychological principles and how these can be implemented within service delivery systems;? ULO4 - demonstrate a full understanding of the complexities of provision of services should be apparent with evidence of appreciation of the wider context in which the client operates and in which the service is provided.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding of the formal elements and principles of drawing as they are incorporated within compositional dynamics; ULO2 - Develop an experimental approach to mark making techniques through a diverse range of media in relation to image production; ULO3 - Analyse the processes of perception and observational drawing to represent spaces, objects, forms and structures, in relation to ideas, narratives and research; ULO4 - Develop drawing skills and strategies to translate data, concepts and communication as a formative skill in studio research; ULO5 - Explore the historical, theoretical, philosophical and aesthetic contexts of drawing; ULO6 - Understand and apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the studio practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explore a range of drawing materials and processes in the representation and characterisation of a variety of figure subjects; ULO2 - Articulate form and space through the drawing process; ULO3 - Create drawings in a variety of scales and media; ULO4 - Contextualise the historical representation of the figure in western art and consider the role and influence of the genre in the context of contemporary culture; ULO5 - Understand and apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the discipline and context.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Employ a broad graphic vocabulary and perceptual approaches and representations of the body; ULO2 - Describe the aesthetic contexts of anatomy in both historical and contemporary art; ULO3 - Apply a broad range of material and techniques relevant to various conceptual approaches to the body; ULO4 - Demonstrate an understanding of the structures of the body through the drawing process; ULO5 - Demonstrate an understanding of the appropriate procedures for complying with OHS and ethical requirements in this area of study.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Competently explore and design a range of information gathering systems appropriate to the area of interest of your major studio research; ULO2 - Make manifest a record of original perceptions and responses to the overseas location as a unique site; ULO3 - Demonstrate a deeper understanding of the significance of site and context for the creation and location of your work; ULO4 - Demonstrate a greater appreciation of the specificity of visual, verbal or conceptual languages to a particular culture; ULO5 - Investigate how to articulate original work through an appreciation and incorporation of such newly experienced languages in a way that remains cogent to your major study; ULO6 - Understand and be able to apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the unit of study.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Define the structure and materials of the whole Earth, including the core, mantle, lithosphere, land surface, oceans and atmosphere and describe how our understanding of these has changed over time. ULO2 - Summarise how the energy, water, biogeochemical, rock, and plate tectonic cycles work, and explain how they act to change the Earth system over time. ULO3 - Synthesise and explain the physical, chemical, and biological processes that have shaped and continue to change the solid Earth, land surface, oceans, and atmosphere. ULO4 - Demonstrate how scientists collect, record, visualise, map, and analyse data in space and time to observe, model and predict deep Earth, climate, and surface processes.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Synthesise and explain how the fundamental physical, chemical, and biological processes change the earth's surface over time, including how they affect and shape landforms, ecosystems, weather and climate. ULO2 - Identify, evaluate and describe the relative contributions of natural and human processes to changes in the Earth's lithosphere, pedosphere, biosphere, cryosphere, atmosphere, and hydrosphere and describe the implications for ecosystem productivity. ULO3 - Analyse the natural resources required to support ecosystems, the human impact on these natural resources and ecosystems, and their sustainable management. ULO4 - Collect and use observations to examine, visualise and map how the processes regulating the Earth System operate in the real world. ULO5 - Describe the role of modelling for understanding how natural and human processes influence the Earth System and evaluate the utility of modelling for prediction for a variety of applications. ULO6 - Understand the science involved in modelling future environments, based on our past and present understanding of Earth's surface processes.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the basic methods for data analysis and scientific modelling of environmental and climate science. ULO2 - Perform statistical analyses of environmental and climate data sets with numerical methods and visualise results using common tools, such as studio. ULO3 - Analyse simple models in terms of sensitivities, quantitative and qualitative relationships. ULO4 - Build simple quantitative models based on theoretical knowledge or statistical data analysis. ULO5 - Communicate clearly the key concepts covered in the unit, both verbally and in written form.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Define the concept of 'climate' and key processes that regulate the climate on the global, regional and micro-scales; ULO2 - Describe how various elements of the climate system are measured and observed, including the instruments employed, how they operate, and application to real-world climate problems; ULO3 - Describe how the climate varies on a number of time and space scales. Explain some of the key physical mechanisms and their interactions that cause these variations, and appreciate their complexity; ULO4 - Know some of the modifications made by humans that can influence the climate and the associated processes by which this occurs; ULO5 - Communicate complex concepts in climate science to scientific and non-scientific audiences.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_TITLE: Introduction to atmospheric physics and dynamics
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the basic thermodynamics of the atmosphere and the forces acting upon it, and explain how these forces lead to atmospheric motions; ULO2 - Identify and describe the main processes leading to the formation of clouds; ULO3 - Distinguish and classify different cloud types; ULO4 - Apply conceptual knowledge of the atmosphere to real-life weather systems, including severe storms, tornadoes and tropical cyclones, and use appropriate techniques for forecasting day-to-day weather; ULO5 - Integrate key concepts of atmospheric physics and dynamics to analyse and solve quantitative meteorological problems ULO6 - Interpret quantitative meteorological information using appropriate mathematical, statistical, and graphical tools.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the biotic and abiotic processes which support the development of Earth's biosphere and lead to the formation of soils and sediments, and how they interact to influence water quality and vegetation; ULO2 - Demonstrate practical, hands-on experience in field description and laboratory analysis of vegetation, water quality sediments and soils; ULO3 - Identify key soil- and sediment-forming materials and processes; ULO4 - Explain the role of plants, vegetation and microorganisms in ecosystem functioning; ULO5 - Analyse interactions between Australia's unique soils, water and vegetation and to apply this knowledge to the future conservation and management of these resources.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Interpret geological processes in the context of global tectonic settings and to demonstrate a broad, integrated overview of crustal processes on planet Earth; ULO2 - Analyse igneous, metamorphic rocks and their deformation (structures); ULO3 - Interpret tectonic environments from igneous, metamorphosed and deformed rocks; ULO4 - Reconstruct the link between the variety of rock types and plate tectonics. How mountain-building and continental rifting processes drive processes that give rise to this variety.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Appreciate the global tectonic context of sedimentary basins; ULO2 - Comprehend the principles of stratigraphy and how geologists determine the age of sedimentary and volcanic rocks; ULO3 - Apply the techniques of sedimentology, physical volcanology, stratigraphy and palaeontology to reconstruct the geological and paleoclimate record of sedimentary basins; ULO4 - Understand how basin evolution is evaluated by the use of geophysical techniques; ULO5 - Apply geological principles to explore for and manage the resources and uses of sedimentary basins, including water and mineral resources, carbon capture and storage, and geothermal energy.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply the basic principles of geological mapping in a variety of settings; ULO2 - Measurement and document structural, lithological and stratigraphic data in the field and use this data to analyse the geological evolution of a region; ULO3 - Construct accurate geological maps and cross-sections based on acquired field data; ULO4 - Analyse and interpret geological maps; ULO5 - Demonstrate their comprehension of the origin of field-based geological information presented in the literature; ULO6 - Synthesize large amounts of geological data and express the findings both orally and as a written scientific report; ULO7 - Practice safe behaviour in the field.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_TITLE: Earth, atmosphere and environment research project
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Generate, manipulate, and interpret data relevant to Earth, Atmospheric, or Environmental Sciences; ULO2 - Review and critically evaluate the scientific literature within the discipline; ULO3 - Conduct independent research, including defining research questions and developing research methodology; ULO4 - Analyse and explain the broader scientific and social aspects of research in their chosen field; ULO5 - Present the outcomes of a research project both orally and in written form.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_TITLE: Earth, atmosphere and environment: Special topics
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate outcomes formulated related to the Special Topic determined and agreed upon between the third-year coordinator and student(s) in writing at the beginning of the project.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_TITLE: Geographical information systems and remote sensing
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate a clear understanding of the key concepts and principles of GIS and remote sensing; ULO2 - Develop an ability to collect, handle and use digital spatial data for mapping, analysis and modelling; ULO3 - Identify sources of spatial data and assess the nature and quality of spatial data; ULO4 - Demonstrate basic problem solving skills with GIS and remote sensing; ULO5 - Demonstrate a high level of skills in the use of GIS software (ArcGIS); ULO6 - Develop their own applications of GIS and remote sensing.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the physical movement of water within the hydrological cycle; ULO2 - Determine the origins of solutes in water and how solute chemistry informs our understanding of hydrological processes; ULO3 - Discuss concepts of groundwater residence times and how these impact on the sustainable management of water resources; ULO4 - Explain the role of groundwater in maintaining river flows and sustaining ecosystems; ULO5 - Indicate the main threats to groundwater, including pollution, pumping, and climate or land use change and also be able to identify management and mitigation strategies. ULO6 - Interpret and integrate hydrological data.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_TITLE: Geophysical interpretations in geoscience, geography and environmental science
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand the basic physical principles of several geophysical methods; ULO2 - Collect and process geophysical datasets so they can be interpreted by expert geoscientist and environmental scientists; ULO3 - Undertake an interpretation of multiple geophysical datasets to solve complex geological, geographical and environmental problems related to the subsurface of the Earth; ULO4 - Integrate large and multiple datasets to resolve geological, geographical and environmental problems; ULO5 - Complete a multi week project and communicate major findings via a map, oral presentation and a written report; ULO6 - Develop decision making skills based on data that provides ambiguous solution; ULO7 - Assess confidence levels, uncertainty, extrapolation of surface observations to the subsurface, and develop rapid 3D visualisation skills.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the history of the Earth's climate system from the formation of Earth (4 billion years ago) to the present. ULO2 - Illustrate physical, chemical and biological proxies of climate and know the techniques used to extract past climate information from these proxies. ULO3 - Interpret past climate changes from reconstructions developed from palaeoclimate proxies. Appreciate and quantify the uncertainties in these reconstructions. ULO4 - Discuss how climate has changed in the past and what have been the physical, chemical and biological processes causing these changes. ULO5 - Use simple climate models to explain past climate changes. ULO6 - Communicate clearly the key concepts of the unit across a range of styles and technologies using spoken, diagrammatic and written forms.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Discuss the basic physical theory of the earth's energy balance and large-scale climate dynamics and how it can be constructed from basic principles using mathematical analysis and numerical modelling. ULO2 - Demonstrate knowledge and skills in using mathematical models and applications in atmospheric science and oceanography. ULO3 - Demonstrate high-level knowledge and skills of the important techniques, terminology and processes of the large-scale physical climate, climate change and variability. ULO4 - Develop, apply, integrate and generate knowledge to analyse and solve problems in physical climate dynamics. ULO5 - Discuss the importance of the physical climate dynamics to climate change and variability. ULO6 - Collect, organise, analyse and interpret quantitative information meaningfully, using mathematical and/or statistical tools as appropriate to physical climate dynamics, including numerical programming. ULO7 - Explain climate dynamics concepts, processes and results to diverse audiences.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the physical theory of precipitation and radiation in the atmosphere and apply these principles to weather radar and satellite imagery using mathematical models; ULO2 - Demonstrate skills in using mathematical techniques to understand the physics of the atmosphere; ULO3 - Demonstrate high-level knowledge of the important techniques and terminology in physical meteorology; ULO4 - Demonstrate competence in information technology, data handling, and laboratory skills; ULO5 - Analyse and solve problems in physical meteorology; ULO6 - Explain physical meteorology concepts, processes and results to diverse audiences.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_TITLE: Future climates: Projections, impacts and adaptation
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the basic physics of climate change, the key leverage points for earth's climate, both natural and anthropogenic. ULO2 - Discuss global carbon cycle, the critical roles of the oceans and biosphere, and the overriding impact of human perturbation on the natural controls on atmospheric CO ULO3 - Recognise the roles of climate change and natural variability in current climate trends. ULO4 - Explain the operation of climate models, their strengths, weaknesses and uncertainties, and the development of projections. ULO5 - Describe the fundamental approaches to climate change mitigation along with a basic understanding of international policy on climate change including successes and failures. ULO6 - Explain how both mitigation and adaptation are required to deal adequately with climate change.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Discuss the physical theory of the motion of the atmosphere and how it can be constructed from basic principles using mathematical analysis; ULO2 - Demonstrate skills in using mathematical techniques to understand the dynamics of the atmosphere; ULO3 - Demonstrate high-level knowledge of the important techniques and terminology in dynamical meteorology; ULO4 - Apply knowledge to analyse and solve problems in dynamical meteorology.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the ways in which past climates and biogeographic conditions may leave an imprint on the surface features of the continents and oceans; ULO2 - Demonstrate a knowledge of fluvial and coastal geomorphic processes such as stream loads, waves and sea levels, and their variation among physiographic, hydrodynamic and climatic environments; ULO3 - Be able to quantify the basic transport of sediments in the oceans and along the coastline; ULO4 - Develop an understanding of ocean circulation patterns and their importance for global climate and global carbon and nitrogen cycles and local marine management; ULO5 - Collect samples and interpret environmental conditions in marine environments ULO6 - Develop a good working capability in using GIS for spatial and remote sensing data analysis.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Exhibit a high level of skill in field description, identification and analysis of soils and regolith. ULO2 - Assess the current explanations for landscape management problems through critical evaluation of the literature and field and laboratory data. ULO3 - Discuss the processes that lead to soil and regolith formation. ULO4 - Discuss the key threats to the soil resource and identify management and remediation strategies. ULO5 - Describe soil and land management issues in the context of both longer-term environmental change and current environmental change.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Appreciate the importance of hydrological processes in water catchments to human activity, and the vulnerability of hydrological processes to manipulation by human activity. ULO2 - Describe how rising human appropriation of fresh water globally poses challenges for security of water and food supply ULO3 - Explain? how hydrological processes vary among climates (arid to wet tropical) and through time, as regional and global climates undergo change. ULO4 - Describe key hydrological processes as explored in practical classes, including canopy interception, infiltration, seepage, and overland flow. ULO5 - Carry out laboratory experiments dealing with key hydrological processes.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_TITLE: Environmental cycles on our living planet
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the processes that underpin earth's major nutrient (ie. C, N, P and S) cycles. ULO2 - Comprehend the importance of metal cycling in the earth system. ULO3 - Describe the roles of microorganisms and minerals in environmental cycles. ULO4 - Develop an understanding of how anthropogenic influence on environment cycles can either cause pollution or be used to remediate it. ULO5 - Use geochemical tracer methods to identify sources and sinks for elements in natural and contaminated systems. ULO6 - Analyse and interpret geochemical datasets from natural and contaminated environments.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_TITLE: Geoscience: Ore deposits and metals of the future
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Recognise and describe different metal-rich minerals in rock specimens and thin sections, and explain their relationship to the needs of renewable energy technology; ULO2 - Describe the characteristic mineralogical, structural and host-rock features of a range of important mineral deposit types; ULO3 - Explain the current hypotheses for genesis of a range of mineral deposit types; ULO4 - Integrate scientific data to form a hypothesis that can be used in mineral exploration for a range of ore deposit types; ULO5 - Combine scientific data to design and evaluate strategies to efficiently and economically extract metals from known mineral deposits; ULO6 - Work as a geologist in the minerals industry.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify and classify small- to large-scale geological structures and interpret their significance; ULO2 - Apply concepts of geometric, kinematic and dynamic structural analysis; ULO3 - Identify the deformation behaviour of major rock forming minerals under different conditions; ULO4 - Develop a sound understanding of analysis and documentation of three-dimensional structures in the field, geological maps and geophysical data; ULO5 - Combine scientific data to understand the relationship between tectonic settings and deformation; ULO6 - Link structural geology and tectonics with geodynamics.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Observe and interpret the distribution of lithologies and structures in the field; ULO2 - Describe the basic concepts of field mapping techniques; ULO3 - Produce a geological map and cross-sections from field observations; ULO4 - Visualise complex three-dimensional geometries; ULO5 - Unravel the geological history of a complexly deformed terrane; ULO6 - Determine overprinting relationships from field geology; ULO7 - Work in a team environment and communicate with peers.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand mineral reactions under changing environments, such as temperature, pressure or fluids, and subsurface mass movement; ULO2 - Relate hard rock geologic concepts and genesis to other geoscience disciplines, such as ore geology and environmental sciences; ULO3 - Translate idealised textbook concepts of rock forming processes within the Earth into more complex, natural rock relationships, including mineral reactions; ULO4 - Apply the concept of geologic time and means to accurately measure it; ULO5 - Synthesise data from real life examples and convert this into a scientific report; ULO6 - Identify rock relationships in the field, in comparison to idealised laboratory environs.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_TITLE: Landscape, environment and sustainability in Italy
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand the range of complex environmental, social and economic interrelationships that shape a particular region and to be able to differentiate a cultural landscape from a natural landscape; ULO2 - Understand the criteria and processes that lead to the designation of a World Heritage Area and to be able to identify, describe and interpret problems of sustainability in the context of a region of truly global significance; ULO3 - Have gained practical experience in problem formulation and solution using field-based techniques of survey and analysis, along with appropriate presentation skills.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand, synthesise and summarise the existing literature. ULO2 - Identify gaps in our knowledge in their chosen area of research. ULO3 - Develop a research plan ULO4 - Commence original research in the chosen area. ULO5 - Present their preliminary findings in a brief written thesis and oral presentation.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand, synthesise and summarise the existing literature. ULO2 - Identify gaps in our knowledge in their chosen area of research. ULO3 - Advance our knowledge in the chosen area through original research. ULO4 - Present their findings in a written thesis and oral presentation.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand, use and explain the basic concepts and principles of the research literature which underpin the chosen area of research in Earth Science. ULO2 - Synthesise and interpret the knowledge gained in the study of the underpinning research literature. This leads to the ability to identify a niche topic or topics within this existing body of literature, which represents a gap in current knowledge. This problem should be suitable for original research. ULO3 - Advance our understanding of an existing problem or problems in the chosen area for original research. ULO4 - Present the preliminary findings in a written report also present key results in oral form as a preliminary seminar.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand, use and explain the basic concepts and principles of the research literature which underpin the chosen area of research in Earth Science. ULO2 - Synthesise and interpret the knowledge gained in the study of the underpinning research literature. This leads to the ability to identify a niche topic or topics within this existing body of literature, which represents a gap in current knowledge. This problem should be suitable for original research. ULO3 - Advance our understanding of an existing problem or problems in the chosen area for original research. ULO4 - Present the results of the original research in written form as a thesis, and also present key thesis results in oral form as a preliminary seminar. ULO5 - Defend the results of the original research in an oral exam.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Do a statistical analysis on probability distributions, time series, and multivariate data. ULO2 - Apply standard statistical methods in climate dynamics data analysis. ULO3 - Interpret the outcomes of the statistical analysis in the context of climate dynamics. ULO4 - Read, understand and critically analyse the scientific literature on data analysis in climate dynamics.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand the dynamical principles governing the fluid flow in a rotating frame of reference; ULO2 - Apply these principles to explain the dynamics of many common mid latitude weather systems; ULO3 - Demonstrate a high level of knowledge of the important mathematical techniques used to solve problems in mid latitude dynamics; ULO4 - Read, understand and critically analyse the scientific literature on mid latitude dynamics.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply the various analysis techniques used to estimate the atmospheric thermodynamic state and large-scale circulation and evaluate their strengths and weaknesses. ULO2 - Appraise the main features of the atmospheric circulation and the processes that contribute to their maintenance. ULO3 - Apply mathematical tools to analyse the transports of energy, momentum and water through the atmosphere. ULO4 - Critically engage with the scientific literature regarding the large-scale atmospheric circulation and its possible changes under climate change.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Appraise the governing equations of global atmospheric flow and their numerical implementation in models; ULO2 - Apply principles of representing sub-grid scale processes in global models; ULO3 - Assess the basic performance of global models against observations; ULO4 - Critically analyse the scientific literature in model evaluation and development.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply a conceptual definition of the atmospheric boundary layer and various quantitative definitions; ULO2 - Appraise the dynamical and physical processes that affect that atmospheric boundary layer; ULO3 - Appraise the diurnal cycle of the terrestrial boundary layer and the evolution of the maritime boundary layer during warm and cold air advection; ULO4 - Appraise a hierarchy of models of the atmospheric boundary layer and construct a 'mixed layer model'; ULO5 - Critically analyse scientific literature on the atmospheric boundary layer.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the physics of interactions of electromagnetic radiation and the atmosphere; ULO2 - Demonstrate a broad knowledge of the range of satellite instruments used in atmospheric remote sensing; ULO3 - Contrast and compare the techniques used to measure atmospheric constituents; ULO4 - Gain valuable big data skills through? analysing, visualising and extracting information from contemporary satellite data; ULO5 - Read, understand and critically appraise the scientific literature on atmospheric remote sensing.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Produce structural geological maps; ULO2 - Observe and interpret the distribution of lithologies and structures in the field; ULO3 - Correlate observations and interpretations at the outcrop scale to produce consistent map and cross-sections; ULO4 - Determine the relationship between structure and metamorphic assemblages; ULO5 - Visualise complex three dimensional geometries; ULO6 - Unravel the geological history of complexly deformed terranes; ULO7 - Determine overprinting relationships from field geology; ULO8 - Communicate results in a written report; ULO9 - Work in a team environment and communicate of results with peers; ULO10 - Equip students with discipline-specific knowledge and expertise appropriate for post-graduate research in the field; equip students with discipline-specific knowledge and expertise enabling them to take their place as professional geologists in industry or government organisations; develop their field mapping techniques.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_TITLE: Geology and tectonics of New Zealand
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the relationships between the ancient geological processes preserved in Australia and the young processes occurring in New Zealand. ULO2 - Use new skills in interpreting evidence of deformation and origin of a fault structure. ULO3 - Understand and interpret field evidence of the different mechanisms driving different types of metamorphism. ULO4 - Prepare a stratigraphic log. ULO5 - Understand and interpret field characteristics of geochemical processes. ULO6 - Present an overview of a complex geological topic to a educated geoscience audience.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand the different analytical tools that can be used to study geochemical systems and the information they deliver. ULO2 - Prepare samples, acquire data, and interpret the results. ULO3 - Use a range of analytical techniques. ULO4 - Design and conduct an analytical campaign - including budgeting, selecting adequate samples and analytical tools, quality control, and reporting the results
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Students will develop the ability to work in a team environment to achieve project objectives; ULO2 - Students will develop their oral presentation skills that enable them to express the concepts they develop, the data required to test the concept, and the outcomes and interpretations of the simulated exploration program; ULO3 - Students will construct a geoscientific report outlining the objectives, methodology, data required and the outcomes and interpretations of the simulated exploration program; ULO4 - Students will gain an ability to integrate multiple large datasets to synthesise and interpret geological information.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Develop a project proposal with appropriate research questions, aims, hypotheses and methodological approaches ULO2 - Critically review the literature relevant to the project. ULO3 - Generate, analyse and interpret data using appropriate data analysis methods ULO4 - Communicate the findings, implications and limitations of the project in the broader scientific and social context in a clear and professional manner, in written and oral forms. ULO5 - Collaborate effectively with their peers.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - An ability to identify the kind of digital information and software most appropriate to solving different geological problems. ULO2 - An opportunity to demonstrate their ability to work with state-of-the-art geological data sets in digital form. ULO3 - Confidence and competence to interrogate geological problems employing modern digital techniques. ULO4 - Equip students with discipline-specific knowledge and expertise appropriate for post-graduate research in the field; equip students with discipline-specific knowledge and expertise enabling them to take their place as professional geologists in industry or government organisations; ULO5 - Develop skills to process regional geophysical datasets, develop strategies to interpret geology from regional aeromagnetic and gravity data, integrate geological data into the geophysical interpretation, practical experience in geophysical interpretation and best practices in modeling geophysical data.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - To explain and apply the major concepts and principles of remote sensing and digital image processing for earth science applications. ULO2 - To identify the types of information that can be extracted from remotely sensed data on the environment and earth resources. ULO3 - To explain and apply the fundamental image interpretation elements (e.g., tone, texture, size, shape, pattern, site and association) ULO4 - To visually interpret aerial photos and satellite images.
