UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - understand the theoretical foundations of economics, and the generic skills essential for progression to upper level units by applying rigorous thinking and understanding to analytical geometric models ULO2 - identify and explain economic systems and the concept of resource allocation, and the role of individuals and businesses in markets ULO3 - discuss the implementation of economic policy in a microeconomic framework, and the ability of economics as an evolutionary science to address the persistent social and economic problems confronted by society ULO4 - recognise regulatory and political environments and how they impact on business ULO5 - demonstrate in individual summative assessment tasks the acquisition of a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered in this unit.

ULO1 - gain an insight into the product, money, labour and foreign exchange markets, and knowledge and understanding of the Australian economy and its operation in an international environment ULO2 - identify and explain economic systems and the concept of resource allocation ULO3 - discuss the implementation of economic policy in a macroeconomic framework, and the ability of economics as an evolutionary science to address the persistent social and economic problems confronted by society ULO4 - recognise regulatory and political environments and how they impact on business ULO5 - acquire the basis for more advanced studies in economics ULO6 - demonstrate in individual summative assessment tasks the acquisition of a comprehensive understanding of the topics covered.

ULO1 - understand the core concepts and tools of labour economics and policy ULO2 - apply economic principles to analyse the operation of labour markets critically ULO3 - critically evaluate government policies affecting labour markets ULO4 - recognise the critical issues involved in labour markets ULO5 - apply analytical skills developed through an analysis of continuing change in the labour market and labour market policy.

ULO1 - understand the measurement of income, prices, money and unemployment ULO2 - distinguish between the short-run and long-run impacts of macroeconomic policy ULO3 - understand the concepts of aggregate demand, aggregate supply and general equilibrium, and be able to use them for policy analysis ULO4 - understand the effect of macroeconomic policy on the trade balance, inflation, unemployment and income ULO5 - be able to critically assess macroeconomic policy.

ULO1 - understand how markets work ULO2 - understand how customers value products ULO3 - understand which production and cost measures are relevant for decision making ULO4 - understand how competition affects business decisions on investment, production, and pricing in different market structures ULO5 - understand the importance of managerial and marketing decisions for changes in foreign exchange rates, technology, incomes, government regulations, sources of energy, the balance of payments.

UNIT_TITLE: Economics of international trade and finance
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - understand and critically evaluate contemporary policy debates in international trade and finance ULO2 - use analytical tools to predict the impact of global economic, political and social policies on Australia as a small open economy ULO3 - recognise the positive welfare effects of worldwide unrestricted trade.

ULO1 - understand the theoretical structure of an open economy with emphasis on monetary policy formulation and implementation ULO2 - analyse and predict the key economic variables when the economy is faced with internal and external market shocks ULO3 - use an economic model that allows for competitive international capital markets and floating exchange rates to analyse policy measures.

ULO1 - understand the 'economic way of thinking' about a broad range of individual, business and government choices and decisions ULO2 - apply economic principles to explain and analyse economic institutions, economic decisions and performance ULO3 - recognise regulatory and political environments and how they impact on business.

ULO1 - interpret recent movements in key economic indicators of the Australian and other economies and appreciate some of the definition and measurement problems associated with the available data ULO2 - understand the importance of distinguishing between the short-run and long-run impacts of macroeconomic policy ULO3 - apply economic analysis appropriate to achieving an understanding of the working of the macroeconomy ULO4 - recognise the significance of Australia's economy in relation to the rest of the world and the implications of this interdependence for the balance of payments and exchange rate ULO5 - understand regulatory and political environments and how they impact on business and the economy.

UNIT_TITLE: Introduction to quantitative skills for social sciences
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - graphically represent the relationship between variables ULO2 - evaluate the qualitative impact of policy changes on relevant outcomes using graphical methods ULO3 - solve for the equilibrium outcomes of interactions using basic algebra ULO4 - formulate and solve simple optimization problems ULO5 - understand how to interpret data

ULO1 - analyse decision-making by individual consumers and producers ULO2 - understand decision making in game-theoretic set ups ULO3 - analyse price determination in product and input markets under various conditions ULO4 - analyse and critically evaluate policies designed to affect individual behaviour and market outcomes.

ULO1 - understand the basic macroeconomic frameworks ULO2 - analyse systematically the forces that determine changes in macroeconomic performance and living standards ULO3 - appraise critically the important current macroeconomic issues ULO4 - appreciate the nature and relevance of some significant recent developments in macroeconomics ULO5 - engage in rigorous economic analysis.

ULO1 - understand how economic theory and data are combined to analyse and frame macroeconomic policies ULO2 - understand how macroeconomic data is created, and used to design macroeconomic policy ULO3 - evaluate the contributions and limitations of economic analysis for helping to understand and to evaluate macroeconomic policy options ULO4 - analyse the causes of recent economic crises, apply macroeconomic theory to understand how they unfolded and describe what policies were used to solve them.

ULO1 - appreciate the economic way of thinking, the methodology of microeconomics and a knowledge of the tools used by economists in problem solving ULO2 - understand the economic behaviour of individual consumers and producers and how value is created, including demand can be derived ULO3 - understand concepts relating to the economic cost of production in both the short and long run for decision making ULO4 - explain the determinants of price and output outcomes under different market structures as well as business strategies ULO5 - undertake industry analysis ULO6 - apply economics to real world problems.

ULO1 - explain how the economy and the environment interact ULO2 - demonstrate the link between environmental problems and the economic concepts of property rights, externalities and non-excludability ULO3 - critically analyse how market failures contribute to environmental problems ULO4 - provide recommendations on how to correct for market failures.

UNIT_TITLE: Design and evaluation of economic, public, and social programs
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - identify and describe the way in which economists apply microeconomic theories and concepts to analyse various economic and social problems ULO2 - identify and describe the way in which economists evaluate theories and policies ULO3 - apply empirical methods to test the predictions of economic theories and evaluate the effectiveness of economic, public, and social programs ULO4 - critically evaluate and effectively communicate current debates on policy-relevant issues ULO5 - demonstrate the ability to evaluate the contributions and limitations of economic analysis for understanding and informing policy options.

ULO1 - examine the so-called 'peculiar' characteristics of sports markets and the policy conclusions that follow ULO2 - analyse the role economic incentives play in determining the behaviour of controlling bodies, leagues, clubs, players, fans, sponsors, the media and government ULO3 - compare and contrast the key features of various sports markets in Australia and overseas ULO4 - use the economic analysis learnt to develop appropriate policies to address economic problems in the sports industry.

ULO1 - understand the key physical and economic features of electricity markets that differ from more standard commodity markets ULO2 - understand the economic incentives that energy market participants face and how they respond to different environmental policies ULO3 - appreciate the complexity of designing energy and environmental policy that meets affordability, reliability and low-pollution goals with focus on the Australian situation ULO4 - understand the main economic drivers for a variety of non-renewable and renewable energy sources.

ULO1 - understand the general outline of economic development ULO2 - critically examine the major explanations of the dynamics of growth and change in the economy over the last centuries ULO3 - critically evaluate and effectively communicate current debates on causes and consequences of economic growth ULO4 - acquire a historical understanding of current economic circumstances.

ULO1 - understand neoclassical economics models of decision making and scientific findings showing how empirically individuals may depart from the predictions of neoclassical models (also known as behavioural irrationality)? ?? ULO2 - provide alternative behavioural models that are used to explain the behavioural irrationality ULO3 - apply the knowledge from behavioural economics to analyse real-world problems, such as policy making, contract designing, marketing, and management ULO4 - propose behavioural economics interventions to reduce inefficiencies resulting from cognitive biases.

ULO1 - identify real situations where game theory can be enlightening ULO2 - put a real situation into game theoretical formalism ULO3 - manipulate the formalism via game theory to reveal insights ULO4 - comprehend and critically assess complex strategies.

UNIT_TITLE: Prosperity, poverty and sustainability in a globalised world
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - apply modern sustainability thinking to the idea of economic prosperity ULO2 - identify sources of connectedness in a complex economy-society-planet system through an economic lens ULO3 - analyse dynamic models and frameworks of economic prosperity and poverty alleviation ULO4 - critically assess prominent economic policies that address at least one major environmental externality facing the planet ULO5 - develop critical and creative thinking, writing and reviewing skills.

ULO1 - understand economic experiments as a scientific method ULO2 - understand the scope of economic experiments ULO3 - identify real situations in which experiments can be enlightening ULO4 - design an experiment capturing a real situation.

ULO1 - understand the possible impacts of climate change on economies ULO2 - analyse the economic costs of climate change, and how industries can adapt to climate change at minimum cost ULO3 - understand how economic instruments such as carbon taxes and emissions trading schemes can mitigate climate change ULO4 - analyse how key industries such as electricity and transport can respond to climate change policies and lessen emissions.

ULO1 - develop rigorous economic analysis to assess contemporary monetary theory and policy ULO2 - discuss the use of empirical and theoretical models to assess the conduct of monetary policy ULO3 - develop theoretical frameworks to understand the factors governing the relationship between monetary forces and economic activity ULO4 - understand the principles, techniques and problems of implementing monetary policies ULO5 - critically assess current controversies in monetary policy.

ULO1 - apply rigorous economic analysis in studying key issues in development economics ULO2 - apply new analytical frameworks and new areas in development where economic analysis can be used ULO3 - discuss the use of econometric and other empirical methodologies for assessing the relevance of economic models ULO4 - develop meaningful questions with deep policy significance in the area of development ULO5 - demonstrate confidence in applying relevant microeconomic or macroeconomic techniques to key issues in developing countries; use (where appropriate) econometric and other methodologies to analyse data sets from developing countries to address key policy questions; and critically read specialist articles in development economics.

ULO1 - understand the key drivers of international trade ULO2 - understand the sources of the gains from trade ULO3 - understand the impact of capital movements and migration on domestic economic outcomes ULO4 - understand the effects of trade policies on the distribution of rents across countries as well as domestic economic actors such as producers, consumers, and the government ULO5 - understand the implications of international interdependence on national income accounts and the exchange rate.

ULO1 - build a conceptual framework that allows students to analyse the incentives and behaviour that determine the labour demand and labour supply decisions, and how these generate an equilibrium in the labour market ULO2 - develop the theoretical and empirical tools to understand the labour market effects of a range of policies and economic changes. Example of such policies or economic changes include, but are not limited to: minimum wage laws, technological changes, welfare programs, educational and on-the-job training programs, affirmative actions ULO3 - develop the skills to critically examine contemporary issues such as labour mobility, labour market discrimination and income inequality.

ULO1 - understand the function of financial markets and intermediation in the modern economy ULO2 - understand how consumers and firms choose their portfolios and investment ULO3 - understand the trade-off between risk and return ULO4 - understand the consequences of financial decision making by firms and households at the micro and macro levels.

ULO1 - discuss critically how different economists in the past understood and analysed the economic problem ULO2 - compare the work on founders of economics such as Adam Smith, David Ricardo, Thomas Malthus, Stanley Jevons, Karl Marx, Alfred Marshall, and others ULO3 - discuss critically diverse theories of value, growth, rent, and decline of economic society ULO4 - be familiar with primary sources relating to the major writings that shaped the evolution of economic analysis.

ULO1 - understand the basic economic concepts and principles applied in the public finance area ULO2 - analyse specific policy issues in the area of public expenditure and taxation from the perspectives of both traditional public finance and public choice ULO3 - critically evaluate contemporary public debate on topics in public finance ULO4 - understand the usefulness and limitations of economic analysis in the public finance area ULO5 - identify both market failure and government failure and understand the causes of each.

ULO1 - explain the basis for competition and rationale for regulation, and the basis of different theories of regulation ULO2 - evaluate the impacts of certain market conducts such as horizontal mergers, vertical integration, exclusive dealing and collusion ULO3 - understand the main features of competition policies in Australia and around the world ULO4 - understand the variety of approaches to competition policies from the international perspective ULO5 - critically evaluate attempts to increase competition in particular industries, such as online retailing, electricity, telecommunications and other relevant industries, where there are ongoing antitrust and regulation concerns.

ULO1 - develop the ability to read and understand the mathematics used in economics ULO2 - develop the ability to formulate an economic question as a mathematical problem ULO3 - learn to apply basic optimisation techniques.

ULO1 - identify real situations where network effects matter ULO2 - put a real situation with social interactions into game theoretical formalism ULO3 - propose adequate policies that are different when network effects matter and when they do not ULO4 - understand the impact of network structure on agents' behaviour.

UNIT_TITLE: Political economy: Institutions, order, and evidence

ULO1 - recognise differences in market structures and understand how those differences affect firms' competitive behaviour and performance ULO2 - understand how and why competition causes changes in market structures by way of mergers, acquisitions, vertical integration and diversification ULO3 - explain the economic rationale for competitive weapons utilised by business in contemporary competitive environment, such as barriers to entry, pricing and advertising strategies, product differentiation, and innovation ULO4 - explain the rationale for regulation and merits of different theories of regulation ULO5 - explain the arguments for and against privatisation ULO6 - understand the main features of national competition policies in the countries of particular interest to Monash University in Australia and overseas ULO7 - critically evaluate attempts to increase competition in particular industries, e.g. aviation, electricity and telecommunications, where there are ongoing reforms.

ULO1 - demonstrate a sound understanding of the historical evolving of the Chinese economy in the context of global business and economy ULO2 - critically review Chinas development strategy since 1978 and the sustainability of the current development model from an economic and environmental perspective ULO3 - critically evaluate the opportunities and challenges of the integration of China with the global economy on trade, investment, and international cooperation ULO4 - develop a strategic perspective on issues facing multinational doing business in China, with insights into successful business models.

ULO1 - apply basic concepts of economic analysis to an understanding of Asian economies ULO2 - describe and interpret emerging economic trends in the Asian region, specifically in the selected Asian economies ULO3 - appreciate the main characteristics of the business environment in the selected Asian economies ULO4 - understand the role of government and the market as allocators of resources and engines of development ULO5 - critically evaluate the dynamics of growth and change in selected Asian economies.

ULO1 - understand the key historical steps of the European Union and the monetary union ULO2 - understand the strategic operations of business operating in the European community ULO3 - comprehend the complexity of the European Union and the economic challenges that businesses and countries will have to face to reach a perfect integration ULO4 - develop a strategic perspective on issues facing multinationals doing business in Europe, with insights into successful business models.

ULO1 - understand the basic economic approach to critically thinking about environmental problems and policy ULO2 - understand the major policies that exist to solve specific environmental problems ULO3 - identify weaknesses in current environmental policy and offer suggestions for how they can be improved ULO4 - demonstrate the ability to consume and synthesize the current empirical evidence on specific environmental problems/policies ULO5 - understand the major environmental challenges facing the developing world.

ULO1 - appreciate the economic way of thinking, the methodology of microeconomics and a knowledge of the tools used by economists in problem solving ULO2 - understand the economic behaviour of individual consumers and producers and how value is created, including demand can be derived ULO3 - understand concepts relating to the economic cost of production in both the short and long run for decision making ULO4 - explain the determinants of price and output outcomes under different market structures as well as business strategies ULO5 - undertake industry analysis ULO6 - apply economics to real world problems.

ULO1 - understand and analyse critically the economic reasons for government intervention to reduce the adverse effects of restrictive trade practices ULO2 - understand the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (and its predecessor, the Trade Practices Commission) ULO3 - evaluate recent decisions from the perspectives of an economist, lawyer, policy-maker and business manager ULO4 - research in-depth a current problem area relating to competition policy and practices that requires investigation beyond topics covered in lectures.

ULO1 - understand the central role of the concept of counterfactual in policy analysis ULO2 - understand the importance of randomisation as the credibility standard, as well as its limitations and difficulties ULO3 - understand the value of different observational designs.

ULO1 - apply basic concepts of economic analysis to an understanding of Asian economies ULO2 - describe and interpret emerging economic trends in the Asian region, specifically in the selected Asian economies ULO3 - appreciate the main characteristics of the business environment in the selected Asian economies ULO4 - understand the role of government and the market as allocators of resources and engines of development ULO5 - critically evaluate the dynamics of growth and change in selected Asian economies.

ULO1 - demonstrate a sound understanding of the historical evolving of the Chinese economy in the context of global business and economy ULO2 - critically review Chinas development strategy since 1978 and the sustainability of the current development model from an economic and environmental perspective ULO3 - critically evaluate the opportunities and challenges of the integration of China with the global economy on trade, investment, and international cooperation ULO4 - develop a strategic perspective on issues facing multinational doing business in China, with insights into successful business models.

ULO1 - understand the possible impacts of climate change on economics ULO2 - analyse the economic costs of climate change, and how industries can adapt to climate change at minimum cost ULO3 - understand how economic instruments such as carbon taxes and emissions trading schemes can mitigate climate change ULO4 - analyse how key industries such as electricity and transport can respond to climate change policies and lessen emissions.

ULO1 - analyse the effects of international trade on real income and its distribution in various market structures ULO2 - understand the allocation and welfare effects of commercial policies ULO3 - possess the skills necessary to evaluate critically contemporary innovations in Australia's trade policies.

ULO1 - Understand the principles and expectations of university scholarship ULO2 - Employ relevant theoretical and practical knowledge in a range of skills central to university learning, including critical reading and writing ULO3 - Exercise the skills necessary to maximise their learning from lectures, tutorials and teaching materials ULO4 - Produce essays and reports that present a critical argument and adhere to the conventions of academic presentation.

ULO1 - Demonstrate a grasp of the relationship between knowledge and context ULO2 - Demonstrate some familiarity with a variety of knowledge traditions ULO3 - Demonstrate independent research skills ULO4 - Construct a bibliography and correctly use citations ULO5 - Write well-structured essays ULO6 - Prepare for and deliver an oral report.

ULO1 - Apply your mathematics knowledge to solve problems in a range of contexts ULO2 - Solve problems requiring linear or curved graphing skills, including sketching, identifying key features and finding equations ULO3 - Apply correct procedures to solve financial application problems, and interpret the solutions ULO4 - Summarise, present and interpret data numerically and graphically ULO5 - Select and apply appropriate procedures for the solution of probability problems, including recognition of dependent and independent events ULO6 - Calculate operation on matrices, including by-hand calculations involving identity and inverse matrices ULO7 - Generate an arithmetic or geometric sequence or series using a recurrence relation, and solve problems in practical contexts.

ULO1 - Understand the components of written academic compositions ULO2 - Structure written academic pieces, demonstrating cohesive sentence and paragraph structuring to progress a coherent argument and perspective ULO3 - Have well developed referencing and attribution practices that adequately cite the work of contributing sources ULO4 - Produce essays and reports that present a critical argument and adhere to the conventions of academic presentation.

UNIT_TITLE: Working in education: An introduction to the profession
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - show an understanding of the structures, policies, behaviours, practices and requirements of the profession ULO2 - orient yourself as an emerging professional within a range of frameworks and legislation that guide the profession of teaching, including curriculum, child safety, teacher standards, improvement frameworks and relevant codes of conduct and ethics ULO3 - demonstrate a developing understanding of the everyday practices, routines and roles connected to teaching as a profession ULO4 - articulate your professional obligations, emerging orientations and educational philosophies ULO5 - exhibit a range of personal and interpersonal capabilities that meet or exceed professional expectations ULO6 - showcase foundational knowledge, skills and understandings of concepts associated with the work ofteaching (curriculum, planning, pedagogy, assessment, reporting) ULO7 - demonstrate understanding of a range of communication skills required in educational and professional settings.

ULO1 - demonstrate knowledge of a variety of teaching approaches and resources to accommodate a range of abilities and interests ULO2 - practice and apply effective goal setting, worked examples, collaborative learning, questioning, feedback and metacognitive approaches to teaching and learning ULO3 - utilise research-informed evidence base to critique or justify a range of teaching and learning approaches within scenarios/case studies or role-playing ULO4 - plan and deliver an effective whole group teaching and learning episode, demonstrating a rationale and effective application of core pedagogical approaches ULO5 - illustrate emerging approaches and techniques to positively and effectively manage teaching and learning contexts (i.e. teacher presence, learner management, resource management, discourse practices) ULO6 - demonstrate understanding of a range of communication skills required in educational and professional settings.

ULO1 - develop an understanding of the role of creativity and the visual arts in young childrens learning ULO2 - demonstrate skills in working creatively in the arts across a variety of materials and processes suitable for young children ULO3 - demonstrate an understanding of theoretical and practical knowledge to effectively plan, teach, document and evaluate quality learning in the visual arts that engage learners of diverse backgrounds and abilities ULO4 - develop and show an understanding of how the visual arts enable children to communicate in multiple ways that link to environment, sustainability, community and culture (including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander, Asia and Pacific perspectives) and information and communication technologies (ICTs) ULO5 - communicate arts-based research through clear presentation, proficient and appropriate writing, well-designed??? layout and cohesive and selective use of images and text ULO6 - apply socially and environmentally active ways to move art education towards sustainability.

UNIT_TITLE: Creative connections 2: Music and performing arts
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - develop practical skills and knowledge in fostering childrens meaning-making and communication through music, dance and drama in early childhood ULO2 - demonstrate an understanding of contemporary approaches and learning theories related to childrens development of communication and creativity through performing arts pedagogies ULO3 - demonstrate an understanding of designing, implementing, documenting and evaluating meaningful performing arts experiences that respond to learners of diverse characteristics and abilities ULO4 - develop capacities for socially engaged early childhood education through an understanding of research and practice in culturally responsive performing arts pedagogy ULO5 - communicate arts-based research through a range of verbal, non-verbal, information and communication technologies and digital arts

ULO1 - recognise the characteristics of mathematical problem solvers, apply these, and translate these to young mathematicians learning ULO2 - demonstrate broad and flexible understanding of the concepts that underpin the mathematics curriculum in the early years ULO3 - display confidence in your capacity to engage in mathematical activity and in your ability to continue to learn mathematical subject knowledge for teaching ULO4 - effectively communicate mathematics to your peers and lecturer, using a variety of media, including information and communication technologies (ICTs) ULO5 - articulate how your learning experiences in the unit relate to teaching and learning mathematics in early childhood settings and primary schools.

ULO1 - reflect on understandings of what literacy is and what it means to be literate ULO2 - critically reflect upon and develop your own personal English and literacy skills ULO3 - demonstrate an understanding of how early literacy is enacted in various cultural and socialsettings, particularly homes and school ULO4 - develop knowledge of effective pedagogies for early literacy learning ULO5 - understand the continuities and transitions in literacy learning from home to school.

ULO1 - describe how early childhood education is governed and show familiarity with key policies, curriculum, and targeted programs and directions ULO2 - discuss roles and responsibilities as a pre-service teacher of early childhood education and demonstrate a developing understanding of your professional, legal and ethical requirements ULO3 - examine and research early childhood educations history, philosophies and theories and how they have informed early childhood education today ULO4 - critically discuss and define key concepts informing early childhood ULO5 - make informed decisions about your own developing understandings of children, childhood and early childhood education pedagogy based on your understandings of the role of history in explaining and defining early childhood education in contemporary Australian society.

UNIT_TITLE: Contemporary approaches to learning for young children: Theories and practices
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - develop and demonstrate broad knowledge and understanding of contemporary theories of childdevelopment for childrens learning ULO2 - identify the application of key theoretical concepts within mandatory curricula frameworks acrosslocal, national and international contexts ULO3 - develop the ability to critically select key theoretical concepts and apply them in practice to supporthigh quality teaching and learning ULO4 - engage in rigorous discussion and decision making about the theory-practice nexus to showdeveloping understanding and sensitivity to childrens learning and development within context

UNIT_TITLE: Global and cross-cultural understandings of education
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - explain the different meanings of education globally ULO2 - demonstrate how education has influenced your own life and that of your extended family over time ULO3 - identify the different ways in which culture has and can affect the philosophy and delivery of education ULO4 - describe frameworks that support cross cultural teaching and learning and how they could be used in practice ULO5 - identify teaching strategies that are responsive to the needs of students from diverse linguistic, cultural, religious and socio-economic backgrounds.

ULO1 - understand both childhood and adolescence (P-12) as periods of diverse individual development,behaviours and relationships in society ULO2 - understand and apply various approaches to fostering positive interactions in classroom contextsacross P-12, including developing a broad range of strategies for involving parents/carers in theeducative process to maximise success for students with diverse needs ULO3 - understand and apply various approaches to managing challenging behaviours in classroomcontexts across P-12, including developing a broad range of strategies for involving parents/carersin the educative process to maximise success for students with diverse needs ULO4 - examine the likely impact of factors such as culture, family, genetic inheritance, environment andlife experiences on children and adolescents ULO5 - analyse a range of learning theories, contemporary theoretical perspectives and practicalapproaches to fostering positive interactions ULO6 - identify effective teaching strategies that support positive interactions and or address challengingbehaviours, whilst enhancing learning.

UNIT_TITLE: Introduction to health and physical education
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - articulate a socio-critical perspective of Health and Physical Education (HPE) as a curriculum area ULO2 - draw upon a range of sources to articulate the aim and rationale of HPE ULO3 - demonstrate an understanding of the content and structure of the Australian/Victorian Curriculum: HPE, and use it to plan for learning and assessment ULO4 - demonstrate an ability to apply and evaluate the use of different pedagogical models and approaches in Health and Physical Education, including High Impact Teaching Strategies ULO5 - identify and apply basic classroom management strategies ULO6 - identify, source and use relevant academic literature to support ideas.

UNIT_TITLE: Sociocultural foundations of health and physical education
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - identify and describe historical, philosophical, sociological, psychological, cultural and politicaldrivers of knowledge and practice in health and physical education, health, physical activity andsport ULO2 - evaluate the influence of sociocultural factors on historical and contemporary policies andpractices in health and physical education, health, physical activity and sport contexts ULO3 - describe how sociocultural factors shape wellbeing, safety and participation in health andphysical education, health, physical activity and sport ULO4 - analyse how varied and changing personal and contextual factors shape understandings of, andopportunities for, health and physical activity locally, regionally and globally ULO5 - demonstrate academic skills of accessing appropriate quality sources of information, extractingrelevant information, summarising and communicating effectively.

UNIT_TITLE: Biophysical and behavioural foundations of health and physical education
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - discuss the biophysical factors that shape individual and community health and wellbeing and physical activity ULO2 - articulate important biophysical theory and content knowledge ULO3 - acquire and apply skills associated with the biophysical sub-discipline in physical activity and health contexts ULO4 - demonstrate familiarity with the appropriate use of specialist equipment commonly used in the biophysical context ULO5 - analyse how varied and changing personal and contextual factors impact the biophysical and subsequent opportunities for health and physical activity.

UNIT_TITLE: Health and education: Frameworks, concepts and practices
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - identify and explain frameworks, concepts and practices relating to Health and Education ULO2 - describe you own practices and experiences of health and wellbeing situated in the largernational/international context and meanings ULO3 - demonstrate academic and research skills in order to evaluate health information ULO4 - create a resource to demonstrate contemporary knowledge associated with foundational healthpractices with an educational intent ULO5 - reflect upon a health and wellbeing framework or practice to demonstrate an understanding offoundational health concepts ULO6 - communicate ideas to others using an appropriate range of verbal and nonverbal communicationstrategies and collaborative techniques

UNIT_TITLE: Games-based approaches to health and physical education
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - use various approaches to plan and deliver movement experiences that are challenging, safe and well structured ULO2 - develop knowledge, skills and understanding related to games-based approaches, and Game Sense in particular ULO3 - demonstrate an understanding of how invasion, net and wall, striking and fielding, and target games could be taught using a Game Sense approach ULO5 - demonstrate your capacity to incorporate Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander/First People's histories, cultures and languages into sport and games delivery

UNIT_TITLE: Beyond the classroom: Local and global learning
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - describe and understand the value and impact of environmental and sustainability education as a way of delivering cross-curriculum ULO2 - critically reflect upon your environmental and sustainability experiences and their connections to place ULO3 - communicate the importance of Country within Indigenous culture and integrate into teaching practice to celebrate its ongoing ULO4 - ?research, develop and present a learning experience for environment and sustainability.

ULO1 - develop a learning and teaching activity using digital technologies ULO2 - demonstrate an emerging knowledge of ICT resources that engage students in learning ULO3 - demonstrate an emerging knowledge of strategies that can be used to evaluate teaching programs to improve student learning ULO4 - demonstrate the capacity to organise a classroom activity and provide clear directions ULO5 - demonstrate awareness of relevant issues and strategies that support the safe, responsible and ethical use of ICT in learning and teaching.

ULO1 - complete the required number of days of professional experience and activities specified in theprofessional experience expectations document ULO2 - document your professional learning through means such as a professional experience folderwhich records lesson planning, self-reflections and an evaluation on developing practice ULO3 - achieve a satisfactory level of progress in your development as a teacher in line with the activities specifiedin the professional experience expectations document and the professional experience report.

UNIT_TITLE: Learning and teaching across school contexts
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - identify core similarities and differences to approaches for teaching and learning across primary, middle years and secondary schooling contexts ULO2 - select objectives and outcomes appropriate to different teaching contexts ULO3 - identify and address challenges and opportunities for preparing to teach in Primary and/or Secondary educational contexts ULO4 - understand key principles of child and adolescent development across schooling contexts ULO5 - identify how changes across schooling contexts might impact teacher/student relationships ULO6 - describe what safe and supportive learning might look like across different schooling contexts ULO7 - use appropriate theories of learning to inform understandings of teaching and learning across schooling contexts.

UNIT_TITLE: Learning and teaching for students with diverse needs in various education settings
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - critically analyse research evidence that supports the use of different learning and teachingpractices ULO2 - identify a range of effective and evidence-based learning and teaching strategies for students withdisabilities to support inclusive student participation and engagement in classroom activities ULO3 - create lesson plans incorporating evidence-based strategies to provide inclusive and personalisedlearning for diverse learners ULO4 - develop and practise positive relationship and communication skills between teachers andstudents ULO5 - demonstrate understanding of principles of effective planning and reflect upon your own practice

ULO1 - demonstrate understanding and critically analyse how society and schools understand and respond to individual differences to ensure inclusive education ULO2 - build understanding of how a range of educational settings support the learning of students with disabilities ULO3 - recognise how policies, legislation and research impacts on schools' and teachers' varied approaches to the education of students with disabilities ULO4 - show evidence of understanding the critical roles educators play in ensuring the positive experiences and successful learning of learners with disabilities in various educational settings.

UNIT_TITLE: Understanding behaviour in classrooms and schools
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - identify factors necessary for creating engaging classrooms for all learners, including those withdisabilities ULO2 - critically examine significant research that can be used by educators to create engaging classroomenvironments ULO3 - learn about theories and strategies that can be used to create engaging classrooms for all ULO4 - understand the need to collaborate with parents and other stakeholders in creating engagingclassrooms

UNIT_TITLE: Fieldwork experience in outdoor education and environmental studies 1A
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Adapt experiential knowledge and skills in diverse outdoor environmental contexts ULO2 - Demonstrate skills to review and analyse individual learning needs in professional practice ULO3 - Complete the required number of days of fieldwork experience and the activities specified in the fieldwork experience guides for this unit ULO4 - Record, through a fieldwork experience logbook, their field-based learning and self-reflections on their developing knowledge and skills in professional practice.

UNIT_TITLE: Fieldwork experience in outdoor education and environmental studies 1B
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Adapt experiential knowledge and skills in diverse outdoor environmental contexts ULO2 - Develop skills to review and analyse individual learning needs in professional practice ULO3 - Complete the required number of days of fieldwork experience and the activities specified in the professional experience guides for this unit ULO4 - Record, through a fieldwork experience logbook, their field-based learning and self-reflections on their developing knowledge and skills in professional practice.

ULO1 - Identify a range of theoretical perspectives on effective English and literacy teaching and learning approaches ULO2 - Understand the importance of using a variety of texts and literature as part of an effective literacy program ULO3 - Demonstrate competence in the use of a range of information and communication technologies (ICT) in accessing relevant research literature, developing teaching resources and strategies, and presenting evidence of their own learning in the area of English and literacy ULO4 - Understand the connections between home, community and school literacy practices for the teaching and learning of literacy ULO5 - Demonstrate an understanding of primary school curriculum relation to literacy learning.

ULO1 - Further develop your repertoire of teaching skills and strategies that promote purposeful, meaningful, engaging, innovative, creative, intellectually challenging, and authentic learning ULO2 - Create positive and productive classroom environments which respond to individual needs, issues and dynamics within the classroom ULO3 - Demonstrate effective teaching skills such as planning and organisation; monitoring and assessing learning; meeting diverse student learning needs; effective classroom management; and developing collaborative, integrated and negotiated curriculum ULO4 - Use a range of specific teaching and learning skills such as reflection, problem solving, negotiation, risk taking, innovation, and creativity ULO5 - Work effectively with peers, students, parents, school authorities and other educational professionals ULO6 - Explore some of the broader roles of teachers in the life of a school such as meetings, professional development, policy formulation, parent-teacher meetings, extra-curricular activities and community-based activities ULO7 - Demonstrate an awareness of teachers' professional responsibilities, ethics and relationships and the changing nature of the role of teachers and schooling.

ULO1 - Build professional knowledge of Victorian curriculum priorities and Australian curriculum capabilities ULO2 - Implement these through planning and developing teaching and learning approaches based on relevant curriculum documents ULO3 - Access and utilise a range of resources for teaching and learning and assessment practices related to these priorities and capabilities ULO4 - Understand and critically comment on a specific education priority.

ULO1 - Appreciate adolescence as a discrete period of individual development in our society ULO2 - Articulate theories of adolescent development from a scientific viewpoint ULO3 - Explain the developmental stages of adolescence ULO4 - Understand how teacher-student relationships are influenced by issues of adolescent development ULO5 - Identify problems in teaching adolescents and apply effective teaching strategies to support their learning ULO6 - Analyse multidimensional influences on adolescents including; motivations; self-esteem; anxiety, stress, resilience; biological processes; cognition; moral development; development of identity; family, peer and sociocultural influences; issues of diversity; additional issues including substance abuse, deviance, depression, truancy and bullying for diverse learners ULO7 - Use relevant resources to support adolescents' development.

ULO1 - Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the social, cultural and political nature of disciplinary knowledge and how this knowledge is embedded within particular 'ways of knowing' ULO2 - Understand the relationship between curriculum, teaching practice and disciplinary knowledge ULO3 - Inquire into, and develop, your professional identity as a specialist teacher ULO4 - Apply broad knowledge and understanding of legislative requirements and teaching strategies that support participation and learning of diverse students including those with special needs and with disabilities ULO5 - Understand the complex relationships between content knowledge and pedagogy and between school knowledge, disciplinary knowledge and everyday knowledge ULO6 - Cultivate an appreciation of integrated, interdisciplinary and disciplinary based curriculum and how 'specialist' teachers in interdisciplinary teams might collaborate productively in this curriculum ULO7 - Design and produce resources for encouraging a rich engagement with particular disciplinary knowledge, capacities and skills ULO8 - Critically evaluate your practicum experiences in schools and other settings.

ULO1 - Understand and apply research and contemporary practices in mathematics and numeracy education to meet diverse learners' needs ULO2 - Recognise how key mathematical concepts are practised in early learning settings including homes, child care, preschools and the early years of school ULO3 - Use a range of appropriate strategies to assist children's development of number sense particularly in the early years of school ULO4 - Apply techniques that link mathematics to practical applications particularly in relation to measurement and geometry ULO5 - Appreciate that numeracy learning occurs in multiple contexts and in multiple ways ULO6 - Identify and employ a range of pedagogical tools and strategies to support children's learning in mathematics and numeracy in line with local and Australian curriculum.

UNIT_TITLE: Health, wellbeing and social learning in primary contexts
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Discuss key concepts and definitions related to your own and young children's health, wellbeing and social learning ULO2 - Identify and analyse key factors that contribute to your own and children's health ULO3 - Demonstrate an understanding of socio-cultural, socio-emotional and ecological perspectives on health and wellbeing ULO4 - Explain the role that schools play in promoting health and wellbeing within contemporary public health, wellbeing and education policy ULO5 - Demonstrate an understanding of how social and emotional health status impacts upon yourself and young people, and plan school-based programs that draw from contemporary health-promoting school programs and curriculum frameworks.

UNIT_TITLE: Active citizenship and community connections: Local and global
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand and evaluate how the learning area of active citizenship in local and global contexts is structured within the Australian Curriculum and the Victorian Curriculum F-10 ULO2 - Develop knowledge and understanding of different theoretical and pedagogical approaches to active citizenship ULO3 - Design and implement primary lessons and units of work using themes and integrated approaches to active citizenship ULO4 - Locate, evaluate and use a variety of appropriate teaching resources and educational providers that support the teaching of active citizenship.

UNIT_TITLE: Contemporary child development theories and practices
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Develop and demonstrate knowledge and understanding of contemporary theories of child development ULO2 - Link and apply this knowledge to pedagogy and curriculum design ULO3 - Develop your capacities as pedagogical leaders of children's learning and development ULO4 - Apply key concepts explored in the unit to mandatory curricula frameworks in local and national contexts.

UNIT_TITLE: Indigenous perspectives on teaching and learning
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate broad knowledge of, understanding of and respect for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, histories, cultures and languages ULO2 - Demonstrate knowledge of Indigenous rights, language and celebration ULO3 - Understand cultural protocols and terms as they pertain to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples ULO4 - Demonstrate understanding of the impact of culture, cultural identity and linguistic background on the education of students from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander backgrounds by developing culturally responsive curriculum practices.

ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding of the importance of learning through play pedagogies ULO2 - Develop an understanding of curricular documents and their application within play-based curricula ULO3 - Critically analyse the research base underpinning the range of theoretical perspectives on play-based learning ULO4 - Develop an understanding of a range of tools and methods to assess children's learning in play ULO5 - Use contemporary theories of play to creatively explore possibilities for pedagogical practice change in early childhood settings, primary schools, families and communities.

UNIT_TITLE: Learning with children, their families and communities
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Develop a critical understanding of theoretical and practical interrelationships of diverse children's learning development and their broader family and social context, including children from different socio-economic, cultural and language backgrounds ULO2 - Assess the impact of contemporary real-life issues on children's learning development in the context of multicultural families and communities ULO3 - Observe sensitively and analyse general and specific children's learning behaviours and skills that can be used in planning and evaluation of support/learning strategies ULO4 - Demonstrate the ability to design innovative learning with children, their families and communities ULO5 - Exhibit knowledge of teaching and learning strategies that are responsive to the learning strengths and needs of children from a range of linguistic, cultural, religious and socio-economic backgrounds.

UNIT_TITLE: Learning about patterns, shapes and numbers through play
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate understanding of key curriculum practice relating to learning mathematically through play, games and resources for young learners ULO2 - Understand children's learning of different aspects of mathematics through the innovative use of ICTs and their implications for teaching ULO3 - Identify and use effective pedagogical approaches to the teaching and learning of mathematics in the early years through play ULO4 - Implement classroom strategies using play, shapes and numbers that link mathematics to practical applications, particularly in relation to pattern, shape and number ULO5 - Understand the importance of and develop techniques for adopting inclusive practices in relation to the teaching and learning of mathematics.

UNIT_TITLE: Health and physical wellbeing in the young child
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Learn and apply research, policies, practices and strategies to support all children and their families to be healthy and active ULO2 - Demonstrate familiarity with community groups and amenities that promote health and physical wellbeing ULO3 - Support a holistic and rights based approach to health and wellbeing based on the UNCRC document ULO4 - Apply approaches to health and wellbeing promotion for children, their families and community with explicit emphasis on diversity and inclusion.

UNIT_TITLE: Curriculum, assessment and documentation in education
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate in-depth understanding of the curriculum guidelines, documentation, assessment and evaluation policies relevant to local, regional and national context ULO2 - Demonstrate the ability to observe, document, analyse, assess and evaluate children's learning and reflect on curriculum effectiveness in your own practice ULO3 - Apply curriculum theories and design to the development of culturally inclusive programs in diverse settings for children ULO4 - Demonstrate reflexive practice to develop effective curriculum, assessment and documentation in education.

UNIT_TITLE: Children and childhood across time: Policies and practices
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand the changing concepts of childhood over time and place ULO2 - Begin to critically analyse how educational philosophies have shaped ideas of childhood ULO3 - Demonstrate critical thinking to develop new understandings of how young children's lives are historically embedded in socio-economic, cultural and political contexts ULO4 - Critically reflect on implications for early years' educational leadership.

ULO1 - demonstrate a broad understanding of play-based learning theoriesapply contemporary play-based learning theories to creatively explore possibilities for pedagogical practices in early childhood settings, primary schools, families and communities ULO2 - critically analyse the research base underpinning the range of theoretical perspectives on play-based learning ULO3 - critically consider the application of play-based learning theories for children from diverse linguistic, cultural and socio-economic backgrounds ULO4 - identify and discuss implications for practice connections between curriculum framework documents and play-based learning theories ULO5 - develop a broad understanding of pedagogical tools and methods to assess childrens learning through play

ULO1 - understand, discuss and apply key theoretical concepts underpinning contemporary childhood ULO2 - identify and investigate a range of issues currently impacting on childhoods and discuss the role of education in working with children to address these issues ULO3 - identify pedagogical approaches that enable teachers to design learning for children and create possibilities for practices that uphold childrens rights as global citizens

ULO1 - demonstrate knowledge of the different concepts, models and frameworks of wellbeing ULO2 - demonstrate knowledge of contemporary contexts and resources related to teacher wellbeingand student wellbeing ULO3 - apply understandings of contemporary contexts to select appropriate wellbeing strategies ULO4 - understand, utilise and have participated experientially in a variety of wellbeing pedagogies thatpromote learning in the area ULO5 - develop, design and plan resources for particular audiences.

ULO1 - understand the theoretical basis of creativity and arts-rich practice in primary educationalcontexts ULO2 - interpret and understand the place of the creative arts content and pedagogy within the widerprimary curriculum ULO3 - adopt a reflective approach and enact a range of creative planning, performing and teachingstrategies ULO4 - apply understandings of arts-rich pedagogies in the development of learning activities thatengage children in deep understanding, expression of personal identity and development of civicand social justice action.

ULO1 - describe and understand the implications for teachers and schools of key Victorian, national and international policies pertaining to ensuring students' wellbeing and safety, social justice, equity and inclusion of students from diverse linguistic, cultural, religious and socio-economic backgrounds ULO2 - understand relevant legislative, administrative and organisational policies and processes required for teachers and schools and how these impact on practice ULO3 - critically investigate the ways in which a range of policies and priority areas are implemented at school and classroom levels and know how to apply these in practice.

ULO1 - explain the importance and role of planning within the teaching and learning practice ULO2 - develop a clear understanding of the role of curriculum frameworks in teaching and learning ULO3 - apply principles of effective planning in order to design effective learning programs that maximise learner's opportunities and progression ULO4 - demonstrate connections between assessment, reporting and planning for learning ULO5 - critically reflect upon and evaluate the effectiveness of implemented plans and utilise informed approaches to refine and improve planning for learning.

ULO1 - identify and critically review a range of assessment practices to determine their fit for purpose and alignment with curriculum and pedagogy ULO2 - effectively select a range of assessment practices and reporting strategies to inform planning, support teaching and learning, evaluate progress, empower learners, provide effective feedback, benchmark and suggest ways to improve practice ULO3 - draw on a range of resources (including effective use of ICT) to support well developed assessment practices, communicate outcomes effectively and adjust practice accordingly ULO4 - use assessment data to inform teaching and improve learning outcomes ULO5 - work effectively in small groups to analyse multiple sources of student data, moderate assessments, suggest ways to improve teacher practice and evaluate the impact of teaching on learning.

ULO1 - reflect upon and develop your own English and literacy skills as a future classroom practitioner ULO2 - demonstrate an understanding of various theoretical perspectives related to how young children develop their literacy knowledge, skills and understanding ULO3 - explore effective ways to plan, teach and assess learning experiences to develop young children's early reading, writing, oral language and new literacies ULO4 - learn how to differentiate learning experiences for children with a wide range of experiences and abilities ULO5 - describe a range of strategies for involving parents/carers in childrens literacy learning and for working with them effectively, sensitively and confidentially.

ULO1 - demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the Number and Algebra strand in the mathematics curriculum ULO2 - draw on a range of theoretical perspectives to understand childrens learning of number and algebraic concepts ULO3 - plan lessons to teach mathematics using open-ended tasks and associated teaching strategies ULO4 - plan a sequence of mathematics lessons to consolidate and extend childrens number learning ULO5 - differentiate teaching to maximise learning and foster engagement for all students ULO6 - promote mathematical understanding, fluency, problem-solving, and reasoning proficiencies using a range of teaching strategies ULO7 - locate, critique, and modify a variety of teaching resources to improve learning outcomes ULO8 - use digital technologies effectively to enhance learning in mathematics.

ULO1 - analyse health and physical education curriculum and practice ULO2 - design and organise content into an effective learning and teaching sequence that is developmentally appropriate for early childhood and primary learners ULO3 - describe a variety of physical education specific pedagogies such as creative games, fundamental motor skills and game-centred approaches, and discuss how they promote physically educative experiences ULO4 - describe and apply health and wellbeing education concepts, including strategies for supporting learner wellbeing and safety.

ULO1 - demonstrate knowledge and understanding of research into how students learn science concepts and the implications for science teaching for early childhood and primary aged learners ULO2 - demonstrate knowledge and understanding of key science concepts, substance and structure of the content and teaching strategies in early childhood and primary science ULO3 - organise specific science content into an effective learning and teaching sequence ULO4 - use your developing curriculum, assessment and reporting knowledge to design learning sequences and lesson plans in science ULO5 - plan lesson sequences using knowledge of student learning, content and effective teaching strategies and resources.

ULO1 - take a critical position with respect to fundamental scholarly concepts in creative arts education and the specifics of dance, drama, music, media arts and visual arts ULO2 - actively demonstrate basic competencies in practical and creative components of one or more of the specific creative arts disciplines as they apply to teaching and learning ULO3 - interpret and understand the place of the creative arts content and pedagogy within the wider primary curriculum ULO4 - adopt a reflective approach and enact a range of inclusive planning, performing, sharing and teaching strategies

ULO1 - demonstrate knowledge of the Humanities and Social Sciences (HASS) curriculum area, especially comparative and unique concepts and skills within Geography, History, Economics and Business, Civics and Citizenship ULO2 - understand how primary school learners develop knowledge, skills and understandings in HASS ULO3 - develop appropriate strategies and techniques for teaching HASS in primary schools ULO4 - plan and develop lessons and units for teaching primary HASS ULO5 - develop inquiry teaching practices that engage primary school learners in active, inquiry-based learning in HASS

UNIT_TITLE: Interdisciplinary approaches to health and physical education
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Display increasingly advanced skills, knowledge and capabilities in programming and planning across schools and curriculum areas in relation to HPE ULO2 - Articulate and devise strategies to implement key priorities in primary and secondary school settings ULO3 - Reflect upon and examine the ways in which relevant policies, practices and theories connect to your pedagogical practice ULO4 - Identify and deploy relevant general capabilities including literacy, numeracy and the use of ICT for teaching and learning ULO5 - Collect and display evidence of the ongoing development of Monash graduate attributes, research and professional teaching skills.

ULO1 - articulate the fundamental concept associated with rhythmic and expressive movement ULO2 - demonstrate basic competencies to teach a range of rhythmic and expressive movement activities ULO3 - explain the theoretical basis of movement analysis as applied to rhythmic and expressive movement ULO4 - identify the place of rhythmic and expressive movement within the health and physical education curriculum and the general capabilities ULO5 - adopt a reflective approach and enact a range of rhythmic and expressive movement planning and teaching strategies to meet the needs of diverse learners

UNIT_TITLE: Skill acquisition and models based practice
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - describe theories of motor control and skill acquisition and how these underpin practice ULO2 - articulate how the body, mind and environment interact in dynamic ways to impact movement outcomes ULO3 - provide a sound justification for particular approaches that might be used to develop motor control and skill acquisition outcomes in sports and movement contexts ULO4 - integrate ICT and performance analysis to assess skill acquisition, provide feedback and support participants learning ULO5 - use various coaching approaches to plan and deliver a sequence of sports and games activities ULO6 - demonstrate your capacity to incorporate Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander/First People's histories, cultures and languages into sport and games delivery.

UNIT_TITLE: Planning, teaching and learning in health and physical education
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - identify and explain the importance of a futures orientation to curriculum policy reform and your role as a policy actor in health and physical education change ULO2 - articulate and devise strategies to implement key curriculum priorities in health and physical education in primary and/or secondary school settings ULO3 - display curriculum navigation skills that connect policies, practices and theories to your professional and/or pedagogical practices ULO4 - apply principles of effective planning in order to design effective health and physical education learning programs and sequences that synthesise curriculum, pedagogy, and assessment ULO5 - collect and display evidence of the ongoing development of research and professional teaching practice skills ULO6 - communicate ideas to others using an appropriate range of verbal and nonverbal communication strategies and collaborative techniques.

ULO1 - demonstrate broad content knowledge and practical skills relating to health, the health status of Australians, youth health, health inequities and health promotion ULO2 - demonstrate specific content knowledge and practical skills in relation to a number of youth health issues, for example: drug use, food and nutrition, body image, and safety ULO3 - display evidence of appreciation of and respect for the ways in which health is experienced and understood by various individuals and groups in society (local, national and international) ULO4 - design, evaluate and apply effective health and health promotion knowledge, theories, frameworks, policies and practices in a variety of contexts and/or settings ULO5 - communicate ideas to others using an appropriate range of verbal and nonverbal communication strategies and collaborative techniques.

UNIT_TITLE: Using assessment to respond to diversity across the school years
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - understand and apply various approaches to assessment used in inclusive classroom contexts across the school years to maximise success for learners with disabilities ULO2 - understand ways standardised assessments can be utilised to assess learning of learners with disabilities ULO3 - determine how the process of assessment can enhance the inclusion and participation of learners with disabilities, including in transition periods ULO4 - understand the ways in which information and communication technologies can be incorporated in learning and assessment of learners with disabilities.

ULO1 - understand the relationship between creative teaching and teaching creativity and criticality ULO2 - articulate the key concepts, content, and skills of critical and creative thinking ULO3 - demonstrate research-informed understandings of how students learn critical and creative dispositions and thinking skills ULO4 - appreciate the challenges associated with teaching and assessing creativity and criticality ULO5 - analyse and evaluate strategies and resources for teaching creativity and criticality.

ULO1 - understand and design strategies for the effective integration of digital technologies within teaching, learning and assessment in the curriculum ULO2 - select and use information and communication technologies (ICT) in appropriate and creative ways to plan lessons and engage students in their learning ULO3 - discuss current and emerging trends in digital technologies and the implications for teaching and learning ULO4 - critically evaluate research and practice in digital technology use in the curriculum ULO5 - describe relevant issues and the strategies available to support the safe, responsible and ethical use of ICT in learning and teaching.
