ULO1 - Appreciate the iterative relationship between research and practice ULO2 - Apply and critique various research approaches ULO3 - Understand how different research processes can be used to inform practice in workplace settings ULO4 - Locate, critique, synthesize and apply relevant evidence to practice

ULO1 - Demonstrate knowledge of psychopathology and differential diagnosis ULO2 - Demonstrate knowledge of personality development, including adaptive and maladaptive trajectories across the lifespan ULO3 - Demonstrate knowledge of the professional ethical, cultural and psychometric issues that arise when assessing for psychopathology across the lifespan ULO4 - Demonstrate skills in administration, scoring, and interpretation of psychopathology and personality instruments, behavioural instruments, and diagnostic clinical interview tools ULO5 - Demonstrate written and verbal communication skills in reporting the conclusions of psychological assessment ULO6 - Demonstrate reflective skills regarding your personal role, interpersonal skills, impact, responsibilities and relationships as a clinician reporting psychopathology and personality assessments

ULO1 - Critically appraise the applications and efficacy of Cognitive Behaviour Therapy and Mindfulness Based Approaches for common presenting issues. ULO2 - Evaluate the appropriateness and suitability of Cognitive Behaviour Therapy and Mindfulness Based Approaches for a diverse range of populations with a specific focus on different contexts. ULO3 - Integrate knowledge of case conceptualisation with evidence-based intervention to develop an intervention plan for clients with commonly seen presenting issues. ULO4 - Demonstrate skill competence (suitable for a provisionally registered psychologist) in a range of cognitive behaviour therapy and mindfulness techniques, and self-reflect on practitioner competence.

ULO1 - Undertake self-reflections and accurate self-assessment of your developing professional competencies ULO2 - Demonstrate satisfactory progress towards the Level 3 professional competencies outlined by the Australian Psychology Accreditation Council, as determined by University professional experience staff and/or supervisors ULO3 - Critique contrasting contemporary psychological practices, including their advantages and disadvantages ULO4 - Apply best-practice industry knowledge relating to developing and accessing resources, applying for and maximising vocational opportunities, and maintaining professional standards ULO5 - Integrate new understandings into practice and identify priorities for continued professional development.

ULO1 - accurately log professional experience activities ULO2 - undertake self-reflections and accurate self-assessment of your initial developing professional competencies ULO3 - demonstrate satisfactory progress towards the Level 3 professional competencies outlined by the Australian Psychology Accreditation Council, as determined by University professional experience staff and/or supervisors.

UNIT_TITLE: Advanced practice in educational and developmental psychology
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - distinguish typical and atypical development across the lifespan in a culturally sensitive manner ULO2 - examine neurodevelopmental, neurocognitive, behavioural, and psychological disorders ULO3 - create developmental and culturally sensitive history questions for psychological assessment ULO4 -  select and critically evaluate therapeutic goals and recommendations for psychological intervention, including interprofessional practices.

UNIT_TITLE: Advanced clinical interventions for mental health
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - demonstrate advanced clinical skills and self-reflective capacities to deliver interprofessional interventions for high-incidence psychological disorders ULO2 - identify, develop and critique based on evidence quality and cultural responsiveness, intervention programs for anxiety disorders, mood disorders, adjustment disorders, substance-use disorders, disorders of childhood and psychological issues associated with ageing ULO3 - implement a range of evidence-based and culturally sensitive interventions with a particular emphasis on cognitive-behavioural principles, psycho-education and effective interprofessional collaboration ULO4 - understand and critique research methodologies for evaluating evidence-based and culturally sensitive practice ULO5 - understand legal/ethical/cultural issues in interventions and safeguards against the use of restricted practices ULO6 - know local human service systems relevant to the needs of the professional psychologist

ULO1 - demonstrate advanced knowledge of psychological assessment for learning and development ULO2 - demonstrate advanced knowledge of the professional ethical, cultural and psychometric issues that arise when assessing and reporting on the cognitive and academic abilities, and individual differences across the lifespan ULO3 - demonstrate the ability to select appropriate and culturally sensitive means of assessment for individuals of different ages and deficits or strengths ULO4 - demonstrate advanced skills in administration and scoring of intelligence tests, psychopathology and personality instruments, behavioural instruments, and tests of academic attainment suitable for use with individuals and groups across the lifespan, and diverse cultural groups, including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, including the administration and scoring of tests for individuals with sensory and neurological deficits ULO5 - demonstrate advanced written and verbal communication skills in reporting the conclusions of testing for various purposes such as ascertainment for eligibility of funding, curriculum adjustment, or intervention planning and for different audiences such as parents, teachers and other professionals ULO6 - demonstrate advanced reflective skills regarding their personal role, interpersonal skills, impact, collaboration skill, responsibilities and relationships as a clinician reporting psycho-educational assessments and recommendations.

UNIT_TITLE: Professional experience: Working with systems and groups
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - identify and critique a range of group-based frameworks and programs for families, schools, and diverse cultural groups, including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples ULO2 - integrate and synthesize research and theoretical perspectives for selecting and planning effective and appropriate interventions for working with groups ULO3 - be familiar with the process of facilitating a group program in a school, private practice, or community clinic setting ULO4 - engage in critical evaluation of professional and interprofessional practice and program outcomes when working across individuals and groups ULO5 - identify and manage ethical and professional issues related to working with multiple clients (e.g. groups and/or families) and other professional groups and agencies.

UNIT_TITLE: Interacting with research in education contexts
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - identify a range of standpoints that characterise some key ideas in the field of education ULO2 - critically read academic texts related to education research and identify the main theories and concepts which underpin these texts ULO3 - conduct a review of academic literature in response to a thematic issue or question ULO4 - build a convincing argument using education research and present this argument in both spoken and written form ULO5 - demonstrate familiarity with academic practices and conventions that support academic engagement in the field of education.

UNIT_TITLE: Investigating education issues in global contexts
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - identify, investigate and understand contemporary issues in education relevant to your roles and interests and work ULO2 - broaden your understanding of education debates through appropriate resources and shared peer learning ULO3 - present your developing views on education in various forms ULO4 - demonstrate understanding of complexities in this field ULO5 - apply the knowledge and understanding to your own learning context and work.

ULO1 - Locate a research interest within broader research perspectives and methodologies in the field of education and social sciences ULO2 - Formulate research questions that are congruent with a chosen research approach ULO3 - Design ways to generate and analyse qualitative and quantitative data that are congruent with specific research questions ULO4 - Use research processes with due regard to ethical procedures ULO5 - Justify proposed research through scholarly and critical discussion.

ULO1 - Locate a research concern within a relevant body of academic scholarship ULO2 - Review the research literature in a particular field ULO3 - Conduct a small-scale research project in a selected research methodology ULO4 - Use research processes with due regard to ethical procedures and academic conventions ULO5 - Demonstrate a capacity to engage in reflective, critical discussion of the relevant research area.

ULO1 - understand the work of professionals in strategic leadership of learning across globalised contexts ULO2 - understand, analyse and apply the concepts of policy studies, leadership and governance to leading learning ULO3 - relate knowledge of research, policy and of self to the practical work of leading learning ULO4 - apply concepts and perspectives to show understanding of leading educational work in a specific case and interpret its significance ULO5 - analyse strategic directions and organisational change strategies adopted to lead learning contexts.

ULO1 - Identify the core features of a curriculum ULO2 - Recognise the ways in which curricula vary across different subjects or educational contexts ULO3 - Discuss the relationship between pedagogies and intended curricula ULO4 - Examine whether and how curriculum alignment meets stated aims of greater equity around learners' educational outcomes ULO5 - Demonstrate an understanding of how external factors or pressures can impact the implementation of curricula in a specific context ULO6 - Apply the principles to relevant 'curriculum' in other contexts or situations ULO7 - Critically interrogate the impact of the 'globalisation' of curriculum, and the political dimensions of curriculum design and implementation.

ULO1 - Identify the range of positions and perspectives which influence learning and learner development ULO2 - Appreciate multiple perspectives on learning ULO3 - Interpret the implications for learning in the light of developing research on the learning process ULO4 - Reflect on your own learning and experiences in different learning environments ULO5 - Consider or develop a case study and apply a range of perspectives to interpret this case ULO6 - Demonstrate consideration of the critical roles played by aspects such as human intellect, knowledge, values, emotion, learning, organisational culture and climate in developing individual, organisational and professional learning.

ULO1 - understand the contemporary state of the environment from within national and global contexts ULO2 - identify contemporary trends, issues and policies shaping the state of the environment, environmental education and education for sustainable development ULO3 - review the interdisciplinary nature of the evidence-base around environmental and ecological sustainability ULO4 - engage with and evaluate the perspectives and contemporary issues facing environmental educators and educators for sustainable development ULO5 - develop a case study of a socio-ecological problem or issue of relevance ULO6 - critically analyse the case from an interdisciplinary and critical perspective.

ULO1 - describe and differentiate diverse perspectives on global educational policy and leadership ULO2 - recognise and critically analyse the prevalent trends in global education policy and policy-making ULO3 - apply knowledge and awareness of the local, national, international, and global actors and institutions engaged in educational policy-making ULO4 - critically reflect on the role of global educational strategies designed for developing country contexts ULO5 - demonstrate a nuanced understanding of the complex and multifaceted issues that influence educational policy-making and leadership across national and international dimensions such as gender, economics, politics, and culture ULO6 - discuss, compare, and critique policy discourses related to trends in international education contexts and leadership

ULO1 - understand how leaders shape organisations and organisational culture ULO2 - think critically and challenge traditional notions of change in educational settings ULO3 - examine the ways leaders can create positive change in educational organisations ULO4 - reflect on personal values, beliefs, thinking, and leadership actions as they relate to organisational change ULO5 - identify issues of inequity in educational organisations ULO6 - develop a plan to create equitable educational organisations

UNIT_TITLE: Ethical leadership and decision making in education
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - identify ethical situations, issues, or problems ULO2 - recognise various ethical frameworks and perspectives related to ethics ULO3 - develop reasoning and reflective skills leading to ethical decisions or judgements ULO4 - understand how to make decisions based on moral and ethical implications ULO5 - comprehend the value and challenges of diverse education communities ULO6 - articulate a professional code of ethics pertaining to educational leadership

UNIT_TITLE: Relationships and wellbeing in educational leadership
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - critically analyse a range of approaches to theorising relationships and wellbeing in leadership and articulate your own position on the utility of these approaches ULO2 - examine the key influences on wellbeing for leaders, staff, and students in learning environments and articulate the effect of the challenges facing contemporary leaders in education ULO3 - analyse and problematize common misconceptions about emotions and leadership and articulate how they relate to your own leadership contexts ULO4 - develop an understanding of how leaders can build trust and develop relationships with a focus on leadership and wellbeing.

ULO1 - articulate a comprehensive and critical understanding of historical, contextual and political influences on leadership for social justice in educational settings ULO2 - analyse and communicate skills and capabilities associated with leading for social justice in local, national, and global contexts ULO3 - lead and promote innovative practices which engender change and address complex issues of social justice ULO4 - synthesise and communicate knowledge and understanding of complex issues at an advanced academic level

UNIT_TITLE: Critical issues in English language learning and teaching
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - describe current issues in English language teaching and learning ULO2 - critically analyse how the social, cultural, and economic contexts of English language teaching and learning impact on the decisions made by educators ULO3 - reflect on how your own practices as educators are impacted by the social, historical and political contexts in which you work ULO4 - apply knowledge of critical social, cultural, economic, and political issues to specific contexts of English language learning and teaching.

ULO1 - analyse and synthesise the concepts and pedagogical implications of communicative competence and of learning as a social practice in a range of contexts ULO2 - critically reflect on the differing language learning needs of adults and children ULO3 - interpret and apply techniques and strategies which integrate the macro-skills and focus on meaning as well as grammatical form

ULO1 - explain the political, sociocultural and organisational issues surrounding bi/multilingualism and bi/multilingual education ULO2 - demonstrate an understanding of how bi/multilingual education impacts on language acquisition ULO3 - critically evaluate political and educational contexts in Australia or in global contexts that impact on the introduction of bi/multilingual programs ULO4 - analyse successful models of bi/multilingual education, and draw on these to determine how you would apply the principles identified to your own language teaching and learning contexts.

ULO1 - identify the key aspects influencing inclusive practice ULO2 - interpret and critically evaluate the reasons that result in some members (particularly those with a disability) of the society are excluded from participation in a range of educational and social activities ULO3 - communicate evidence that explains the basis of exclusion from educational contexts ULO4 - evaluate practices that strengthen inclusion across different educational contexts ULO5 - analyse responsive inclusive practice for all learners including those with disabilities within a particular educational context.

ULO1 - demonstrate an understanding of key theories of - and perspectives on - language ULO2 - apply relevant theories to your experiences with language ULO3 - demonstrate an understanding of different kinds of language learning settings ULO4 - apply an understanding of various dimensions of communication to your lived experiences with education ULO5 - critically evaluate different ways of facilitating language learning in a range of contexts.

ULO1 - understand the characteristics and features commonly found in capable organisations ULO2 - identify appropriate leadership strategies to develop and sustain a capable organisation ULO3 - identify the cognitive dimensions of organisational problem solving and decision making ULO4 - evaluate and communicate the critical roles that human intellect, knowledge, values, emotion, learning, and organisational culture and climate, play in maintaining and sustaining capable organisations ULO5 - locate and critically scrutinise strategies which identify how to design, realise and sustain organisational capability and performance ULO6 - plan a strategy for assessing organisational capability and developing capacity in a particular context.

ULO1 - understand concepts of power and authority in organisational and institutional contexts, and how these concepts relate to problem solving, decision making and change in organisations ULO2 - understand and appreciate how 'good' decisions ought to be made in administrative contexts from a normative or prescriptive research perspective ULO3 - understand and appreciate how decisions actually do get made in organisations from an empirical research perspective ULO4 - understand and appreciate how a range of psychological framing effects and cognitive biases and heuristics influence judgement and decision making ULO5 - understand and appreciate how factors associated with complexity, uncertainty, ambiguity and social choice affect decision making in organisations ULO6 - critically examine and evaluate how organisations might be designed to improve problem-solving and decision-making processes and outcomes, and enhance organisational capabilities.

UNIT_TITLE: Inner leadership: Understanding self and others
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - understand and critically evaluate theoretical paradigms of leadership development ULO2 - apply theoretical concepts and instruments to identify personal strengths of leaders ULO3 - engage in meaningful reflective practice about personal leadership ULO4 - articulate and plan personal leadership growth and development ULO5 - identify relationships between individual leadership and organisational sustainability ULO6 - distinguish and apply reflective and scholarly approaches to cognitive and emotional meaning-making and evaluation.

ULO1 - develop specialised knowledge and skills for professional practice and further learning as English language teachers ULO2 - demonstrate advanced and integrated understanding of language in context and language pedagogy in context ULO3 - synthesise and critically reflect on approaches and models of language use in context ULO4 - analyse texts using a systemic functional linguistic approach ULO5 - apply the systemic functional linguistic approach to text analysis to inform teaching and learning practices ULO6 - demonstrate autonomy, expert judgement, adaptability and responsibility as a practitioner in selecting and analysing texts and making pedagogical decisions.

UNIT_TITLE: Integrating language and content in content-based programs
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - demonstrate an understanding of various pedagogies that support the integration of language and content in content-based programs ULO2 - apply pedagogical principles to situated contexts of teaching and learning ULO3 - demonstrate an understanding of how language-subject area teacher collaboration can support students in content-based programs ULO4 - incorporate and critically examine pedagogical approaches in a chosen content-based? educational context.

ULO1 - Develop an understanding of language as a social, cultural and political practice ULO2 - Critically reflect on how this understanding is relevant to yourself as an educator through your identity and experiences ULO3 - Understand how sociocultural perspectives apply to language pedagogy ULO4 - Develop an understanding of the social, historical and political contexts in which language is shaped in contemporary Australian society across institutional contexts ULO5 - Explore ways that language and culture are framed in different curriculum frameworks and policy documents ULO6 - Apply understandings gained through reflection and exploration of the issues raised throughout the unit.

ULO1 - Understand the concepts and pedagogical implications of communicative competence and of learning as a social practice in a range of contexts ULO2 - Recognise the differing language learning needs of adults and children ULO3 - Become familiar with techniques and strategies which integrate the macro-skills and focus on meaning as well as grammatical form ULO4 - Articulate your understanding of the principles of good assessment practices and how they impact learning ULO5 - Demonstrate skills in evaluation and design of assessment tasks.

ULO1 - Explain the political, sociocultural and pedagogical issues surrounding bilingualism and bilingual education ULO2 - Demonstrate an understanding of how bilingual education and/or content-based programs are positioned in the field of second language acquisition and applied linguistics ULO3 - Apply principles of second language acquisition and bilingual education to understanding rationale statement(s) of bilingual and/or content-based programs ULO4 - Analyse key policies and documents relating to bilingual education and content-based programs, including those associated with the Australian Curriculum for EAL students ULO5 - Analyse successful models of bilingual and content-based language teaching methods, and draw on these to determine how you would apply the principles identified to your own language teaching and learning contexts ULO6 - Critically evaluate political and educational contexts in Australia or in global contexts that impact on the introduction of bilingual and/or content-based programs.

ULO1 - analyse the diverse purposes and uses of language assessment ULO2 - critically reflect on the principles of assessment, including recognizing the issues of fairness and consequences of language testing ULO3 - critically engage with recent debates and developments in language testing research and practice ULO4 - interpret and apply the theoretical and practical skills related to assessment task design.

UNIT_TITLE: Curriculum design and innovation in TESOL contexts
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - develop an advanced understanding of language curriculum, its design and implementation ULO2 - critically analyse existing curriculum design models ULO3 - reflect critically on specific curriculum contexts ULO4 - synthesise theoretical approaches to curriculum design with specific language teaching contexts to develop innovations in English language education.

ULO1 - Know and understand conceptual frameworks and theories of giftedness and talent ULO2 - Know and understand behavioural characteristics of gifted individuals and how that can impact students' learning experiences ULO3 - Demonstrate cognitive skills in relation to identifying gifted and talented students and reflect critically on identification approaches as professional practice ULO4 - Identify students' learning styles and how they relate to students' talent development ULO5 - Evaluate teacher beliefs, competencies and strategies for teaching gifted students effectively and reflect on self-beliefs and competencies as teachers ULO6 - Evaluate different programming options of ability grouping, enrichment, extension and acceleration and how they apply to the educational needs of gifted students ULO7 - Know and understand differentiated curriculum and how it can meet the needs of gifted students ULO8 - Engage with and apply teaching and learning models of curriculum that provide for the educational needs of gifted students.

ULO1 - know and understand conceptual frameworks and theories of talent development ULO2 - outline approaches to identify and program for diverse gifted students including gifted students with learning disabilities, gifted students on the autism spectrum and underachieving gifted students ULO3 - appreciate how mentoring can be effective for developing diverse gifted students' talents ULO4 - understand creativity and the creative process and its influence on gifted students and their talent development ULO5 - examine giftedness and gender and how they interact to impact individuals' talent development ULO6 - recognise how social and emotional development of gifted students impacts the talent development process ULO7 - enhance your professional practice by the application and evaluation of a range of theories to students' talent development.

UNIT_TITLE: Technology and education: Key issues and debates
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - recognise the current and emerging trends in digital technologies being used in education, and the social, political, economic, cultural and historical issues surrounding their adoption ULO2 - grasp some of the theories, models and frameworks for understanding digital technology in education and society ULO3 - develop evaluation skills to critically assess the value of technology use in educational settings ULO4 - synthesise theory and practice in order to improve understanding of the roles digital technologies play in educational settings.

ULO1 - synthesise and apply theories, models and practical strategies of instructional design ULO2 - critique and improve upon the instructional design of digital technologies and materials, including interface, structure, values, content, activity and assessment ULO3 - demonstrate a critical understanding of debates, challenges and dilemmas in the field ULO4 - discuss current and emerging trends in the field and the implications for instructional design ULO5 - critically evaluate research and practice in instructional design.

UNIT_TITLE: Language and literacies across educational contexts
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand language and literacy development in and beyond formal education institutions and workplaces ULO2 - Interpret the latest research and theory in the areas of language and literacies education across a range of sociocultural contexts ULO3 - Construct and articulate an informed and critical perspective on language and literacy debates and policy developments nationally and internationally ULO4 - Create innovative and robust curriculum and practices in schools, workplaces and/or community settings ULO5 - Conduct research into literacy practices and/or policies in familiar settings, and critically evaluate language and literacy research in less familiar settings ULO6 - Communicate the findings of your research to educators, administrators and the wider community.

UNIT_TITLE: Literacy leadership in schools, workplaces and communities
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - understand the ways literacy leadership is framed and experienced in different contexts and settings ULO2 - interpret and critically evaluate local, national and international research and policy concerned with English language and literacy education ULO3 - critically scrutinise and plan initiatives and strategies for improving literacy outcomes through research-based changes to curriculum, pedagogy and/or assessment ULO4 - understand the many ways in which 'data' about literacy and its various dimensions can be generated and reported on, and appreciate the potential value and limitations of such data ULO5 - generate and read narrative-based autobiographical writing to promote reflection on your work and professional identity as literacy leaders ULO6 - collaboratively research literacy policy, practice, curriculum and/or assessment in familiar and/or unfamiliar settings.

ULO1 - Demonstrate awareness of a range of issues associated with the teaching and learning of mathematics in different contexts ULO2 - Review the implications that curricular, pedagogical, learning, assessment and technology issues hold for mathematics teaching and learning in relevant contexts ULO3 - Appreciate that various imperatives at many levels impinge on the design, implementation and outcomes of mathematics curricula ULO4 - Recognise the contexts and settings in which mathematical knowledge and skills are relevant and applicable in society ULO5 - Critically evaluate evidence and research findings to inform and guide practice.

ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding of current approaches to teaching music ULO2 - Understand how music education can be successfully employed across the lifespan ULO3 - Critique current teaching policy and practice in music education ULO4 - Explore a selected music teaching and learning approach and apply it to a particular music education setting.

ULO1 - Understand multiple theoretical perspectives about teaching and learning ULO2 - Critically examine your own educational approaches through a range of theoretical lenses ULO3 - Develop and evaluate new approaches to the professional practice of educators.

ULO1 - identify reasons some members of the society are excluded from teaching and learning ULO2 - assess learners and their learning environment ULO3 - use evidence-based strategies to enhance participation of excluded learners (including learners with behavioural issues and autism spectrum disorders) ULO4 - acquire skills to work with key stakeholders (e.g. parents and paraprofessionals) ULO5 - design and implement effective educational plans to deepen inclusive teaching and learning practices.

ULO1 - Extend cross-cultural skills and knowledge in developing partnerships with Indigenous experts ULO2 - Deepen your appreciation of the impact of culture, cultural identity and linguistic background on the provision of services to people from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander backgrounds ULO3 - Lead others in the appropriate cultural protocols and the terms 'Indigenous', 'local', 'Traditional' and 'Traditional Owner' as they pertain to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples ULO4 - Lead your organisation into the development of broad knowledge of, understanding of and respect for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, histories, cultures and languages, to promote reconciliation between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander and non-Indigenous Australians ULO5 - Develop an Indigenous-focused organisational learning strategy and/or strategic change plan to improve service delivery to Indigenous populations appropriate to your profession.

UNIT_TITLE: Young people: Culture, communities and education
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand young people's varying social and cultural expressions and experiences ULO2 - Identify ways in which young people live, experience and negotiate cultural expressions and experiences ULO3 - Explore the intersections between identity formations and cultural expressions and experiences ULO4 - Examine programs and policies designed to promote social inclusion and equity among young people from diverse backgrounds.

UNIT_TITLE: Building partnerships with families and communities
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - develop a critical understanding of knowledge and skills in building partnerships ULO2 - assess the practical and professional issues in building partnerships with families and communities ULO3 - demonstrate a sensitive and ethical approach to building partnerships with families and community ULO4 - analyse and reflect on social and educational processes to establishing professional partnerships with families and community ULO5 - apply acquired knowledge to exhibit leadership in developing partnerships with families and communities.

ULO1 - understand main schools of thought in adult education ULO2 - critically review theories and concepts related to adult learning ULO3 - explore the interplay of theory and practice in adult education ULO4 - examine and evaluate current issues in adult and lifelong learning ULO5 - review approaches to designing interactive learning for adults ULO6 - design a learning session for adults to exemplify a particular theoretical and practical orientation.

UNIT_TITLE: Leading local, rural and regional learning and participation
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand the diverse distinctions between definitions of metropolitan, rural and regional communities as they relate to educational policy, leadership, resourcing and experience ULO2 - Analyse and develop strategies to work collaboratively with other professionals and community-based personnel to enhance learning and wellbeing in local, rural and regional contexts ULO3 - Identify the opportunities and challenges of working in local, rural and regional contexts particularly in relation to leadership and community engagement and increasing participation ULO4 - Understand how to develop place-based learning experiences that connect the local and the global ULO5 - Examine a particular community and apply approaches to build community resilience, engagement and participation.

UNIT_TITLE: Education and globalisation in the Asian century
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the impact of globalisation and internationalisation on practices and policies in diverse educational and work contexts ULO2 - Critically evaluate academic debates and discussions in the field of global studies in education ULO3 - Develop a case study to describe an educational issue of cross/intercultural significance ULO4 - Analyse the case study to evaluate evidence of cross/intercultural issues and challenges ULO5 - Increase awareness of the ethical responsibilities of global citizens, workers and professionals.

ULO1 - Understand competing theoretical perspectives explaining social inclusion and inclusive communities ULO2 - Review critical and experiential teaching and learning approaches that bring about community transformation ULO3 - Critically analyse the value of different teaching and learning approaches in addressing core social problems ULO4 - Develop and evaluate the practical application of community inclusion projects across a variety of settings.

UNIT_TITLE: Environmental education, design and learning for sustainability
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand the historical, contemporary and prospective development of environmental education and education for sustainable development ULO2 - Identify how different contexts and sites of environmental learning inform the design and evaluation of ecologically sustainable education ULO3 - Articulate the qualities and characteristics of effective ecopedagogy and environmental learning ULO4 - Develop a case study portraying a case of environmental learning and sustainability education ULO5 - Critically analyse the case study to identify the nature of the design and practices incorporated within it.

ULO1 - Understand and evaluate the relationships between learning and socio-ecological community development ULO2 - Review and critically evaluate the literature of development studies in education and education for sustainable development ULO3 - Review perspectives on education for sustainability and the learning languages they adopt ULO4 - Identify the key global, regional and national policy shapers and educational providers in the field: donor agencies (multi-lateral and bi-lateral), non-government agencies, civil society, private sector, government; and how these differ ULO5 - Develop a case study of practices and approaches to education for sustainable development in a local, Indigenous, urban/rural, national or global context of relevance ULO6 - Analyse the significance of the case study using the literature around education for sustainable development ULO7 - Reflect on and articulate the qualities, characteristics and sociocultural sensitivities required of workers for sustainable development.

ULO1 - understand the key principles of using a system-wide PBS framework ULO2 - communicate the rationale for using positive strategies to prevent and respond to challenging behaviours ULO3 - demonstrate knowledge about a range of PBS strategies and reinforce these through practice ULO4 - critically review strategies designed to develop whole school-wide/system-wide PBS plans ULO5 - design a PBS plan that responds to your educational contexts and issues ULO6 - identify an evidence-based approach that gathers data to underpin the development and evaluation of PBS practices ULO7 - develop knowledge of broader strategies to lead and sustain PBS practices in schools and/or systems.

ULO1 - understand the complexities of leading equitable and excellent learning ULO2 - identify ways that practices of leading might constrain or enhance learning within various education contexts ULO3 - apply growing conceptual and theoretical understandings of leadership to respond to contemporary challenges in education ULO4 - synthesise knowledge of leading learning and applying understanding to a problem in a specific educational context.

ULO1 - understand different aspects of educational policy including how policy is enacted in a variety of educational contexts ULO2 - articulate the various influences on education policy, demonstrating an understanding of politics and power as they relate to contemporary education policy ULO3 - analyse the way education policy reflects dominant political and ideological beliefs about education ULO4 - apply theoretical and methodological analysis approaches towards policy enactment in their own educational contexts.

ULO1 - understand the nature of leadership as a context-bound, attributed status; and leadership as a socially and institutionally constructed phenomenon ULO2 - identify the ways in which leaders learn about leadership and construct their career trajectories ULO3 - engage with recent trends in leadership theory and practice, particularly as these apply in a variety of policy contexts and educational and non-educational settings ULO4 - appreciate the demands confronting leaders in a variety of contexts and workplaces ULO5 - apply growing conceptual and theoretical understanding in examining leadership within practice, in a context of relevance.

ULO1 - identify a leadership challenge ULO2 - articulate the design aspects of an inquiry project in order to secure appropriate evidence to use to examine the challenge ULO3 - access literature that is relevant to your professional challenge and identify how the literature responds to it ULO4 - consider additional evidence that may address the challenge and their implications ULO5 - analyse the evidence used and determine the relevance of the findings to the challenge ULO6 - articulate the implications and actions that may address the challenge ULO7 - communicate findings of the project to a professional and/or academic audience.

UNIT_TITLE: Engaging with practices of contemporary science

ULO1 - research, analyse and critique multiple theories of play to examine play as a pedagogical construct in early childhood education ULO2 - examine contemporary play-based learning theories and critically analyse their relevance across multiple childhoods and their worlds ULO3 - design and implement appropriate play-based learning experiences for diverse children and childhoods ULO4 - examine different forms of documentation of childrens play with the purpose of identifying their strengths and challenges ULO5 - critically examine and discuss the role of the adult in child-led play-based learning contexts.

ULO1 - investigate and describe key policy, curriculum, regulatory and legal obligations of early childhood education and care within Australia and their implications for teaching ULO2 - investigate and describe historical and contemporary philosophies and theories in early childhood education and care and understand their implications for current practices ULO3 - examine key policy trends in relation to leadership, management and administration and how they are shaping the early childhood profession ULO4 - demonstrate professional and ethical knowledge and understandings that are consistent with the early childhood profession ULO5 - critically reflect on your own emerging understandings of leadership and professional identity, including strengths, challenges and uniqueness and articulate what it means to be a professional.

ULO1 - reflect on understandings of what literacy is and what it means to be literate ULO2 - identify the ways that language develops from birth through early childhood ULO3 - demonstrate an understanding of how early language and literacy development is shaped and enacted in various cultural and social settings and what this means for children who speak languages other than, or in addition to, English ULO4 - demonstrate an understanding of a range of literature and other media appropriate for children of diverse backgrounds and abilities that will promote literacy learning ULO5 - develop knowledge of effective pedagogies for early literacy learning, including strategies for supporting literacy learning with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children ULO6 - develop communicative competence in and across different modes, including listening, reading, viewing, speaking, writing, and creating ULO7 - understand the continuities and transitions in literacy learning from home to school.

ULO1 - demonstrate critical understanding of childrens creative learning through the arts (visual arts, media arts, music, dance, drama) ULO2 - explore your own creative arts skills across a variety of materials and design processes suitable for young children and develop pedagogical practices for early childhood contexts ULO3 - demonstrate an understanding of theoretical and practical knowledge to effectively plan, teach, document and evaluate quality learning in the arts that engage children of diverse backgrounds and abilities ULO4 - develop and show an understanding of how the arts enable children to communicate in multiple ways that link to environment, sustainability, community and culture including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander, Asia and Pacific perspectives, and information and communication technologies (ICTs) ULO5 - apply socially and environmentally active ways to move arts education towards sustainability.

ULO1 - demonstrate advanced knowledge of relevant curriculum frameworks and theories about early childhood mathematics and numeracy development ULO2 - articulate the key concepts for young children in each of the mathematics strands and apply these to program planning and evaluation ULO3 - identify everyday learning experiences in a range of settings that foster young childrens mathematical thinking and reasoning ULO4 - demonstrate the capacity to use tools, technologies, and processes for monitoring childrens thinking and fostering their mathematical progress. ?

ULO1 - demonstrate knowledge and understanding of curriculum theories and their application to learning and teaching in early childhood education ULO2 - demonstrate understanding of how policies and legislative requirements intersect and inform curriculum development learning and assessment ULO3 - evaluate how social, cultural and political contexts shape curriculum, with particular attention to Indigenous knowledge and values underpinning design, assessment and reporting ULO4 - examine the ways in which data informs learning and planning to support full participation of children of all abilities ULO5 - create challenging learning goals by applying knowledge and understanding of planning and assessment ULO6 - demonstrate understanding of assessment and reporting making consistent and comparable judgement on childrens learning and achievements.

UNIT_TITLE: Health and well-being of children, families and communities
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - demonstrate a sound understanding of childrens physical, social, emotional and spiritual well-being and apply this knowledge by designing and implementing effective education and care programs ULO2 - understand and analyse factors contributing to childrens physical health and how they may be supported through interactive and immersive programs that address nutrition, physical activity and mindfulness ULO3 - critically analyse the impacting factors that can compromise childrens health and wellbeing including childhood trauma, media and life events that may have a life-long effect on childrens mental and physical health and wellbeing ULO4 - engage with and discuss childrens health, wellbeing and safety in relation to child safe standards and how these standards can be incorporated into service level policies and implemented effectively through evidence-based practice ULO5 - understand, analyse and apply Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander perspectives in relation to childrens health and wellbeing, including kinship care and community partnership modelling ULO6 - apply legislative policy and workplace requirements in relation to the wellbeing of teachers, educators, leaders and families ensuring that operations are compliant and lead to positive health and wellbeing of all stakeholders ULO7 - identify and address workplace situations that potentially compromise the health and wellbeing of children, families and communities including designing ways to be proactive in promoting mentally healthy communities.

ULO1 - develop an understanding of how English and literacy skills develop in the early years both in- and out-of-early childhood and primary school, and expand upon ones own literacy skills with a view to becoming an effective language and literacies teacher ULO2 - develop knowledge of relevant theoretical perspectives and how these help us understand the ways early literacies are both developed and fostered ULO3 - recognise the ways in which the use and learning of oral language, reading, writing, multiliteracies and digital technologies are interwoven ULO4 - begin to use effective techniques for planning, teaching and assessment of early literacy learning ULO5 - consider ways to differentiate learning opportunities for young children with different experiences, abilities, interests and needs in early childhood and primary contexts, including children who speak languages other than, or in addition to, English.

ULO1 - demonstrate understanding of key curriculum principles relating to the learning of mathematics through play, games and resources for young learners ULO2 - identify everyday learning experiences in a range of settings that foster young children's mathematical thinking and reasoning ULO3 - develop appropriate strategies that link mathematics to practical applications in relation to the four domains (Number, Measurement, Geometry and Probability and Statistics) ULO4 - synthesise findings and information in the research literature about how young children learn mathematics and effective strategies for promoting their ability to think mathematically ULO5 - demonstrate the capacity to use tools, technologies, and processes for monitoring children's thinking and fostering their mathematical progress ULO6 - reflect on your personal professional learning in the field of mathematics.

UNIT_TITLE: Approaches to learning and teaching in primary schools
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - demonstrate knowledge of the Australian Professional Standards for Teachers, how the standards guide the work of teachers, and sources of professional learning ULO2 - understand how context influences learning and teaching ULO3 - plan individual lessons and lesson sequences ULO4 - identify effective teaching strategies and resources for learning ULO5 - identify effective classroom management and communication strategies ULO6 - demonstrate knowledge of strategies for creating supportive and safe learning environments ULO7 - use strategies for reflecting on practice and improving learning.

ULO1 - demonstrate an understanding of various theoretical perspectives related to how middle and upper primary students develop their English knowledge, skills and understanding ULO2 - explore effective ways to plan, teach and assess learning experiences to develop middle and upper primary student's reading, writing, oral language and new literacies ULO3 - plan inclusive learning experiences that consider students who come from diverse social, cultural, religious and linguistic backgrounds.

ULO1 - demonstrate mathematical knowledge for teaching including pedagogical content knowledge and horizon knowledge ULO2 - demonstrate understanding of Australian and Victorian mathematics curricula, including each mathematical proficiency: understanding, fluency, problem solving and reasoning ULO3 - transform the intended learning of the primary mathematics curriculum into effective lessons that encourage positive dispositions, curiosity and engagement, including use of digital technologies to expand learning opportunities for learners ULO4 - build connections between mathematics concepts and sequence lessons to support students on-going learning, assess their progress and report learning outcomes ULO5 - anticipate student responses and solutions to learning activities and tasks, and plan to avoid and overcome student misconceptions ULO6 - explain the meanings of mathematics and make connections between mathematics, other subjects and students everyday environments ULO7 - critically evaluate the mathematics research evidence-base to recommend effective approaches for student-centred inclusive mathematics teaching that is relevant for the 21st century.

ULO1 - critically assess the purpose and value of current and future technology use in educational settings ULO2 - engage with the issues surrounding the use of technology in education ULO3 - demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the concepts, substance and structure of technologies in the curriculum as a stand-alone learning area and integrated across the curriculum ULO4 - demonstrate competence and confidence with a range of technologies ULO5 - identify relevant issues and strategies that support the safe, responsible and ethical use of technology in learning and teaching ULO6 - implement teaching strategies using technologies that expand learning opportunities for students.

ULO1 - demonstrate knowledge of teaching strategies that are responsive to the learning strengths and needs of students from diverse linguistic, cultural, religious and socioeconomic backgrounds ULO2 - demonstrate broad knowledge and understanding of the impact of culture, cultural identity and linguistic background on the education of students from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander backgrounds ULO3 - demonstrate broad knowledge of, understanding of and respect for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander histories, cultures and languages ULO4 - implement teaching strategies for using ICT to expand curriculum learning opportunities for students.

ULO1 - develop and reflect upon your own English and literacy skills as a future classroom practitioner ULO2 - demonstrate an understanding of various theoretical perspectives related to how young children develop their literacy knowledge, skills and understanding ULO3 - explore effective ways to plan, teach, assess, reliably record and report learning experiences to effectively develop young children's early reading, writing, oral language and new literacies ULO4 - differentiate learning experiences for children with a wide range of experiences and abilities.

ULO1 - demonstrate understanding of key curriculum principles and mathematics concepts and proficiencies relating to childrens mathematics and numeracy learning across the early years of schooling (F-3) ULO2 - synthesise findings and information in the research literature about how young children (5-9 years) learn mathematics, and effective teaching strategies ULO3 - critically examine personal assumptions about mathematics and numeracy teaching, learning and dispositions, reflecting on contemporary discussions in the research, professional and wider communities ULO4 - identify everyday opportunities in a range of settings that foster young children's mathematical thinking and reasoning ULO5 - demonstrate the capacity to assess children's mathematical thinking, and reliably record, report and respond to assessment information to advance their learning ULO6 - identify and critically examine concrete and digital resources that support mathematics learning and teaching in the early years of schooling, with reference to the mathematics research literature and contemporary policy advice.

ULO1 - demonstrate knowledge and understanding of physical, social and intellectual development and characteristics of students and how these may affect learning ULO2 - demonstrate a range of verbal and non-verbal communication strategies to support student engagement ULO3 - be able to access and explore the Australian Professional Standards for Teachers and their place in identifying professional learning needs ULO4 - understand and apply the key principles described in codes of ethics and conduct for the teaching profession ULO5 - understand the relevant legislative, administrative and organisational policies and processes required for teachers according to school stage.

ULO1 - identify a range of constructions defining adolescence and adolescent identity: biological, psychological, sociological, and cognitive ULO2 - articulate how young peoples physical, social and intellectual development influences learning ULO3 - develop an understanding of how student characteristics and identities, including ethnicity, religion, socioeconomic status, gender and sexuality impact on how adolescents learn ULO4 - analyse and apply theory, research relevant to adolescent learning and key policy documents to inform teaching approaches that engage and challenge adolescent learners ULO5 - describe teaching strategies that create a supportive learning environment for adolescents.

ULO1 - identify the learning needs of a diverse range of learners, with a focus on learners with disabilities ULO2 - compare and critique theories, models and frameworks used to inform inclusive teaching approaches ULO3 - apply knowledge of and critically assess teaching strategies that support differentiation across the full range of abilities ULO4 - identify legislative and policy requirements relating to inclusion in educational settings (including requirements relating to learners with disabilities) and outline how these influence teaching approaches ULO5 - outline a range of teaching and learning practices and partnerships that can assist in managing challenging behaviour.

UNIT_TITLE: The teaching profession and the professional teacher
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - recognise and respond to the range and depth of teachers' work (including ethical, professional, industrial, legal, emotional, intellectual and physical dimensions) ULO2 - engage critically with the legislative, administrative and organisational policies and procedures that are part of the teaching profession ULO3 - articulate your goals and targets as part of a plan for ongoing professional learning and career progression ULO4 - cultivate collaborative working relationships with parents, carers and community members through acknowledging the role these people play in supporting quality learning and teaching ULO5 - engage in deep, authentic and critical reflection about your work and responsibilities as professional educators? ULO6 - understand the ways in which ongoing professional learning and teacher research enable professional educators to respond to the challenges and pressures facing the profession.

ULO1 - analyse and design various assessment strategies (informal, formal, diagnostic, formative and summative) to support student learning and guide teaching ULO2 - critically analyse a range of feedback approaches to support student learning ULO3 - collaborate with peers and analyse multiple sources of student data to facilitate moderation and the consistent and comparable judgements of student achievement ULO4 - describe strategies for reporting student achievement and learning to parents and carers and the purpose of keeping accurate and reliable records of student achievement ULO5 - interpret student assessment data to evaluate student learning and improve teaching practice.

ULO1 - demonstrate the capacity to research teaching and learning by generating data ethically and critically and analysing its significance ULO2 - develop, conduct and report on a small-scale project on a professional practice or policy related topic ULO3 - demonstrate a clear and coherent exposition of the knowledge you have gained in written and oral forms ULO4 - critically discuss how educational research supports professional learning and improves student learning outcomes ULO5 - articulate relevant and appropriate sources of professional learning for teachers.

ULO1 - articulate the importance of engaging with parents/carers and communities, and identify strategies to support the development and maintenance of school, family and community partnerships ULO2 - understand the role of external professionals and professional organisations in broadening teachers professional knowledge and practice ULO3 - understand and critique different definitions, models and frameworks of health, wellbeing and safety ULO4 - describe strategies that support and maintain students wellbeing and safety, and that align with school, curriculum and legislative requirements.

ULO1 - complete the required number of days of professional experience and activities specified in the professional experience expectations document ULO2 - document your professional learning through means such as a professional experience folder which records lesson planning, self-reflections and an evaluation on developing practice ULO3 - achieve a satisfactory level of progress in your development as a teacher in line with the activities specified in the professional experience expectations document and the professional experience report.

ULO1 - Develop an appreciation of the range and magnitude of environmental issues ULO2 - Develop an understanding of the different possible perspectives on environmental issues ULO3 - Understand the effects of population growth and urbanisation ULO4 - Understand community concerns about the environment ULO5 - Understand the role of the environmental engineer in society, and with respect to environmental issues ULO6 - Understand the importance of environmental ethics ULO7 - Understand the conceptual basis of sustainability ULO8 - Learn to integrate conflicting viewpoints regarding environmental issues ULO9 - Begin to integrate environmental criteria into engineering project work ULO10 - Develop skills in information retrieval and analysis ULO11 - Develop skills in the oral and written presentation of technical information.

ULO1 - Understand the broad interrelationship of materials in society and issues related to their reuse or disposal ULO2 - Have a basic understanding of the mechanical properties of materials, of how these properties are measured and their importance in various applications ULO3 - Have an understanding of the key classes of materials (metals, ceramics and polymers), how their structure relates to their properties and applications and how this differs between classes ULO4 - Understand the technical aspects of other alternatives to disposing of these materials such as incineration, degradation and recycling ULO5 - Have an understanding of the basic concepts of an energy balance (life-cycle analysis) with regards to materials usage
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Materials Science and Engineering

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - identify the key sustainability issues that should be addressed in different phases of the building?lifecycle ULO2 - think critically and apply appropriate techniques for sustainable development of the built?environments ULO3 - analyse the building performance using a combination of simulation and measurement?approaches ULO4 - compare different building codes and rating systems, and use one of them to appraise the?building performance ULO5 - generate high-quality technical reports to summarise the design and operation of a?sustainable building.?

ULO1 - evaluate the principles of contaminant fate and transport within soil, water and air systems ULO2 - describe the fate and transport of different contaminants in soil, water and air ULO3 - assess the potential environmental impacts of contaminants ULO4 - construct a fate and transport model for environmental contaminants ULO5 - communicate contaminant fate and transport principles and associated environmental?impacts to inform management options.

ULO1 - Describe the major types and causes of air pollution and the associated impacts to human health, ecosystems, aesthetic and infrastructure in the context of Australian legislation. ULO2 - Interpret various atmospheric stability conditions drawing from a description of atmospheric conditions and demonstrate how the conditions affect plume behaviour. ULO3 - Quantify the atmospheric dispersion of discharges from both point and areal sources of air pollution. ULO4 - Analyse different types of emission control technologies and discuss the theoretical basis of the control provided, relevant to common industrial air emission sources. ULO5 - Discern the concept of the advanced greenhouse effect and discuss major greenhouse gas emissions sources and sinks, both natural and anthropogenic. ULO6 - Determine greenhouse gas emissions associated with energy use and analyse mitigation strategies.

UNIT_TITLE: Soil remediation and solid waste management
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Analyse soil condition and solid waste composition, including the chemical and physical properties. ULO2 - Evaluate and prioritise waste management and soil remediation techniques and practices. ULO3 - Assess and interpret the potential environmental impacts arising from waste management and soil remediation practices. ULO4 - Design and generate suitable mitigation strategies to inform management options.

ULO1 - describe the concepts of EIA, ERA and EMS ULO2 - determine the role of these assessments and management systems in society, especially?the relevant environmental legislation, policies, codes of practice and local/international?standards ULO3 - comprehend the government, industry and community perspectives on engineering projects ULO4 - apply key concepts of life cycle analysis, environmental auditing, waste prevention, cleaner?production, community consultation, and economic analysis in engineering projects ULO5 - assess various types of environmental impact assessment, risk evaluation and?environmental management system methodologies ULO6 - prepare and present a group project based on the knowledge derived in EIA/ERA and EMS.

ULO1 - Relate theoretical knowledge to engineering practice in workplace. ULO2 - Follow professional engineering practices, and health and safety rules of the workplace. ULO3 - Uphold engineering ethical principles and responsibilities, and have the ability to carry out engineering tasks given to acceptable standards. ULO4 - Demonstrate the ability to communicate engineering tasks to relevant parties and the ability to write technical reports. ULO5 - Show the ability to work independently and to collaborate with colleagues on common tasks effectively. ULO6 - Exhibit the willingness and ability to engage in life-long learning.

ULO1 - Identify different structural systems (e.g. beams and trusses) and translate physical structures into appropriate models for analysis and design. ULO2 - Determine forces acting in simple beams and truss systems using free body diagrams and rigid body equilibrium. ULO3 - Determine internal axial and bending stresses in beams, struts and/or trusses structures and select appropriately sized members. ULO4 - Determine the motion of particles and rigid bodies using fundamental concepts of kinematics and kinetics. ULO5 - Determine the motion of particles and rigid bodies using energy methods. ULO6 - Describe the key properties of structural materials for specific applications. ULO7 - Describe, determine and summarise the importance of the microstructure of materials and analyse the microstructure-property relationship. ULO8 - Describe how different material processing routes directly influence material structural properties. ULO9 - Function as part of a team and communicate effectively with team members to prepare and present engineering prototypes and oral and written reports in a professional engineering format.

ULO1 - Apply (i) Ohm's and Kirchhoff's laws, (ii) equivalent resistance and (iii) Nodal analysis to find voltages and currents for elements in simple electrical circuits. ULO2 - Analyse basic circuits containing (i) transistors (via the simple model), (ii) resistors and capacitors and to (iii) formulate Thevenin/Norton equivalent circuits. ULO3 - Describe the functions of standard electrical laboratory equipment and how to use them to measure electrical quantities in circuits. ULO4 - Apply the concepts of material balances and unit operations to design a flow diagram of a chemical process. ULO5 - Apply engineering design principles and critical thinking skills to plan and design a solution to an identified process engineering problem. ULO6 - Apply scientific and technical theory to engineering problems, explain the principles of sustainable design and cleaner production principles, showing a systems approach to design. ULO7 - Determine the expansion of materials as the temperature of the material is increased. ULO8 - Apply the concept of resistivity in calculating the resistance of an electrical component. ULO9 - Identify how the band gap of a material influences its optical and electronic properties and explain how the chemistry of a semiconductor affects its electronic properties. ULO10 - Work collaboratively and articulate practices that lead to successful teamwork in a multicultural context. ULO11 - Generate and present written reports in a professional engineering format from a template.

ULO1 - Describe the capabilities and limitations of mobile computing devices, as well as the interaction between developments in IT and their use in modern Engineering practice. ULO2 - Construct mobile applications that utilise device capabilities to solve engineering problems using a simple object-oriented software approach. ULO3 - Use IT tools for aspects of the software engineering process, including a code editor, debugger, shared code repository and version control system, task-tracking and team communication tools. ULO4 - Generate written technical documentation in a standard design format from a template. ULO5 - Execute tasks as part of a team, and communicate effectively with team members. ULO6 - Compile and deliver oral presentations in a professional engineering format.

ULO1 - Evaluate cross products of vectors, and use vectors to represent lines and planes. ULO2 - Perform matrix algebra. ULO3 - Solve up to 3x3 systems of linear equations and find eigenvalues and eigenvectors. ULO4 - Use hyperbolic functions. ULO5 - Evaluate improper integrals of elementary functions and use integration by parts. ULO6 - Appreciate convergence of numeric and power series, construct Taylor series and estimate errors in numerical approximations . ULO7 - Solve first order ordinary differential equations, including by separable variables and integrating factors. ULO8 - Solve second order linear differential equations with constant coefficients. ULO9 - Use differential equations to model simple engineering problems. ULO10 - Evaluate and invert Laplace transforms and use them to solve ordinary differential equations. ULO11 - Calculate partial derivatives, use the gradient vector to find directional derivatives, and find extreme values of two-variable functions. ULO12 - Express and explain mathematical techniques and arguments clearly in words.

ULO1 - Create hand sketches and drawings (2D/3D) ULO2 - Create digital engineering drawings (2D/3D) using computer-aided packages ULO3 - Collect and communicate spatial data ULO4 - Create digital visualisations containing spatial information in Geographic Information Systems (GIS); and ULO5 - Communicate engineering information effectively in written and oral formats

ULO9 - Apply integration techniques to calculate areas, average values, volumes, and centres of mass or moment.
