UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the benefits and ethical issues involved in randomisation as a mechanism for reduction and balancing bias, and implement a variety of randomisation schemes. ULO2 - Describe the principles behind the common experimental designs and be able to implement, analyse and interpret data from a variety of randomised designs. ULO3 - Describe the advantages and disadvantages of the use of surrogate endpoints. ULO4 - Describe the principles underlying Phase I, II and III and IV studies as well as of the scientific basis underlying issues in clinical studies including intention-to-treat, blinding, interim analyses, missing data subgroup analyses and the reporting thereof. ULO5 - State the reasons for the importance of sample size in clinical studies, and perform sample size calculations for a variety of trial designs with different outcomes.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Recognise the existence of correlated or hierarchical data structures, and describe the limitations of standard methods in these settings. ULO2 - Develop and analytically describe an appropriate model for longitudinal or correlated data based on unit matter considerations. ULO3 - Be proficient at using a statistical software package (e.g. Strata or SAS) to properly model and perform computations for longitudinal data analyses, and to correctly interpret results. ULO4 - Express the results of statistical analyses of longitudinal data in language suitable for communication to medical investigators or publication in biomedical or epidemiological journal articles.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_TITLE: Categorical data and generalised linear models
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand the major theoretical aspects of generalised linear models. ULO2 - Appreciate regression modelling strategies for generalised linear models. ULO3 - Including estimation issues, choice of models, prediction and goodness of fit of a selected model. ULO4 - Be proficient in the analysis of binary outcome data, either form a standard study design or from a matched study design. ULO5 - Be capable of analysing ordered and unordered categorical outcomes using simple measures of association and complex regression models. ULO6 - Be capable of analysing count data whether it satisfies standard distributional assumptions or whether it is over dispersed.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand the major theoretical and computational issues underlying survival analysis. ULO2 - Develop appropriate survival analysis strategies based on unit matter considerations, including choice of models, control for confounding and appropriate parameterisation. ULO3 - Be proficient at using at least two different statistical software packages (e.g. Strata, Excel) to perform survival analysis. ULO4 - Understand the construction, use and interpretation of appropriate graphs for showing results and checking statistical assumptions. ULO5 - Express the results of statistical analyses of censored data in language suitable for (a) communication to medical investigators (b) publication in biomedical or epidemiological journals ULO6 - Appreciate the role of newer techniques including parametric non-modelling, floating odds ratios and competing risks.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Appreciate the challenges facing a biostatistician in professional practice. ULO2 - Demonstrate strategies for elicitation of pertinent research questions and associated biostatistical issues from a health or medical research project. ULO3 - Collaborate with a medical researcher in devising a strategy for statistical analysis of the research data. ULO4 - Perform data integrity checks and an appropriate statistical analysis. ULO5 - Present the results and their interpretation in a written report suitable for presentation to a clinical research journal.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the core dogma of molecular biology and the central ideas of population genetics. ULO2 - Given a problem which requires genome or proteome data for its solution, access appropriate web based sources for data, and download the data in suitable format. ULO3 - Understand and apply core bioinformatics techniques for the analysis of DNA and protein sequence data, such as global sequence alignment, CLAST, Hidden Markov Models, evolutionary models and phylogenetic tree fitting. ULO4 - Process large quantities of data (such as the expression profiles of thousands of genes resulting form microarray experiments) using R, and communicate results in language suitable for presentation to both a bioinformatics journal and a lay audience.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the logic of Bayesian statistical inference i.e. the use of full probability models to quantify uncertainty in statistical conclusions. ULO2 - Develop and analytically describe simple one-parameter models with conjugate prior distributions and standard models containing two or more parameters including specifics for the normal location-scale model. ULO3 - Appreciate the role prior distributions and have a thorough understanding of the connection between Bayesian methods and standard 'classical' approaches to statistics, especially those based on likelihood methods. ULO4 - Recognise situations where a complex biostatistical data structure can be expressed as a Bayesian hierarchical model, and specify the technical details of such a model. ULO5 - Explain and use the most common computational techniques for use in Bayesian analysis, especially the use of simulation from posterior distributions based on Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods, with emphasis on the practical implementation of such techniques in the WinBUGS package. ULO6 - Perform practical Bayesian analysis relating to health research problems, and effectively communicate the results.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding of the meaning and laws of probability. ULO2 - Recognise common probability distributions and their properties. ULO3 - Apply calculus-based tools to derive key features of a probability distribution, such as mean and variance. ULO4 - Manipulate multivariate probability distributions to obtain marginal and conditional distributions. ULO5 - Obtain mean, variance and the probability distribution of transformations of random variables. ULO6 - Understand properties of parameter estimators and the usefulness of large sample approximations in statistics. ULO7 - Appreciate the role of simulation in demonstrating and explaining statistical concepts.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Appreciate the challenges facing a biostatistician in professional practice. ULO2 - Demonstrate strategies for elicitation of pertinent research questions and associated biostatistical issues from a health or medical research project. ULO3 - Collaborate with a medical researcher in devising a strategy for statistical analysis of the research data. ULO4 - Perform data integrity checks and an appropriate statistical analysis. ULO5 - Present the results and their interpretation in a written report suitable for presentation to a clinical research journal.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe situations where machine learning methods can offer advantages over traditional statistical modelling approaches to data analyses in health applications ULO2 - Recognise and explain the differences between the goals of description and prediction ULO3 - Determine and implement appropriate machine learning approaches for description and prediction in real-world health applications ULO4 - Measure and explain the uncertainty of the results of analyses using machine learning approaches ULO5 - Interpret the results of analyses using machine learning in light of the assumptions required, the quality of input data, and the sensitivity to the specific technique implemented ULO6 - Critically appraise current literature concerning machine learning applications for classification or prediction in health ULO7 - Effectively communicate in language suitable for the scientific community the results of analyses using machine learning methods
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Use counterfactuals (potential outcomes) to precisely define causal effects ULO2 - Describe the differences between association and causation, and the fundamental assumptions required for causation ULO3 - Construct causal diagrams and use them to identify potential sources of bias ULO4 - Implement causal inference methods, using software, for single time point and longitudinal exposures, and for mediation analyses ULO5 - Interpret results of analyses in light of the causal assumptions required ULO6 - Effectively communicate in language suitable for the scientific community the results of analyses using causal inference methods
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Analyse the impact of colonisation on health priorities and practices during the 18th and 19th centuries, and its continuing influence over health. ULO2 - Determine the impact of the global political, economic, and social order on the shape of international frameworks and mechanisms governing health. ULO3 - Determine the impact of key international agencies and processes that influence health at a local level. ULO4 - Identify and analyse ethical issues in international health and health research. ULO5 - Collaborate and communicate effectively within a group. ULO6 - Evaluate and apply international frameworks and mechanisms governing health to case studies.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - interpret business data using descriptive statistics techniques, including the use of spreadsheet functions ULO2 - apply simple concepts of probability and probability distributions to problems in business decision-making ULO3 - describe the role of statistical inference and applying inference methods to single population means ULO4 - evaluate relationships between variables for business decision-making, using the concept of correlation and simple linear regression ULO5 - apply suitable statistical techniques for describing and forecasting time series data.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - demonstrate an understanding of sampling design and apply appropriate sampling methods relevant to the business context at hand ULO2 - demonstrate an understanding of the importance of statistical inference in business, specifically, be able to determine and interpret significant differences required for decision making ULO3 - demonstrate the ability to conduct and understand regression analyses, as well as interpret the findings and communicate their business value ULO4 - demonstrate an understanding of non-parametric methods and their role when applied in business.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - interpret business and economic data using tables, charts and descriptive statistics techniques, applying standardisation techniques where appropriate ULO2 - describe the concept of a sampling distribution, estimators and their properties ULO3 - make inference on single and multiple population means, difference between means and the slope for business and economic decision-making ULO4 - interpret and evaluate relationships between variables for business and economic decision-making using simple and multiple linear regression ULO5 - apply the main ideas of probability theory to business and economic decision-making.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - learn to read different data formats, learn about tidy data and wrangling techniques ULO2 - apply effective visualisation and modelling to understand relationships between variables, and make decisions with data ULO3 - develop communication skills using reproducible reporting.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - understand and derive the properties of ordinary least squares in summation and matrix notation ULO2 - interpret, evaluate and apply inferential methods to multiple linear regression ULO3 - understand the use and implications of data scaling, functional form and dummy variables in regression modelling ULO4 - identify the presence of heteroscedasticity, adjust OLS standard errors and perform feasible GLS in regression models ULO5 - understand issues related to modelling with time-series data.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - characterise the variability in data ULO2 - build statistical models to support decision-making and risk assessment ULO3 - use randomisation methods to assess uncertainty in relation to parameter estimates, hypothesis testing, predictions and model assessments ULO4 - explain the basic concepts of Bayesian analysis and credibility theory, and be able to implement them in conjugate settings ULO5 - explain the differences between the frequentist and Bayesian frameworks ULO6 - develop computing and communication skills, using reproducible reporting.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - introduce actuarial discounting concepts and basic actuarial notation ULO2 - introduce statistical techniques in actuarial work ULO3 - develop an understanding of interest rates and the actuarial analysis of cash flows ULO4 - understand the use of equation of value in actuarial pricing and appraisal.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - provide a practical training in basic mathematics needed for the study of econometrics ULO2 - examine the calculus of many variables and its application in econometrics and business statistics ULO3 - have a basic understanding of matrix algebra ULO4 - provide a training in the use of mathematical software.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_TITLE: Probability and statistical inference for economics and business
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - understand concepts of probability, statistical inference, generating functions and cumulants ULO2 - derive and use generating functions to evaluate moments and establish the distribution of linear combinations of independent random variables ULO3 - understand and apply the main methods of estimation and the main properties of estimators ULO4 - construct confidence intervals for unknown parameters and test hypotheses ULO5 - develop written, presentation and group work skills through a series of assessed essays, assignments and tutorial work.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - select and develop appropriate models for clustering, prediction or classification ULO2 - estimate and simulate from a variety of statistical models ULO3 - measure the uncertainty of a prediction or classification using resampling methods ULO4 - apply business analytic tools to produce innovative solutions in finance, marketing, economics and related areas ULO5 - manage very large data sets in a modern software environment ULO6 - explain and interpret the analyses undertaken clearly and effectively.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - consolidate the core principles underlying econometric and statistical analysis ULO2 - understand and implement the technique of maximum likelihood estimation and develop an appreciation of the associated asymptotic distribution theory ULO3 - understand and implement likelihood-based hypothesis testing and quasi-maximum likelihood inference ULO4 - develop the skills needed to demonstrate and explore theoretical sampling properties using computer simulation.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - conduct statistical inference in statistical models with a binary dependent variable ULO2 - conduct statistical inference in statistical models with one or more endogenous explanatory variables ULO3 - conduct statistical inference in a system of simultaneous equations ULO4 - conduct statistical inference on data that has both a time series and a cross section dimension.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - calculate probabilities and moments of loss distributions both with and without limits and risk-sharing arrangements ULO2 - construct risk models involving frequency and severity distributions and calculate the moment generating function and the moments for the risk models both with and without simple reinsurance arrangements ULO3 - explain the concept of ruin for a risk model ULO4 - describe the fundamental concepts of risk rating and apply them to simple experience rating systems ULO5 - describe and apply techniques for analysing a delay (or run-off) triangle and projecting the ultimate position.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - describe and classify stochastic processes including counting processes and understand state and time spaces and mixed processes ULO2 - define and apply the Markov Chain and Chapman-Kolmogorov equation; understand the stationary distribution, experience rating systems, time homo and inhomo-geneous Markov Chains and application of such as modelling tools ULO3 - define and apply a Markov process. Understand the poisson process as a counting process derive and solve Kolmogorov equations, understand and solve multiple state models including the HSD model, generalise to models where transition also depends on duration of stay in a state and describe how to model using such models ULO4 - explain concept of survival models, lifetime models, distribution and density functions for future lifetime, force of mortality, actuarial notation, life expectancy (complete and curtate) and the two-state model ULO5 - describe estimation procedures for lifetime distributions. Identify censoring by types and problems caused by censoring; understand and apply the Nelson-Aalen and Kaplan-Meier estimation procedures and the Cox proportional hazards model ULO6 - derive maximum likelihood estimators for transition intensities and functions for constant transition models ULO7 - estimate transition intensities dependent on age (exact or census); understand the principle of correspondence, calculate central and initial exposures, explain the concept of rate intervals, estimate initial and central mortality rates from census data and death data ULO8 - describe and carry out graduation of mortality data and understand and apply graduation tests ULO9 - describe approaches to forecasting mortality rates; discuss some of the more commonly used forecasting approaches including p-splines, time series modelling and APC models.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - understand and derive the properties of ordinary least squares in summation and matrix notation ULO2 - interpret, evaluate and apply inferential methods to multiple linear regression ULO3 - understand the use and implications of data scaling, functional form and dummy variables in regression modelling ULO4 - identify the presence of heteroscedasticity, adjust OLS standard errors and perform feasible GLS in regression models ULO5 - understand issues related to modelling with time-series data.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - model and forecast stationary autoregressive and moving average time series ULO2 - test for unit roots in univariate time series ULO3 - analyse the relationships between multiple, stationary time series ULO4 - test for, estimate and interpret the long run relationships between non-stationary time series.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - describe the time series and distributional features of financial data ULO2 - explain appropriate specification, estimation and testing of asset pricing models ULO3 - evaluate the need for volatility models for financial returns ULO4 - describe the specification and estimation of conditional volatility models.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - understand the modern approach to evaluation of uncertain future payoffs ULO2 - understand the concepts of arbitrage and fair games and their relevance to finance and insurance ULO3 - understand the?concept of conditional expectation and martingales and their relation to pricing of financial derivatives ULO4 - understand the random processes such as Random Walk, Brownian Motion and Diffusions and be able to apply them for modelling real life processes and risk models ULO5 - use Ito's formula ULO6 - price options by using the Binomial and Black-Scholes models ULO7 - simulate the price process and obtain prices by simulation ULO8 - formulate discrete time Risk Model in Insurance and use it for control of probabilities of ruin.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - understand the foundational theories of financial market behaviour ULO2 - understand measures of investment risk as they relate to insurance ULO3 - estimate, interpret and utilise models of investments returns, term structure of interest rates, and credit risk models ULO4 - understand the theoretical foundations and practice of option pricing models, including various methods for pricing options.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - calculate, using ultimate or select mortality, net premiums and net premium reserves for increasing and decreasing benefits and annuities ULO2 - develop techniques for the valuation of annuity and assurance products involving two lives, and the use of actuarial functions in that situation ULO3 - develop methods which can be used to model cash flows contingent upon competing risks ULO4 - use the technique of discounted emerging costs as used in profit tests, pricing assessments and reserving calculations for various insurance and pension products ULO5 - address practical issues such as guarantees and options, risk classification and the effects of the pricing and reserving basis on the emergence of profit.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - understand common statistical methods used in business and economic forecasting ULO2 - develop computer skills for forecasting business and economics time series data ULO3 - provide insights into the problems of implementing and operating large scale forecasting systems.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - identify and understand the statistical and computational trade-offs in modern data analysis problems ULO2 - develop computer skills for exploring modern data sets ULO3 - understand and apply machine learning algorithms to solve modern data analysis problems.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - understand statistical models for handling common data analysis problems ULO2 - develop skills for fitting, interpreting and assessing statistical models ULO3 - develop computer skills for exploring and modelling different kinds of data.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - discuss and apply an actuarial control cycle in a variety of practical commercial situations ULO2 - apply the tests of professionalism ULO3 - examine the need for and impact of regulation and government policy on medium and long term commercial decisions ULO4 - analyse the main features and risks of financial products and contracts, from the point of view of consumers and providers ULO5 - demonstrate an understanding of enterprise risk management and its role in organisational management ULO6 - apply a risk assessment framework to identify and assess the risks in a range of commercial situations.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - discuss and apply the process of product design ULO2 - select an appropriate model to solve client problems ULO3 - recognise the importance of capital ULO4 - apply relevant approaches and techniques to the valuation of liabilities ULO5 - apply appropriate techniques to the pricing of products and contracts ULO6 - measure, report and manage solvency ULO7 - measure and report emerging profits and/or costs ULO8 - monitor and assess experience ULO9 - manage the business and respond to the experience.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Econometrics and Business Statistics

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - describe and critically discuss the characteristics and behaviour of different Investment types under different economic conditions, understanding the relationship between risk and return and recognising risk factors which includes issuer default, counterparty failure, systemic liquidity, the collapse of speculative bubbles, shocks to the economic system and cyclical/structural changes ULO2 - develop an understanding of the methods used for valuation of the common forms of debt, equity, property and derivative securities. In particular students should be aware of the valuation methods and principles, data requirements and sources and the implicit assumptions and limitations of these models ULO3 - develop an understanding of the application and limitations of the major economic and financial theories relevant to investment, and be able to critically evaluate these theories including the efficient market hypothesis, the capital asset pricing model, multi-factor pricing models and theories from behavioural finance ULO4 - define appropriate investment objectives based on the liability profile of a fund ULO5 - specify appropriate investment constraints, based on the liability profile of a fund ULO6 - identify the characteristics of different types of asset models ULO7 - critically evaluate the appropriateness of an asset model for a given context ULO8 - derive consistent asset assumptions for asset models, taking into account historical data, prevailing industry expectations, contemporary investment literature, and other practical considerations such as tax ULO9 - apply asset assumptions, and the linkages contained within asset models, to real world situations ULO10 - describe and critically evaluate different approaches to asset allocation.

ULO1 - Describe the historical and conceptual development of AI; foundational issues for AI, including the frame problem and the Turing test; ULO2 - Explain, apply and evaluate the goals of AI and the main paradigms for achieving them including logical inference, search, machine learning and Bayesian inference; ULO3 - Explain the social and economic roles of AI; ULO4 - Describe, analyse, apply and evaluate heuristic AI for problem solving; ULO5 - Describe, analyse and apply basic knowledge representation and reasoning mechanisms; ULO6 - Describe, analyse and apply probabilistic inference mechanisms for reasoning under uncertainty; ULO7 - Describe, analyse, apply and evaluate machine learning techniques; ULO8 - Describe, analyse, apply and evaluate the use of the above techniques in different domain, specifically language technology.

ULO1 - Describe the characteristics and limitations of different IT and IKM governance frameworks and strategy perspectives, and how competing perspectives can be reconciled in practice; ULO2 - Evaluate the concepts underpinning the dominant intellectual capital perspective on IT and IKM strategy, the strengths and limitations of this approach, and how social capital and emotional capital insights can augment this view of strategy; ULO3 - Analyse the distinct features, the functional/disciplinary origins, and the key drivers of IT and IKM strategies focused primarily on (1) people, (2) business processes, and (3) content and technology, and the supporting technologies that can facilitate each approach; ULO4 - Analyse links between strategy, performance and measurement, and the issues associated with demonstrating the value and benefits of IT and IKM; ULO5 - Describe the nature of the IT and IKM regulatory environment and approaches to controlling risk; ULO6 - Evaluate the importance of marketing, leading and championing IT and IKM within the organisation, and of reflective practice.
