UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Extend your skills in art making and aesthetic vocabulary of materials and studio processes;  ULO2 - Employ considerable technical skills in your chosen area of self-expression; ULO3 - Extend your level of experimentation and investigation within your artwork, moving towards a focus on specific themes and concepts within an interdisciplinary practice; ULO4 - Develop a position in relation to current issues in fine art and various modes of professional practice and recognise the potential to produce artworks within the framework of contemporary culture; ULO5 - Demonstrate an increased capacity for the constructive appraisal of your own artwork, and that of others, and are able to articulate this through oral presentations and written documentation; ULO6 - Analyse individual and collaborative studio cultural production in response to Indigenous cultural frameworks; knowledge, cultures; and; ULO7 - Consistently apply the rules of occupational health and safety in force in the studio appropriate to a developing interdisciplinary practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Develop practical processes that generate ongoing film based research; ULO2 - Demonstrate awareness of theoretical and technical issues related to the medium of film in relation to design and its expression; ULO3 - Critically reflect on the place of film processes in the field of contemporary cultural production, nationally and internationally; ULO4 - Demonstrate an understanding of film narrative and be capable of analyse its technical features; ULO5 - Position and engage recent critical theory related to film culture and its relation to contemporary studio practices.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Initiate a self-motivated of artwork that engages experimental studio processes appropriate to the rationale of a studio program; ULO2 - Defend, present and edit conceptual and material engagement of studio production and its research methodologies; ULO3 - Apply existing materials and technologies in new contexts and interdisciplinary aesthetic languages; ULO4 - Show a deeper understanding of current issues in fine art, various modes of professional practice and recognise the potential to produce ethically engaged, critical and creative artworks within the framework of contemporary culture; ULO5 - Position, contextualise and articulate the evaluation of their artwork and that of other students within appropriate precedents found in the historical and contemporary field of fine art and broader cultural contexts; ULO6 - Evaluate the artworks produced in the studio in relation to Indigenous cultural frameworks; knowledge, cultures and values, within local and international contexts; and; ULO7 - Demonstrate an increased understanding and practice the rules of occupational health and safety in force in the studio, and are able to collaborate and co-operate safely within the studio environment with observance of the OHS&E regulations and policies of the studio.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate strong self-reliance, and able to construct a program of work with a coherent direction which imaginatively addresses your own concerns; ULO2 - Produce outcomes that display advanced skills, confidence and control in theoretical concepts and materials, and be able to isolate areas of your work that require further research and sustain a directed inquiry into these; ULO3 - Demonstrate possession of a strong faculty and methodology for critical inquiry, enabling you to question and discuss the issues relevant to current theory and practice in your chosen field of fine art and in broader art practice; ULO4 - Approach contemporary art practice and aesthetics with challenge and vigour, and be able to establish a personalised and informed discourse within the context of fine art practice; ULO5 - Achieve a professional presentation and documentation of works in the final submission of your completed folio; ULO6 - Independently practice the rules of occupational health and safety in force in the studio, and are able to collaborate and co-operate safely and productively within the studio environment with observance of the OHS&E regulations and policies of the studio.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply and critically evaluate appropriate and sustainable studio methodologies to support sustained independent practice; ULO2 - Extend and refine your technical and creative capabilities through the development of a major practice-based research project; ULO3 - Reflect on the appropriate application of intuitive process and critical reasoning which underlies your studio practice; ULO4 - Communicate your studio research using individuated language, conscious of relevant precedents and affinities, and define these through debate, critical discourse and collaborative learning contexts; ULO5 - Position your creative works, such as exhibitions, texts, performances and actions, within contemporary discourses.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply a cogent language for your practice that is defined by appropriate material and conceptual frameworks; ULO2 - Extend your application and critical evaluation of appropriate and sustainable studio methodologies to support sustained independent practice; ULO3 - Critically reflect and discuss the aesthetic, social, ethical and cultural dimensions of your studio practice; ULO4 - Position your outcomes critically within your studio and expanded environment, through informed debate and discourse; ULO5 - Evaluate traditional discipline approaches and test new modes of knowledge production within the studio context.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate a discursive approach to your field of enquiry; ULO2 - Demonstrate a critical understanding of studio methodologies in contemporary practice; ULO3 - Demonstrate the ability to generate a studio methodology relevant to your practice; ULO4 - Demonstrate the potential for advanced research in your field; ULO5 - Demonstrate an understanding of research ethics and research integrity; ULO6 - Appreciate the difference between professional practice in your discipline and studio research in your discipline.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Work autonomously on a range of tasks to an effective professional standard within a cultural workplace; ULO2 - Operate effectively and constructively as a team-member within a cultural workplace; ULO3 - Apply and extend knowledge of studio research and production in a professional setting; ULO4 - Understand from first-hand experience a variety of the tasks and problems that constitute cultural production within a professional workplace, and be able to communicate this through a reflexive journal; ULO5 - Reflect critically upon the operational, managerial and logistical requirements of the workplace against a broader set of contemporary cultural issues; ULO6 - Observe and apply the OHS requirements of the working environment.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically analyse and respond to a set brief to research and design a real world public art project proposal; ULO2 - Communicate conceptual ideas, developments, and material resolutions of the proposed public art project; ULO3 - Contextualise the produced work in the field of practice, with consideration to the social, political, cultural, economic, physical, ethical and environmental factors; ULO4 - Reflect on and understand the professional roles and responsibilities of the public art practitioner; ULO5 - Understand and apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the discipline practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: Presentation and production for public art
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply digital publishing and 3D digital imaging techniques to prepare layouts for public art project proposal submissions; ULO2 - Generate and manipulate digital models using industry standard computer aided design (CAD) software to communicate project ideas and developments; ULO3 - Understand and apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the discipline practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: Principles of forensic medicine and science
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Summarise the principles and scope of forensic medicine and science in their application in the Australian Criminal Justice and Coronial legal systems. ULO2 - Distinguish the application of Clinical Forensic Medical services and apply them to the Australian Criminal Justice and Coronial legal systems. ULO3 - Describe the core elements of forensic odontology, anthropology and forensic entomology and be able to expo how these specialties assist forensic medical investigations. ULO4 - Discuss the core elements of forensic toxicology and forensic molecular biology and how these science disciplines are integrated into a comprehensive death investigation service. ULO5 - Distinguish basic forensic autopsy principles in the setting of medico-legal death investigation the approaches to autopsy. ULO6 - Explain the interface between forensic pathology and other forensic medical and scientific disciplines in a team based approach to death investigation. ULO7 - Summarise the legal frameworks within which forensic practitioners work.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Epidemiology and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Justify decision making processes in legal practice. ULO2 - Critically evaluate the general principles of the laws of evidence and the special rules regarding opinion evidence. ULO3 - Determine the role of the expert witness and be conversant with the rules governing the reception of evidence to the courts. ULO4 - Apply medical, forensic, and legal principles to the preparation of medico-legal reports. ULO5 - Demonstrate skills and knowledge in the presentation of evidence in court. ULO6 - Use high level techniques to manage examination-in-chief, cross examination and re-examination.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Provide a high level explanation of the pathophysiology of injuries. ULO2 - Critically evaluate the factors limiting accurate injury interpretation, including the interpretation of forces producing injury. ULO3 - Apply advanced forensic imaging skills to the principles of forensic photography. ULO4 - Demonstrate a comprehensive and detailed understanding of the classification of injuries. ULO5 - Apply the skills required to accurately document injuries. ULO6 - Analyse and interpret mechanisms and circumstances by which the injuries were sustained.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Develop a high level awareness and understanding of the ideas and issues in medical ethics so that in practice the interests of their patients/clients are safeguarded. ULO2 - Critically evaluate relevant areas of the law so that in practice their contribution to the justice system is optimal. ULO3 - Appreciate the importance of both law and ethics in the treatment of patients/clients and the application of these principles to optimal pateint/client outcomes. ULO4 - Acquire skills in the constructive approach to complex situations with competing ethical issues. ULO5 - Critically evaluate your own practice through the lens of medical ethics and law. ULO6 - Discuss and critically interpret issues related to justice in forensic medicine from the perspectives of law, rights and ethics.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically analyse the principles of forensic science generally and its scope. ULO2 - Critically assess the scope and limitations of forensic science generally and its subsections in particular. ULO3 - Evaluate the application of tests and analyses used in branches of forensic science to assist in the proper application of their results in particular cases. ULO4 - Apply skills and knowledge in deciding what specimens would be applicable for forensic science analysis in particular cases. ULO5 - Develop advanced competencies in the collection storage and security of forensic specimens. ULO6 - Critically evaluate results of forensic scientific analysis meaningfully.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Provide a comprehensive medical service for a victim of sexual assault, including consultation, examination, and documentation; ULO2 - Apply comprehensive knowledge of forensic responsibilities in sexual assault cases, including medical responsibilities related to acute injuries, pregnancy issues, medical certificates and prophylaxis; ULO3 - Collect forensic evidence based on the application of relevant scientific and legal methods theory; ULO4 - Demonstrate strong familiarity with the laboratory treatment of forensic evidence; ULO5 - Write a medico-legal report and appear in court under subpoena to assist the court; ULO6 - Evaluate epidemiological, historical, theoretical and cultural aspects across a broad range of circumstance in which sexual assault;
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the history of road trauma and analyse the efficacy of counter measures introduced to combat the road toll; ULO2 - Evaluate the relationship between road safety legislation and policing practices to traffic medicine and road safety; ULO3 - Predict and evaluate the effects of a range of medical conditions upon driving skills with particular reference to licensing; ULO4 - Outline  the known effects of various blood levels of alcohol and other drugs upon driving skills, and how their likely effects  apply to traffic medicine; ULO5 - Identify road safety implications for ageing road users; ULO6 - Interpret common injury patterns resulting from road trauma.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Appropriately and correctly use technical terms associated with analytical toxicology; ULO2 - Give examples of the range of techniques used in forensic toxicology and illustrate where they may be applicable; ULO3 - Discriminate between the common types of drugs seen in forensic medical cases; ULO4 - Comprehend and evaluate the main pharmacological effects of alcohol and common illicit drugs with the emphasis on their effects on behaviours, psychomotor control and cognition; ULO5 - Analyse the relevant behavioural effects of common illicit drug combinations and common adverse illicit drug reactions ; ULO6 - Apply forensic toxicology to case work for the purpose of report preparation and presentation to courts.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Evaluate the responsibilities and powers of custodians; ULO2 - Distinguish between the functions and purposes of custodial and penal institutions; ULO3 - Outline procedures for investigating complaints by prisoners, and the issues surrounding deaths in custody; ULO4 - Evaluate the ethical issues of the doctor/patient relationship in a custodial setting; ULO5 - Conduct an assessment of an individual's fitness to be interviewed or detained in custody; ULO6 - Create management strategies for a range of medical problems presenting in the custodial setting; ULO7 - Identify and evaluate the challenges related to safe prescribing of medications in a custodial environment.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Recommend actions related to victims of sexual violence in terms of counselling, policing and legal perspectives; ULO2 - Assess sexual violence in a global context; ULO3 - Evaluate issues relating to sexual assault medical service provision, considering theory, models and practice; ULO4 - Identify issues in quality assurance in the provision of sexual assault services; ULO5 - Apply medical and psychological skills in dealing with vicarious trauma prevention and management; ULO6 - Interpret sexual violence research, key issues, data and sources.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Complete the collection of data in accordance with the norms of research informed investigation and the boundaries of any ethics approval. ULO2 - Organise, analyse and interpret data meaningfully and according to research norms. ULO3 - Synthesise critical arguments in relation to the existing literature about the topic. ULO4 - Demonstrate writing skills that meet the academic standards associated with a research informed investigation. ULO5 - Communicate research findings to a wider professional audience. ULO6 - Effectively manage time and resources to achieve pre-determined goals.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Advanced issues in non-accidental injury of children
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Detect and characterise inflicted neural and ocular trauma in childhood; ULO2 - Identify the key procedures and medico-legal issues of child death investigations; ULO3 - Discuss factitious illnesses in childhood with particular reference to the medico-legal issues; ULO4 - Apply analytical skills in the understanding of toxicology as it applies to a paediatric population, and appraise the toxic effects on children and adolescents of several commonly abused drugs (both legal and illicit); ULO5 - Critique theories of causation, and interrogate current controversies and areas of uncertainty in the field of non-accidental injury of childhood; ULO6 - Identify and interpret mechanisms of injury associated with abusive head trauma, spinal injury, and ocular injury, and the evidence base upon which the determination as to cause and timing of injury are made; ULO7 - Articulate the difficulties inherent in medical evaluations of complex situations involving suspicions of child abuse, emphasising on the strengths and limitations of medical investigations, and the methods used to present complex medical information to others.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Evaluate the role of health practitioners in assessing cases of suspected child sexual abuse; ULO2 - Identify and explain sexual development and behaviour in children at different developmental stages; ULO3 - Analyse the ethical and legal issues relevant to cases of suspected child sexual abuse; ULO4 - Assess and compare normal genital anatomy and physiology, and interpret abnormal genital findings and pathological conditions; ULO5 - Apply medical and forensic principles to the evaluation, treatment and prevention of cases of suspected child sexual abuse; ULO6 - Distinguish how protective workers, lawyers and police contribute to the investigation of child sexual abuse; ULO7 - Recognise and assess the medical and legal implications of a sexually transmitted infection in a child.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Compare and contrast types of injuries and common injury patterns observed in childhood development stages with those observed in non-accidental injuries and abuse. ULO2 - Accurately assess and document injuries using notes, diagrams and photography. ULO3 - Apply knowledge of non-accidental injury to the analysis of bones, intra-abdominal and intra-thoracic trauma. ULO4 - Outline the processes involved in assessing children when there are concerns of neglect. ULO5 - Critically apply knowledge of the epidemiology of child neglect and physical assault to support injury assessment. ULO6 - Interpret and apply current legislation concerning offences against children.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe ?the core elements of ethical forensic odontological investigations with particular reference to mortuary practice, protocols and examinations ?3.?Explain? human skeletal and dental development over the life span ?including? forensic age estimation methods; ULO2 - Perform advanced mortuary procedures and protocols, including ethical treatment of the deceased, post-mortem dental examination and imaging procedures; ULO3 - Estimate and classify human skeletal and dental development, using appropriate forensic age estimation methods; ULO4 - Distinguish ?human from non-human skeletal and dental elements; ULO5 - Outline ?a dentists role in Disaster Victim Identification; ULO6 - Explain the use of ?CT technology and software systems in medico-legal death investigations; ULO7 - Apply medico-legal report writing to the discipline of forensic odontology.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Post mortem dental identification: Principles and methods
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Confidently follow and apply relevant mortuary protocols and practice - giving specific consideration to OH&S issues and requirements; ULO2 - Perform dental post-mortem examinations using appropriate techniques, including standard and advanced imaging modalities; ULO3 - Analyse the techniques involved in ante-mortem record collection and interpretation methods specifically related to dental issues; ULO4 - Correctly interpret the Interpol DVI guidelines and comprehend the complex issues involved in reconciliation of ante-mortem and post-mortem data using the Interpol standard forms; ULO5 - Accurately describe and report on injuries to the teeth, cranio-facial skeleton, and soft tissues of the face; ULO6 - Evaluate the role of other mortuary based identification methods, such as molecular biology, fingerprints, the weight given to circumstantial evidence, and cranio-facial superimposition.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Evaluate facial trauma giving consideration to the bio-mechanics of the bones of the facial skeleton. ULO2 - Analyse and interpret soft tissue injury in relation to bite mark evidence, applying skills in the discrimination and comparison of such injuries; ULO3 - Evaluate dental age estimation methods as applied to living individuals; ULO4 - Recognise and evaluate the dental manifestations of child abuse; ULO5 - Illustrate the limitations inherent in identification of individuals from CCTV images; ULO6 - Discuss the regulations of the Australian Dental Board as they relate to malpractice and fraud investigation; ULO7 - Construct dento-legal reports, and discuss the ramifications involved in presentation of clinical forensic odontology evidence before the courts.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Disaster victim identification (DVI): Principles and methods
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Evaluate the core elements of Disaster Victim Identification (DVI) principles and methods in odontology investigations following natural and man-made mass fatality incidents; ULO2 - Analyse the role the forensic odontologist plays in each of the 5 phases of a DVI operation; ULO3 - Outline procedures and apply skills in the operation of the common computer based systems used during a DVI operation; ULO4 - Competently apply international protocols, standards, charting methods and the Interpol forms that are used during a DVI incident; ULO5 - Work within the various cultural, religious and legal frameworks in which international DVI incidents may occur; ULO6 - Employ advanced imaging modalities, such as CT technology to DVI scenarios;
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain and assess the role of forensic archaeology and anthropology in the search, location and recovery of human remains. ULO2 - Identify individual skeletal elements, and formulate a hypothesis in respect to their origin (human or nonhuman). ULO3 - Evaluate the preservation and condition of human remains, and assess how preservation impacts on techniques employed by forensic anthropologists. ULO4 - Analyse the principles related to developing a biological profile (estimation of ancestry, sex, age and stature). ULO5 - Explain the differences between biological and personal identity. ULO6 - Describe and evaluate the role of the forensic anthropology in the analysis and interpretation of skeletal pathology and trauma. ULO7 - Appraise the role of forensic anthropology in different contexts of investigation and identification.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically discuss the physical principles and compare and contrast mechanisms of cross sectional imaging in a forensic context; ULO2 - View and manipulate CT images in a medico-legal context using special application software; ULO3 - Identify forensically significant CT findings in all anatomical areas and discriminate between real findings and artefacts; ULO4 - Integrate CT findings with other evidence to present cases in forensic practice; ULO5 - Evaluate and apply advanced CT applications including angiography and guided biopsy, as well as other modalities including MRI and Ultrasound in forensic medicine; ULO6 - Utilise evidence from cross-sectional imaging in the construction of a medico-legal report;
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify and evaluate the role of a mortuary technician as part of a multidisciplinary team in the setting of medico-legal death investigation; ULO2 - Analyse skills in compliance with mortuary OH&S and PPE, and consider and formulate the variations in requirements depending on different case types and situations; ULO3 - Perform the necessary skills in and describe the theory behind the evisceration and reconstruction of a forensic autopsy, including specialist autopsy techniques; ULO4 - Analyse and evaluate the legal framework within which a mortuary technician works, especially the Coronial system applicable in Australia; ULO5 - Assess the roles and elements of successfully managing a mortuary in a disaster situation; ULO6 - Appraise the ethical principles which underpin good forensic mortuary practices.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Advanced methods in forensic science: emerging trends and issues
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically evaluate the changes occurring in forensic science practice and explain these as the result of the engagement with social science and criminalistics. ULO2 - Recognise the links and possible tensions between emerging issues such as forensic intelligence, triage, and cognitive bias, and how these may impact data collection, analysis, and interpretation. ULO3 - Identify risks of existing insular (siloed) approaches between medicine, science, law and law enforcement and its impact on forensic science. ULO4 - Understand and articulate how the proposed changes to insular work practices will affect the current forensic science work flow patterns. ULO5 - Comprehend and articulate the need for the forecast changes in forensic intelligence processes, siloed workplaces, issues of bias and triage, and the benefits these changes will bring to the end-users of forensic science.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Quality management in the forensic sciences
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Comprehend and critically evaluate the principles of quality management and relate these to a forensic investigation ULO2 - Critically evaluate how International Quality Managementstandards in forensic science are applied within the workplace ULO3 - Review and evaluate the underlying principles for International Standards on which QM in the forensic sciences is based. ULO4 - Articulate the management and technical requirements of formal quality accreditation in forensic science laboratories. ULO5 - Comprehend and evaluate the reasons/need for institutionalised QM practices in the context of forensic practice. ULO6 - Explain the role and positioning of quality management in the criminal justice system.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Articulate the specialist applications for specimens in particular types of cases where drug involvement is suspected. ULO2 - Critically evaluate key elements to initiate an investigation where drug involvement is suspected. ULO3 - Demonstrate a thorough understanding of the concepts of advanced analytical practice with its strengths and limitations in relation to drug detection. ULO4 - Demonstrate an advanced understanding of complex pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics responses to drugs and be able to apply this to relevant cases. ULO5 - Articulate the various types of drug interactions of relevance to forensic medicine and their relevance to drug actions. ULO6 - Explain and evaluate the common types of genetic variations that can significantly modify drug effects. ULO7 - Review and evaluate the key elements involved in cases where drug use has modified behaviour, e.g. in drug facilitated assaults.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Synthesize knowledge of different models for death investigation systems. ULO2 - Evaluate how issues of organisation and administration of Coroners death investigation systems and management of key processes impact on the community. ULO3 - Apply the principles of death scene investigation, the processes and procedures used and the roles of the relevant participants. ULO4 - Analyse the principles of the forensic examination of a deceased person, the processes and procedures used and the roles of the relevant participants. ULO5 - Apply the principles of forensic examination of a deceased person to a range of different circumstances where forensic death investigation is required.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Correctly interpret data obtained from chemical analysis techniques to qualitatively and quantitatively determine food components; ULO2 - Apply food chemical concepts to industry-related issues; ULO3 - Effectively communicate the meaning of chemical data to a range of audiences, including industry, using a variety of media; ULO4 - Articulate the molecular, macro, symbolic composition and chemical structure of macro- and micro-nutrients such as carbohydrates, fats, proteins, vitamins, minerals, and additives found in food; ULO5 - Summarise and contrast the chemistry associated with conversion of different sources and types of meat, milk, plants and fats into foods; ULO6 - Explain the chemical principles of reactivity and stability of food components, applying these principles to describe functional properties of foods and ingredients including colour and sensory properties and attributes that confer benefit and risk to consumers; ULO7 - Predict the effects of imposing physical (eg, thermal, pressure, dehydration) and chemical (eg. acid/base, surfactants) stresses during processing of foods, and assess the resulting benefits and risks to consumers.

ULO1 - Interpret information that describes intersections of different aspects of food chemistry and biochemistry, including data generated from practical testing and analysis, and relationships to innovation; ULO2 - Identify and demonstrate solutions to problems of a food chemistry and biochemistry nature, and make the link to innovation and improvement; ULO3 - Relate how in-food or in-process chemical processes influence in-body functionality of foods; ULO4 - Critically analyse and reflect upon quantitative and qualitative data, and technical literature relevant to study topics, including sources of data from different stakeholders, e.g; consumers, industry, government; ULO5 - Design and select sound methodological approaches and frameworks to explaining conceptual challenges in food-related applications, including lab-based testing; ULO6 - Investigate and communicate appropriate professional knowledge and practices relevant to a defined problem, by completing individual and group-based tasks.

ULO1 - Describe microorganisms and assess the relationships that exist between microorganisms and food, including the factors affecting microbial growth and survival; ULO2 - Explain how factors affecting microbial growth are applied to form the principal techniques of food preservation, including the process of fermentation; ULO3 - Describe the microorganisms and microbial enzymes associated with food spoilage, and evaluate the impact of spoilage on global food production; ULO4 - Explain the common causes of food borne illness and evaluate their threat to public health; ULO5 - Outline and evaluate the current methods for examining the microbiological quality and safety of food; ULO6 - Interpret and apply the principles of food safety management such as GMP and HACCP principles and articulate how these are put into practice in different operational settings; ULO7 - Develop effective methods for communicating the importance of food safety to a variety of different stakeholders.

ULO1 - Describe the macro and micro nutrients required for a human health, including the role of key nutrients in human function and the apply nutrient reference values in the context of assessing nutritional status of individuals and populations. ULO2 - Critically reflect on current consumption patterns at national, household and individual levels and how this can impact on over and under nutrient consumption and future sustainability of current dietary patterns. ULO3 - Assess the role, benefits and limitations of food in the aetiology, prevention and treatment of chronic diseases such as obesity, heart-disease, type 2 diabetes, irritable bowel syndrome and bowel cancer. ULO4 - Explain the role of governments on formulating, implementing and enforcing modern food law at the national and international level. ULO5 - Critically evaluate the role food labelling and food-related claims in driving food consumption in the population. ULO6 - Critically evaluate how public policy, both health and non-health, may influence food consumption and nutritional status.

UNIT_TITLE: Advanced food, nutrition and human health
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Appraise the value of functional foods with relevance to population health and the current food landscape; ULO2 - Explain the process of functional food research, including how evidence is generated and used to support innovation; ULO3 - Critically appraise the latest developments in the commercialisation of food and health applications and technologies; ULO4 - Justify the benefits of taking a public health approach to food, including economic, environmental and health impacts; ULO5 - Apply the best available evidence to critically evaluate and solve problems in public health nutrition; ULO6 - Communicate scientific concepts relating to food, nutrition and health effectively and efficiently with peers, professionals and the public.

UNIT_TITLE: Innovation consumer behaviour and food marketing
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the process of taking an innovation to market in the food and beverage industry; ULO2 - Formulate actionable solutions to new product innovation and marketing issues using theoretical and practical approaches; ULO3 - Apply the new product innovation process to the launch of a selected product, with a focus on the important initial phases of the new product innovation process; ULO4 - Analyse and interpret market data and apply innovation theory to create and communicate compelling innovation strategies and plans to key stakeholders and; ULO5 - Reflect on the key facilitators and inhibitors of innovation success in the food and beverage industry.

ULO1 - Discuss how the sustainable development goals relate to food security and theorise how apparent conflicts between them could be managed; ULO2 - Assess the economic and environmental costs and benefits of new approaches to agriculture; ULO3 - Compare different approaches to genetic improvements for enhanced animal and plant production and discuss the governance issues surrounding their introduction; ULO4 - Evaluate and discuss the relationships between the nutritional requirements of consumers and the sustainable production of high quality protein.

UNIT_TITLE: Food science and technology in practice
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Relate the practical application of food science and agribusiness principles to authentic work place contexts and analyse the theory underpinning the practical choices; ULO2 - Correctly and safely manipulate food unit processes in order to produce and analyse food and beverage products and generate empirical data; ULO3 - Assess data collected from practical activities and observations to synthesise research briefs and policy recommendations for industry, research and/or government audiences; ULO4 - Observe food and beverage production from a variety of industries and map these procedures to explain and contrast the considerations of food production from a variety of discipline perspectives; ULO5 - Create the specifications, quality assurance and risk management procedures related to the food industry and food processing suitable for a range of stakeholders.

UNIT_TITLE: Food science and agribusiness research project
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Design and select sound research questions and methodological approaches and frameworks; ULO2 - Develop a project proposal, including a clear model or conceptualisation of the project; ULO3 - Investigate and use established professional practice relevant to the project; ULO4 - Critically analyse outcomes, using appropriate data analysis and established theory and practice related to the project; ULO5 - Communicate the findings, implications and limitations of the project in a clear and professional manner, in written and verbal forms; ULO6 - Collaborate with supervisor and the research team effectively to deliver a major project; ULO7 - Reflect and participate constructively in strategic and outcome-aware decision making consistent with impact areas relevant to food science and agribusiness.

UNIT_TITLE: Food science and agribusiness industry internship
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Develop a practical project proposal, including a clear model or conceptualisation of the project; ULO2 - Investigate and use established professional practice relevant to the project; ULO3 - Communicate the findings, implications and limitations of the project in a clear and professional manner, in written and verbal forms; ULO4 - Collaborate with industry partner effectively to deliver a major project; ULO5 - Demonstrate knowledge and ability to carry them out of modern laboratory practices and procedures; ULO6 - Reflect and participate constructively in strategic and outcome-aware decision making consistent with impact areas relevant to food science and agribusiness.

UNIT_TITLE: Fundamentals of food and sensory science
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Define the scope of food science and its relationship with nutrition and food technology; ULO2 - Describe food composition, food groups and their constituents, and the nutritive aspects of various food groups; ULO3 - Recall nutrition labelling, halal food production and regulations and sensory evaluation; ULO4 - Discuss current issues in food science, nutrition, and technology; ULO5 - Acquire and assess information and knowledge from scientific literature; ULO6 - Demonstrate teamwork; ULO7 - Exhibit skills in scientific writing.

ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding of the digestion and absorption of food and specified nutrients; ULO2 - Display knowledge and understanding on key functions, food sources and requirements of specified nutrients; ULO3 - Display knowledge and understanding on the concept of weight management in regards to energy intake and exercise. ULO4 - Critically analyse personal dietary intake within the framework for Malaysian dietary guideline; ULO5 - Demonstrate ability to collaborate effectively in the production of scientific report and presentations and communicate effectively in giving constructive feedback to peers.

ULO1 - Demonstrate knowledge of typical symbols and terminology used in food processing industries; ULO2 - Describe upstream and downstream processes and equipment; ULO3 - Describe typical bioreactor steps employed in a bioprocess operation; ULO4 - Demonstrate understanding of simple equipment design; ULO5 - Comprehend the effect of financial and safety aspects on process design; ULO6 - Demonstrate communication and report writing skills; ULO7 - Exhibit teamwork skills.

ULO1 - Discuss food as a habitat for microorganisms; ULO2 - Describe microorganisms characteristic to the food industry and their roles in food production, food spoilage, and food-borne illnesses; probiotics and useful microorganism in food. ULO3 - Explain the principles involved in microbiological spoilage of food, microbial control, conventional and new and methods of preserving foods; ULO4 - Recognise the importance of microbiological food criteria and HACCP systems for maintaining food safety in industry; ULO5 - Discuss the use of microorganisms in industrial processes, and providing examples representing the breadth of these applications; ULO6 - Describe the principles and applications of batch and continuous fermentation processes; ULO7 - Describe the application of industrial microbiology for the production of new high-value products of commercial importance.

ULO1 - Apply the knowledge and skills acquired during your academic studies to the practical requirements of the workplace; ULO2 - A positive contribution to the organisation; ULO3 - Demonstrate the capacity to work effectively as a member of a team through well-developed skills in job planning, time management, problem solving, critical thinking and the organisation of work; ULO4 - A sound understanding of the requirements of working with others in a position of responsibility; ULO5 - Effective and appropriate communication skills; ULO6 - Awareness of OHS issues and demonstrate application of safe practices in a workplace environment; ULO7 - An ability to set personal goals and to pursue these goals in a manner appropriate to the workplace.

ULO1 - Define the roles of major and minor food nutrients in the human body and apply nutritional guidelines to plan healthy and balanced diets for various individuals; ULO2 - Describe the digestion, absorption and metabolism of major nutrients in the human body in order to meet the body's needs; ULO3 - Apply the understanding of nutrition management to various nutrition-related diseases; ULO4 - Identify the nutritional requirements of pregnant and lactating women, infants, children, adolescents, adults and older adults; ULO5 - Describe weight management, nutrients usage and dietary requirements of individuals to support daily activities; ULO6 - Acquire information from scientific resources and demonstrate team work and communication skills in their learning.

ULO1 - Demonstrate theoretical and practical knowledge of the various ways that foods may be preserved including thermal and non-thermal processing; ULO2 - Explain the scientific basis of the various preservation techniques and to be able to apply the appropriate preservation techniques for different foods; ULO3 - Select the appropriate packaging for different foods with consideration of the use of resources, packaging stability and food safety; ULO4 - Determine shelf life for foods subjected to different preservation techniques, and be able to locate and appraise appropriate legislation and authoritative guidelines relating to shelf life extension; ULO5 - Demonstrate an understanding of how regional culture may affect acceptance of different preservation techniques; ULO6 - Demonstrate advanced scientific report writing and team work skills.

ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding of the scientific basis for functional foods in promoting health benefits; ULO2 - Justify a role for functional foods in the prevention and/or delay of onset of specific health disorders or disease syndromes; ULO3 - Describe market and social drivers that determine the development, growth and expansion opportunities of functional foods in a global environment; ULO4 - Obtain evidence-based information on the safety and efficacy of functional foods; ULO5 - Evaluate experimental data obtained from the scientific literature and epidemiological sources as a basis to generate ideas for further research and investigation; ULO6 - Critically evaluate current literature relating to innovation and development as well as marketing of novel functional foods within the requirements of a global legislative framework; ULO7 - Demonstrate advanced scientific report writing and oral presentation skills.

ULO1 - Demonstrate theoretical and practical knowledge of the various processing technologies that are used to transform raw materials into nutritious, safe and attractive food products; ULO2 - Demonstrate knowledge of food processing equipment; ULO3 - Explain the scientific basis of the various food processing unit operations; ULO4 - Select the appropriate processing techniques for different foods; ULO5 - Assess the effects of various processing techniques on food quality, safety and nutrition; ULO7 - Keep up to date with new and emerging technologies in food processing; ULO8 - Demonstrate advanced scientific report writing skills.

ULO1 - Demonstrate knowledge of the essential principles, theories, processes and techniques that are applicable to food product development; ULO2 - Appraise food regulations, food sensory evaluation and statistical analysis in food product development; ULO3 - Integrate knowledge and skills to develop new food products and prepare a product prototype for product exhibition; ULO4 - Demonstrate critical and innovative thinking, problem-solving skills, team building and communication skills in learning and product development teamwork; ULO5 - Plan, conduct, and complete a project efficiently; ULO6 - Demonstrate professional communication skills in oral and written presentations.

ULO1 - Describe and explain methods used in quality assurance and quality management in the food industry; ULO2 - Explain how quality assurance can be used to monitor and control food quality and safety; ULO3 - Apply HACCP principles to design food safety plan; ULO4 - Explain how food legislation is enacted and enforced in Malaysia and internationally; ULO5 - Demonstrate an ability to work in teams and to communicate and discuss concepts and applications related to food safety and quality management.

UNIT_TITLE: Food science and technology research project
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding of the processes involved to design, develop and implement a supervised research project; ULO2 - Plan and critically analyse research; ULO3 - Use a variety of computer data systems in a proficient manner; ULO4 - Write and present scientific work in a potentially publishable way; ULO5 - Demonstrate communication skills in oral and written presentations to scientists; ULO6 - Demonstrate technical skills appropriate to their area of study.

UNIT_TITLE: Honours coursework in food science and technology
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding of experimental design and sampling methods that are relevant to their research project; ULO2 - Demonstrate an understanding of the impacts of resource limitation on experimental design and implementation; ULO3 - Critically analyse articles from the scientific literature and use this ability to enhance the quality of their own written work; ULO4 - Express themselves clearly and effectively to a scientific audience; ULO5 - Write and manage assessment tasks expeditiously and competently.

ULO1 - Describe the difference between large scale industrial programming and small scale or scientific programming; ULO2 - Identify common logic patterns in problem descriptions and implement code solutions to these problems using best practice Java coding patterns; ULO3 - Analyse and debug existing Java programs; ULO4 - Describe and use the Java Class Libraries; ULO5 - Code and test multi-class Java applications; ULO6 - Apply good programming practices in accordance with industry standards and professional ethics.

ULO1 - Describe and analyse a range of system development methodologies and be able to assess when to use a particular approach; ULO2 - Describe key activities required for systems development; ULO3 - Apply problem solving techniques at different levels of abstraction; ULO4 - Select suitable techniques and methods to conduct analysis, design and implementation activities; ULO5 - Apply analysis and design techniques to a practical system development problem within a contemporary development methodology framework; ULO6 - Demonstrate an understanding of the professional skills required for effective systems development practice.

ULO1 - Explain the ten knowledge areas of the Project Management Body of Knowledge; ULO2 - Identify the unique attributes and diverse nature of Information Technology projects; ULO3 - Select, justify and use project management techniques and tools for IT projects; ULO4 - Use the appropriate communication method for different types of stakeholders; ULO5 - Identify and apply the characteristics of a collaborative team member.

ULO1 - Analyse simple algorithms to work out an order of magnitude estimate of running time and space; ULO2 - Describe and implement the most common data structures: stacks, queues, lists, priority queues, tables, sets, collections using various common data representations: arrays, linked lists, heaps, trees (including balanced trees), hashing; ULO3 - Evaluate which implementation would be most appropriate for a given data structure and application; ULO4 - Apply the same principles used in implementing the common data structures to implement other data structures and design and implement new data structures; ULO5 - Describe more advanced algorithms in areas such as: graph theory (shortest path etc), pattern searching, data compression (precise selection of advanced algorithms will vary from year to year); ULO6 - Design new algorithms to solve new problems.

ULO1 - Implement basic programming concepts through designing and constructing simple programs using Java as the implementation language; ULO2 - Explain object-oriented concepts such as inheritance, polymorphism, and abstract classes and interfaces and interpret how they are implemented in Java; ULO3 - Apply the object-oriented design principles to a multiple-class object-oriented program; ULO4 - Construct Java programs that include graphical user interface with event handling, collection classes, exception handling and files for persistent data storage; ULO5 - Identify a range of modern tools to support the process of programming complex software systems.

ULO1 - Perform object oriented design and coding to create, test and debug non-trivial, working mobile applications that are maintainable and use the best practices of the development platform; ULO2 - Upload these applications to an appropriate marketplace; ULO3 - Describe the current software technologies and standards used in mobile application development; ULO4 -   Describe the current platform and ecosystem landscape in the mobile application space.

ULO1 - Be able to explain the principles of wireless communication; ULO2 - Understand the role of standardisation bodies for wireless communication; ULO3 - Be able to explain how current wireless networking standards operate; ULO4 - Be able to give a functional description of the components of current wireless networking standards; ULO5 - Be able to describe the architecture and mechanism of current wireless networking standards; ULO6 - Be able to explain the Internet of Things; ULO7 - Appreciate and understand the relevance of each wireless network standard; ULO8 - Be able to design and demonstrate how a wireless network can be applied to solve a real-life problem.

ULO1 - Describe the role of business processes of a typical organisation; ULO2 - Select an appropriate process design and modelling methodology to create a business process model; ULO3 - Document and communicate a business process model for business process improvements; ULO4 - Analyse factors relating to managing small to medium sized projects for in-house development or software outsourcing; ULO5 - Discuss ethical issues related to the management and use of business information systems.

ULO1 - Critically assess cyber threats and risks to an organisation's information systems; ULO2 - Implement access control mechanisms to prevent unauthorised access; ULO3 - Apply cryptographic techniques to disguise information; ULO4 - Apply appropriate countermeasures to defend against cyber security threats; ULO5 - Describe the ethical and privacy issues relating to security of information systems.

ULO1 - Explain the motivations behind the development of database management systems; ULO2 - Describe the underlying theoretical basis of the relational database model and apply the theories into practice; ULO3 - Develop a sound database design; ULO4 - Develop a database based on a sound database design; ULO5 - Construct queries that meet user requirements; ULO6 - Develop a simple web-based interface for a database; ULO7 - Use data modelling and database development tools effectively.

ULO1 - Describe the current technological options with respect to e-business application development and the most likely trends going forward; ULO2 - Analyse and debug existing e-Business applications; ULO3 - Design, code and test basic e-Business applications using current industrial strength techniques; ULO4 - Describe and use some of the core APIs used in e-Business applications; ULO5 - Apply good programming practices in accordance with industry standards and professional ethics.

ULO1 - Analyse and evaluate various strategies used by an operating system in managing the system resources and running applications efficiently; ULO2 - Analyse and identify parameters that can improve the performance of multi-programming operating systems; ULO3 - Apply synchronisation techniques in the development of applications, using operating system services; and ULO4 - Apply system calls in the design of applications, to improve application performance, robustness or functionality.

ULO1 - Design multi-dimensional databases and data warehouses; ULO2 - Use fact and dimensional modelling; ULO3 - Implement online analytical processing (OLAP) queries; ULO4 - Explain query optimisation and its impact on multi-dimensional design; ULO5 - Create business intelligence reports using data warehouses and OLAP.

ULO1 - Describe OSI security architecture and apply common security standards and protocols for network security applications e.g. electronic mail, IP, web and network management; ULO2 - Critically assess threats, vulnerabilities and risks to an organisations information assets and propose control technologies and techniques which can be applied to reduce the security risk; ULO3 - Apply cryptographic techniques to develop methods to disguise information to ensure its integrity, confidentiality and authenticity; ULO4 - Describe the ethical, legal and criminal issues relating to the security of information and computer networks both Wired and Wireless; ULO5 - Implement cryptographic algorithms and security protocols to provide security over networks and the Internet using Virtual Private Networks; ULO6 - Design system security against intruders and malicious software; ULO7 - Apply security configurations to computer and network based applications. ULO8 - Describe and apply firewall configurations to protect networks. ULO9 - Implement network management protocols and security requirements.

ULO1 - Explain how IT applications are developed, including all aspects of the development process; ULO2 - Explain the roles and responsibilities of clients, system users, management and developers in a development project; ULO3 - Apply, in a practical setting, aspects of the theoretical work covered in their course; ULO4 - Develop an IT application using a prescribed methodology, conducting all activities associated with the development methodology; ULO5 - Work with clients or client representatives, communicating effectively with them to meet their requirements; ULO6 - Operate effectively as a member of a development team; ULO7 - Evaluate, assess and communicate both personal and team progress and learning, thus engaging in meaningful reflective practice.

ULO1 - Apply, in a practical setting, aspects of the theoretical work covered in their course; ULO2 - Develop an IT application using a prescribed methodology, conducting all activities associated with the development methodology; ULO3 - Work with clients or client representatives, communicating effectively with them to meet their requirements; ULO4 - Operate effectively as a member of a development team; ULO5 - Evaluate, assess and communicate both personal and team progress and learning, thus engaging in meaningful reflective practice; ULO6 - Explain the roles and responsibilities of clients, system users, service providers, management and developers in the implementation phase of an IT project; ULO7 - Develop documentation and processes that can be used to implement and maintain an IT system.

ULO1 - Model and design flexible software at the architectural level using various tools and techniques; ULO2 - Analyse and design software systems taking into consideration various quality attributes and requirements; ULO3 - Take requirements for simple systems and develop software architectures and designs at a high level; ULO4 - Use configuration management tools effectively; ULO5 - Apply a variety of design patterns, frameworks and architectures in designing software; ULO6 - Locate and use off-the-shelf components in the construction of software.

ULO1 - Explain the concepts of innovation and entrepreneurship ULO2 - Demonstrate entrepreneurial creativity ULO3 - Apply the concepts of intellectual property & venture funding to projects ULO4 - Conduct basic market research, and analyse the results ULO5 - Create and evaluate a value proposition ULO6 - Formulate, review and defend a business case ULO7 - Devise a pitch and demonstrate pitching competency.

ULO1 - Develop interactive decision models for business analysis and business process improvements; ULO2 - Design and implement and analyse spreadsheet-based simulations and mathematical optimisation models; ULO3 - Interpret the results of mathematical decision models and conduct sensitivity analyses; ULO4 - Critically assess the accuracy and applicability of modelling techniques; ULO5 - Communicate the results of model-based decision analysis.

ULO1 - Differentiate between mobile data and traditional stationery databases; ULO2 - Explain the concepts required for efficient persistent and client-side data management; ULO3 - Design and implement mobile databases that apply the principles of mobile storage mechanisms, mobile transaction management, and recovery; ULO4 - Demonstrate the use and impact of multi-source data synchronisation, data caching and invalidation, and data consistency and integrity in mobile data management; ULO5 - Apply push, pull and broadcast data techniques to the design and evaluation of mobile databases.

ULO1 - Explain the network architecture standards for open systems; ULO2 - Describe and apply the ISO reference and Internet models; ULO3 - Implement programs using internetworking concepts, IP addressing, IPC and socket-level interface; ULO4 - Analyse the fundamentals and technologies of cabled and wireless physical layer; ULO5 - Analyse the fundamentals and technologies of cabled and wireless data-link layer; ULO6 - Apply and implement the fundamentals and technologies of the network layer, including packet-switching and queueing concepts; ULO7 - Analyse designs based on the functions and architectures of cabled and wireless LAN and WAN, including ALOHA and CSMA/CD models; ULO8 - Implement system level designs based on LAN architecture for organisational requirements.

ULO1 - Explain and apply advanced concepts related to mobile data, content storage, management, networking and interfaces to mobile systems; ULO2 - Integrate knowledge and skills related to mobile standards, networks, data management, and pervasive and ubiquitous computing in designing mobile system solutions; ULO3 - Demonstrate solutions and selection of appropriate tools to solve various challenges of wireless communications, such as mobility, security, quality of service, resource allocation, interference, inter-operability, spectrum management; ULO4 - Explain advanced concepts of the Internet of Things; ULO5 - Propose applications and design mobile systems that implement concepts of the Internet of Things.

ULO1 - Model the possible vulnerabilities and threats for a given application system; ULO2 - Apply appropriate methods for the design and realisation of secure software; ULO3 - Analyse and evaluate security properties of concurrent and networked applications.

ULO1 - Demonstrate the capability to develop an appropriate type of IT strategy which is consistent with the corporate strategy of business organisations; ULO2 - Demonstrate a capacity to describe how IT governance can be applied to improve IT function and its performance; ULO3 - Critically evaluate the benefits associated with various IT outsourcing options suitable for business organisations; ULO4 - Demonstrate the capability to avoid IT systems failure using IT governance; ULO5 - Critically discuss the major legal issues that may affect IT systems and operations; ULO6 - Demonstrate an ability to prepare IT budgets for business.

ULO1 - Demonstrate a broader and deeper understanding of the twelve principles of green chemistry and how to apply them to problem solving; ULO2 - Evaluate technologies and products by applying the methods and tools to of green chemistry in the practice of chemistry; ULO3 - Explain how the application of green chemistry principles can address the UN Sustainable Development Goals. ULO4 - Identify the tools and strategies to improve the chemical reaction and process using the principles of green chemistry ULO5 - Explain how the practice of green chemistry enhances competitiveness, innovation and faster time to market, while addressing critical ethical and sustainability issues.

UNIT_TITLE: Green chemistry innovation - transforming industry and manufacturing
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify and articulate the sources of innovation in the chemical sector in terms of value creation and capture through applying green/sustainable chemistry principles; ULO2 - Describe and explain the components of a chemical business and show understanding of the economic drivers (including regulatory) for the industry; ULO3 - Characterise and interpret the financial considerations that determine the rules of the game for the chemical industry; ULO4 - Identify bottlenecks and other factors that set operational constraints and apply strategies that offer solutions to optimise the production system; ULO5 - Apply green/sustainable chemistry principles to circular economy initiatives life cycle analysis, and propose realistic solutions that can be adopted by industry; ULO6 - Engage, with a progressive voice, in regulatory discussions that will facilitate government and industry cooperation

ULO1 - Plan and execute a collaborative team project in cooperation with a partner organisation; ULO2 - Translate, evaluate and integrate varied green chemistry knowledge to find green chemistry solutions; ULO3 - Identify and critically appraise social, environmental and economic considerations when designing green chemistry solutions; ULO4 - Propose and justify a solution-based approach to the industry problem; ULO5 - Demonstrate critical understanding of the real-world challenges associated with addressing sustainable development; ULO6 - Present and report the outcome in a clear and coherent way that is effective for the purpose and the intended audience.

ULO1 - Critically analyse, evaluate and integrate research and other relevant literature; ULO2 - Formulate a research hypothesis and effective objectives that can be addressed through appropriate research question; ULO3 - Conceptualise, design and manage an independent research project; ULO4 - Conduct independent and ethical research, applying sound principles of study design and appropriate data analysis methods; ULO5 - Develop a sound and logical argument through correctly analysing, interpreting and presenting evidence to support or reject a research hypothesis; ULO6 - Demonstrate advanced academic writing skills by?producing a thesis and/or manuscripts appropriate for?publication in the field of chemistry; ULO7 - Clearly communicate the implications and applications of the research to the broader society.

ULO1 - Critically analyse, evaluate and integrate research and other relevant literature; ULO2 - Formulate a research hypothesis and effective objectives that can be addressed through appropriate research question; ULO3 - Conceptualise, design and manage a research project, either individually or in a collaborative situation; ULO4 - Conduct independent and/or group and ethical research, applying sound principles of study design and appropriate data analysis methods; ULO5 - Develop a sound and logical argument through correctly analysing, interpreting and presenting evidence to support or reject a research hypothesis; ULO6 - Demonstrate advanced academic writing skills by?producing a thesis and/or manuscripts appropriate for?????? publication; ULO7 - Clearly communicate the implications of the research to broader society and applications of the research.

ULO1 - Explain the central role of genes in the inheritance of traits and describe the complex variations in inheritance patterns due to interaction of genes with each other and with the environment; ULO2 - Illustrate the common chromosomal and molecular mechanisms that underlie inheritance and the structure of DNA, genes and chromosomes; ULO3 - Explain what genes are, how they are regulated, how they control phenotypes, and how they can be altered by mutation; ULO4 - Describe a range of organisms used in studying genetics (viruses, bacteria, fungi, plants, invertebrates and vertebrates, including humans) and explain their common and unique features; ULO5 - Convey to a non-specialist audience the relevance and value of genetics to human society; ULO6 - Demonstrate skills in basic laboratory techniques, in genetics problem-solving and experimental design, and in data collection, analysis, interpretation and presentation; ULO7 - Demonstrate and recognise the value of working with peers.

ULO1 - Explain how genes are organised in chromosomes and genomes and the implications of this for gene expression and function, how genomes are mapped and sequenced, how genes and genomes are analysed at a molecular level, and the uses of genomics in modern genetic research; ULO2 - Illustrate how DNA and genomes change and the implications of this for evolution and the uses of DNA variation in modern applications such as DNA profiling; ULO3 - Explain how genes behave in populations, describe concepts such as mutation and genetic drift, and illustrate how genetic variation can result in fitness differences that may drive evolution through the process of natural selection; ULO4 - Describe the relevance and value of genetics and genomic to human society; ULO5 - Evaluate basic bioinformatics methods such as sequence alignment in comparative genomics and interpret the statistical results. ULO6 - Demonstrate skills in basic laboratory techniques in problem-solving and experimental design, and in data collection, analysis, interpretation and presentation.

ULO1 - Analyze current high-throughput techniques to generate omics data and apply standard workflows to analyze them. ULO2 - Implement gene set enrichment, network analysis and data visualization protocols. ULO3 - Evaluate genome assemblies and underlying algorithms using short and long read sequencing data. ULO4 - Perform basic computer programming with case studies involving DNA pattern finding. ULO5 - Describe applications of machine learning in biology. ULO6 - Demonstrate team work, scientific communication and peer to peer learning and feedback.

ULO1 - Compare and contrast techniques used to study gene function, including techniques to monitor gene transcription and protein cellular localisation and to manipulate gene activity in living organisms; ULO2 - Articulate the advantages provided by the use of model laboratory organisms to investigate molecular, cellular and developmental processes; ULO3 - Illustrate the application of gene function analysis techniques to advance medical, biological, agricultural, biotechnology and environmental research; ULO4 - Collect, analyse, interpret and present genetic data effectively in the preparation of scientific reports; ULO5 - Synthesise and critique new discoveries from the scientific literature in molecular, developmental and cellular genetics.

ULO1 - Describe recent advances in genetic knowledge gained from genomic analysis of species ranging from unicellular to multicellular organisms. ULO2 - Explain the philosophy of forward and reverse genetics including genome editing techniques. ULO3 - Determine potential applications for genomic techniques in the areas of medical research, agriculture, biotechnology and environmental management; ULO4 - Utilise bioinformatic tools to compare DNA and protein sequences, search for genetic variants controlling complex traits, analyse transcriptome data and search for genomic signatures for adaptation; ULO5 - Illustrate the processes required to map and identify genes controlling complex biological traits and articulate how forward genetics approaches can be used to determine gene function; ULO6 - Collect, analyse, interpret and present genetic data effectively in the preparation of scientific reports; ULO7 - Synthesize and critique new discoveries from the scientific literature in genomics.

ULO1 - Explain the application of modern genetic techniques such as gene mapping, genome-wide association studies and individual genome-sequencing to: i) the characterisation, diagnosis and treatment of simple and complex human diseases; and ii) the identification of individuals and relationships between individuals by forensic genetics; ULO2 - Describe how variations in the DNA sequence of a gene can result in changes in gene function that ultimately lead to disease symptoms and explain how improved understanding of this molecular pathology can aid in the treatment of disease, and illustrate the value of model organisms in investigating the molecular pathology of human diseases; ULO3 - Appraise ethical issues affecting both the individual and society raised by advances in human genetics; ULO4 - Demonstrate high-level skills in data collection, analysis, interpretation and presentation, and apply these in written scientific reports and oral presentations; ULO5 - Apply advanced problem-solving skills to issues of medical and forensic genetics; ULO6 - Critically evaluate and summarise new discoveries from the scientific literature in medical and forensic genetics.

ULO1 - Understand the role of evolutionary processes in diverse biological contexts. ULO2 - Define genetic diversity, explain how to measure it, and explain how the different types of genetic diversity influence evolutionary processes; ULO3 - Explain quantitative, genomic and experimental approaches to measuring genetic variation and studying evolution in natural populations. ULO4 - Illustrate how evolution by natural selection can be detected, and how evolution and genetic diversity are central to the successful management of biodiversity, invasive species and disease. ULO5 - Demonstrate high-level skills in data collection, analysis and interpretation, and data presentation, and apply these in the preparation and presentation of scientific reports in written form and oral presentations. ULO6 - Critically evaluate and summarise new discoveries from the scientific literature in the field of applied evolutionary genetics.

ULO1 - Comprehend the fundamental process and requirements of scientific research; ULO2 - Review and critically evaluate the scientific literature within a relevant discipline; ULO3 - Demonstrate skills in experimental design, data collection and statistical analysis; ULO4 - Interpret experimental results, and place the results in the broader context of the research discipline; ULO5 - Communicate scientific findings and their implications, via oral presentations and written reports.

ULO1 - Demonstrate and apply knowledge of contemporary areas of molecular genetics and biotechnology, and the challenges faced; ULO2 - Illustrate and explain how transgenic organisms are produced via genome manipulation across a range of species; ULO3 - Source, synthesise and critically analyse literature to form the basis of a project; ULO4 - Independently design and implement experimental approaches to solve a research problem in genetics and biotechnology; ULO5 - Demonstrate proficiency in molecular genetics laboratory techniques, in problem-solving and experimental design, and in data collection, analysis, interpretation and presentation; ULO6 - Convey to a non-specialist audience the relevance and value of genetics and biotechnology to human society.

ULO1 - Identify relevant and significant nursing issues for investigation. ULO2 - Analyse varying understandings of the nature of evidence and the process of evidence-based practice. ULO3 - Critically analyse various approaches to nursing research. ULO4 - Discuss the strengths and weaknesses of different methodologies and research designs. ULO5 - Apply appropriate research methodologies and designs to specific nursing questions. ULO6 - Identify, apply and defend the use of appropriate strategies for collecting and analysing quantitative and qualitative data within specific methodological frameworks. ULO7 - Locate, critically appraise and synthesise research evidence relating to nursing questions. ULO8 - Analyse the principles of ethical research conduct and discuss their application in practice. ULO9 - Identify and analyse breaches of academic and research integrity. ULO10 - Analyse strategies to achieve rigour in specific research methodologies.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically analyse leadership and management theories relevant to nursing and their application to nursing practice ULO2 - Evaluate clinical leadership readiness and related skill sets of nurses in practice ULO3 - Explore and analyse the impact of nursing leadership and management to patient safety and care quality ULO4 - Discuss how clinical risk, near misses, errors and risk assessment and incident monitoring promote a culture of patient safety and care quality ULO5 - Analyse and apply risk management principles to identify, assess and report potential risks in healthcare delivery ULO6 - Critically analyse the components of governance within healthcare contexts in relation to patient safety and care quality ULO7 - Critique approaches and techniques for improving patient safety and care quality in contemporary nursing practice ULO8 - Critically examine risk management plans in service delivery for inclusion of concepts of safety, quality and clinical governance ULO9 - Critique the effectiveness of a range of continuous quality improvement strategies for the purpose of risk reduction in the clinical setting ULO10 - Formulate strategies to address an identified risk in health care delivery using a continuous quality improvement process
