UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the mechanisms that enable cells to move in response to external stimuli; ULO2 - Discuss the way in which DNA is replicated within the cell, the mechanisms for maintaining DNA integrity and the implications of acquiring errors in the DNA sequence; ULO3 - Outline the mechanisms that drive gene expression and the way in which gene expression is regulated; ULO4 - Illustrate how our understanding of cellular and molecular processes is enhanced through the use of animal models, microscopy and laboratory techniques; ULO5 - Demonstrate skills in laboratory techniques relevant to cell and molecular biology, and the ability to analyse experimental data by integrating concepts and knowledge.

ULO1 - Explain the central role of genes in the inheritance of traits and the complex variation in inheritance patterns that arise due to interactions of genes with each other and the environment; ULO2 - Explain how genetic variation is generated by mutation and the importance of this in phenotypic variation, evolution and disease; ULO3 - Describe the value of model organisms in studying human gene function in development and disease; ULO4 - Demonstrate understanding of the relevance and value of genetics to human society; ULO5 - Demonstrate skills in independent problem-solving and experimental design, and in data collection, analysis and interpretation; ULO6 - Demonstrate skills in written and oral communication through written reports and oral presentations of research findings by small groups.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate and apply knowledge of contemporary areas of molecular genetics and biotechnology, and the challenges faced; ULO2 - Illustrate and explain how transgenic organisms are produced via genome manipulation across a range of species; ULO3 - Source, synthesise and critically analyse literature to form the basis of a project; ULO4 - Independently design and implement experimental approaches to solve a research problem in genetics and biotechnology; ULO5 - Demonstrate proficiency in molecular genetics laboratory techniques, in problem-solving and experimental design, and in data collection, analysis, interpretation and presentation; ULO6 - Convey to a non-specialist audience the relevance and value of genetics and biotechnology to human society.

ULO1 - Identify functionally important sequences within a genome and explain how changes in these can impact phenotypes at both the mechanistic and molecular level; ULO2 - Design experimental approaches to determine the functional consequences of sequence variants; ULO3 - Demonstrate proficiency in: molecular biology and genetics laboratory techniques; problem-solving; data collection; and analysis, interpretation and presentation of results; ULO4 - Illustrate, with examples, how the concepts presented in this unit can be applied to real-world situations.

ULO1 - Evaluate current high-throughput techniques to generate omics data and apply standard workflows to analyse them; ULO2 - Investigate gene set enrichment, network analysis and data visualisation protocols; ULO3 - Evaluate genome assemblies and underlying algorithms using short and long read sequencing data; ULO4 - Perform basic computer programming with case studies involving DNA pattern finding; ULO5 - Compare and contrast machine learning applications in biology; ULO6 - Demonstrate team work, scientific communication and peer to peer learning and feedback.

ULO1 - Contrast the data types generated by all commonly used sequencing platforms; ULO2 - Compare common techniques used for library preparation and explain which library preparation methods are used for a particular task; ULO3 - Assess data quality and perform error correction for different types of sequence data; ULO4 - Manipulate sequence data from commonly used sequencing techniques and identify suitable variant calling approaches; ULO5 - Perform basic genomic analyses associated with functional characterization of variants.

ULO1 - Evaluate recent advances in genetic knowledge gained from genomic analysis of species ranging from unicellular to multicellular organisms; ULO2 - Explain the philosophy of forward and reverse genetics including genome editing techniques; ULO3 - Critique applications of genomic techniques in the areas of medical research, agriculture, biotechnology and environmental management; ULO4 - Utilise and appraise bioinformatic tools to compare DNA and protein sequences, search for genetic variants controlling complex traits, analyse transcriptome data and search for genomic signatures for adaptation; ULO5 - Illustrate the processes required to map and identify genes controlling complex biological traits and articulate how forward genetics approaches can be used to determine gene function; ULO6 - Collect, analyse, interpret and present genetic data effectively in the preparation of scientific reports; ULO7 - Synthesise and critique new discoveries from the scientific literature in genomics; ULO8 - Develop biological hypotheses and justify experimental approaches to evaluate them using genomic techniques and bioinformatic tools.

ULO1 - Assess the application of modern genetic techniques to: i) the characterisation, diagnosis and treatment of human diseases; and ii) the identification of individuals and relationships between individuals by forensic genetics; ULO2 - Evaluate how variations in? sequence can? affect gene function and? lead to disease symptoms; outline how understanding molecular pathology can aid in the treatment of disease; and illustrate the value of model organisms in investigating human disease; ULO3 - Demonstrate high-level skills in data collection, analysis, interpretation and presentation, and combine these in written scientific reports and oral presentations; ULO4 - Combine advanced problem-solving skills to evaluate issues involving medical and forensic genetics; ULO5 - Critically evaluate and summarise new discoveries from the scientific literature in medical and forensic genetics.

ULO1 - Demonstrate proficiency in basic laboratory skills associated with research in reproductive biology ULO2 - Comprehend the literature available and synthesize a review that describes the current scientific understandings ULO3 - Develop skills in report writing and scientific biostatistics ULO4 - Demonstrate skills in the presentation of scientific data ULO5 - Compose a research plan to solve a problem using well established experimental design and measurable outcomes ULO6 - Outline the current scientific methods used in the reproductive sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Human pathology 2: Pathology of human diseases
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain how human?pathologies differ from normal?organ and physiological?systems ULO2 - Use analytical techniques to generate and evaluate clinical and pathological data for a range of human diseases including kidney pathology; brain pathology; multiple sclerosis; leukaemia; skin cancer; liver pathology and red blood cell pathology; ULO3 - Apply clinical and pathological?knowledge to determine a?diagnosis; ULO4 - Identify and distinguish between different disease mechanisms that cause tissue damage in major organ systems and examine how drugs may interrupt these pathological pathways; ULO5 - Categorise and compare?different human pathologies?based on diagnostic molecularmarkers and/or biomarkers.

ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding of how the organs and tissues of a healthy body become diseased; ULO2 - Demonstrate appreciation of the involvement of metabolic interrelationships in health and disease, including vitamins, micro and macro minerals and also some organ functions; ULO3 - Explain the biochemical, physiological and immunological processes involved in normal body functions and disturbances that may occur in different diseased states with respect to blood eg. anaemias, leukaemias and some bleeding disorders; ULO4 - Interpret and critically analyse laboratory results in order to distinguish between normal and pathological specimens; ULO5 - Demonstrate capacity to work effectively as part of a team in a medical laboratory; ULO6 - Be aware of OHS issues and demonstrate application of safe practices in a medical/clinical diagnostic laboratory; ULO7 - Communicate scientific information via written reports.

ULO1 - Describe the causes and clinical effects of diseases eg. cytological problems associated with gynaecological and non-gynaecological abnormalities, circulatory disorders and disorders of growth such as hyperplasia and neoplasia; ULO2 - Describe the pathophysiology of some parasitic diseases borne by insects and arachnids found in the Malaysian region and understand their life cycles; ULO3 - Identify important parasites and vectors in various parasitic diseases; ULO4 - Process tissues, slides and specimens including sputum and other body fluids, and prepare Papanicolaou (cervical) smears for diagnosis; ULO5 - Interpret and critically analyse laboratory results in order to distinguish between normal and pathological specimens; ULO6 - Demonstrate capacity to work effectively as part of a team in a medical laboratory; ULO7 - Be aware of OHS issues and demonstrate application of safe practices in a medical/clinical diagnostic laboratory; ULO8 - Communicate scientific information via written reports.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Respond creatively to design briefs of advanced complexity; ULO2 - Investigate relevant concepts and precedents in design discourse and incorporate these into design proposals; ULO3 - Demonstrate the resolution of competing needs during the development of a design proposal; ULO4 - Apply design strategies with increasing awareness and independence; ULO5 - Explore and communicate design schemes through appropriate modes of representation; ULO6 - Understand and apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the discipline practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate a high level of proficiency and autonomy in interior architectural production; ULO2 - Identify and evaluate relevant research concepts, strategies and methods, and apply them in interior architecture and associated fields; ULO3 - Develop design briefs and strategies in relation to research agendas; ULO4 - Critically assess and apply contemporary design theories and practices within local and international contexts; ULO5 - Engage productively with reflective practices in design and integrate relevant skills developed throughout the course; ULO6 - Understand and apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the discipline practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Perform a variety of tasks to an adequate professional standard within an architectural/interior architectural working environment; ULO2 - Operate effectively and constructively as a team-member within an architectural/interior architectural project team; ULO3 - Reflect critically upon the operational strengths and weaknesses of project and office management procedures employed within an architectural/interior architectural professional context; ULO4 - Understand from first hand experience a variety of the tasks and problems that constitute interior architecture practice, and be able to describe approaches to them.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Investigate, consider and apply diverse design research approaches; ULO2 - Describe and defend a considered position using scholarly conventions; ULO3 - Situate personal and speculative design practices within a critical discourse; ULO4 - Develop an appropriate interior architecture design research proposal; ULO5 - Understand and apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the discipline practice.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate reflective approaches for the production of design research; ULO2 - Document and communicate the processes and findings of a design research project; ULO3 - Locate your work in relation to socio-economic, cultural, design and intellectual developments relevant to interior architecture; ULO4 - Select and apply appropriate design research concepts, strategies and methods; ULO5 - Understand and apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the discipline practice.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Integrate knowledge, skills and understanding gained in the classroom and laboratory settings; ULO2 - Relate scientific knowledge and skills gained in coursework to productive employment experience; ULO3 - Apply their expertise to real-world problems.

ULO1 - Develop ideas through drawing that show salient features of an intended design, rather than a pre-existing object; ULO2 - Use drawing as a method for externalising your thoughts and developing ideas; ULO3 - Persuasively communicate your ideas through the development of concept presentation sketches and renderings in a product design context; ULO4 - Demonstrate proficiency in the selection and use of appropriate drawing mediums, techniques and equipment to suit the nature of the design; ULO5 - Understand and apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the discipline practice.

UNIT_TITLE: Basic immunology: The body's defence system
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Define the key structural and cellular components of the immune system; ULO2 - Define the key features associated with the development of the immune system; ULO3 - Generate, evaluate and compile practical laboratory based data into define structured written reports; ULO4 - Generate and deliver an oral presentation on a defined area of immunology; ULO5 - Draw upon learnt knowledge of immunology to explain how the immune system is associated with protection against pathogens.

ULO1 - Define the key role of the immune system in a range of human immune mediated diseases; ULO2 - Define the mechanisms of inflammation used in a range of immune based diseases of conditions; ULO3 - Work constructively in a group to design, research and generate a web based information site on selected areas of immunology; ULO4 - Work within a group environment to design, research, generate and deliver oral presentations on selected aspects of immunology; ULO5 - Apply skills developed in this unit to research, appraise and generate a written, oral or video output that focuses on a defined area of immunology.

ULO1 - Evaluate the contributions of cells and molecules to the immune system; ULO2 - Demonstrate how the immune system responds to infection and disease; ULO3 - Describe and distinguish how differing arms of the immune response are integrated and regulated; ULO4 - Define and compare the innate and adaptive immune systems and how these discriminate self from non-self; ULO5 - Critically appraise experimental data, cutting edge technologies, and the immunological literature and demonstrate skills in oral and written communication.

ULO1 - Describe the functional and regulatory pathways of the normal immune system. ULO2 - Explain how various pathogens evade the immune system and evaluate immunopathologies resulting from infection. ULO3 - Examine and compare the pathogenesis of different disorders of the immune system such as autoimmunity, allergy, inflammatory diseases, immunodeficiency, leukemia/lymphoma and transplant rejection. ULO4 - Evaluate immunotherapeutic and immunomodulatory strategies, and determine their suitability for prevention, treatment or cure of immune disorders. ULO5 - Analyse and interpret data from immunopathology experiments, and demonstrate effective communication of data to an appropriate audience in both written and oral formats in relation to these experiments.

ULO1 - Compare different methods of purifying antibodies from a range of different biological sources; ULO2 - Validate different methods of testing purified antibody products; ULO3 - Perform common laboratory experimental techniques, laboratory skills and calculations; ULO4 - Accurately record, analyse and report experimental outcomes to a variety of audiences;? ULO5 - Synthesise and present experimental findings in the context of relevant scientific literature.

ULO1 - Perform research and diagnostic laboratory techniques, laboratory skills and calculations; ULO2 - Implement safe and competent scientific work-practices; ULO3 - Identify relevant questions for scientific inquiry through a written assessment and present this in a research forum; ULO4 - Accurately record, analyse and report experimental outcomes; ULO5 - Synthesise and present experimental findings in the context of relevant scientific literature.

ULO1 - Describe the normal function, regulation and anatomy of the immune system and how it provides defence against microorganisms; ULO2 - Demonstrate an understanding of pathogenesis of disorders of the immune system and strategies for immunosuppression and immunopotentiation to correct these disorders; ULO3 - Apply principles of immunological techniques used in diagnostic and research laboratories; ULO4 - Demonstrate advanced scientific report writing and team work skills.

ULO1 - Undertake a research project with regard to ethical and safety regulations; ULO2 - Demonstrate technical skills in experimental methods and the ability to collect, analyse and interpret data using methods relevant to the discipline of Immunology; ULO3 - Communicate appropriately and effectively with supervisors, laboratory staff and students; ULO4 - Maintain accurate and up-to-date records of experimental procedures, results and outcomes; ULO5 - Identify relevant published scientific literature and critically analyse and evaluate the content in the context of the discipline of Immunology; ULO6 - Construct written reports.

UNIT_TITLE: Foundations of health in primary clinical care
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Reflect on their own values and assumptions regarding health and well-being. ULO2 - Explain the influence of diverse definitions, concepts and interpretations of health and well-being on health care. ULO3 - Compare and contrast various models and frameworks of health and describe the value of these. ULO4 - Identify the various determinants of health and describe how these affect health care provision and create inequalities in health. ULO5 - Apply the principles of the 'determinants of health' approach in discussing selected health issues. ULO6 - Discuss critical perspectives used to explore health and examine their implications for health and social care practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - design, construct, test and document small computer programs using Java; ULO2 - interpret and demonstrate software engineering principles of maintainability, readability, and modularisation; ULO3 - explain and apply the concepts of the "object-oriented" style of programming.

ULO1 - design, construct, test and document computer programs using Python; ULO2 - recognised the relationship between a problem description and program design; ULO3 - demonstrate how basic data structures and data types function; ULO4 - investigate different strategies for algorithm development and evaluate these to select an appropriate solution to a given problem.

ULO1 - Examine and describe computer hardware and software architectures; ULO2 - Explain the three major functions of an operating system (OS), namely, process management, memory management, and file management; ULO3 - Describe the underlying fundamental theories, models and protocols for transmitting data across a network; ULO4 - Describe the functions and architectures of local area networks, wide area networks and the Internet; ULO5 - Identify and describe fundamental concepts of network security including common threats and countermeasures; ULO6 - Evaluate several different design options and formulate a simple network design.

ULO1 - Investigate methods that are appropriate for the realisation software security; ULO2 - Investigate and model the possible vulnerabilities and threats for a given application system; ULO3 - Design, implement and produce test procedures and perform evaluation of software security features of concurrent and networked applications; ULO4 - Analyse and evaluate software security related scenarios with reference to the code of ethics and professional practice.

ULO1 - Explain the theoretical foundations of Artificial Intelligence (AI) - such as the Turing test, Rational Agency and the Frame Problem - that underpin the application to information technology and society; ULO2 - Critically explain, evaluate and apply appropriate AI theories, models and/or techniques in practice - including logical inference, heuristic search, genetic algorithms, supervised and unsupervised machine learning and Bayesian inference; ULO3 - Utilise appropriate software tools to develop AI models or software; and ULO4 - Utilise and explain evaluation criteria to measure the correctness and/or suitability of models.

ULO1 - Describe the breadth and nature of the software engineering process and distinguish various phases of the process; ULO2 - Create and develop the required artefacts during each phase of the software engineering process; ULO3 - Differentiate and evaluate the software engineering techniques used to produce the artefacts; ULO4 - Assess the issues in constructing large software systems from its components, and the nature and design of these components; ULO5 - Employ group working skills in solving software development problems; and ULO6 - Analyse and evaluate IT-related scenarios with reference to the software engineering code of ethics and professional practice.

ULO1 - Critically assess threats, vulnerabilities and risks to an organisation's information assets and propose control technologies and techniques which can be applied to reduce the security risk; ULO2 - Apply a variety of cryptographic algorithms to develop methods to disguise information to ensure its integrity, confidentiality and authenticity; ULO3 - Apply a variety of methods for key management and distribution and analyse the risks associated with the various approaches; ULO4 - Implement user authentication and access control mechanisms to create a security architecture to protect the assets of the information system; ULO5 - Implement cryptographic techniques to preserve the security of information and evaluate its effectiveness; ULO6 - Apply a variety of security control technologies to IT systems in an organisation.

ULO1 - Perform exploratory data analysis with descriptive statistics on given datasets; ULO2 - Construct models for inferential statistical analysis; ULO3 - Produce models for predictive statistical analysis; ULO4 - Perform fundamental random sampling, simulation and hypothesis testing for required scenarios; ULO5 - Implement a model for data analysis through programming and scripting; ULO6 - Interpret results for a variety of models.

ULO1 - Describe what statistical machine learning and its theoretical concepts are; ULO2 - Assess a typical machine learning model and algorithm; ULO3 - Develop, and apply major models and algorithms for statistical learning; ULO4 - Scale typical statistical learning algorithms to learn from big data.

UNIT_TITLE: Material transformations: jewellery and object forming
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Establish experimental studio processes that generate ongoing creative enquiry in jewellery, body related objects and object based sculpture; ULO2 - Demonstrate an understanding of different material properties and the conceptual implication of basic studio techniques; ULO3 - Articulate and engage critical dialogue and research surrounding methods, design and materials; ULO4 - Apply technical skills in metal, wood and plastic fabrication and other creative strategies as a form of expression appropriate to the concepts you are investigating; ULO5 - Demonstrate an understanding of the place contemporary jewellery and object-based practice in the fields of contemporary creative practice, nationally and internationally; ULO6 - Understand and apply the rules of occupational health and safety appropriate to the discipline and context.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain how the institutions of the Australian legal system shape the content and administration of the law ULO2 - Reflect on the role and responsibilities of lawyers in the administration of justice ULO3 - Demonstrate a developing awareness of the role of law in facilitating the formation, operation and regulation of private legal entities, and the commercial significance of law's role in this respect ULO4 - Locate efficiently the current law on a legal issue using library resources critically evaluate the relevance, quality, authority and currency of the materials that they find ULO5 - Find the statutes and related extrinsic materials relevant to answering a legal question ULO6 - Extract and formulate legal propositions from judicial decisions, and assess their scope, legal validity and weight ULO7 - Interpret, analyse, synthesise and apply the law when located, to solve a legal problem ULO8 - Make a legal argument, or provide an opinion, and to do so clearly, accurately and concisely ULO9 - Design and implement an efficient research strategy to answer a legal research question, using the most appropriate online and paper-based research tools ULO10 - Identify the hallmarks of good legal writing, and use them to edit and improve their own writing.

ULO1 - Explain the legal principles and institutional arrangements that underpin government in Australia ULO2 - Demonstrate an awareness of the principles and values that have shaped the Australian system of government, including representative democracy, the rule of law and human rights ULO3 - Critically examine the framework of Australian government with reference to a range of broader perspectives ULO4 - Demonstrate an understanding of constitutionalism and the rule of law as values and modes of government that shape the broader political and institutional context within which particular legal issues arise ULO5 - Articulate and critically examine the purposes and scope of the fundamental constitutional rules that govern the relationships between Parliament, the executive and the judiciary ULO6 - Select, interpret and apply relevant rules and principles of statutory interpretation in order to reach a considered view on the legal meaning, or likely legal meaning, of a doubtful legislative provision ULO7 - Give a reasoned opinion as to the appropriate meaning of a legislative provision which takes adequate account of the law of statutory interpretation ULO8 - Demonstrate the intellectual and practical skills needed to identify, research, evaluate and synthesise relevant factual, legal and policy issues.

ULO1 - Articulate and apply the fundamental principles of negligence law, false imprisonment, trespass to land and nuisance, including defences and remedies ULO2 - Analyse the aims of torts law and its relationship with alternative schemes of compensation, and critically evaluate its role and effectiveness in redressing civil wrongs and compensating losses ULO3 - Demonstrate intellectual and creative skills to articulate legal and policy issues, to research, interpret and synthesise relevant legal, policy and factual matters, and to formulate reasoned and appropriate responses to legal problems ULO4 - Communicate effectively and persuasively ULO5 -   Learn and work autonomously and use feedback to improve their own capabilities and performance.

ULO1 - Critically evaluate the purpose and scope of criminal laws with reference to theories of criminal justice and broader theoretical and comparative perspectives ULO2 - Research, evaluate and synthesise relevant factual, legal and policy issues and effectively communicate the results ULO3 - Recognise and reflect on the professional responsibilities of lawyers to justice and to the community ULO4 - Select, analyse, interpret and apply criminal law doctrines and principles to generate appropriate responses to simulated legal problems ULO5 - Communicate and present criminal law ideas effectively and persuasively to specified audiences in a format appropriate to criminal law practice ULO6 - Work effectively in a group and manage their own learning including time management and organisational skills.

ULO1 - Locate and apply regulatory requirements relevant to the student's intended profession ULO2 - Research, articulate and apply the legal principles relevant to issues arising in professional practice ULO3 - Communicate effectively about legal principles to a professional audience in a suitable format ULO4 - Integrate and synthesise inter-disciplinary perspectives to resolve legal problems arising in professional practice ULO5 - Collaborate effectively with students within and across disciplinary backgrounds in producing a group work output.

ULO1 - Identify and articulate legal issues that arise in scenarios involving contracts, including formation, privity, estoppel and contractual terms ULO2 - Select and use appropriate research tools and reasoning methods to synthesise and evaluate relevant legal and factual issues ULO3 - Interpret, evaluate and apply principles of contract law with awareness of broader social, economic, international and policy contexts ULO4 - Engage in critical analysis and exercise professional judgement in make reasoned choices among alternative interpretations and actions ULO5 - Apply legal reasoning and research to formulate appropriate responses to legal issues ULO6 - Collaborate and communicate effectively and persuasively ULO7 - Learn and work with autonomy, accountability and professionalism

ULO1 - Identify and articulate legal issues that arise in scenarios involving contracts, including performance, breach, termination, remedies and vitiating factors ULO2 - Use appropriate research tools and reasoning methods to synthesise and evaluate the relevant legal and factual issues ULO3 - Interpret, evaluate and apply principles of contract law with awareness of broader social, economic, international and policy contexts ULO4 - Engage in critical analysis and exercise professional judgement in make reasoned choices among alternate interpretations and actions ULO5 - Apply legal reasoning and research to formulate appropriate responses to legal issues ULO6 - Collaborate and communicate effectively and persuasively ULO7 - Learn and work with autonomy, accountability and professionalism

ULO1 - Describe, discuss and analyse Commonwealth and State constitutional law and practice. ULO2 - Evaluate judgements on Australian constitutional cases demonstrating particular attention to the interpretive techniques used and the principles/policies underlying the judgements and doctrines. ULO3 - Assess the constitutional validity of Commonwealth and Victorian legislation and executive actions. ULO4 - Evaluate and apply constitutional law and interpretative principles of constitutional law to generate appropriate legal responses.

ULO1 - Critically evaluate the purpose and scope of property rules with reference to relevant theories of property or broader perspectives ULO2 - Apply interpretive techniques to synthesize legal principles from judicial decisions and legislation ULO3 - Engage in critical analysis and use professional judgment to make reasoned choices among alternative interpretation and actions ULO4 - Research, interpret and apply property law principles to generate appropriate responses to problem scenarios and legal issues ULO5 - Communicate in ways that are effective, appropriate and persuasive ULO6 - Learn and work independently.

ULO1 - Articulate and critically analyse the key doctrines of equity, their relationship to common law, their development in Australia, and their theoretical underpinnings, with reference to international and comparative perspectives; ULO2 - Engage in critical analysis and make reasoned and appropriate choices among alternatives; ULO3 - Demonstrate cognitive skill, creativity and professional judgement to research and synthesise relevant legal and practical issues, to interpret and evaluate professional conclusions, and to formulate appropriate responses to complex legal problems; ULO4 - Communicate and collaborate effectively orally and in writing; ULO5 - Learn and work with autonomy, independence and professionalism, and reflect on and asses their own capabilities and performance.

ULO1 - Critically evaluate the law relating to corporations in a broader regulatory, social or economic context; ULO2 - Demonstrate the intellectual and practical skills needed to interpret legal conclusions and professional decisions ; ULO3 - Identify, research, synthesise and evaluate relevant legal, factual and policy issues, including interpreting and applying relevant provisions of the Corporations Act; ULO4 - Demonstrate cognitive and creative skills in approaching legal issues and generating appropriate responses and developing new understandings; ULO5 - Engage in critical analysis and make reasoned and appropriate choices among alternatives; and ULO6 - Communicate effectively and persuasively to specified audiences.

ULO1 - Demonstrate advanced and integrated knowledge of property law, building upon learning in previous units; ULO2 - Identify, research, evaluate and synthesize relevant factual, legal and policy issues; ULO3 - Demonstrate the intellectual and legal skills to interpret judicial decisions and legislation; ULO4 - Engage in critical analysis and make reasoned and appropriate choices among alternatives; ULO5 - Demonstrate cognitive skill, creativity and professional judgement to formulate appropriate responses to complex legal problems; ULO6 - Communicate and collaborate effectively and persuasively; and ULO7 - Work with autonomy, independence and professionalism

ULO1 - Demonstrate understanding of the operation of the Australian banking system, as well as the general principles of law governing the Australian payments system and negotiable instruments. ULO2 - Identify and accurately describe the legal relationship that exists between customers and their banks, including the duties owed by each to the other, as well as the day-to-day issues that can arise between banks and customers. ULO3 - Demonstrate understanding of the financial industry ombudsman system and its role in the mediation of banker-customer disputes. ULO4 - Critically analyse problems arising from the application of statute and case-law to specific banker-customer transactions. ULO5 - Identify, evaluate and convincingly articulate emerging trends in bankers' liability especially theimpact of consumer protection legislation to banking business. ULO6 - Synthesise information from a broad range of sources and apply this to the identification andanalysis of legal issues respecting the lending practices of banks.

ULO1 - Demonstrate an advanced understanding of the nature of constitutional law and constitutional interpretation in Australia, and especially its fundamental constitutional principles; ULO2 - Demonstrate the intellectual and practical skills needed in the complex process of constitutional interpretation. ULO3 - Articulate and critically examine contemporary issues relating to the Australian constitutional system; ULO4 - Demonstrate an advanced ability to evaluate the role and functioning of the High Court in contemporary Australian society, and its relationship with the elected branches of government;

ULO1 - Define, interpret and reflect upon contemporary issues and problems in criminal law and procedure; ULO2 - Identify, analyse and elucidate the relevant principles, laws and precedents and apply them to resolve issues relating to clients with contemporary or advanced issues in criminal law and procedure; ULO3 - Critically assess policies and principles relating to the criminal law ULO4 - Demonstrate an advanced understanding of the intellectual and practical skills needed to interpret legal conclusions and professional decisions, as well as to identify, research, evaluate and synthesise relevant factual, legal and policy issues in criminal law ULO5 - Demonstrate an advanced understanding of the legal research and writing, and legal argument skills by undertaking systematic research into legal policy, rules, procedures and comparative perspectives relating to criminal law and procedure; and ULO6 - Demonstrate developed skills of oral presentation of criminal legal policy, rules and argument in an interactive learning context

ULO1 - Understand and appraise the importance of international conventions and domestic legislation in relation to industrial dispute settling and setting minimum terms and conditions of employment in Australia, United States, Canada, United Kingdom and Europe; ULO2 - Appreciate the impact of constitutional powers in establishing workplace relations systems; ULO3 - Determine how minimum standards for workers are set and enforced; ULO4 - Critique the legal nature of collective or enterprise bargaining and the role of industrial action in bargaining for terms and conditions of work; ULO5 - Debate and critically analyse how legislation protects workplace rights, including the right to bargain collectively and the freedom to choose whether or not to join a union; and ULO6 - Research and apply the law studied to new and emerging contemporary problems in the labour law field.

ULO1 - Critically examine the fundamental principles of international law; the theoretical framework of international law and its relationship with domestic law; the crucial role of States, international institutions and individuals in the international legal system; ULO2 - Analyse and interpret international law, taking into account the complexities involved in interpreting and applying its sources; and the political context and nature of international law. ULO3 - Compare and contrast some of the different areas of international law; how Australia interprets and applies international law in relation to its own legal framework; the use of force and self-defence in international law; and international dispute resolution; ULO4 - Communicate effectively, appropriately and persuasively on issues pertaining to International Law; and ULO5 - Reflect on and assess their own capabilities and performance, and make use of feedback as appropriate, to support personal and professional development.

ULO1 - Demonstrated an advanced knowledge of the main and current issues of the Asian legal systems; ULO2 - Identified and articulated complex legal issues in which economic, political, cultural and ethical values shape the development of law in Asia; ULO3 - Articulated and critically compared aspects of Asian law and legal institutions with Australian counterparts; ULO4 - Recognised and reflected on how Australian lawyers might adapt when dealing with Asian legal institutions and legal professionals.

ULO1 - Appreciate the international sources of collective labour rights and assess the compliance of Australian law with specified international labour standards; ULO2 - Determine the extent to which Australian workers are impacted, if at all, by any non-compliance by Australian law with international standards; ULO3 - Understand and appraise the role of unions and assess the regulatory regime applying to Australian unions; ULO4 - Research and apply the Australian law taught in the Unit to new problems to resolve these problems; ULO5 - Debate and critically evaluate the need for, and the efficacy of, Australian law on collective labour rights.

ULO1 - Acquired knowledge of the problem of unjustifiable discrimination and its Australian social context, and of anti-discrimination laws and their application and interpretation ULO2 - Developed their research and writing skills through preparing a research paper ULO3 - Developed an understanding of the philosophical and legal concepts of equality and discrimination and the problems of the development of this area in the common law context ULO4 - Developed the ability to think critically about concepts of equality, discrimination, special treatment, and the capacity and limits of law as a mechanism of social change.

ULO1 - Be aware of, and be able to demonstrate their grasp of, the significance of social theory to the understanding of law as a social phenomenon; ULO2 - Be aware of the nature of social theoretic scholarship, and of the theoretical and methodological underpinnings that distinguish research and scholarship in the social sciences and humanities from research in law; ULO3 - Be able to produce written work that is adequate relative to the theoretical and methodological underpinnings mentioned in (2); ULO4 - Have closely read a number of primary texts in the social theoretic tradition having implications for the study of legal topics (both classical and contemporary texts, demonstrating a range of social theoretic approaches); ULO5 - Be able to communicate, in written form, the outcomes of the reading described in (4), and thereby display familiarity with, articulate the content of and undertake sustained critical analysis of those texts, synthesise multiple texts, and integrate their own social theoretic insights; and ULO6 - Learn and work autonomously and use feedback to improve their own capabilities and performance.

ULO1 - Identify a contract of employment and explain the rights and obligations that flow from regulation by contract and its termination ULO2 - Distinguish between employees and other kinds of workers and critically evaluate the implications of the distinction for workers and employers; ULO3 - Understand and apply the National Employment Standards of the Fair Work Act to problems; ULO4 - Recognise and apply the statutory protections available to individual employees under Australian workplace and anti-discrimination legislation to problems; ULO5 - Research the law of employment and apply the law to problems to resolve them; ULO6 - Critically evaluate the efficacy of the law in this area; ULO7 - Convincingly state the need for changes to the law.

ULO1 - Comprehend and critically analyse the laws pertaining to defamation, breach of confidence and privacy in terms of their impact on the media. This will involve reading, understanding and interpreting primary sources - both cases and legislation - and demonstrating an ability to apply them to complex factual scenarios. ULO2 - Develop reasoned opinions as to whether the laws studied in this unit strike an appropriate balance between freedom of speech and the protection of reputation.? ULO3 - Communicate the substantive law, and their opinions thereon, effectively and persuasively with minimal errors in expression, grammar, spelling and punctuation. ULO4 - Learn and work with autonomy and professionalism.

ULO1 - Apply knowledge and understanding of comparative continental European legal systems with creativity and initiative to new situations for further learning; ULO2 - Investigate, analyse and synthesise complex information, problems, concepts and theories in relation to comparative continental European legal systems; ULO3 - Conduct research in comparative continental European legal systems based on knowledge of appropriate research principles and methods; ULO4 - Use cognitive, technical and creative skills to generate and evaluate at an abstract level complex ideas and concepts relevant to comparative continental European legal systems.

ULO1 - Analyse international human rights standards and evaluate mechanisms designed to enforce human rights at the international/regional level; ULO2 - Explain and critically discuss the content of various human rights, such content being identified, inter alia, by reference to the case law of the UN treaty monitoring committees and regional human rights courts; ULO3 - Critically evaluate some of the philosophical bases of and problems with international human rights law in light of contemporary human rights issues; and ULO4 - Communicate effectively about human rights issues.

ULO1 - Define, interpret and reflect upon the common law, constitutional and statutory framework that has applied to indigenous peoples of Australia, and particularly of Victoria; ULO2 - Identify, analyse and elucidate the relevant principles, laws and precedents and apply them to resolve issues relating to indigenous clients; ULO3 - Critically assess policies and principles relating to Indigenous people in order to promote a fair justice system recognising past and present injustices ULO4 - Demonstrate an advanced understanding of the intellectual and practical skills needed to interpret legal conclusions and professional decisions, as well as to identify, research, evaluate and synthesise relevant factual, legal and policy issues ULO5 - Demonstrate an advanced understanding of the legal research and writing, and legal argument skills by undertaking systematic research into legal policy, rules, procedures and comparative perspectives relating to indigenous peoples and interests; and ULO6 - Demonstrate developed skills of oral presentation of legal policy, rules and argument in an interactive learning context

ULO1 - Demonstrate negotiating behaviour in a variety of contexts and document reflective analysis as to what works, what doesn't work, and why; ULO2 - Explain and apply the theories of integrative negotiation, distributive negotiation and principled negotiation in real-world contexts; ULO3 - Express effective negotiation, mediation and conflict resolution decisions based on conscious, rational, informed choice, from a broad array of available tools and methods; ULO4 - Generate real-time appropriate responses in a variety of legal and interpersonal contexts; ULO5 - Demonstrate the ability to recognise and appropriately address ethical issues generated in preparing for and participating in negotiation; ULO6 - Demonstrate the ability to collaborate and communicate in ways that are efficient, effective, appropriate and persuasive; and ULO7 - Reflect on and evaluate their own capabilities and performance, with a view to continuing personal and professional development.

ULO1 - Comprehend and explain the essential concepts and policies underlying the division of family property and financial disputes in Australia including the broader context in which the system operates. ULO2 - Critically evaluate the challenges and debates surrounding the division of property and maintenance on relationship breakdown including the ethical debates and professional responsibilities facing family lawyers. ULO3 - Identify, analyse and critically comment on disputes between parties to a marriage or parties in a de facto relationship involving issues of property and maintenance. ULO4 - Demonstrate reasoning skills and professional judgement which generate appropriate responses to complex statutory problems. ULO5 - Communicate effectively appropriately and persuasively on issues pertaining to financial disputes on relationship breakdown. ULO6 - Learn and work autonomously and collaboratively and use feedback to improve their own capabilities and performance.

ULO1 - identify and evaluate a knowledge of the common law and statutory principles which govern the relations between parents and children and between children, parents and the State and develop some understanding of the way in which these laws operate in practice ULO2 - analyse and interpret the jurisdictional issues and legal procedures relevant to the determination of such disputes ULO3 - research and evaluate theoretical and critical debates about the laws governing parents and children and the adequacy of current laws and procedures ULO4 - communicate effectively and persuasively on issues relevant to family law? ULO5 - evaluate and reflect on some of the skills necessary for practice in this area of the law and recognize ethical issues they may encounter in practice ULO6 - learn and work autonomously and use feedback to improve their own capabilities and performance

ULO1 - Articulate the background and nature of international refugee law. ULO2 - Investigate and apply the international instruments applicable to asylum seekers, including the Refugees Convention. ULO3 - Critically evaluate comparative state and regional practices towards refugee applicants. ULO4 - Undertake legal research and reasoning to explain legal and policy issues so as to formulate reasoned and appropriate responses to legal problems in international refugee law. ULO5 - Develop skills of oral presentation and argumentation in an interactive class context; and ULO6 - Strategically apply feedback to improve capabilities and performance of tasks.

ULO1 - be able to apply knowledge and understanding of the various alternatives in the institutional design of the principal constitutional organs, and the advantages and disadvantages of each; as well as of the role of constitutions as a framework for protection of human rights in selected constitutional systems; ULO2 - be able to formulate, investigate and critically consider key problems relating to the issues identified in the synopsis; ULO3 - have further developed legal research and writing, and legal argument skills by undertaking systematic research into legal policy, rules and procedures and comparative perspectives relating to constitutional law and individual rights; ULO4 - have developed skills of oral presentation, and participation in an interactive learning context, in relation to issues of legal policy, rules and arguments from the field of comparative constitutional law.

ULO1 - articulate and critically examine the role and law of trusts in in a broader commercial, social and regulatory context, the methods of creating them and the rights and obligations of parties; ULO2 - demonstrate cognitive and creative skills and professional judgement to make reasoned and appropriate choices among alternatives and to generate appropriate responses to legal issues; and ULO3 - demonstrate the intellectual and practical skills needed to interpret trust documents, legal conclusions and professional decisions as well as to identify, research, evaluate relevant factual, legal and policy issues.

ULO1 - Articulate and critically analyse the diverse cultural, philosophical, political and legal origins of human rights ULO2 - Evaluate the nature and degree of Australia's human rights obligations under international law and their impact on Australian law and practice ULO3 - Critically assess the variety of domestic legal forms by which human rights are expressed - constitutional, statutory, interpretive, common law and codes of practice and evaluate their role and effectiveness in implementing Australia's international human rights obligations ULO4 - Analyse and distinguish between the various Australian laws across the whole range of legal specialities that seek to, or in practice do, protect human rights in Australia ULO5 - Demonstrate cognitive and creative skills in articulating the institutional, policy and procedural mechanisms for human rights protection in Australia and evaluating the impact of statutory and common law changes on human rights protection in Australia ULO6 - Demonstrate legal research and reasoning skills in assessing the impact of statutory and common law changes on human rights protection in Australia ULO7 - Communicate effectively and persuasively in respect of legal rules and policies in an interactive learning environment. ULO8 - Learn and work with autonomy and utilise feedback in this unit and across their undergraduate studies to improve on their capabilities and relate the material covered to relevant aspects of other LLB units they have undertaken.

ULO1 - Learn and work with autonomy, accountability and professionalism through a largely self-directed research project or practical professional project in an internship as appropriate ULO2 - Identify and articulate complex legal issues ULO3 - Apply legal reasoning and research to generate appropriate responses to legal issues ULO4 - Engage in critical analysis and make reasoned choices amongst alternatives ULO5 - Demonstrate cognitive and creative skills in approaching legal issues and generating appropriate responses and developing new understandings ULO6 - Demonstrate the intellectual and practical skills needed to interpret legal conclusions and professional decisions, as well as to identify, research, evaluate and synthesise relevant factual, legal and policy issues ULO7 - Communicate in ways that are effective, appropriate and persuasive for legal and non-legal audiences as appropriate for the particular research project.

ULO1 - Learn and work with autonomy, accountability and professionalism through a largely self-directed research project or practical professional project in an internship as appropriate. ULO2 - Identify and articulate complex legal issues ULO3 - Apply legal reasoning and research to generate appropriate responses to legal issues ULO4 - Engage in critical analysis and make reasoned choices amongst alternatives ULO5 - Demonstrate cognitive and creative skills in approaching legal issues and generating appropriate responses and developing new understandings ULO6 - Demonstrate the intellectual and practical skills needed to interpret legal conclusions and professional decisions, as well as to identify, research, evaluate and synthesise relevant factual, legal and policy issues. ULO7 - Communicate in ways that are effective, appropriate and persuasive for legal and non-legal audiences as appropriate for the particular research project.

ULO1 - comprehend and explain the essential concepts and policies underlying the Australian family law system including the broader context in which the system operates. ULO2 - critically evaluate the challenges and debates surrounding family law including the ethical debates and professional responsibilities facing family lawyers. ULO3 - identify, analyse and critically comment on disputes between parties to a marriage or parties in a de facto relationship involving issues of property, children and maintenance. ULO4 - demonstrate reasoning skills and professional judgement which generate appropriate responses to complex statutory problems. ULO5 - communicate effectively appropriately and persuasively on issues pertaining to family law. ULO6 - learn and work autonomously and collaboratively and use feedback to improve their own capabilities and performance.

ULO1 - Apply knowledge and understanding of the key principles in dispute resolution in international commerce with creativity and initiative to new situations for further learning; ULO2 - Investigate, analyse and synthesise complex information, problems, concepts and theories in relation to the practical aspects of arbitration; ULO3 - Conduct research into the dispute resolution in international commerce to create new understandings of key developments that contribute to an understanding of how to draft arbitration clauses and how to enforce awards, based on knowledge of appropriate research principles and methods; ULO4 - Use cognitive, technical and creative skills to generate and evaluate at an abstract level complex ideas and concepts relevant to dispute resolution in international commerce including an appreciation of international solutions to domestic problems.

UNIT_TITLE: International law of the sea and maritime security: Pirates, poachers, people smugglers & terrorists
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Articulate and apply the international law of the sea as a body of rules to legal problems; ULO2 - Identify and critically discuss the content of the law of the sea with reference, inter alia, to appropriate treaty law, case law, evidence of custom and the writing of scholars; ULO3 - Explain the dynamic process by which the law of the sea is made and understand its place within the broader system of public international law; ULO4 - Analyse and critically evaluate some of the strengths and weaknesses of the law of the sea as a system for ensuring maritime security, for resource allocation and management, and for the resolution of disputes over maritime resources; and ULO5 - Conduct self-directed legal research.

ULO1 - Articulate and apply principles of international criminal law; and, in terms of those principles, critically evaluate the doctrines and processes of international criminal law as they have developed historically. ULO2 - Examine the theoretical and policy concerns underpinning the law, as well as the broader political and social context within which international criminal law issues arise. ULO3 - Analyse and interpret key documents which codify and illustrate international criminal law, through their application to complex case scenarios. ULO4 - Collaborate and communicate effectively, appropriately and persuasively on issues pertaining to the development of international criminal law and its implementation by applicable institutions. ULO5 - Learn and work with autonomy, accountability and professionalism, using reflection and feedback to improve their own capabilities and performance.

ULO1 - be familiar with the different types of contracts used on construction projects and the pros and cons of each; ULO2 - understand risk allocation and the different methods of project delivery; ULO3 - be able to apply the contract provisions that relate to various issues that impact on construction projects such as variations, latent defects, delays and defective works and the legal ramifications of each; ULO4 - recognise the different types of insurance required for construction projects and be able to critically assess the contractual provisions relevant to them; ULO5 - have knowledge of the various statutes and regulations governing the construction industry; and ULO6 - be able to write clearly, concisely and logically on issues relating to construction law.

ULO1 - Coherent and advanced knowledge of the principles and concepts underpinning the application of traditional legal rules, and the development of new legal rules, to socio-economic issues raised by biotechnology; ULO2 - Skills and knowledge to provide basic advice to scientists and those wanting to commercially exploit biotechnology and its outcomes on their rights and responsibilities in law; ULO3 - An understanding of the development of legal rules and institutions tailored to biotechnology (e.g., Australian Gene Technology Regulator; legislation governing human embryo research and cloning; regulatory approaches to genetics research and commercialisation); ULO4 - An understanding of, and the ability to critically analyse and evaluate, the interests and forces that influence and shape the development and application of the law to biotechnology; ULO5 - Skills to review, analyse, consolidate and synthesis the above knowledge to identify and provide solutions to complex problems arising out of the practice or development of, or activities pertaining to, biotechnology; ULO6 - Further developed their writing skills; and ULO7 - Enhanced their skills of statutory interpretation in the context of technical and complex legislation.

UNIT_TITLE: Current issues in Indigenous rights: International, comparative and regional perspectives
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - identify the key current issues regarding the recognition, protection and enforcement of indigenous rights by way of international and regional law and fora; ULO2 - understand the basic parameters of comparative law theory and methodology; ULO3 - research the major theoretical and practical issues about indigenous peoples from international, regional and comparative perspectives; ULO4 - comment on the prospect for reform of the legal rights of indigenous peoples, in the light of current legislative, judicial, political and comparative developments; and? ULO5 - present written and oral analysis of complex problems involving indigenous peoples.

ULO1 - To develop an understanding of the issues facing buyers and sellers in relation to the transfer of property in goods ULO2 - To give students an understanding of the state, national and international regulation of contracts for the sale of goods ULO3 - To develop in students the capacity to advise both buyers and sellers of goods about their legal rights in relation to the transfer of ownership of those goods ULO4 - To provide students with an understanding of the legal and commercial issues facing partners in their dealings with others and with third parties ULO5 - To develop an understanding of the legal and commercial issues involved in the relationship of principal and agent, both as between principal and agent and as between them and third parties ULO6 - To build on the skills and knowledge acquired by students in the prerequisite subject.

ULO1 - Identify, articulate, critically assess and apply the law of armed conflict, including its sources and modern application; ULO2 - Understand, analyse and critically evaluate cases which apply the law of armed conflict; ULO3 - Compare and contrast different regimes, including the human rights regime, and the different LOAC regimes applicable in international and non-international armed conflicts; ULO4 - Demonstrate independent research skills to interpret and synthesise relevant legal and policy issues and apply them to a set of facts; ULO5 - Evaluate the role of international law in managing the phenomenon of armed conflict; ULO6 - Communicate knowledge from this subject effectively and persuasively; ULO7 - Learn and work autonomously and assess their own capabilities, using feedback to improve performance.

ULO1 - Apply knowledge and understanding of theoretical debates, models, and concepts that underpin policy, regulation, and practice of corporate governance, responsibility, and sustainability with creativity and initiative to new situations for further learning ULO2 - Investigate, analyse and synthesise complex information, problems, concepts and theories in relation to comparative corporate regulatory systems ULO3 - Conduct research in comparative corporate regulatory systems based on knowledge of appropriate research principle and methods ULO4 - Use cognitive, technical and creative skills to generate and evaluate at an abstract level complex ideas and concepts relevant to comparative corporate regulatory systems

ULO1 - Creatively apply knowledge and understanding of the basic principles of the law and the practice of corporate finance to new situations for further learning such as those that will be introduced and examined in both the class participation assessments and in the written assessments for the unit; ULO2 - Investigate, analyse and synthesise complex information, problems, concepts and theories in relation to legal and commercial aspects of various forms of debt finance, including secured and unsecured transactions and other forms of raising debt, including the debt capital markets and solve questions;? ULO3 - Research the concept of the 'capital markets' particularly debt capital markets as a means of raising funds by Australian issuers in both the Australian domestic market and in the international capital market, based on knowledge of appropriate research principles and methods so as to be able to understand how these markets operate and to be able to assess critically the regulation of these markets; ULO4 - Generate and evaluate at an abstract level complex ideas and concepts relevant to the international financial transactions.

ULO1 - Compare, contrast and evaluate the adversarial and non-adversarial systems, including the rationales and needs for each system and their various functions.? ULO2 - Demonstrate understanding of the theoretical underpinnings and the nature of a range of non-adversarial processes in civil, criminal and family law processes. ULO3 - Identify and critically analyse how lawyers can work ethically and effectively with non-adversarial processes. ULO4 - Identify and discuss features of non-adversarial mechanisms, and evaluate their impact on lawyers, courts and the community. ULO5 - Communicate effectively and persuasively both orally and in writing on issues relating to non-adversarial processes.

ULO1 - Demonstrate understanding of the principles and objectives underlying the regulatory schemes that apply to our treatment of animals; ULO2 - Critically analyse policies and objectives in light of ethical considerations and jurisprudence and relate them to proposals for law reform; ULO3 - Collaborate and communicate effectively, appropriately and persuasively on issues relevant to the understanding of Animal Law; ULO4 - Apply skills in legal reasoning and argumentation to animal law issues.

ULO1 - Evaluate the role of taxation in the modern Australian state and within a market economy. ULO2 - Critically analyse the Australian tax system from a range of policy and disciplinary perspectives including law, economics, politics and philosophy. ULO3 - Critically assess the impact of key tax policy choices relating to the tax mix (ie the combination of taxes), tax base (what should be taxed), tax rates and taxpaying units (ie who should be taxed). ULO4 - Assess the role of key norms and values such as equity, efficiency and justice in the tax policy debate. ULO5 - Develop and apply an understanding of how debates in relation to tax policy affect the practical administration of tax laws. Develop and refine skills of policy analysis to interpret, synthesise and critically evaluate legislative provisions and case law from a broader policy perspective. ULO6 - Demonstrate research and reasoning skills and professional judgement to generate appropriate responses to complex legal and policy problems ULO7 - Effectively communicate complex ideas in oral and written form. ULO8 - Collaborate with teaching staff and students in the development of an ongoing dialogue and critical assessment of the policy and legal issues within the Australian tax system. ULO9 - Actively participate in class discussions and make use of feedback to strengthen knowledge of key issues.

ULO1 - be able to articulate and explain the causes of construction disputes and the factors contributing to the escalation of construction conflicts into construction disputes; ULO2 - identify and distinguish between different types of dispute avoidance processes (DAPs) used on construction projects around the world and evaluate the pros and cons of each; ULO3 - be able to explain the ways in which parties can engage in 'real time' resolution of construction disputes during the course of a project, and the legal ramifications of such processes; ULO4 - be able to compare and contrast different ADR options available (mediation, expert determination, senior executive appraisal and early neutral evaluation) and identify the factors that influence the suitability of each for particular construction disputes; ULO5 - be able to critically evaluate the use of arbitration for the resolution of construction disputes at both a domestic and international level; ULO6 - be able to describe and outline the regulatory regimes governing domestic and international arbitrations of construction disputes; ULO7 - be able to assess the judicial systems in place in Australia and other countries for the determination of construction litigation and the need for reform; and ULO8 - be able to undertake scholarly research and write clearly, concisely and logically on the avoidance, management and resolution of construction disputes.

ULO1 - Analyse the role of the lawyer within diverse legal systems in a global context ULO2 - Critique transnational legal practice from the perspective of ethics and accountability ULO3 - Evaluate the role of digital technologies in transnational and domestic legal practice ULO4 - Integrate diverse elements of transnational legal practice to build a personal profile indicative of a skilled global lawyer

ULO1 - Apply a knowledge and understanding of fundamental issues in Chinese law so as to advise on simple specific legal problems and more broadly on matters of general policy ; ULO2 - Investigate, analyse, and synthesise complex information, concepts and theories in relation to Chinese law and policy ULO3 - Conduct research into the Chinese legal system to develop understandings of key issues, likely future directions, and current and emerging difficulties and problems; ULO4 - Examine the concept of law as serving a political function as an instrument of policy, and law as being implemented, through executive and administrative fiats and action, with courts acting in a facilitative role.

ULO1 - Demonstrate and apply specialised knowledge of a range of torts other than negligence as well as of current controversies in torts law; ULO2 - Demonstrate advanced skills in interpreting civil liability legislation, torts law cases, academic commentary and law reform materials and applying them to solve practical problems and to evaluate torts law policy issues; ULO3 - Critically evaluate the effectiveness of torts law in redressing civil wrongs having regard to the social, economic and political context in which tort law operates; ULO4 - Conduct independent research into relevant domestic and international materials on current controversies in torts law; and ULO5 - Write clear, creative and persuasive opinions and critical essays demonstrating an advanced understanding of contemporary torts and torts-related issues.

UNIT_TITLE: The law of public listed companies
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate understanding of the operation and regulation of listed companies in Australia, and the principal requirements regarding fundraising, capital management, continuous disclosure, related party transactions and takeovers; ULO2 - Analyse and critically examine the present regulatory regime from different perspectives and have an appreciation of relevant policy and practice; ULO3 - Demonstrate ability to interpret and apply the regulatory requirements considered in this unit; and ULO4 - Articulate and critically examine the fundamental policy issues in this area.

ULO1 - Identify the key principles, concepts and policies relating to the resolution of civil disputes. ULO2 - Show an ability to exercise professional judgment in recognising and responding appropriately to ethical issues that arise in the context of civil dispute resolution. ULO3 - Critically evaluate the available processes of civil dispute resolution and the steps in civil litigation. ULO4 - Demonstrate effective legal writing and written communication skills by clear and persuasive articulation and application of procedural rules and principles. ULO5 - Demonstrate effective oral communication through class discussion and collaborative effectively. ULO6 - Demonstrate ability to work with a high degree of autonomy and professionalism. ULO7 - Demonstrate cumulative knowledge and skills to propose appropriate solutions to complex legal problems.

UNIT_TITLE: Forensic evidence: Law, science, medicine and technology
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify and articulate the challenges presented and the tensions which arise when forensic evidence is tendered in legal proceedings; ULO2 - Critically assess forensic evidence in a range of fields, in order to identify its strengths and weaknesses; ULO3 - Recognise and reflect upon the ethical issues that may arise when forensic evidence is given in legal proceedings, and the professional responsibilities of lawyers in addressing these issues; ULO4 - Demonstrate research skills and the reasoning and professional judgment required to formulate appropriate responses to complex legal problems involving forensic evidence; ULO5 - Communicate effectively and persuasively on issues relating to forensic evidence; ULO6 - Learn and work autonomously and use feedback to improve their own performance.

ULO1 - possess an overview of the legal framework within which offenders against federal and state law in Victoria are sentenced or subjected to other measures such as civil action for confiscation of proceeds of crime under state or federal law, or administrative sanctions such as infringement notices, or other post sentence sanctions such as detention and supervision orders, or orders made under the Sex Offenders Registration Act 2004 (Vic); ULO2 - appreciate the role that problem-oriented or solution-focused courts have in relation to the sentencing of drug dependent or mentally disordered persons, family violence offenders and Koorie offenders; ULO3 - understand some of the empirical and criminological dimensions of sentencing; ULO4 - have obtained an overview of different philosophical underpinnings of the sentencing systems.

ULO1 - Apply knowledge of a range of current controversies in restitution and the law of unjust enrichment to new situations; ULO2 - Investigate and analyse information, problems, concepts and theories in relation to the unjust enrichment principle and to critically evaluate the effectiveness of restitution and restitutionary remedies within the private law, including the desirability of reform; ULO3 - Conduct research into relevant domestic and international materials on contemporary restitution law issues and effectively communicate the results of that research; ULO4 - Formulate reasoned and appropriate responses to legal problems.

ULO1 - Explain the law, principles and values integral to ethical practice of the Law ULO2 - Demonstrate approaches to ethical decision-making that require recognition, reflection and response to ethical issues likely to arise in legal practice, with particular attention to exercising professional judgement in the areas of justice promotion and community service. ULO3 - Use critical analysis to make reasoned choices and demonstrate creativity in applying these to specific ethical issues ULO4 - Communicate how they would effectively, appropriately and persuasively apply professional responsibility principles across different practice contexts to resolve ethical issues ULO5 - Demonstrate autonomy, accountability and professionalism in relation to ethical judgement and make effective use of feedback.

ULO1 - demonstrate knowledge of the role of the advocate in the adversarial system of justice including some of the ethical duties of an advocate; ULO2 - construct a comprehensive and persuasive case theory and be able to communicate it both verbally and in writing; ULO3 - be able to apply some fundamental rules of evidence and fairness; ULO4 - demonstrate a basic understanding of advocacy skills and techniques; ULO5 - confidently present the facts and oral arguments to a court.

ULO1 - To explain how the property of a deceased person will be distributed if the person has not made a valid will disposing of all of their property. ULO2 - To document the requirements for a valid will, and assess a variety of circumstances to determine whether a particular will is valid. ULO6 - To identify the people who are eligible to make a family provision claim and describe how the courts will deals with such a claim. ULO1 - Identify and articulate the principles and concepts governing the medical profession and healthcare setting and the ethical and policy issues raised by medical law; ULO2 - Critically assess claims in relation to medical negligence and new and novel claims that have arisen in medical law; ULO3 - Apply skills to review, analyse, consolidate and synthesis the above knowledge to identify and provide solutions to complex problems arising out of the practice or development of, or activities pertaining to medical law; ULO4 - Demonstrate legal research and reasoning skills in approaching complex legal problems and the ability to articulate and evaluate policy considerations in response to difficult dilemmas and areas that may require legal reform; ULO5 - Communicate effectively, appropriately and persuasively on issues pertaining to medical law; and ULO6 - Learn and work autonomously and make use of feedback to assess their own capabilities and performance and to support personal and professional development.

ULO1 - critically analyse the historical evolution of international environmental law and policy in response to the increasingly global nature of ecological problems? ULO2 - demonstrate intellectual and creative skills to articulate the diverse ideological character and claims of the modern environment movement and the major lines of contestation in the broader global environmental debate? ULO3 - reflect on and assess the major sources and principles of 'hard' and 'soft' international environmental law and the key principles and cases which have shaped the law's development? ULO1 - Critically evaluate the purpose and scope of evidentiary principles in ensuring the conduct of fair trials in the civil and criminal justice systems, drawing upon broader theoretical and comparative perspectives; ULO2 - Engage in critical analysis and use professional judgement to make reasoned and appropriate choices among alternative interpretations, arguments and actions; ULO3 - Research, interpret and apply evidentiary principles to generate appropriate responses to problem scenarios and legal issues in trial practice; ULO4 - Recognise the professional responsibilities of lawyers to promote justice and reflect upon ethical issues arising in trial practice; ULO5 - Collaborate and communicate effectively and persuasively in professional formats appropriate to trial practice; ULO6 - Learn and work with a high degree of autonomy, accountability and professionalism; and ULO7 - Reflect on and assess their own capabilities and performance, and make use of feedback to support personal and professional development.

ULO1 - Have planned, executed and reported on a piece of research or scholarship undertaken with a significant degree of independence; ULO2 - Have acquired a detailed knowledge and expertise in the area of the topic which is the subject of the thesis; ULO3 - Have developed and demonstrated both intellectual and practical research skills, including the skills needed to identify, evaluate, interpret and synthesise material relevant to the student's chosen research topic; ULO4 - Have developed and demonstrated skills of critical analysis and original thought, including in-depth analysis of the legal and policy issues relevant to the student's chosen research topic; ULO5 - Be able to identify, articulate and effectively communicate complex legal and policy issues in a manner that is succinct, scholarly and persuasive; ULO6 - Be able to exchange knowledge and ideas with other scholars in order to achieve a high quality of legal scholarship; ULO7 - Be able to learn and work with autonomy, accountability and professionalism; ULO8 - Be able to reflect on and assess their own capabilities and performance, and make use of feedback as appropriate, to support personal and professional development.

ULO1 - Demonstrate a cognitive appreciation of the principles of international tax law and tax system design; ULO2 - Critically analyse, articulate and apply a variety of substantive international taxation law concepts ULO3 - Understand the broad framework of Australia's international tax rules; ULO4 - Demonstrate legal research and reasoning skills and professional judgment to generate appropriate responses to international taxation law problems; ULO5 - Critically assess international taxation law policies and principles ULO6 - Generate appropriate responses to technical international tax law problems; and ULO7 - Engage in discussion about jurisdictional and policy issues relating to international tax law.
