UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - demonstrate a contextual appreciation of management as an evolving set of contested ideas for how managers may influence people, organisations, and their environments to achieve organisational goals ULO2 - identify what managers do in practice, and analyse how the various activities that comprise managing both shape and are shaped by individual and group behaviour and diversity in organisational settings ULO3 - critically evaluate the impact of contemporary management practices on employee experiences of being managed ULO4 - explain the concepts of stakeholder interests, ethics and responsible management and assess their implications for individuals and organisations in a global context ULO5 - apply research, analytical and communication skills required of the management discipline to address business challenges.

ULO1 - critically evaluate communication theories underpinning business communication ULO2 - analyse the relationships between different business communication theories and concepts ULO3 - demonstrate creative solutions to persuasive and informative business communication challenges ULO4 - understand the roles of verbal and non-verbal communication and interpersonal communication in business contexts ULO5 - develop professional writing skills for business, electronic communication and social media for business communication.

ULO1 - examine theories of organisational behaviour to develop fundamental knowledge of organisational behaviour as an area of management ULO2 - analyse organisational behaviour issues from multiple workplace perspectives ULO3 - examine how managers can use knowledge of organisational behaviour to manage individual employees and teams ULO4 - apply theoretical organisational behaviour concepts to organisational situations using the case study method ULO5 - demonstrate skills in evaluation and analysis of organisational behaviour concepts.

ULO1 - define the scope and purpose of HRM through the principles and practices of contrary people, culture and strategy initiatives ULO2 - critically evaluate and analyse conceptual frameworks for assessing HRM systems in a global business environment and across different cultural/national setting ULO3 - develop creative solutions to a range of contemporary HRM challenges involving people, culture and strategy initiatives ULO4 - enhance student employability and job readiness skills, through personal development opportunities.

ULO1 - synthesis concepts of mindset, openness, difference and inclusion ULO2 - analyse internal management inclusion opportunities and challenges ULO3 - analyse and compare solutions for external management inclusion opportunities and challenges ULO4 - demonstrate awareness of self and inclusive management practices ULO5 - identify predictors and consequences of 'wellness' and 'toxicity' in the organisational context ULO6 - describe and critically evaluate current organisational wellness initiatives.

ULO1 - examine, analyse and synthesise the concepts, principles, processes and practice of project management ULO2 - apply and critically evaluate the project management techniques and decision tools within constrained, ambiguous and uncertain business environments ULO3 - assess the interrelationship between organisational strategy, innovation and change with project management ULO4 - enhance communication, interpersonal, research, problem solving and critical thinking capabilities.

ULO1 - identify and explain the core concepts of business strategy ULO2 - explain and evaluate the influence of key contextual variables on a business' strategy ULO3 - apply and critically analyse business strategy formulation, implementation and evaluation concepts and the relationships between them to different contexts ULO4 - identify and explain future directions and trends for forming, implementing and evaluating business strategy.

ULO1 - explain fundamental concepts, models and approaches that represent the theory of management ULO2 - apply management theory and research evidence to practical situations using a case-based approach ULO3 - develop skills in team-based decision making that demonstrate effective teamwork and communication skills ULO4 - critically evaluate managerial decisions in the context of the organisation's ethical and social responsibilities.

ULO1 - compare a classical and critical understanding of work organisations with reference to key academic theories and approaches ULO2 - critically assess key theoretical debates surrounding topics introduced in the unit with reference to the organisational/socio-cultural interface ULO3 - evaluate the different ways in which the organisational/socio-cultural interface manifests in and around organisational contexts ULO4 - demonstrate evidence of skills in independent assessment and synthesis of academic literature and the effective communication of academic knowledge ULO5 - demonstrate recognition of ethical, social and cultural issues and their impact on multiple stakeholders.

ULO1 - define the nature and purpose of the field of organisational behaviour ULO2 - distinguish the major theories used to explain the behaviour of people in organisations ULO3 - identify the major factors influencing individual and group behaviour in organisations ULO4 - read and critically evaluate published research in the field of organisational behaviour.

ULO1 - demonstrate the role of Human Resource Management in achieving organisational objectives ULO2 - critically evaluate some of the key theoretical models of Human Resource Management ULO3 - critically evaluate some of the key technical, legal and ethical issues in Human Resource Management ULO4 - analyse the policies, practices and procedures associated with the effective management of people in organisations ULO5 - explain the impact of the social, political and economic environment on the theory and practice of Human Resource Management.

ULO1 - explain the practical implications of different perspectives on strategic management ULO2 - select and apply a framework and techniques to analyse particular cases ULO3 - research and select information to analyse particular cases ULO4 - identify and evaluate strategic issues and recommend actions in particular cases ULO5 - integrate and effectively communicate analysis in presentations and reports.

ULO1 - analyse and critically evaluate the role of entrepreneurship and intrapreneurship within organisations within the Australian economic context ULO2 - analyse and critically evaluate the contemporary public policy frameworks in which entrepreneurship and intrapreneurship operates both domestically and internationally ULO3 - identify, select and apply frameworks and techniques to analyse specific business cases ULO4 - recommend and communicate creative business solutions to particular actions which are financially, ethically and socially responsible.

ULO1 - demonstrate a contextual appreciation of management as an evolving set of contested ideas for how managers may influence people, organisations, and their environments to achieve organisational goals ULO2 - identify what managers do in practice, and analyse how the various activities that comprise managing both shape and are shaped by individual and group behaviour and diversity in organisational settings ULO3 - critically evaluate the impact of contemporary management practices on employee experiences of being managed ULO4 - explain the concepts of stakeholder interests, ethics and responsible management and assess their implications for individuals and organisations in a global context ULO5 - apply research, analytical and communication skills required of the management discipline to address business challenges.

ULO1 - describe and discuss contemporary theories and concepts in interpersonal communication ULO2 - examine the role of communication in management, particularly in leadership, decision making, conflict resolution, creativity and problem-solving ULO3 - extend personal communication skills by identifying opportunities for growth and strategies for development ULO4 - demonstrate competence and professionalism in structuring and delivering persuasive messages ULO5 - critically analyse communication style.

ULO1 - describe and discuss the major theories and concepts that pertain to understanding behaviour in organisations ULO2 - describe and discuss contemporary perspectives in organisational behaviour, including the positive organisational behaviour approach to this field ULO3 - engage with the relevant research literature, and draw on that literature to make plausible, evidence-based predictions about how environmental factors may influence organisational behaviour ULO4 - examine the role of organisational behaviour theory in enhancing both individual and organisational effectiveness.

ULO1 - differentiate between employee relations issues and industrial relations issues using current research ULO2 - describe the main institutional features and key developments in the Australian industrial relations system as they impact upon employee relations ULO3 - identify management strategies for dealing with employee relations in Australian workplaces and those in other countries ULO4 - participate in individual and team-based analysis of workplace case studies and activities ULO5 - develop basic skills in managing communication, negotiation, and bargaining at the workplace.

ULO1 - classify the key features and issues in the global environment in which international business takes place ULO2 - explain the impact that the environment has on the internationalisation process of a business organisation ULO3 - demonstrate an understanding of the role of entry mode choice and other strategic issues in order to succeed in international business.

ULO1 - explain and critically evaluate the major challenges impacting on workforce planning in organisations ULO2 - integrate theoretical and empirical knowledge with practical examples ULO3 - evaluate and recommend human resource management solutions to global workforce challenges.

ULO1 - define the scope and purpose of HRM as an academic discipline and activities associated with HRM as a management practice ULO2 - identify major changes in the global business environment that impact on organisations and HRM ULO3 - critically evaluate competing models of HRM that underpin perceived good practices ULO4 - critically apply knowledge about HR activities to identify solutions to HRM issues ULO5 - enhance students' research capabilities to work individually and in groups.

ULO1 - identify and analyse the characteristics of conflict in society and in relationships ULO2 - apply ethical communication, counselling, negotiation and mediation techniques to a variety of conflict situations ULO3 - examine the influence and implications of power in understanding and managing conflict ULO4 - evaluate a range of dispute resolution techniques and assess the applicability of these techniques to specific situations ULO5 - assess and develop dispute resolution systems.

ULO1 - identify strategies and actions for planned organisational change ULO2 - critically evaluate different frameworks and philosophies for change management in organisations ULO3 - integrate and synthesise previous knowledge of organisational change processes ULO4 - analyse change processes that exist at an individual level, group level and across the organisation as a whole ULO5 - examine management practices which directly influence the success or otherwise of implementing a planned change process.

ULO1 - assess the application of management theory to various global cultures ULO2 - explain the complex challenges of the multinational business enterprise at the interpersonal and operational levels ULO3 - compare a range of cross-cultural variables in the business environment ULO4 - apply theory to cross cultural scenarios ULO5 - critically assess the strengths and weaknesses of national culture assessment tools.

ULO1 - understand business strategy creation and implementation as an ambiguous process ULO2 - create an organisation and group member analysis based on conventional business strategy concepts ULO3 - evaluate the influence of contemporary issues and critical perspectives on business strategy ULO4 - analyse and apply the critical diversity framework to the micro-foundations of strategy implementation.

UNIT_TITLE: Business ethics in a global environment
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - explain the relationship between ethics, morals and values in the workplace ULO2 - explore, analyse and synthesise different perspectives of ethical aspects ULO3 - critically examine ethical theories to explain how they contribute to ethical business practices okay ULO4 - critically analyse some of the competing demands on business when scrutinising the ethics of business activity in a global context ULO5 - discuss the interface between business, state and civil society organisations across different context.

ULO1 - understand the concepts of diversity and inclusion applied to the workplace ULO2 - evaluate the legal, social and business issues associated with diversity management in the contemporary workplace ULO3 - identify the strategic business and HRM issues associated with developing and implementing diversity and inclusion initiatives in the workplace ULO4 - understand contemporary issues related to the management of workplace diversity and inclusion issues ULO5 - analyse practical case studies of inclusion, diversity and discrimination in the workplace.

ULO1 - describe the concepts and use the tools for competitive analysis and strategic planning in the international environment ULO2 - formulate and implement strategies for SMEs and multinational organisations in a global setting ULO3 - identify and analyse the opportunities and dangers involved in international strategic management ULO4 - evaluate the impact different types of foreign operations have on the internationalising organisation.

UNIT_TITLE: Talent management and professions of the future
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - explain the strategic importance of talent management by understanding how to attract, select, develop and retain employees in the context of dynamic change ULO2 - identify and examine the human resource management practices and competitive forces which influence strategic approaches to talent management ULO3 - develop skills in identifying talent and evaluating the talent renewal needs of professionals ULO4 - critically analyse talent management challenges faced by different types employers and formulate and evaluate potential ways in which they may address these challenges.

ULO1 - evaluate the changing nature of international management process ULO2 - relate management theory to varying and different cultures ULO3 - describe and explain the complex challenges facing business and managers in a cross-cultural setting ULO4 - critically compare and contrast a range of cross-cultural variables in the international business management environment and understand their impact on international management.

ULO1 - develop strategies for managing innovation and its commercialisation ULO2 - design an appropriate process for screening a new product service idea through to introduction ULO3 - define criteria for the sustainability of innovations ULO4 - describe the impact of networks and role of networking on managing the innovation process.

UNIT_TITLE: People management and work in a global context
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - critically analyse the globalisation of trade and production systems and the impact on employment relations and labour standards ULO2 - identify the implications of globalisation for the management of labour via human resources management in different national settings ULO3 - evaluate the work practices and labour standards in MNC's by applying ethnocentric and polycentric approaches ULO4 - examine institutions governing trade and labour standards, including international labour standards, trade agreements, and corporate codes of conduct ULO5 - critically assess the relationship between business, labour and government internationally.

ULO1 - explain in detail the elements of integrated supply chain management ULO2 - critically evaluate contemporary literature in the field of logistics and supply chain management ULO3 - apply contemporary logistics and supply chain management concepts to an organisation ULO4 - formulate logistics and supply chain strategies.

ULO1 - critically evaluate the common characteristics of conflict in a wide range of exchange relationships ULO2 - evaluate theoretical foundations for effective negotiation ULO3 - develop practical skills through application of concepts in negotiation exercises.

ULO1 - explain the concept of culture and its determinants ULO2 - develop an understanding of the principles of effective cross-cultural communication ULO3 - critically evaluate the role communication and negotiations play in international operations ULO4 - explain the negotiation process and identify and analyse impediments to effective negotiations ULO5 - assess the relevance of culture to management practises in different cultural settings ULO6 - identify and evaluate the links between culture, economic processes and organisations.

ULO1 - define the purposes and scope of leadership theories and research outcomes, and identify their applications to real-life situations ULO2 - describe and evaluate the principles and practices of management, their differences and similarities to leadership, and their relationship to leadership in an organisational setting ULO3 - evaluate the multifaceted nature of leadership in Australia and internationally, and enhance students' own leadership skills in the process ULO4 - evaluate the trends in and implications of leadership and management research in organisations and their impact on work environments ULO5 - critically analyse the development of leadership in relation to research outcomes and practical applications.

UNIT_TITLE: Managerial problem solving and decision making
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - interpret organisational phenomena effectively, in order to define problems and identify decision-making situations ULO2 - analyse patterns and relationships in problem solving and decision making processes ULO3 - identify and evaluate problem contexts, explanations and alternative solutions ULO4 - recognise and avoid errors in reasoning and decision-making ULO5 - identify implicit assumptions, constraints and biases in problem solving and decision making, and develop strategies to effectively communicate these to stakeholders.

ULO1 - define and distinguish between services and operations management principles and practices ULO2 - outline and apply operations management concepts in delivering value to customers ULO3 - apply and analyse discretionary and non-discretionary service management concepts ULO4 - synthesise services and operations management concepts.

UNIT_TITLE: Sustainable operations and supply chain management
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - understand the environmental and social implications of global production and distribution ULO2 - recognise and implement more sustainable design in processes and products ULO3 - understand the implications of sustainability for organisational survival and the role that operations plays in facilitating sustainability ULO4 - understand the technological and behavioural dimensions of sustainable process and product innovation ULO5 - understand the application of these dimensions in local, regional and global supply chains.

ULO1 - assess the advantages and limitations of the multilateral trading system in terms of its decision making processes and its agreements (agriculture, services, intellectual property, etc.) ULO2 - explain the recent surge of bilateralism and regionalism and assess the implications of this surge for the multilateral trading system ULO3 - evaluate the opportunities and the limitations of formally linking human rights and environmental issues to the global trading system ULO4 - judge whether the current global trading system treats trade liberalisation as a means to an end (the end being sustainable and equitable development) or an end in itself ULO5 - evaluate the implications of the global financial crisis for the global trading system.

ULO1 - acquire an understanding of the theory and processes of global governance ULO2 - acquire an understanding of the purpose, motivations and strategies of the United Nations System, regional organisations, civil society and multinational corporations ULO3 - assess the roles of the intergovernmental, non-governmental and corporate sectors in shaping and influencing global governance ULO4 - analyse key issues and themes relating to international institutions and organisations.

ULO1 - acquire an understanding of the grand theories that strive to explain business globalisation and the rules that govern this process ULO2 - reason in an informed way regarding geo-politics and the activities of states and firms ULO3 - read critically and report the ideas and agendas of global state and business actors ULO4 - gain a working knowledge of how state and business actors in Australia, China, Russia and the USA are addressing the shift in power that is occurring globally.

ULO1 - examine the conceptual foundations of work and employment relations ULO2 - apply these concepts to developments within the Australian system of employment relations in comparative context ULO3 - describe the main institutional features and key developments in the Australian industrial and workplace relations system ULO4 - identify the implications of these developments for labour management practices, employee voice and participation in the workplace and representative organisations of employers and employees ULO5 - understand the potential effects of institutions governing work and employment relations using workplace and industry case studies.

ULO1 - critically analyse the strategic nature of organisational leadership ULO2 - develop an understanding of strategy and leadership as dynamic processes ULO3 - analyse the role of strategic decisions in a range of contexts and understand approaches to addressing strategic decision-making challenges ULO4 - develop creative solutions to challenges associated with industry dynamics when responding to competitive challenges, and improving organisational performance.

ULO1 - critically evaluate how national culture informs values, socialisation, behaviour, and identity in an international business context ULO2 - understand how cultural differences impact the communication and negotiation process in different international business settings ULO3 - analyse how we categorise people into cultural groupings and understand the practical and ethical consequences of this practice for communicating and negotiating in intercultural business settings ULO4 - demonstrate intercultural competence by applying practical skills to intercultural communication and negotiation exercises ULO5 - develop intercultural competence skills by generating creative solutions to complex business challenges associated with intercultural communication and negotiation in organisations operating globally.

ULO1 - analyse the broad nature of organisations and the function of management in relation to its people, purpose and structure ULO2 - critically analyse the importance of aligning individual, the team and the organisation's contribution in attaining organisational goals ULO3 - assess the role of ethics and social responsibility in determining the culture and internal practices of an organisation in the overall conduct of its business ULO4 - critically apply and evaluate contemporary management theory and research and generate creative business solutions to current organisational issues ULO5 - understand the impact of complex external environments on organisational function.

ULO1 - explain the strategic and operational perspectives of logistics ULO2 - describe the elements of the logistics mix and explain the trade offs between these elements ULO3 - discuss the mechanisms and issues involved in supply chain integration ULO4 - analyse the performance of logistics and the supply chain management in an organisation ULO5 - apply the concept of integrated logistics and supply chain management to solve an organisational problem.

ULO1 - analyse and apply current management theory and research to current organisational issues ULO2 - understand the personal challenges involved in becoming a new manager in an organisation in today's world ULO3 - understand the importance of the individual, the team and the organisation's contribution to the effective performance of work ULO4 - assess the role of ethics and social responsibility in determining the culture of an organisation ULO5 - identify techniques for improving decision making in today's turbulent environment.

ULO1 - recognise the challenges and issues arising out of organisational change initiatives ULO2 - recall various change models and frameworks, their foundations and relative strengths and weaknesses ULO3 - apply change models and concepts to real-life organisational change ULO4 - identify the skills and abilities required to be an effective change agent ULO5 - develop reflective and evaluative skills as a change agent.

ULO1 - understand the dynamic nature of business and the strategic management processes employed by businesses to gain sustainable competitive advantage ULO2 - develop analytical skills to plan the future of an organisation in its competitive environment from the viewpoint of the chief executive ULO3 - identify the necessary skills for developing and implementing strategies that will enable the organisation to achieve competitive advantage and sustainability ULO4 - critically analyse the strategic management theories and practices to apply to organisational realities ULO5 - develop management skills and knowledge to examine strategic management challenges from strategy, change and learning perspective.

ULO1 - define the purpose and scope of traditional and emerging Human Resource Management (HRM) activities drawing from HRM theory, empirical research and practice ULO2 - analyse and evaluate the contribution that can be made by the HR function to the competitive advantage of the organisation ULO3 - critically analyse how HRM activities can support the sustainability of an organisation ULO4 - evaluate the contribution of HRM activities to the creation of an ethical and future focused organisation ULO5 - develop a portfolio of 21st century skills such as communication, collaboration and teamwork to effectively navigate the changing nature of work.

ULO1 - develop skills in self-awareness ULO2 - develop skills and competencies deemed necessary for business professionals ULO3 - understand and develop effective, mutually beneficial relationships, particularly in team contexts ULO4 - develop capabilities for successfully enhancing and/or changing careers.

ULO1 - critically analyse the strategic nature of organisational leadership ULO2 - develop an understanding of strategy and leadership as dynamic processes ULO3 - analyse the role of strategic decisions in a range of contexts and understand approaches to addressing strategic decision-making challenges ULO4 - develop creative solutions to challenges associated with industry dynamics when responding to competitive challenges, and improving organisational performance.

UNIT_TITLE: Legal aspects of human resource management
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - evaluate the effectiveness of employee protection in Malaysia through a comparative approach ULO2 - critically analyse emerging local employment trends and the legal issues that they pose ULO3 - critically analyse global issues in employment and the impact on employment regulation in Malaysia ULO4 - identify and evaluate the main challenges in industrial relations in Malaysia ULO5 - evaluate the extent of Malaysias conformance with international labour law standards.

UNIT_TITLE: Contemporary issues of human resource management in Asia
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - explore the multiple and often competing perspectives that pertain to the human resource management to understand the implications to the context of modern organisations in Asia ULO2 - critically analyse human resource challenges to identify the impact/implications for contemporary Asian businesses ULO3 - debate and critically evaluate contemporary themes of human resource management, such as diversity management, digitalisation, and career management, and assess how these have impact on human resource policies and practice of contemporary organisations.

UNIT_TITLE: Strategic human resource management and business strategy
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - examine the relationship between strategic management theories and human resource management models ULO2 - critically analyse the integration between human resource strategies and processes at business and corporate levels ULO3 - develop decision-making skills and propose innovation solutions to enhance organisational competitiveness, sustainability and innovation ULO4 - critically analyse current analytic tools to enhance human resource management for better organisational performance.

UNIT_TITLE: Corporate social responsibility and business ethics
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - identify important ethical issues that arise in various business contexts ULO2 - explain the implications of adopting different approaches to Corporate Social Responsibility ULO3 - critically assess the strengths and weaknesses of the different approaches to Corporate Social Responsibility ULO4 - critically assess the strengths and weaknesses of different mechanisms for regulating business behaviour ULO5 - apply different approaches to Corporate Social Responsibility and different approaches to regulation to issues specific to marketing, HRM, environment and social accounting.

ULO1 - demonstrate the development of responsible international business citizenship characteristics in strategic business decisions ULO2 - critically analyse and evaluate international business contexts to offer evidence-based, innovative and perceptive recommendations for strategic decision-making ULO3 - design a critical and nuanced strategic implementation plan that responds to international business challenges ULO4 - demonstrate autonomous, collaborative and active research and professional skills to generate and communicate international business strategy knowledge, skills and ideas to others.

ULO1 - critically examine the theoretical links between strategy and HRM ULO2 - critically analyse how HRM can be used as a strategic tool to gain competitive advantage with respect to the global context ULO3 - formulate, evaluate and recommend solutions to strategic HRM problems ULO4 - critically analyse strategic HRM theories and practices and their applications to organisational realities.

ULO1 - identify and describe the components of the operations management function in different types of organisations ULO2 - explain operations process planning and control including capacity, scheduling, inventory and materials requirements planning ULO3 - examine the concepts of managing people and processes as part of a manufacturing system ULO4 - analyse decision problems in operations and the relationship of operations decisions to other business decisions ULO5 - communicate in writing the results of analysis of operations.

ULO1 - critically assess the strengths and weaknesses of major theories of organisational leadership ULO2 - formulate a framework of leadership that would help students make sense of their current and future leadership experiences and discern critical lessons drawn ULO3 - develop a higher self awareness of students' own personality, values, attitudes, and styles as well as strengths and weaknesses pertinent to their leadership aspirations ULO4 - construct a personal leadership philosophy outlining students' convictions on ethical and compassionate leadership and its impacts in real-world organisational contexts ULO5 - analyse and synthesise crucial roles and positive impacts that managers and leaders can make to organisations and their stakeholders.

ULO1 - critically analyse and interpret basic research designs in the management discipline ULO2 - construct research questions grounded in a theoretical and conceptual framework ULO3 - assess the appropriateness, types, and use of qualitative and quantitative data collection and analysis techniques as a means of investigating and answering research questions in the management discipline ULO4 - identify, search for, and locate secondary data and knowledge relevant to management research, as well as understanding the process of generating or collecting primary data ULO5 - develop academic writing skills appropriate to the discipline for reporting on business management research projects.

UNIT_TITLE: Perspectives and paradigms in management theory
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - identify the different perspectives from which a particular event or process may be viewed ULO2 - demonstrate a sound understanding of a selection of paradigms that are relevant for solving contemporary management problems ULO3 - critically assess the strengths and weaknesses of competing paradigms ULO4 - select a particular area of interest and appropriate paradigms for paradigm comparison.

ULO1 - select and conduct preliminary analyses of data in order to assess their suitability for further analysis ULO2 - demonstrate proficiency in the use of data analytic software such as SPSS ULO3 - analyse data using qualitative techniques (eg: content, thematic analysis) in order to answer research questions and/or test hypotheses ULO4 - analyse data using quantitative techniques (univariate, bivariate, multivariate) in order to answer research questions and/or test hypotheses ULO5 - interpret and report the results/findings obtained from qualitative and quantitative data analytic techniques.

ULO1 - identify and critically examine a range of contemporary issues in management from a variety of theoretical and practical perspectives ULO2 - demonstrate a range of relevant scholarship/research skills in acquiring, integrating, interpreting, synthesising, utilising and communicating information about the contemporary issues examined ULO3 - summarise the major implications of the issues examined as they relate to their own lives and their careers in organisations, the theory and practice of managers and management, and the broader societal and environmental implications of the issues, both now and into the future ULO4 - demonstrate skills in written and inter-personal communication including creating effective learning environments for themselves and others.

ULO1 - critically analyse and interpret basic research designs in the management discipline ULO2 - construct research questions grounded in a theoretical and conceptual framework ULO3 - assess the appropriateness, types, and use of qualitative and quantitative data collection and analysis techniques as a means of investigating and answering research questions in the management discipline ULO4 - identify, search for, and locate secondary data and knowledge relevant to management research, as well as understanding the process of generating or collecting primary data ULO5 - develop academic writing skills appropriate to the discipline for reporting on business management research projects.

ULO1 - identify major political, economic and regulatory forces that underpin the globalisation process ULO2 - critically analyse how international political and economic developments are shaping the structure of global institutions ULO3 - evaluate how the globalisation of rules can become a source of competitive advantage for firms, governments and non profit organisations ULO4 - identify solutions that would enhance the sovereignty of ordinary citizens over the globalisation process.

UNIT_TITLE: International study program in international business
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - examine the cultural, political, and institutional issues that influence the business activities in the selected countries ULO2 - critically analyse the impact of the cultural, political and other institutional influence on company's strategic decisions as well as other management practices ULO3 - apply the basic theories and concepts in managing multinational firms in the international companies we tour and analyse both congruency and discrepancy between theories and real practices.

ULO1 - conduct a research project on a significant issue in the field management ULO2 - critically evaluate the extant literature based on the relevant research topic ULO3 - design and execute a research plan, identifying appropriate methodology contributing to the overall analysis ULO4 - critically analyse the findings in a major analytical report on the project.

ULO1 - identify a research project on a significant issue in the field management ULO2 - identify and critically evaluate relevant literature on the research topic ULO3 - identify and critically evaluate an appropriate methodology for the research project.

ULO1 - describe the concepts and use the tools for assessing country attractiveness and strategic planning in the international environment ULO2 - formulate and implement strategies for various modes of operations in an international setting ULO3 - identify and analyse the opportunities and risks involved in international business strategy ULO4 - evaluate the impact different foreign operations have on the internationalising organisation.

ULO1 - explain the concept of culture and its determinants ULO2 - develop an understanding of the principles of effective cross-cultural communication ULO3 - critically evaluate the role communication and negotiations play in international operations ULO4 - explain the negotiation process and identify and analyse impediments to effective negotiations ULO5 - assess the relevance of culture to management practises in different cultural settings ULO6 - identify and evaluate the links between culture, economic processes and organisations.

ULO1 - assess the advantages and limitations of the multilateral trading system in terms of its decision making processes and its agreements (agriculture, services, intellectual property, etc.) ULO2 - explain the recent surge of bilateralism and regionalism and assess the implications of this surge for the multilateral trading system ULO3 - evaluate the opportunities and the limitations of formally linking human rights and environmental issues to the global trading system ULO4 - judge whether the current global trading system treats trade liberalisation as a means to an end (the end being sustainable and equitable development) or an end in itself ULO5 - evaluate the implications of the global financial crisis for the global trading system.

ULO1 - define the concept of international business from a multi-disciplinary perspective ULO2 - explain the diversity and complexity of the international business environment ULO3 - provide a historical overview of the evolution of the international business phenomenon ULO4 - discuss the economics and politics of international business transactions ULO5 - analyse the concept of globalisation and its impact on businesses worldwide ULO6 - describe the firm internationalisation process ULO7 - examine the economic, social and political implications of multinational corporate activities ULO8 - extend awareness of global issues based on current affairs and their implications for international business.

UNIT_TITLE: Introduction to microbiology and microbial biotechnology
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe different microorganisms and the relationships that exist between them; ULO2 - Describe microbial cell structure, function, nutrition, physiology and growth and how microorganisms are controlled; ULO3 - Explain microbial DNA replication, gene structure and expression, regulation of gene expression and mechanisms of genetic variation; ULO4 - Explain the role that microorganisms play in the preservation, fermentation, preparation and spoilage of food; ULO5 - Outline environmental microorganisms and their importance in the biogeochemical cycles, environmental pollution, water quality and treatment, bioremediation, bioleaching and waste treatment; ULO6 - Demonstrate basic microbiological laboratory skills such as the use of the microscope, microscopic staining and visualisation techniques, 'microbial culture', and be able to identify common species of bacteria and fungi; ULO7 - Demonstrate effective communication of microbial concepts and experiments by written means.

ULO1 - Explain the importance of micro-organisms in human health and disease; ULO2 - Outline how host and pathogenic factors of micro-organisms affect the outcome of infection; ULO3 - Describe basic mechanisms of immunity to infection and the development and use of vaccines; ULO4 - Explain how infectious diseases are spread and controlled, and the susceptibility and resistance of microbial pathogens to antimicrobial agents; ULO5 - Outline different microbial pathogens including bacteria, viruses and parasites, their modes of pathogenesis, diseases caused, epidemiology and treatment; ULO6 - Demonstrate knowledge of microbiological methodology and laboratory skills that are used to study microbial pathogens; ULO7 - Demonstrate effective communication of microbiology concepts and experiments by oral and written means.

ULO1 - Compare and contrast different sequencing strategies and analyse bacterial genomic data using bioinformatics; ULO2 - Explain the processes of homologous recombination and site-specific recombination and how bacteria repair damaged DNA; ULO3 - Compare and contrast the different types of mobile genetic elements; ULO4 - Articulate how bacteria respond to changes in their environment by regulating gene expression; ULO5 - Assess and interpret the mechanisms of replication, maintenance and transfer of bacterial plasmids; ULO6 - Explain the molecular mechanisms of transport, assembly and secretion in the bacterial cell; ULO7 - Demonstrate the ability to execute laboratory experiments relevant to advanced molecular microbiology, as well as analyse and report experimental results by formulating a scientific laboratory report and poster presentation.

ULO1 - Describe the fundamental principles underlying infection by all major groups of viruses, and apply this knowledge to understand infection and disease caused by specific pathogenic viruses; ULO2 - Explain how viruses interact with target host cell components and defence mechanisms and how this can lead to disease; ULO3 - Describe specific strategies used to limit and control viral infections; ULO4 - Demonstrate practical skills and knowledge of molecular virology laboratory techniques; ULO5 - Apply knowledge of molecular virology and viral pathogenesis to critically analyse interpret and discuss experimental data and scientific literature; ULO6 - Demonstrate a range of scientific communication skills, developed through oral presentations, participation in workshops and written laboratory reports.

ULO1 - Describe the processes of bacterial pathogenesis including adhesion, cell invasion, replication and the production of bacterial toxins; ULO2 - Explain the genetic approaches used to study bacterial pathogenesis; ULO3 - Describe the innate immune response to bacterial pathogens; ULO4 - Demonstrate knowledge of the current literature on pathogenic mechanisms for selected bacterial infections; ULO5 - Perform literature based research using online databases to collect, analyse and interpret research literature relevant to a specific bacterial pathogen and to effectively communicate this by oral presentation and the preparation of a book chapter; ULO6 - Demonstrate the ability to work cooperatively in a small group writing, planning, editing and assembling a scientific book.

ULO1 - Describe medically important micro-organisms that cause disease in human and animal hosts; ULO2 - Describe the micro-organisms that cause infections in different body systems such as skin; respiratory tract; gastrointestinal tract; genitourinary tract and the cardiovascular system. ULO3 - Compare and contrast the microbial pathogenesis, transmission, diagnosis, prevention and treatment of different infections; ULO4 - Explain the host response to infection, mechanisms of host resistance and; describe the principles of antimicrobial action and how microbes become resistant to them; ULO5 - Demonstrate the ability to execute laboratory experiments relevant to advanced medical microbiology, including culturing of micro-organism, microscopy and advanced diagnostic methods used to identify microbial pathogens; ULO6 - Communicate experimental results through the writing of scientific reports and oral presentations.

ULO1 - Undertake a research project with regard to ethical and safety regulations; ULO2 - Demonstrate technical skills in experimental methods and the ability to collect, analyse and interpret data using methods relevant to the discipline of Microbiology; ULO3 - Communicate appropriately and effectively with supervisors, laboratory staff and students; ULO4 - Maintain accurate and up-to-date records of experimental procedures, results and outcomes; ULO5 - Identify relevant published scientific literature and critically analyse and evaluate the content in the context of the discipline of Microbiology; ULO6 - Construct written reports.

ULO1 - Explain the philosophical foundations of midwifery, the models of maternity care and the midwife's scope of practice; ULO2 - Describe the essential components required to perform a comprehensive women's health assessment; ULO3 - Examine factors impacting the care of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander childbearing women and those from different cultures; ULO4 - Apply theoretical knowledge of health promotion to issues relevant to maternity care; ULO5 - Describe legal and ethical issues that demonstrate a beginning understanding relevant to midwifery practice; ULO6 - Demonstrate beginning level competency based upon the Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia (NMBA) Midwife standards for practice and Code of conduct for midwives, and the International Confederation of Midwives (ICM) Code of ethics for midwives.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain in depth the normal maternal anatomical and physiological adaptations relevant to pregnancy, labour, birth and the puerperium; ULO2 - Apply the theoretical knowledge of the normal anatomical and physiological adaptations during pregnancy to describe a woman-centred approach pivotal to midwifery practice for women of all cultural backgrounds; ULO3 - Explain the role of the midwife in assessment of foetal and maternal well-being during pregnancy, labour, birth and the puerperium; ULO4 - Recognise the importance of using evidence to inform clinical practice and implement developing clinical midwifery skills in the appraisal of mother and baby during pregnancy, labour, birth and postpartum; ULO5 - Describe the midwifery skills required to provide comprehensive physical and psychosocial assessments when providing maternity care for women and their babies across the childbearing continuum; ULO6 - Differentiate the difference between screening and diagnostic tests and list the routine screening and basic diagnostic tests in pregnancy, labour and birth assessment; ULO7 - Explain the need for reflective practice in the implementation of evidence informed care; ULO8 - Demonstrate developing midwifery competence based upon Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia (NMBA) Midwife standards for practice and Code of conduct for midwives, and the International Confederation of Midwives (ICM) Code of ethics for midwives.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the comprehensive assessment and care of a woman, from all cultural backgrounds, and her baby, during the birth process; ULO2 - Interpret the philosophical, physiological, psychosocial, spiritual, cultural and environmental factors influencing the birth process; ULO3 - Discuss the midwife's scope of practice and collaboration with other members of the healthcare team, when working with women during childbirth; ULO4 - Describe common variations from normal that may arise during pregnancy, labour, birth and the postnatal period and the midwife's role in managing these ULO5 - Identify vulnerable populations within Australian society and examine the impact of the current birth options for refugees, asylum seekers, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women; ULO6 - Critique the implications of obstetric interventions and use of technology upon the woman and her family; ULO7 - Critically reflect on the professional health care partnership role when working with vulnerable women and their families, during childbirth; ULO8 - Recognise women's rights, values and cultural beliefs in creating an appropriate and culturally safe environment for women and their partners to birth; and ULO9 - Demonstrate beginning level competency based upon the Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia (NMBA) Midwife standards for practice and Code of conduct for midwives, and the International Confederation of Midwives (ICM) Code of ethics for midwives.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically examine the social-cultural context in the provision of care to babies and their families in Australia and globally; ULO2 - Describe normal anatomical and physiological changes during transition from intra-uterine to extra-uterine life, to enable recognition of deviations from normal health; ULO3 - Outline fetal, maternal and intrapartum risk factors associated with maladaptive transition to extra-uterine life and describe appropriate midwifery management; ULO4 - Review the physiology of lactation, outlining strategies to promote and protect breast feeding, including the nutritional adaptions that may be required for preterm and sick infants; ULO5 - Outline the circumstances and neonatal conditions that may necessitate admission of a baby to a SCN; ULO6 - Demonstrate the knowledge and skills required to resuscitate and stabilise a newborn infant; ULO7 - Identify the role and rights of parents in decision-making for their newborn in association with the multidisciplinary SCN team; ULO8 - List strategies designed to deliver culturally appropriate care for vulnerable families in SCN, including refugees, asylum seekers and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders; ULO9 - Employ reflective practice strategies to inform implementation of evidence-based holistic care for women, babies and their families, enabling appropriate clinical decision making; ULO10 - Demonstrate developing midwifery competence based upon the Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia (NMBA) Midwife standards for practice and Code of conduct for midwives, and the International Confederation of Midwives (ICM) Code of ethics for midwives.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Safety in midwifery and nursing contexts
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the complexities of healthcare safety and evaluate the principles of clinical risk and governance; ULO2 - Explain the contribution of 'human factors' to the provision of healthcare and the importance of inter-professional collaboration to minimise risk in the provision of healthcare; ULO3 - Apply the principles of quality improvement including the methods and tools used to measure patient/woman safety in varying clinical contexts; ULO4 - Evaluate the scope of practice of a nurse and midwife in relation to the Nursing Practice and Midwifery Practice decision making frameworks; ULO5 - Critically analyse the complexity of the healthcare and safety risks of maternal health for women in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people;; ULO6 - Demonstrate developing midwifery competence based upon the Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia (NMBA) Midwife standards for practice and Code of conduct for midwives, and the International Confederation of Midwives (ICM) Code of ethics for midwives.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Theory and practice of complex midwifery
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the role of the midwife and collaborative practice related to challenges for women with complex obstetric and medical conditions, including the interventions required during the childbearing period ULO2 - Describe the pathophysiology, diagnosis, evidence for care, including pharmacological management and expected outcomes, associated with selected specific conditions that affect pregnancy, labour and birth, and the first few weeks after birth ULO3 - Apply appropriate knowledge to liaise within a multidisciplinary healthcare team contributing to development and implementation of collaborative care for women experiencing complex challenges in childbearing ULO4 - Discuss and critique screening tests, technologies and interventions during pregnancy, labour, birth and after childbirth ULO5 - Discuss vulnerable situations during childbirth and the support services available for women experiencing pregnancy loss, perinatal mental health issues or domestic violence ULO6 - Evaluate available community peri-natal mental health support services appropriate for women including those from vulnerable populations (+/- such as indigenous woman and refugees and asylum seekers) ULO7 - Identify and manage a range of maternity care emergency situations, including complex physical health problems during pregnancy, birth and the postpartum period ULO8 - Demonstrate the ability to identify and manage selected emergencies in a simulated setting ULO9 - Demonstrate midwifery competency based upon the Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia (NMBA) Midwife standards for practice and Code of conduct for midwives, and the International Confederation of Midwives (ICM) Code of ethics for midwives.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Reflect critically upon the role that midwifery led models of care play in the Australian maternity context; ? ? ULO2 - Discuss the challenges of autonomous practice and midwife leadership and demonstrate proficiency in the implementation of planned midwifery care; ULO3 - Apply knowledge of the Australian Safety and Quality Framework for Healthcare improvement framework, as applied to midwifery practice; ULO4 - Design a quality improvement project relevant to an area of midwifery practice (mental health, primary healthcare, vulnerable populations or hospital based midwifery); ULO5 - With the use of clinical reasoning appraise evidence to demonstrate research literacy skills when searching for evidence relevant to midwifery; ULO6 - Review the key priority areas for research and policy relevant to current midwifery practice; ULO7 - Translate midwifery knowledge in preparation for leadership in practice; ULO8 - Introduce the models of midwife leadership and discuss their impact of in the advancement of the profession ULO9 - Demonstrate midwifery competency based upon the Nursing and Midwifery Board of Australia (NMBA) Midwife standards for practice and Code of conduct for midwives, and the International Confederation of Midwives (ICM) Code of ethics for midwives.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically analyse global trends in infant and maternal outcomes and how they align with the United Nations sustainable development goals (SDGs) for maternity care; ULO2 - Synthesise the?Framework for Quality Maternal and Newborn Care and reflect on how it relates to the student's own maternity context; ULO3 - Investigate and analyse the barriers and enablers to implementing quality care as described in the Respectful Maternity Care charter; ULO4 - Interrogate the use of a evidence and the role of data to advance midwifery knowledge and practice; ULO5 - Critically address professional skills and knowledge deficits in self and others within the student's own maternity care context; ULO6 - Research and apply evidence-based clinical midwifery decision making skills; ULO7 - Reflect on and improve own practice in accordance with the midwifery practice standards and codes that relate to the student's own maternity context; ULO8 - Critically analyse the role of midwifery leadership in advancing quality maternity care; ULO9 - Demonstrate ability to critique and promote the role of the midwife to advance midwifery practice in collaborative and autonomous roles.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically review the scientific literature that underpins the area of the research project; ULO2 - Undertake a supervised research project and contribute to project design and management; ULO3 - Apply appropriate laboratory techniques, research methodologies and data analysis methods to collect, interpret and report research findings; ULO4 - Effectively present research and findings orally showing a firm grasp of the area; ULO5 - Analyse research undertaken in the context of the discipline area and report findings in an extended written report.

ULO1 - Critically review scientific literature in the discipline area of research; ULO2 - Apply knowledge of current methodologies and concepts to appraise scientific literature in the discipline area; ULO3 - Apply analytical and data analysis techniques relevant to the discipline area of research; ULO4 - Effectively communicate concepts in the discipline area of research both in writing and orally.

ULO1 - describe fundamental marketing frameworks and concepts ULO2 - explain the role and influence of marketing in an organisational environment ULO3 - discuss how marketing concepts are used in the marketplace and everyday life ULO4 - apply key marketing concepts, tools, and techniques to a range of marketing problems ULO5 - discuss the role of marketing in creating value for an organisation and its stakeholders.

ULO1 - explain how psychological characteristics of consumers can influence consumer decision making ULO2 - discuss how external factors can influence consumer decision making ULO3 - discuss core theoretical explanations of consumer decision making ULO4 - apply acquired knowledge of consumer psychology to segment markets and develop appropriate marketing strategies.

ULO1 - explain the research process ULO2 - identify a business research problem ULO3 - plan a research proposal ULO4 - design a survey ULO5 - analyse and interpret data ULO6 - prepare a research report.

ULO1 - discuss the function of products and brands in firms and organisations ULO2 - explain the models, concepts, and tools for new product development ULO3 - evaluate the application of branding theories, concepts, and tactics across different firm and organisational contexts ULO4 - apply acquired unit knowledge to develop appropriate strategies for building and managing brand equity.

ULO1 - explain the factors involved in designing and coordinating marketing channels in a variety of organisational contexts ULO2 - describe the dynamics of different selling situations ULO3 - critique and recommend effective sales strategies across different organisational contexts ULO4 - explain how sales management functions are integrated into channel management ULO5 - evaluate the potential for sales management and marketing channels to contribute to the creation of customer value.

ULO1 - construct an appropriate marketing plan to achieve specific organisational objectives and goals ULO2 - discuss the role and use of social marketing in society ULO3 - apply commercial marketing tools with the aim of effecting positive change in society ULO4 - effectively communicate social marketing ideas and information to an organisational client.

ULO1 - describe key marketing concepts ULO2 - recognise the applications of these key marketing concepts in real-life situations ULO3 - discuss how these key marketing concepts can be used in analysing a range of marketing problems ULO4 - demonstrate how marketing helps organisations to satisfy their customers' needs and wants.

ULO1 - equip students with the knowledge of a range of marketing metrics and models and an ability to apply them to analyse marketing scenarios, phenomenon, issues and problems ULO2 - develop a capability to interpret metrics and model outcomes, evaluate strategies and develop managerial recommendation ULO3 - recognise the strengths and limitations of various metrics and models.

ULO1 - describe the steps in planning and implementing marketing research projects ULO2 - demonstrate the skills and competencies required to conduct both qualitative and quantitative marketing research ULO3 - demonstrate the skills required to analyse and interpret sample data ULO4 - understand the role and importance of marketing research within organisations ULO5 - communicate the results of marketing research projects.

UNIT_TITLE: Strategic retailing in the global market

ULO1 - distinguish the nature of marketing decisions that a firm makes according to the hierarchy of strategy ULO2 - explain the contribution that marketing makes to the value of the firm ULO3 - conduct analysis of the internal and external environments of an organisation that informs marketing strategy development ULO4 - formulate and recommend marketing strategies that add measurable value to the organisation ULO5 - develop the written and oral communication skills required to justify a strategic recommendation.

ULO1 - demonstrate the skills required to conduct, analyse, and interpret secondary data ULO2 - track and analyse trends and use them to inform strategy ULO3 - use secondary research to draw strategic implications and form recommendations ULO4 - appraise the role and importance of trends analysis and consumer insight techniques within organisations.

ULO1 - integrate the theoretical and functional aspects of marketing (and other business disciplines) into a practical problem-solving framework ULO2 - analyse information supplied from a case and identify the core marketing problem ULO3 - design, evaluate and recommend marketing strategies that solve the identified core marketing problem ULO4 - source and select relevant marketing theories and marketing tools to support analysis and recommendations.
