UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Take responsibility for own attitudes and behaviour, by acknowledging prejudices, limitations, and lack of knowledge, and commitment to change and growth as a result of professional development, and reflective learning; ULO2 - Adopt an ethical and socially responsible approach to practice and practice based enquiry; ULO3 - Interact with consumers and carers in a fieldwork practice setting acknowledging their rights and using strategies to integrate their lived experience of health issues into service planning and delivery; ULO4 - Apply theoretical understanding of primary care, health promotion and population health in a practice setting; ULO5 - Describe the stages of program management; ULO6 - Undertake a needs analysis by scoping an organizationally useful and occupationally relevant project or program; ULO7 - Apply program management skills and function as a project manager and liaise with an organization to define a project; ULO8 - Share power in relationships with service providers, community leaders, consumers and carers, as demonstrated by the development of a partnership approach to service development and provision; ULO9 - Consult with service providers, community leaders, consumers and carers about their rights, service choices, and options; ULO10 - Share resources in a mutual educational process to facilitate decision making and advocacy about service choices, and options; ULO11 - Develop strategies to empower service providers, community leaders, consumers and carers to determine and set priorities for change; and ULO12 - Use findings of assessments/needs analyses to develop programs using best available evidence.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Synthesise and critically appraise a view of the nature and meaning of occupation, the occupational nature of human beings and the theories and basic principles related to enabling occupation and occupational performance. ULO2 - Describe different research methodological approaches used in health sciences and occupational therapy research and be skilled at accessing, critically appraising and applying the best available evidence to their everyday practice. ULO3 - Demonstrate ability to design a research project suitable for honours level and to write a research project proposal which includes a literature review, research aim and/or question/s and appropriate qualitative and/or quantitative methodology. ULO4 - Demonstrate ability to complete an ethics proposal suitable for submission to an ethics committee. ULO5 - Describe the role, relevance and significance of occupational therapy research in clinical and professional settings.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain and justify the role of an occupational therapist, in relation to the history of the profession, current practice, and similarities and differences from other health professionals within a collaborative practice environment. ULO2 - Apply client-centred communication and interviewing to simulated occupational therapy practice situations. ULO3 - Compare and contrast key features of contemporary occupational therapy models of practice and an interdisciplinary framework of functioning and disability, and apply these to a practice scenario. ULO4 - Identify the socio-cultural, economic, and physical determinants of health with respect to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples ?and culturally diverse populations, and describe how these affect care provision within a practice scenario. ULO5 - . Identify the challenges and barriers to community participation likely to confront a person with a disability. ULO6 - Describe and apply ethical,? legal and workplace safety issues pertinent to a practicing occupational therapist, including identification of ideal professional behaviours to a practice scenario. ULO7 - Apply the process of reflective practice in the context of simulated disability experience task and community -based experience activities. ULO8 - Locate, retrieve and use resources that inform understanding about health and occupational issues.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe, examine and explain how humans use time, classify occupation and influence of person-environment-occupation interactions on peoples' health and wellbeing; ULO2 - Articulate and contrast contemporary developmental lifespan concepts, theories and research; ULO3 - Examine, compare and contrast the physical, cognitive, emotional, behavioural, social and occupational aspects of human development across the lifespan, with respect to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples? and culturally diverse populations, and the influence of external factors on development; ULO4 - Source and appraise literature related to the physical, social, cultural, economic, political and institutional environments of individuals and groups, with respect to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Peoples? and culturally diverse populations, to inform occupation-based practices across the lifespan; ULO5 - Describe observations and critique these in relationship to developmental theories about typical childhood occupations; ULO6 - Demonstrate effective communication and interview skills for practice and professional behaviour; ULO7 - Describe and apply ?occupational therapy clinical reasoning process to practice situations; ULO8 - Identify data collection methods, collect and analyse data on the occupational performance of self and others that inform understanding about health and wellbeing, key occupational issues and concepts for practice; ULO9 - Demonstrate basic knowledge related to body functions and structures.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate and apply skills in self reflection, critical appraisal, critical reasoning and critical thinking skills to case-based learning and to fieldwork practice, and behave in a manner appropriate for professional practice in both the academic and clinical environment, including interacting respectfully with different members of the health care team, consumers and carers. ULO2 - Recognize the challenges and rights of consumers and carers, and integrate their lived experience of health methods into service planning and delivery by acknowledging their expertise. ULO3 - Describe the importance of multicultural diversity and cultural relationships to professional practice. ULO4 - Explain the mechanisms and consequences of problems related to mental/psychosocial, physical and social capacities of humans, across the lifespan and apply knowledge of body functions, body structures and related clinical conditions to occupational performance challenges for clients of occupational therapy. ULO5 - Describe and apply key theoretical models of human occupation to client-centred occupational therapy assessment, goal setting, intervention, and follow-up evaluation. ULO6 - Describe and apply the principles of occupational analysis and grading and adaptation of occupations to a therapy situation. ULO7 - Describe and apply the clinical reasoning process to the occupational therapy process and formulate appropriate occupational therapy goals and objectives for specific clients. ULO8 - Select, administer and critique assessment methods used in occupational therapy practice including initial assessment interview using this information to evaluate occupational performance and occupational engagement. ULO9 - Accurately record and document professional information. ULO10 - Locate, retrieve and use resources to inform decision making about health and occupational issues.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate skills in self-assessment and the provision of constructive feedback to others. ULO2 - Describe typical occupational therapy theories, intervention strategies, methods and modalities used with clients of occupational therapy presenting with physical, mental/psychosocial, cognitive, social and other related occupational performance challenges. ULO3 - Apply principles of client-centred practice, activity and occupational analysis, grading and adapting equipment, tasks, activities and environments, and energy conservation to enhance occupational participation and performance with clients. ULO4 - Describe common musculoskeletal, medical, surgical, neurological, mental/psychosocial disease processes relevant to clients of occupational therapy and their occupational sequelae. ULO5 - Evaluate a home/office for home/workplace modifications, use technical drawing techniques and write recommendations for home/workplace modification professionals and describe the role of external agencies (e.g. Archicentre, TADVIC and the SWEP) and use of Australian Standards in home modification. ULO6 - Demonstrate the use and principles of orthotic fabrication using low temperature thermoplastic materials and justify design, manufacture and application of a specific orthosis. ULO7 - Select, measure, prescribe and use appropriate assistive equipment to enable client occupational participation and performance (e.g. mobility equipment, lifting devices/hoists, pressure care equipment and communication devices). ULO8 - Describe different quantitative and quantitative research methods and methodologies, and critique research strategies relevant to occupational therapy practice. ULO9 - Describe ethical research issues and practices. ULO10 - Describe and demonstrate how to apply the principles of evidence-based practice using best evidence available for practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Articulate ethical and legal issues pertinent to project work; ULO2 - Articulate funding systems and submission processes in health care; ULO3 - Apply change management processes and systems theory in a community partnership project; ULO4 - Develop, implement, evaluate and disseminate information concerning a project that has occupational relevance to a community or population; ULO5 - Implement, undertake, deliver or operationalise a project according to stated goals and objectives detailed in a project proposal; ULO6 - Communicate effectively with stakeholders and facilitate stakeholder commitment; ULO7 - Identify and apply approaches that may be adopted to address population based health issues and apply the principles of enabling occupation to a population/community; ULO8 - Maintain the professional standards and emergency procedures set by the clinical facility, Monash University and by Occupational Therapy Australia code of ethics; ULO9 - Report and disseminate information pertaining to community partnership projects using effective verbal and written communication; ULO10 - Manage project information and timelines.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Reflect upon and critique your capacity to practice with regard to the Australian Occupational Therapy Competency Standards; ULO2 - Develop and evaluate a range of relevant professional support and supervision strategies for safe and competent practice; ULO3 - Apply principles of reflection, self-critique, and ongoing professional development and learning to the development of a learning contract for your final fieldwork placement; ULO4 - Analyse and critique current professional issues influencing occupational therapy practice, and factors driving change in evolving service contexts; ULO5 - Critically review and provide constructive feedback to peers with regard to skills required for transition to practice; ULO6 - Develop and evaluate an innovative occupational therapy service and/or product in an evolving, demand-driven service context; ULO7 - Recognise and apply leadership principles that support collaborative practice; ULO8 - Develop and evaluate knowledge and skills required for job seeking and career development as a new graduate.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate autonomous and competent application of all stages of the occupational therapy process to the level expected of a new graduate in occupational therapy as outlined in the Australian Minimum Competency Standards for New Graduate Occupational Therapists (ACSOT); ULO2 - Apply professional attitudes and behaviours, and effective time and workload management strategies to occupational therapy practice; ULO3 - Document personal and professional learning using a portfolio in preparation for professional accreditation; ULO4 - Devise strategies to overcome service delivery constraints to provide effective occupational therapy intervention for clients in a fieldwork agency; ULO5 - Collaborate, co-operate and communicate with other health professionals and health service providers to deliver effective and efficient practice; ULO6 - Select and critique occupational therapy interventions on the basis of best available evidence; ULO7 - Design and implement strategies for critical self-reflection, evaluation and improvement of own professional development; ULO8 - Develop strategies to provide effective occupational therapy service considering the broad political, legal and industrial issues in the workplace, profession and client group; ULO9 - Plan, implement and evaluate an occupational therapy service; ULO10 - Critique an organization's key performance indicators and service delivery for continuous improvement and meeting the regulatory standards.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate the ability to be reflective, think critically, learn independently and be innovative in their approach to the research project ULO2 - Possess appropriate oral, written and information technology skills, including the ability to present a coherent argument, negotiate effectively and manage conflict. ULO3 - Demonstrate an understanding of basic statistics and measurement concepts: levels of measurement, reliability, validity, normative data; as well as basic qualitative concepts of rigor, trustworthiness, authenticity and transferability. ULO4 - Describe and demonstrate knowledge and understand functioning of qualitative and quantitative research designs and methods relevant to occupational therapy practice and community development. UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critique professional issues arising from contemporary practice as a result of organisational and team management, finance, and partnering with consumers; ULO2 - Plan, participate in and present research/project findings at a professional conference; ULO3 - Demonstrate effective presentation skills in written, visual and verbal modes; ULO4 - Create an original scenario that highlights evidence-based occupational therapy intervention/s for a client or group in the context of a client's total service provision from an agency or organisation; ULO5 - Demonstrate ability to reflect on own role within health and human service systems; ULO6 - Critique own performance within an organisation or agency (e.g. self-management, own role and contribution in the team); ULO7 - Identify areas for own continuing learning and professional development to support transition to practice. UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate responsibility for own attitudes and behaviour, and maintain the legal, ethical, and professional standards and emergency procedures set by the fieldwork facility, Monash University, and OT AUSTRALIA code of ethics; ULO2 - Evaluate contextual factors that impact clients occupational issues from biopsychosocial, organisational, workforce and systemic perspectives; ULO3 - Analyse and demonstrate a critical understanding of the ways in which culture, multicultural contexts, and diversities inform professional practice ULO4 - Implement critical reasoning in the development and implementation of occupationally relevant and service user-focused intervention strategies; ULO5 - Critique the evidence available for individual and group-focused occupational therapy intervention strategies to address physical, mental/psychosocial, cognitive, social, and other occupational performance issues and challenges; ULO6 - Develop and document an occupationally informed strategy to collect, appraise and present quantitative and qualitative data in written reports regarding service user group-level needs and challenges; ULO7 - Apply team working skills to prepare, produce and deliver group presentations and reports; and, ULO8 - Appraise the influence of government policy and available funding systems on the development of services to prevent ill health and promote health and wellbeing, as they relate to occupational therapy practice.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically appraise the role of occupational therapists in population-level service planning, evaluation and resource management. UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Create a learning plan based on appraisal of your learning needs to maintain competence and professional development that meet professional standards and credentialing processes in occupational therapy. UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate professional attitudes and behaviours at the level expected of a new graduate occupational therapist as assessed through the SPEF-R; ULO2 - Demonstrate autonomous and competent application of all stages of the occupational therapy process to the level expected of a new graduate in occupational therapy according to the Australian Minimum Competency Standards for New Graduate Occupational Therapists; ULO3 - Reflect, develop and critique personal and professional learning using an electronic portfolio in preparation for professional accreditation, including opportunities for supervision and a plan for continual professional development that reflects a self-directed and life-long approach to learning; ULO4 - Implement, critique and evaluate strategies to effectively meet own learning needs using a learning contract; ULO5 - Provide effective occupational therapy service considering the broad political, legal and industrial issues in the workplace, profession and client group; ULO6 - Critique and devise strategies to address the change management processes, human resource management and service planning and delivery structures within an organization; ULO7 - Critique professional issues arising from contemporary practice as a result of organisational and team management, finance and partnering with consumer groups; ULO8 - Create an original scenario that highlights evidence-based occupational therapy intervention/s for a client or group in the context of a client's total service provision from an agency or organisation.

ULO5 - Describe person-environment-occupation interactions models of practice and their relationship to a person's health and well-being, and ethical and culturally sensitive practice. ULO4 - Explore issues such as drug/alcohol abuse, homelessness, mental health and family violence and how these intersect and impact patient health and well-being. ULO7 - Recognise and examine how personal prejudices and those of others, can impact patient care and outcomes. ULO8 - Identify issues associated with self-care and examine and implement strategies to ensure this is prioritised. ULO9 - Conduct themselves in a professional and respectful manner as members of a health care team with other health care providers, emergency workers, bystanders and patients.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the epidemiology, population health, pathophysiology, and clinical manifestations of acute and chronic cardiovascular conditions commonly encountered in paramedic practice across the lifespan; ULO2 - Interpret electrocardiograms for a normal patient and those experiencing cardiovascular abnormalities including dysrhythmias and acute coronary syndromes; ULO3 - Systematically assess a patient experiencing a cardiovascular emergency and associate the assessment with cardiovascular disease pathology; ULO4 - Plan and implement appropriate and safe management for a patient experiencing a cardiovascular emergency and accurately document and communicate the care provided; ULO5 - Identify drugs commonly used by advanced life support paramedics for the management of cardiovascular conditions. Discuss their actions and evaluate the appropriateness of their use in differing circumstances during a cardiovascular emergency; ULO6 - Discuss the diagnostic reasoning, clinical problem solving and clinical decision making processes that determine the care of patients with cardiovascular conditions in order to evaluate and justify management.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the epidemiology, population health and pathology related to injuries and commonly encountered in paramedic practice. ULO2 - Describe criteria used to identify major trauma and demonstrate the application of pre-hospital trauma triage guidelines. ULO3 - Identify and evaluate evidence that informs paramedic clinical practice guidelines used to care for patients with injury. ULO4 - Relate the pharmacology of drugs and fluids used by paramedics for the management of injury to drug indications and actions. ULO5 - Demonstrate the ability to integrate the theoretical knowledge and clinical skills to the assessment and management of patients with injury in real time simulation. ULO6 - Demonstrate clinical reasoning skills related to the management of trauma patients.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the basic principles of pharmacology, drug administration and monitoring as they relate to paramedic practice; ULO2 - Identify routes of administration, absorption rates and safe work practices as they relate to paramedic practice; ULO3 - Demonstrate proficiency in calculation of drug dosages for administration of medications by paramedics by a variety of routes; ULO4 - Examine legal responsibilities associated with the administration and safe keeping of drugs within paramedic practice; ULO5 - Identify and explain the actions and side effects of common pharmaceutical agents encountered within the pre-hospital setting; ULO6 - Review and interpret the historical and current use of drugs used within paramedic practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the epidemiology, population health, pathology and clinical manifestations of mental illness commonly encountered in paramedic practice. ULO2 - Communicate effectively with people who are experiencing disturbances of thoughts, feelings and behaviour. ULO3 - Perform a mental status assessment as applied to paramedic practice. ULO4 - Comply with the Victorian Mental Health Act (2014) guidelines when carrying out a search and search procedure on patients with a mental health emergency ULO5 - Identify and apply therapeutic interventions and techniques appropriate to managing a mental health emergency in the community setting. ULO6 - Initiate appropriate care for patients with mental health issues, family members and carers in response to correctly identifying factors contributing to the situation.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the epidemiology, population health, and pathology related to acute and chronic emergency medical conditions commonly encountered in paramedic practice; ULO2 - Describe the clinical manifestations of the selected medical conditions commonly encountered in paramedic practice; ULO3 - Demonstrate the ability to integrate and apply theoretical knowledge and clinical skills to the assessment and management of patients with selected acute and chronic medical emergencies across the lifespan; ULO4 - Relate the pharmacology of drugs and fluids used by paramedics in the management of common medical conditions, including drug indications and actions.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Evaluate a range of local and international disease aetiologies and epidemiologies that impact on a community setting and the role pre-hospital professionals play in addressing these diseases. ULO2 - Analyse and apply the practices of advanced prescribing, health promotion, health assessment, discharge planning and a range of treatment schedules using an evidence-based approach. ULO3 - Outline the clinical presentations, signs and symptoms and treatments associated with various ailments, diseases and conditions commonly encountered in the community practice settings including children and geriatrics. ULO4 - Recognise risk factors for disease or injury, while using appropriate screening tools to be able to triage patients to remain in their home, refer to general practice or other appropriate health services. ULO5 - Develop strategies targeted at leadership and education to inform change in models of paramedic practice to meet evolving community needs.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the roles and responsibilities of paramedics, emergency services and other health agencies in relation to a multi-casualty or major incident. ULO2 - Compare and contrast the management of major incident in a rural, remote or complex setting compared to the urban environment. ULO3 - Describe the broader requirements of paramedics, emergency services and other health agencies during disaster management, in particular the management of public health issues and logistics management. ULO4 - Analyse the contemporary structure of a major incident control system in the Australian context, and describe the role of the paramedic in major incidents and disasters, particularly compared to normal operations. ULO5 - Outline the role of the paramedic in emergency management planning and preparedness in local and international settings. ULO6 - Demonstrate effective logistical management, patient triage or participation in a response team during a simulated mass-casualty situation or major incident.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_TITLE: Clinical education and leadership in paramedic research and practice
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Examine and implement health education strategies designed to reduce paramedic attendance and hospitalisation for patients in the community. ULO2 - Analyse modes of feedback delivery and develop fit for purpose strategies for giving and receiving feedback in the clinical setting. ULO3 - Contrast leadership styles and discuss the effectiveness and appropriateness of each in specific settings. ULO4 - Demonstrate leadership skills in the clinical setting using effective communication, prioritisation and delegation. ULO5 - Critically appraise research and evidence and examine approaches of research translation in clinical settings. ULO6 - Design and implement a pilot research project incorporating best practice research procedures.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_TITLE: Paramedic management of maternal and neonatal health
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the epidemiology, presentation and management of selected health conditions experienced by women during pregnancy, birth and following childbirth and recommend appropriate paramedic strategies; ULO2 - Evaluate models of care available in the maternity services and explain how cultural diversity can influence the care for pregnant women and consider approaches to paramedic care in a variety of situations; ULO3 - Identify and interpret the evidence supporting the paramedic care of pregnant and childbearing women and their babies; ULO4 - Plan and implement a model of care for a woman experiencing a normal or complicated birth; ULO5 - Demonstrate the processes of paramedic assessment of the newborn immediately after childbirth in both, uncomplicated and emergency situations, and select appropriate patient management; ULO6 - Discuss how cultural diversity can influence the care for pregnant women and consider approaches to paramedic care in a variety of situations.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_TITLE: Paramedic management of acute conditions affecting special populations
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Examine the epidemiology, pathophysiology, and clinical manifestations of acute and chronic conditions commonly affecting special population groups ULO2 - Evaluate and recommend appropriate prehospital interventions to complex patients within dynamic environments ULO3 - Consolidate knowledge of paramedic practice and apply that knowledge to patients with complex medical histories or life states ULO4 - Analyse the complexities of different working environments, including rural and remote practice and how care to these populations is delivered ULO5 - Demonstrate clinical reasoning and decision making skills expected of a graduate paramedic.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically evaluate the standard paramedic clinical approach to the assessment and care of patients in the community, hospital or other related health setting; ULO2 - Analyse and appraise the communication techniques utilised to inform, instruct and empower patients to manage their care; ULO3 - Provide appropriate care for patients at an advanced level within the simulation environment and while under supervision in a range of authentic clinical settings; ULO4 - Demonstrate appropriate professional, inter-professional and teamwork behaviours within the community and primary health care settings; ULO5 - Work as an effective team member with fellow paramedics and other health care professionals to provide high level evidence-based patient care; ULO6 - Demonstrate a culturally sensitive approach to personal reactions and those of patients and their families or carers to acute or chronic illness and or injury; ULO7 - Critically reflect on performances in the clinical setting to identify the adequacy of personal judgements and the internal and external factors influencing clinical decision making and higher order thinking; ULO8 - Appraise the care given by peers within simulations and where possible within the authentic environments through public reflection to learn from these actions and inform future practice; ULO9 - Evaluate the experiences gained within the simulation environment through reflection and judge the influence these may have on future practice within the workplace.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify areas of knowledge deficit in community-based emergency health practice and research and plan a study approach to address their learning needs; ULO2 - Demonstrate a commitment to learning by identifying resources within the university and community-based emergency health services that can be accessed to address their learning needs; ULO3 - Accurately locate and critically assess research literature, with an emphasis on community-based emergency health; ULO4 - Demonstrate suitable oral presentation skills to an audience of peers, superiors and academic staff; ULO5 - Demonstrate an advanced knowledge of an aspect of community-based emergency health.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Discuss the different methods of knowledge acquisition and synthesis. ULO2 - Discuss the ethical, legal and cultural responsibilities of scientific investigation. ULO3 - Describe the principles of "Good clinical research" as described by the NH&MRC, with an emphasis on research in community-based emergency health. ULO4 - Describe the phases of the research process. ULO5 - Discuss basic research concepts and methodology, in both quantitative and qualitative experimental designs. ULO6 - Critically review scientific literature in community-based emergency health. ULO7 - Consult with both a statistician and a qualitative researcher to discuss the role of methodology consultants in the research process. ULO8 - Write up scientific work in a potentially publishable manner. ULO9 - Prepare and present suitable oral and written presentations for the emergency health academic, research and scientific community. ULO10 - Demonstrate the ability to pursue higher studies in community-based emergency health. ULO11 - Demonstrate competence in locating, assessing and storing research literature with an emphasis on community-based emergency health. ULO12 - Design an appropriate research methodology to address an identified research issue/question in consultation with the supervisor.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Discuss the different methods of knowledge acquisition and synthesis. ULO2 - Discuss the ethical, legal, and cultural responsibilities of scientific investigation. ULO3 - Describe the principles of "Good Clinical Research", as described by the NH&MRC, with an emphasis on research in community-based emergency health. Critically review the scientific literature in community-based emergency health.    ? ? ULO7 - Consult with both a statistician and a qualitative researcher to discuss the role of methodology consultants in the research process. ULO8 - Write up scientific work in a potentially publishable manner. ULO9 - Prepare and present suitable oral and written presentations for the emergency health academic, research and scientific community. ULO10 - Demonstrate a range of technical skills appropriate to community-based emergency health research. ULO11 - Demonstrate the ability to pursue higher studies in community based emergency health. UNIT_TITLE: Introduction to aeromedical and retrieval concepts
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Examine and explain the basics of aviation, including meteorology in relation to both rotary and fixed wing aircraft; ULO2 - Critically examine the physiological effects of flight upon crew and patient(s) and identify strategies to appropriately manage a range of patient conditions. ULO3 - Evaluate the integral role of retrieval medicine within the broader health care system, identifying all of the factors to be considered when coordinating an aero medical retrieval; ULO4 - Examine aspects of aviation safety including Crew Resource Management (CRM) to optimise safety practices within the aviation environment. ULO5 - Examine the factors to be considered when working around both rotary and fixed wing aircraft to ensure ones safety. ULO6 - Examine the concept of self-preservation following an aircraft incident and actions that can be taken to maximise ones chances of survival.?
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate advanced communication skills in a range of operational circumstances, including the participation in critical incident debriefing; ULO2 - Apply effective and professional leadership skills in complex, stressed and/or time-critical environments both in the team environment or working independently ULO3 - Engage effectively and cooperatively with a comprehensive range of co-professional agencies and/or professional roles which support their practice; ULO4 - Integrate effective reflective practice, peer review and other methods of evaluation for the purpose of continued personal and professional growth and demonstrating professional behaviours; ULO5 - Synthesise the best available evidence and research base to support the formulation and implementation of critical care decision pathways; ULO6 - Recognise hazards, limitations, and/or barriers to effective practice within their operational environment and construct strategies for managing them.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_TITLE: Aeromedical and retrieval clinical 1: Advanced life support/critical care
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Predict the specific effects of altitude on susceptible medical, surgical and traumatic conditions; ULO2 - Generate pharmacotherapeutic and fluid administration plans to manage common conditions requiring aeromedical transport, demonstrating effective forward planning to manage potential complications that may arise; ULO3 - Formulate holistic patient care plans appropriate to the professional practice level of the student; ULO4 - Devise clinical management strategies which will predict and prevent potential aeromedical problems which affect safe and efficient patient transport; ULO5 - Analyse the principles of operation of medical equipment utilised in the care of patients during flight. ULO6 - Evaluate the pivotal role of teamwork within the aeromedical retrieval environment
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Analyse the functions and relationships of the components of aeromedical retrieval systems, and their integration with the broader health system; ULO2 - Describe the functions and processes relating to the complexities of planning and logistics in aeromedical retrieval systems, and their relationships with other health system components; ULO3 - Formulate planning skills to facilitate efficient multi-platform planning and retrieval tasking, along with their integration with call-taking and dispatch systems; ULO4 - Evaluate and formulate coordination strategies to minimise mission risk and maximise efficiency in crew and platform selection, along with recognition of factors that would preclude mission tasking; ULO5 - Analyse the principles of aviation logistics and platform selection, and how they may be impacted by variables such as weather, duty times, and resource availability; ULO6 - Formulate Aeromedical Management plans to operate in conjunction with hospital emergency response plans, multi patient incidents/disaster/military response, along with search and rescue and other emergency response providers
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_TITLE: Aeromedical retrieval rescue for intensive care paramedics
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Appraise the role of fixed and rotary wing aircraft and the aeromedical team in search and rescue; ULO2 - Explain air search techniques including the role of the observer; ULO3 - Determine the specific requirements for packaging patients for rescue; ULO4 - Evaluate different survival techniques on land and in sea; ULO5 - Participate in helicopter winching techniques; and ULO6 - Identify the required elements of aeromedical retrieval rescue pertaining to their professional role.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_TITLE: Aeromedical and retrieval clinical 2: Intensive care
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically appraise the facilities and equipment available on non-dedicated aeromedical airlines (including commercial airlines) to facilitate care of the patient during flight. ULO2 - Analyse the implications of common international travel conventions and legal requirements related to moving patients, equipment and medications from port to port to the successful and safe retrieval of the patient. ULO3 - Predict the specific effects of altitude on susceptible medical, surgical and traumatic conditions; ULO4 - Generate pharmacotherapeutic and fluid administration plans to manage common conditions requiring aeromedical transport, demonstrating effective forward planning to manage potential complications that may arise; ULO5 - Formulate holistic patient care plans appropriate to the professional practice level of the student, demonstrating a comprehensive knowledge of medical equipment; ULO6 - Devise clinical management strategies which will predict and prevent potential aeromedical problems which affect safe and efficient patient transport;
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate core knowledge of the normal structure, function and development of the human body at all stages of life. ULO2 - Demonstrate knowledge of the aetiology, pathology, symptoms and signs, natural history, and prognosis of common ailments in children, adolescents, adults and the aged. ULO3 - Recognise risk factors for disease or injury, while using appropriate screening tools to be able to triage patients to remain in their home, refer to general practice or other appropriate health services. ULO4 - Select and interpret appropriate, cost-effective diagnostic tools and use them as an adjunct to the history and physical examination findings to formulate an appropriate diagnosis, differential diagnosis and implement an appropriate management plan. ULO5 - Make informed decisions about diagnostic and therapeutic interventions and reflect critically on the justifications for decisions using an evidence-based approach. ULO6 - Identify emergent cases and complex conditions beyond the paramedic's range of medical knowledge and competence. ULO7 - Recognise the limitations of the student's medical knowledge, and how this relates to scope of practice, patient safety and their role within the broader health care team.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Examine and apply knowledge of normal gastrointestinal and genitourinary anatomy and physiology to describe the structure and function as well as common abnormalities and significant acute or chronic pathologies associated with these two systems; ULO2 - Analyse the common causes, clinical assessments, complications and outcomes associated with foreign body objects in both adult and paediatric patients; ULO3 - Implement knowledge, skills and evidence based practice to safely and professionally manage acute complications associated with urinary catheters, PEG's and non-complicated foreign body object removal; ULO4 - Formulate appropriate pharmacotherapeutic regimes using the relevant drugs available for the extended care paramedic in the management of acute or chronic gastrointestinal and genitourinary conditions including appropriate and judicious use of antibiotics, non-opioid analgesics, anti-inflammatories and antipyretic drugs; ULO5 - Synthesise how community emergency health practitioners might relate to and coordinate with hospital emergency departments, general practitioners and other healthcare services for optimal patient-centred outcomes in the management of these conditions. ULO6 - Reflect on the acute or chronic presentations beyond the technical skill, scope of clinical practice or diagnostic capabilities of an extended care paramedic as it relates to the management of gastrointestinal, genitourinary or foreign body object removal presentations.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically appraise research literature for validity and discuss the importance of evidence-based practice in paramedicine. ULO2 - Justify the importance of a structured and systematic clinical approach in advanced paramedic practice. ULO3 - Critically review human factor theory and the relevance to paramedic practice. ULO4 - Explain the concept of professionalism, its relevance to and integration in paramedicine practice. ULO5 - Develop and implement strategies to incorporate reflective practices into all aspects of paramedic practice. ULO6 - Demonstrate an advanced knowledge of pathophysiology and apply key concepts to patient care. ULO7 - Identify key anatomical landmarks relevant to advance paramedic interventions. ULO8 - Explain advanced principles of pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics and construct links between these and paramedic practice. ULO9 - Examine the role of pharmacological agent in paramedic practice and how they are used in conjunction with non-pharmacological interventions.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_TITLE: Intensive care management of cardiac conditions
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the epidemiology of cardiac disease ULO2 - Systematically Interpret common ECGs and relate waveform morphology to the underlying structure and function of the heart; ULO3 - Formulate appropriate pharmacotherapeutic regimes using the relevant drugs available for the intensive care management of cardiac conditions; ULO4 - Implement knowledge, skills and evidence based practice to professionally manage a cardiac emergency as an intensive care paramedic; ULO5 - Assess the benefits of pre-hospital advanced cardiac life support and the related role of the intensive care paramedic; ULO6 - Evaluate how community emergency health practitioners might relate to and coordinate with coronary care units in the management of patients with emergency cardiac conditions.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_TITLE: Intensive care management of respiratory conditions
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Analyse the epidemiology of respiratory disease and construct a natural history of the pathology related to acute and chronic respiratory conditions; ULO2 - Formulate appropriate pharmacotherapeutic regimes using the relevant medications available for the intensive care management of respiratory conditions; ULO3 - Integrate knowledge, skills and evidence based practice to professionally manage respiratory and airway emergencies at an intensive care level; ULO4 - Construct treatment pathways through the application of advanced clinical reasoning; ULO5 - Examine the risks and benefits to patients associated with the out-of-hospital intensive care management of respiratory conditions; ULO6 - Demonstrate advanced airway management skills including drug facilitated intubation.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_TITLE: Intensive care management of trauma and environmental conditions
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Examine and apply knowledge of the structure of trauma systems and define the related trauma triage criteria including the benefits of pre-hospital support and the related role of community emergency health practitioners; ULO2 - Analyse the pathophysiology of common traumatic and environmental conditions as it relates to specific intensive care interventions and clinical management strategies; ULO3 - Formulate appropriate pharmacotherapeutic regimes using the relevant drugs available for the intensive care management of trauma and environmental conditions; ULO4 - Implement knowledge, skills and evidence based practice to professionally manage trauma and environmental emergencies as an intensive care paramedic; ULO5 - Synthesise the epidemiology of traumatic injuries and environmental conditions; ULO6 - Determine the likely ongoing management of patients in hospital critical care units using the framework of a trauma system.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_TITLE: Advanced care paramedic management of paediatric and obstetric patients
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate the skills and knowledge to effectively manage obstetric emergencies and provide advanced care for the pregnant patient presenting with physical trauma and/or a medical emergency; ULO2 - Relate the pathophysiology of common paediatric conditions to the early identification of severe illness in paediatric patients; ULO3 - Formulate treatment pathways for the effective management of paediatric and obstetric emergencies including appropriate pharmacotherapeutic regimes, and demonstrating forward planning for ongoing management; ULO4 - Synthesise the contemporary evidence base and employ the principles of best practice into the management of paediatric and neonatal trauma and medical emergencies, using a clinical problem solving and clinical decision making model; ULO5 - Evaluate the psychological and physiological responses of children to illness and injury compared to the adult population; ULO6 - Interpret the epidemiology of paediatric and obstetric conditions including the common patterns of paediatric and obstetric injury and related contemporary interventions.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Transition to intensive care paramedic practice
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the impact of human factors upon the development of expert clinical decision making and clinical judgement ULO2 - Analyse an emergency situation and demonstrate both scene and clinical leadership to formulate and implement appropriate clinical care ULO3 - Competently perform high ranging life-saving clinical skills safely and efficiently in a simulated environment ULO4 - Competently perform a range of paramedic skills including advanced airway management, diagnostics and the administration of pharmacotherapeutic agents. ULO5 - Apply theoretic concepts of paramedicine to a simulated clinical setting ULO6 - Evaluate the outcome of the simulation, using reflective practice as the basis for improvements to their ongoing patient care practices.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_TITLE: Transition to intensive care clinical practicum
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Examine the importance of a sound structured clinical approach and the consequences of deviating from this on decision making, patient management and outcomes. ULO2 - Justify clinical decisions regarding patient diagnosis and management, using clinical knowledge and experience. ULO3 - Evaluate the elements of clinical scene leadership and how these can impact the scene dynamic, other team members, bystanders and patients. ULO4 - Develop a personal plan to continue to develop clinical competence in areas including error mitigation, accepting and acting on feedback, reflective practice and maintenance of well-being. ULO5 - Demonstrate a structured clinical approach, decision making, and scene leadership skills of an intensive care paramedic in a simulated setting.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Community Emergency Health and Paramedic Practice

UNIT_TITLE: Intensive care management of medical conditions
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Analyse the epidemiology of acute and chronic medical illness/disease and synthesise the available contemporary evidence base to inform and/or support improvements in the approach to the management of medical emergencies; ULO2 - Formulate treatment pathways for medical patients through the application of clinical decision-making frameworks and problem-solving; ULO3 - Formulate appropriate pharmacotherapeutic regimes using the relevant drugs available for the intensive care management of medical conditions; ULO4 - Implement knowledge, skills and evidence based practice to professionally manage a medical emergency as an intensive care paramedic; ULO5 - Assess the benefits of pre-hospital advanced medical interventions and the related role of the intensive care paramedic in the management of medical conditions; ULO6 - Evaluate how intensive care paramedics might relate to and coordinate with hospital intensive care units in the management of patients with emergency medical conditions.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Distinguish different approaches to health communication. ULO2 - Define theoretical models of communication, social change and marketing in relation to health and their application in approaches to health promotion. ULO3 - Demonstrate oral and written presentation skills for a range of professional and lay audiences including low literate audiences. ULO4 - Identify key stages in designing a communication campaign and apply them to a selected health issue. ULO5 - Examine the role of the media in the construction of health issues. UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify current and future global health challenges; ULO2 - Analyse the complex underlying causes of global health challenges; ULO3 - Provide an explanation of why there is growing inequity in the world and reflect on the responsibility of all to address this as "global citizens"; ULO4 - Identify and critique initiatives to address global health challenges; ULO5 - Explain and critique the Sustainable Development Goals published by UN.

OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

ULO4 - Formulate and evaluate research hypotheses into a statistical context in public health studies. ULO5 - Accurately interpret statistical methods and results reported in health publications. ULO6 - Analyse data output generated using a statistical software package.?
