UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the regulatory and legislative mechanisms of the Australian legal system in relation to healthcare practice ULO2 - Describe medical and professional ethics and different ethical perspectives as related to healthcare ULO3 - Relate the importance of law, human rights and ethics in professional practice ULO4 - Discuss the concepts of confidentiality, privacy, informed consent ULO5 - Examine topical issues in health from the perspectives of law, rights and ethics.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the steps in planning a preventive health program; ULO2 - Identify data sources for needs assessment and community profiles; ULO3 - Develop a needs assessment incorporating elements of community profiling as the basis of an evidence-based program plan; ULO4 - Identify determinants of population health needs that can be changed by health promotion action; ULO5 - Write SMART project goals and objectives that are clearly linked to health determinants; ULO6 - Identify administrative and management issues that need to be addressed for successful program implementation.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the processes by which drugs act on, and are handled by, the human body. ULO2 - Explain the role of drugs in prevention and treatment of specific diseases. ULO3 - Explain the role of other therapeutic (non-drug) interventions in prevention and treatment of specific diseases. ULO4 - Describe how drugs and other treatments are developed, evaluated and regulated. ULO5 - Discuss the social context of drug use and abuse. ULO6 - Discuss the relationship between drug therapy and public health in local and global contexts.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_TITLE: Introduction to health policy and politics
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Discuss health policy as a key dynamic element of the determinants of health, with effects on the health of populations and societies. ULO2 - Distinguish the major structures, systems and institutions that contribute to the health policy environment with emphasis on health promotion and public health policy. ULO3 - Examine how different processes can be engaged to inform public health policy. ULO4 - Discuss types of health policy within the context of Australia's federal system. ULO5 - Explain the role of government and their agencies, non-government organisations (NGOs) and the community in the development and implementation of health policy. ULO6 - Distinguish between different types of stakeholder influence and involvement, and how these are used in policy development.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_TITLE: Public health and clinical research methods
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Develop an answerable research question to address an evidence gap ULO2 - Critically appraise the strengths and limitations of different study designs ULO3 - Develop and select appropriate measures for use in clinical research ULO4 - Design and conduct epidemiological research in clinical settings ULO5 - Understand and address ethical and practical considerations in clinical research
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the risk factor and causal mechanisms of communicable diseases. ULO2 - Explain the epidemiology and burden of communicable diseases. ULO3 - Apply principles of communicable disease prevention to a range of scenarios ULO4 - Investigate evidence-based strategies in the detection, prevention and control of outbreaks. ULO5 - Interpret epidemiological data on communicable disease surveillance and outbreaks. ULO6 - Design communicable disease surveillance and control programs. ULO7 - Explore similarities and differences in prevention and control strategies for non communicable diseases and communicable diseases.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_TITLE: Environmental determinants of health and disease
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the essential principles of hazard identification, risk assessment, risk management and risk communication. ULO2 - Demonstrate fluency with the basic concepts and terms used to describe chemical, physical and biological hazards. ULO3 - Describe basic principles of identifying common hazards and nominate ways to assess the risks presented. ULO4 - Nominate common interventions used to control environmental risks and the key personal, social and economic factors which may reduce the effectiveness or prevent control measures being successful. ULO5 - Critically evaluate environmental health research evidence and explain the limitations, relevance and application of the evidence to specific situations.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain how evaluation measures the effect of health promotion and public health programs, and identify the importance of evaluation in terms of influencing long-term health outcomes. ULO2 - Apply principles of evaluation planning of health programs and promotions, including theoretical approaches, to evaluation design and assess their suitability for different contexts ULO3 - Distinguish between the different levels of evaluation, and consider how they work together to provide a comprehensive assessment of a program. ULO4 - Examine the range of quantitative and qualitative data collection methods appropriate to evaluation designs, including the use of tools and resources specific to health promotion and public health programs. ULO5 - Critically analyse the key features of an evaluation plan designed for a health promotion or public health program and assess the extent it incorporates evaluation principles and design features. ULO6 - Apply an evaluation planning process and develop an evaluation plan tailored to a health promotion or public health program.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_TITLE: Social and behavioural sciences in public health
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Discuss the social and behavioural theories in relation to prevention, health, and their application to the development, onset, recovery and management of disease. ULO2 - Describe the psychosocial determinants of health, and the influence of these contributing factors to health and illness. ULO3 - Compare the behavioural and psychosocial interventions in relation to health and disease, and their application to real world scenarios. ULO4 - Critically analyse a range of behaviour issues, and assess behavioural interventions and practices that could be utilised. ULO5 - Recognise the cultural and social context of behaviour change, and their relevance to health care, chronic illness and death. ULO6 - Communicate the nature and application of behavioural and psychosocial interventions for both professional and lay audiences, including low literate audiences.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply knowledge and skills of research design, methodology and data analysis in the practice of public health/epidemiological research ULO2 - Demonstrate an in-depth understanding of the practical and methodological issues in conducting public health/epidemiological research ULO3 - Critically reflect on the skills required for good research practice, including professional, ethical and practical issues ULO4 - Present oral and written reports of research processes and research outcomes.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply health promotion knowledge and skills to the resolution of an industry based health issue. ULO2 - Appreciate how organisational purpose contributes to the field of health promotion. ULO3 - Apply health promotional theories to the design of programs or their delivery. ULO4 - Critically reflect on the professional attitudes and skills required of health professionals, including personal strengths and areas for improvement required for graduate employment. ULO5 - Critically assess a workplace/your host organisation and provide an overview on the workplaces role, history, structure, services and values.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_TITLE: Case studies in global and public health
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the current and future threats to global health and their underlying causes ULO2 - Discuss the interaction of the environment and health including climate change, conflict and natural disasters ULO3 - Demonstrate increased cultural capability in relation to Aboriginal health and how to apply a 'strengths based' approach to Aboriginal health issues ULO4 - Assess public health programs addressing health issues at a national and global level including the program's capacity to address health inequities and the appropriateness of design ULO5 - Critique key global strategies and frameworks including the sustainable development goals, the Ottawa charter and the global framework for tobacco control
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the epidemiology and burden of chronic disease ULO2 - Evaluate methods used to measure the impact of chronic disease ULO3 - Appraise risk pathways associated with important chronic diseases ULO4 - Examine the impact of determinants of health in chronic disease ULO5 - Evaluate strategies for the public health control of chronic diseases
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Develop a data management workflow ULO2 - Appraise the processes of data linkage ULO3 - Construct interim data reports ULO4 - Implement strategies for monitoring data quality ULO5 - Compile a data set handbook
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the benefits of statistical modelling to answer research questions in the health sciences ULO2 - Recognise an appropriate statistical method to suit a particular substantive problem ULO3 - Formulate and communicate a statistical analysis plan ULO4 - Use statistical modelling procedures appropriate for survey, experimental, and observational data using the SPSS software ULO5 - Interpret and present the results of statistical analyses in written and oral form ULO6 - Critically appraise the use of statistical methodology in the health sciences literature
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand the evidence-practice gap ULO2 - Describe the knowledge translation cycle ULO3 - Understand and analyse systematic review and guideline development methods ULO4 - Develop and implement a public health evaluation plan ULO5 - Design strategies for assessing barriers and enablers to translating research into practice
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Public Health and Preventive Medicine

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Develop clinical questions which can be answered using literature evidence. ULO2 - Prepare and execute an appropriate search strategy (of relevant electronic databases and resources) to find evidence to answer clinical questions. ULO3 - Evaluate the validity and relevance of literature evidence when answering clinical questions. ULO4 - Interpret and synthesise the evidence to provide an answer to the clinical question posed. ULO5 - Effectively communicate evidence based findings to peers and relevant health professionals to support clinical decisions. ULO6 - Demonstrate attributes of a life-long learner by reflecting on gaps in knowledge and skills relating to the practice of EBP.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Implement a standardised approach to patient care in a range of healthcare settings. ULO2 - Describe the pathophysiology of selected disease states and explain the rationale and expected outcomes for drug therapy. ULO3 - Use current best evidence to determine and justify a valid/optimal therapeutic approach to management of these disease states. ULO4 - Develop, with an evidence based rationale, customised management and monitoring plans considering patient specific parameters, clinical test results and pharmacokinetic parameters. ULO5 - Critically reflect on their individual learning process and progress in clinical competence.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Develop a research proposal and timeline for a practice based research project, using appropriate data collection and analysis methods. ULO2 - Create a research team; including identifying and negotiating with collaborators and preparing ethics applications. ULO3 - Effectively integrate knowledge, experience, and research skills to develop and refine a research proposal. ULO4 - Use peer, collaborator and supervisor feedback and critical reflection to refine a research proposal. ULO5 - Prepare and deliver oral and written presentations about research objectives and methodologies to a diverse audience of healthcare personnel and academics.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate understanding of research ethics as encountered at their practice site and at Monash University by gaining appropriate ethics approval. ULO2 - Locate and, critically evaluate literature sources relevant to the chosen research project and generate a written literature review suitable for academic publication. ULO3 - Collect data according to approved methodology for subsequent analysis. ULO4 - Prepare and deliver an oral presentation about research work in progress to a diverse audience of healthcare personnel and academics. ULO5 - Integrate peer, collaborator and supervisor feedback and critical reflection to refine their research process. ULO6 - Demonstrate time management skills by meeting set deadlines and proactively negotiating adjustments to agreed timelines.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Analyse data in a manner appropriate to the chosen study design and results obtained. ULO2 - Interpret research findings in the context of previous research in the field. ULO3 - Develop and conduct a program of research. ULO4 - Prepare and deliver an oral presentation about research findings to a diverse audience of healthcare personnel and academics. ULO5 - Integrate peer, collaborator and supervisor feedback and critical reflection to prepare a written research report. ULO6 - Demonstrate time management skills by meeting set deadlines and proactively negotiating adjustments to agreed timelines. ULO7 - Reflect and report on limitations of the research process and outcomes.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Prepare and analyse treatment plans that optimise the use of antimicrobials. ULO2 - Recommend evidence based approaches to manage patients requiring antimicrobial treatment. ULO3 - Demonstrate critical thinking, communication skills relevant to peers and patients and problem-solving, with a focus on infectious diseases related and antimicrobial related topics. ULO4 - Critically reflect on their individual learning process and progress in clinical competence.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe dermatological conditions using appropriate morphological terms to peers or patients. ULO2 - Propose a differential diagnosis of common skin conditions given visual and symptomatic criteria. ULO3 - Formulate an evidence-based treatment plan for common skin conditions. ULO4 - Synthesise information from current research regarding the efficacy of treatments used in dermatology. ULO5 - Reflect on learning and performance to formulate ongoing professional practice development regarding dermatological knowledge.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Advise healthcare professionals and consumers on the changes in physiology and pathophysiology in older patients, and how this impacts the quality use of medicines in this population. ULO2 - Explain the principles of prescribing and medication management in older patients to healthcare professionals and consumers. ULO3 - Identify and manage medication related problems in individual older patients and in institutional care settings in the context of best available evidence. ULO4 - Prepare for and conduct medication management interviews with elderly patients using effective communication skills. ULO5 - Evaluate collected information to provide evidence based recommendations in a medication management review (MMR) report. ULO6 - Inform and refer older patients to relevant aged care health services where appropriate. ULO7 - Communicate effectively (oral and written) with patients, carers and healthcare professionals to complete medication management reviews (MMR) and provide education. ULO8 - Critically reflect on their individual learning process and progress in clinical competence.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify effects of ageing, disease and medications on cognitive function, falls and balance, bone health, bladder and bowel function and pain. ULO2 - Provide evidence based recommendations and interventions to prevent and manage: cognitive disorders, falls, dizziness, osteoporosis, bladder and bowel problems and pain in older people in the context of best evidence, ULO3 - Communicate effectively (oral and written) with patients, carers and other health professionals to complete clinical medication reviews and develop and implement medication management plans.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate knowledge of common mental health conditions, the associated pharmacological and non -pharmacological treatment options and the required clinical monitoring. ULO2 - Provide professional evidence based advice and education to patients, carers and healthcare professionals about pharmacological and non -pharmacological treatment options, potential side effects of psychotropics and clinical monitoring relevant to common mental health conditions. ULO3 - Identify and manage medication related problems in patients with common mental conditions in the context of best available evidence. ULO4 - Critically evaluate currently available treatments (pharmacological and non-pharmacological) used in the management of patients with common mental health conditions. ULO5 - Inform and refer patients to relevant mental care health services where appropriate. ULO6 - Critically reflect on their individual learning process and progress in clinical competence.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Integrate clinical assessments and patient history to develop evidence-based clinical management plans in palliative care. ULO2 - Justify evidence based pharmacological recommendations relating to palliative care to healthcare consumers including patients, family members and multi-disciplinary healthcare professionals. ULO3 - Recognise, monitor, and manage (pharmacologically and non-pharmacologically) symptoms and treatment side-effects common in palliative care. ULO4 - Apply the principles of quality use of medicines in prescribing and de-prescribing in palliative care. ULO5 - Critically reflect on their individual learning process and progress in clinical competence.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Synthesise learning from all units undertaken in the Masters program in a professional practice portfolio. ULO2 - Generate appropriate evidence of ability to use the advancing practice competencies embedded in the National Competency Standards Framework for Pharmacists in Australia to successfully complete the full cycle of Continuing Professional Development (CPD). ULO3 - Demonstrate attributes of a life-long learner by identifying steps required to continue advancing practice. ULO4 - Report learning and reflect on performance in ways that are appropriate for the profession.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the relationship between the phases of wound healing, including the molecular and cellular components. ULO2 - Contrast and compare acute and chronic healing. ULO3 - Identify factors that enhance, inhibit or delay wound healing and illustrate how these impact on the normal wound healing process. ULO4 - Demonstrate critical analysis skills in relation to wound care literature.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Integrate physical, psychosocial and environmental components into comprehensive wound assessment. ULO2 - Critically appraise frameworks as tools for systematic assessment of a wound. ULO3 - Incorporate wound measurement, exudate assessment, wound bed tissue identification, wound tunnelling and undermining and pain assessment into systematic wound assessment. ULO4 - Describe and develop a multidisciplinary team approach to management resulting from the assessment process. ULO5 - Identify and utilise criteria used to monitor and evaluate wound healing progress. ULO6 - Formulate a wound assessment chart to assess and communicate wound healing progress at a patient, local and organisational level.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Formulate a wound care management plan incorporating skin and wound assessment to guide selection of appropriate products or technologies. ULO2 - Critically review wound dressings and technologies describing their properties and place in therapy. ULO3 - Evaluate the role of debridement in wound bed preparation. ULO4 - Critically appraise adjunctive/alternative therapies used in wound care, including suggested mode of action and level of evidence to support use. ULO5 - Communicate effectively with patients to improve concordance with wound care management plans.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Contrast and compare similarities and differences between acute and chronic wound healing. ULO2 - Identify evidence-based measures for surgical wound management including dressings, techniques, topical treatments and care of sutures, staples and tissue adhesives. ULO3 - Evaluate the appropriate use of antiseptics, disinfectants and antimicrobial agents in the management of wound infection. ULO4 - Appraise management approaches for chronic wounds such as venous and arterial leg ulcers, diabetic foot ulcers and pressure injuries. ULO5 - Identify barriers to the appropriate use of compression bandaging and hosiery and propose interventions to overcome them. ULO6 - Analyse the psychosocial impact of a chronic wound on the individual's quality of life. ULO7 - Describe assessment and management strategies for patients with atypical wounds. ULO8 - Communicate effectively with patients to improve concordance with wound care management plans for acute, chronic and atypical wounds.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically appraise the role of the multidisciplinary team within the wound care setting. ULO2 - Integrate advanced knowledge, problem solving and current best evidence in formulating wound management plans. ULO3 - Develop and implement a multi-disciplinary approach in the management of a patient with a wound. ULO4 - Reflect critically on wound care management practices. ULO5 - Communicate effectively with peers and patients on wound care related issues.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the role of factors (such as aetiology, pathophysiology and weight bearing functions) in the development of a diabetes-related foot wound. ULO2 - Analyse causes of foot ulceration in those with diabetes demonstrating an appreciation for the multi-factorial nature of this complication. ULO3 - Using clinical assessment as a basis, formulate a holistic management plan for a patient with a diabetes-related foot wound including local wound care, pressure reduction techniques, medical management, psychological and sociological aspects. ULO4 - Discuss the advantages of using a multidisciplinary approach in the care of a patient with a diabetes-related foot wound. ULO5 - Investigate potential complications of diabetes-related foot wounds including infection and amputation. ULO6 - Communicate strategies for planning and evaluating outcomes of care for patients with diabetes-related foot wounds.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the significance of pressure injury from both a personal and community perspective. ULO2 - Critically appraise currently available clinical practice guidelines related to the prevention and/or treatment of pressure injuries. ULO3 - Review risk assessment tools and prevention strategies for use in the development of a pressure injury prevention plan. ULO4 - Formulate a treatment plan for an individual with an existing pressure injury demonstrating knowledge of assessment, monitoring and interventions required. ULO5 - Develop and implement a multi-disciplinary team approach in the management of a patient at risk of or with an existing pressure injury. ULO6 - Investigate the psychosocial impact of a pressure injury on an individual's quality of life. ULO7 - Communicate strategies for planning and evaluating care outcomes for patients with pressure injuries.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Advanced clinical practice in wound care
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Integrate the roles of teacher, leader, consultant, researcher, change agent, role model and reflective practitioner as part of the advanced practitioner role. ULO2 - Identify barriers that may impact on the delivery of effective wound care and suggest appropriate management strategies for overcoming them. ULO3 - Utilise evidence based practice in the management of complex wounds. ULO4 - Demonstrate advanced knowledge through planning, implementation and evaluation of care for patients with complex wounds. ULO5 - Develop communication strategies for planning and evaluating outcomes of care for patients with wounds. ULO6 - Critically analyse wound management interventions in light of available research and evidence. ULO7 - Reflect critically on professional practice in wound care.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Clinical risk management and wound care
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Examine clinical risk management in relation to wound prevention. ULO2 - Critically evaluate prevention strategies and the evidential basis supporting best practice guideline recommendations. ULO3 - Formulate a prevention pathway for pressure injuries, skin tears, venous ulcers or diabetes related foot ulcers using a clinical risk management approach. ULO4 - Examine patient, local and organisational barriers to wound prevention and develop a plan for overcoming them. ULO5 - Investigate appropriate measures for monitoring effectiveness of wound prevention strategies for the individual and the healthcare service. ULO6 - Design suitable communication strategies for distributing the findings of clinical audits.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Discuss immediate first aid and emergency management and its impact on a burn injury. ULO2 - Integrate burn assessment, topical or surgical management options, pain control and nutritional support into a management plan for a patient with a burn injury. ULO3 - Examine potential complications associated with burn injury and suggest how these could be prevented. ULO4 - Critically evaluate scar management interventions including medical/surgical management, pressure therapy, massage, silicone, exercise and splinting and demonstrate their appropriate use. ULO5 - Identify potential barriers that might impact on a patient's concordance with scar management interventions and make recommendations for overcoming these. ULO6 - Investigate the psychosocial impact of a significant scar on the individual's quality of life. ULO7 - Examine long term consequences of burn injury for the individual, carer/family members and health care professionals.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Examine the differences between chronic and non-healing wounds including identifying factors which may lead to a wound become non-healing. ULO2 - Apply holistic patient assessment and realistic goal setting in the management of an individual with a non-healing wound. ULO3 - Critically appraise treatment options for a patient with a non- healing wound. ULO4 - Develop and implement a multi-disciplinary team approach in the management of a patient with a non-healing wound. ULO5 - Formulate a pain management plan incorporating the use of validated pain assessment tools. ULO6 - Critically appraise treatment modalities for pain. ULO7 - Investigate barriers to effective pain management and develop strategies for overcoming them. ULO8 - Examine quality of life issues in relation to the individual with a non-healing wound or who is experiencing pain.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Discuss the targets of drug action, their mechanisms of action and the factors that influence their use as therapeutics; ULO2 - Apply knowledge of drug action to discuss the risks and benefits of drug use and some of the non-pharmacological issues associated with drugs in our society; ULO3 - Discuss the steps involved in the discovery, development and regulation of drugs from bench to market; ULO4 - Demonstrate the ability to obtain, present and interpret data from pharmacological experiments; ULO5 - Demonstrate the ability to source, evaluate and use information from a range of sources to critically analyse socially relevant drug controversies; ULO6 - Demonstrate the ability to work both independently and as part of a team.

ULO1 - Discuss mechanisms by which drugs can act to produce changes in living systems; ULO2 - Utilise the basic principles of pharmacokinetics to explain individual differences in responses to drugs; ULO3 - Apply knowledge of endogenous mediator systems to predict the potential therapeutic and adverse effects of drugs; ULO4 - Access relevant scientific literature to design a set of experiments to address a specific hypothesis relating to a drug's mechanism of action; ULO5 - Demonstrate the ability to execute pharmacological experiments to obtain, present and interpret data relating to mechanisms of drug action; ULO6 - Demonstrate the ability to source, critically evaluate and use scientific literature to address a defined pharmacological problem; ULO7 - Demonstrate the ability to work individually and collaboratively.

ULO1 - Explain the major principles underlying the therapeutic use of drugs, including the relevance and assessment of evidence-based medicine; ULO2 - Apply knowledge of the actions of major drug classes to explain their therapeutic applications and potential adverse effects; ULO3 - Use knowledge of the mechanisms of drug action to predict effects in intact organisms; ULO4 - Demonstrate the ability to execute pharmacological experiments to obtain, analyse and interpret data and present this in a written report; ULO5 - Demonstrate the ability to undertake literature based research to source and critically evaluate information relevant to current topics in pharmacology and to effectively communicate ideas in oral, visual or written forms.

ULO1 - Apply knowledge of central neurotransmitter and endocrine systems to predict the effects of drugs; ULO2 - Integrate and reconstruct knowledge underlying the cellular mechanisms of neuro- and endocrine pharmacology to predict outcomes in the whole animal; ULO3 - Present, analyse and interpret data from a range of experiment types and discuss this in the context of current scientific literature; ULO4 - Execute experiments in neuropharmacology and endocrine pharmacology to present, analyse and report the data obtained; ULO5 - Source, integrate and critically evaluate the scientific literature to address a defined pharmacological problem relating to neuro- or endocrine pharmacology.

ULO1 - Discuss the steps involved in the drug discovery process, including sources of drugs, how targets are identified and screening processes that can be used to test for desired activity; ULO2 - Discuss the steps involved in developing a commercial product from a potential drug candidate, including the relevant regulatory framework and marketing considerations; ULO3 - Critically evaluate methodologies and data from experiments in the context of the drug development process; ULO4 - Obtain, present and interpret data from pharmacological experiments relevant to the area of drug development; ULO5 - Source, integrate and critically evaluate the scientific literature to address an issue in the area of drug development and to communicate this orally, in written form or via a poster presentation; ULO6 - Work both independently and as part of a team.

ULO1 - Demonstrate the basic principles of toxicology and the behavioural mechanisms of various toxicants targeting different organ systems. ULO2 - Deduce the general pharmacokinetics, biotransformation and toxicokinetics of xenobiotics in whole organisms. ULO3 - Critically evaluate the adverse effects of chemicals, metals, radioactive materials, and animal and plant toxins on living organisms. ULO4 - Present the different stages of carcinogenesis and assess the effects of toxic agents on the alteration of genetic materials and growth development. ULO5 - Demonstrate an appreciation towards environmental toxicology that includes air pollution and ecotoxicology. ULO6 - Perform and critically evaluate risk assessments of general toxicants, and propose appropriate safety precautions. ULO7 - Foster teamwork, perform good laboratory practice, and communicate research observations/ findings in the form of written reports and presentations.

ULO1 - Describe how drugs work, when and how they are used, their side-effects and toxicity; ULO2 - Demonstrate understanding of the risk-benefit aspects of drug use; ULO3 - Demonstrate knowledge of the sources of drugs and rationales for their use; ULO4 - Demonstrate appreciation of ethical issues encompassing drug research and clinical trials; ULO5 - Carry out tissue bath experiments to elicit drug effects.

ULO1 - Undertake a research project with regard to ethical and safety regulations; ULO2 - Demonstrate technical skills in experimental methods and the ability to collect, analyse and interpret data using methods relevant to the discipline of Pharmacology; ULO3 - Communicate appropriately and effectively with supervisors, laboratory staff and students; ULO4 - Maintain accurate and up-to-date records of experimental procedures, results and outcomes; ULO5 - Identify relevant published scientific literature and critically analyse and evaluate the content in the context of the discipline of Pharmacology; ULO6 - Construct written reports.

UNIT_TITLE: Preventative health and management of chronic disease
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically analyse the patient-centred orientation of existing published guidelines for aged care, including aspects of patient experience and expectations as determined by their psycho-socio-cultural environment ULO2 - Create and justify a database of resources and processes that will optimise team-based care of the aged, including available community-based supports ULO3 - Analyse a small self-audit of aged patients who take multiple medications (or attend multiple healthcare providers) and develop a strategy to optimise patient safety and the management of medico-legal risk ULO4 - Create a plan for quality improvement in one area of aged care that is informed by evidence-based assessment and practice  Issues in General Practice prescribing ULO5 - Discuss the Australian and international use of prescribed medication in terms of research directions, funding, rates of prescribing, the major stakeholders, the influences on prescribing and policy directions such as quality use of medicines initiatives ULO6 - Demonstrate the use of a particular model for deciding the most appropriate therapeutic medication for a particular condition ULO7 - Demonstrate knowledge, practice and skill in a chosen prescribing situation in general practice, including the therapeutic medications used, and the particular steps necessary for safe prescribing ULO8 - Demonstrate critical thinking in reviewing the evidence about a medication via a planned and recorded interview with a pharmaceutical detailer ULO9 - Create a plan for improving the quality of prescribing in your own practice or within the clinic, using audit and feedback  Prevention in General Practice and Primary Care ULO10 - Explain why prevention is a priority for general practice and primary care with particular reference to chronic disease and the prevalence of lifestyle risk factors in the student's country of origin ULO11 - Reflect on the role of General Practitioners and members of the General Practice and Primary Care team in delivering preventive care ULO12 - Appraise the evidence supporting preventive care interventions in General Practice and Primary Care and identify current evidence practice gaps ULO13 - Critically analyse patient perceptions of prevention and the role of General Practitioners in preventive care ULO14 - Identify the barriers and facilitators to optimal delivery of prevention in General Practice and Primary Care settings ULO15 - Describe and evaluate strategies to improve delivery and uptake of preventive care in General Practice and Primary Care settings ULO16 - Locate, retrieve and use current evidence based guidelines, tools, resources and recommendations for prevention in General Practice and Primary Care settings and suggest an implementation plan for their application in practice  Chronic disease management ULO17 - Describe the burden, distribution and determinants of chronic disease within their own country and internationally ULO18 - Analyse the place of Primary Care (General Practice) in the management of chronic diseases with particular reference to their own country and health care system ULO19 - Describe responses to the challenges of chronic disease management as embodied in models such as the chronic care model (Wagner) and their own country's responses to the challenges of this field ULO20 - Evaluate their current work-place performance in managing chronic disease, utilising audit and comparison with chosen standards or guidelines ULO21 - Plan change within the student's current work-place to improve chronic disease management, utilising their previous evaluations, known effective interventions and published guides, templates and financial modelling
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Depressive and anxiety disorders in General Practice  Interpret the principal psychiatric classification system currently in use, and apply it, in conjunction with appropriate clinical reasoning skills, to determine whether or not a patient has a depressive or anxiety disorder. Determine the risk factors and underlying causes of depressive and anxiety disorders, and argue how these influence treatment. Devise and implement a systematic approach to assessing the severity of different types of depressive and anxiety disorders, including their morbidity and mortality. Devise and implement a systematic approach to the management of depressive and anxiety disorders, which includes a synthesis of the best available evidence, in addition to considering patient wishes and circumstances, community resources and the clinician's experience. Distinguish between the presentations in General Practice of different types of depressive and anxiety disorders. Devise a plan for future personal practice and professional development in the diagnosis and management of patients with depressive and anxiety disorders.  ULO2 - Mindfulness-based stress management  Critically review the significant body of research linking psychological states like stress with a range of illnesses and lifestyle including disciplines within mind-body medicine such as neuroplasticity, psychoneuroimmunology and psychogenomics. Critically review research demonstrating the benefits of psychological interventions like stress management and mindfulness Practice the mindfulness meditation exercises in their various forms and critique their effectiveness. Apply the principles of the mindfulness-based cognitive strategies and critique their effectiveness. Critically reflect on their own experience of stress and ways in which they manage it. Develop and implement mindfulness-based stress management in practice. Demonstrate professional skills as a counsellor in mindfulness-based stress management.  ULO3 - Women's sexual and reproductive health in General Practice  Analyse the psychosocial context of women's lives and apply this analysis to women's sexual and reproductive health Develop a systematic and evidence based approach to the diagnosis and management of women's sexual and reproductive health issues which commonly present in the General Practice setting Evaluate those factors contributing to the prevalence of unplanned pregnancy and based on best available evidence formulate an appropriate response that addresses these issues in the General Practice setting Develop a systematic and evidence based approach to contraceptive counselling and counselling for unplanned pregnancy and sexual problems Critically appraise the evidence concerning hormone replacement therapy and screening for cervical, breast and ovarian cancer Evaluate the health outcomes of violence against women and formulate appropriate responses in the General Practice setting based on best available practice evidence  ULO4 - Child health  Develop a systematic and evidence-based approach to the diagnosis and management of child health issues which commonly present in the Primary Health Care setting Assess child development using valid and reliable assessment instruments, determine deviations from the norm and formulate appropriate management strategies in the Primary Health Care setting Formulate a comprehensive management plan surrounding child health by collaborating with other health professionals Analyse the psychosocial and environmental context of children's lives and apply this analysis to child health. Identify paediatric emergencies which commonly present in the Primary Health Care setting and formulate an appropriate initial management plan Effectively use the available literature to inform ongoing learning needs relating to child health  ...(1)
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the signs and symptoms, diagnostic and epidemiological aspects of selected pain, dermatological, gastrointestinal, cardiovascular and respiratory conditions. ULO6 - Define and calculate drug bioavailability, clearance and volume of distribution and describe how these parameters relate to the plasma concentration profile of a drug. ULO7 - Describe different types of drug-drug interactions and predict their impact on plasma drug concentration vs time profiles and therapeutic response. ULO8 - Describe, calculate and apply a range of pharmacokinetic parameters that determine dosage regimens and explain how the relationship between pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics determines the time-course of drug response. ULO9 - Demonstrate proficiency in fundamental pharmaceutical calculations. ULO10 - Define, incorporate, interpret and apply a standardised approach to patient-centred care. ULO11 - Identify and describe common healthcare issues in primary care, by demonstrating safe and systematic procedures for the supply of medicines and the provision of professional advice. ULO12 - Diagnose, manage and communicate effectively information about medicines for a simple healthcare issue in relation to pain, dermatological, cardiovascular, respiratory or gastrointestinal conditions. ULO13 - Reflect on identified strengths and weaknesses in communication and other non-cognitive skills via a Personalised Learning Plan to enhance professional skills required to practice as a pharmacist. ULO14 - Identify and describe the relevant aspects of the Australian health care system and pharmacy settings, by:  applying guiding principles of pharmacy practice. observing the role of pharmacists in pharmacy settings.

ULO3 - Describe and perform calculations appropriate to the classical free electron model, the quantum free electron model and the band theory model for electrical conduction in solids, and compare the strengths and shortcomings of these models. ULO4 - Demonstrate awareness of scientific computing methods and visualization. ULO5 - Acquire, manipulate and interpret physical data and write scientific reports at a level suitable for publication.

ULO1 - Describe concepts and perform calculations in quantum mechanics, using the Dirac and Schrodinger formalism, and apply this knowledge to the analytical solution of model quantum systems. ULO7 - Approach new problems and find solutions on the basis of general principles, and evaluate the appropriateness of their proposed models or solutions.

ULO1 - Describe and perform calculations associated with fundamental concepts in Statistical Mechanics, which include both classical and quantum many-body systems. ULO5 - Demonstrate an ability to work in teams and to communicate and discuss physics concepts. ULO6 - Approach new problems and find solutions on the basis of general principles, and evaluate the appropriateness of their proposed models or solutions.

ULO6 - Demonstrate an ability to work in teams and to communicate and discuss physics concepts. UNIT_TITLE: Neuroscience of communication, sensory and control systems
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the structures of the nervous, sensory, muscular and endocrine systems; ULO2 - Explain how physiological systems function to detect, communicate, analyse and respond to stimuli under normal conditions; ULO3 - Apply knowledge of these physiological systems to determine how they respond to changes in physiological states under normal activity (e.g., exercise) or environmental demands (e.g., living in cold condition; ULO4 - Predict how perturbations to physiological systems, such as diseases and normal ageing, effect their functioning; ULO5 - Accurately perform common biomedical calculations used in research; ULO6 - Collect, analyse, and interpret experimental data while considering variability inherent in working with biological tissue.

ULO1 - Describe the structure and function of the digestive, endocrine and reproductive systems of the body; ULO2 - Explain how these body systems integrate with nutrition, growth and development; ULO3 - Use specific examples of adaptations or dysfunction of these body systems to explain their normal functions; ULO4 - Work in groups to complete a project, including experimental procedures in laboratory classes and oral and written scientific communications; ULO5 - Demonstrate physiology laboratory skills, including data analysis and presentation; ULO6 - Communicate scientific information via a variety of media.

ULO1 - Describe the structure and function of the cardiovascular, respiratory and renal systems of the body; ULO2 - Explain how these body systems integrate in a way that facilitates maintenance of homeostasis and responses to challenges such as exercise and blood loss; ULO3 - Evaluate how altered structure and/or function of these body systems may lead to disease; ULO4 - Apply evidence from experimental and clinical observations to generate knowledge of physiological principles; ULO5 - Perform physiology laboratory techniques, including calculation of drug concentrations, the use of stimulating electrodes and physiological data acquisition systems and the tabulation and graphing of experimental data; ULO6 - Communicate experimental observations and the conclusions drawn from them in the form of written practical reports.

ULO1 - Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the structure and function of the autonomic nervous system, the cardiovascular system, the respiratory system, the muscular-skeletal system and the renal system; ULO2 - Explain how these body systems integrate to maintain homeostasis in the body; ULO3 - Describe and explain how changes in normal physiology may lead to a disease state; ULO4 - Perform laboratory techniques that are integral to the study of physiology, including the use of cardiovascular recordings and urinary analyses to assess the effects of exercise; ULO5 - Collaborate effectively in a group to complete academic tasks; ULO6 - Communicate experimental physiology data via written practical reports.

ULO1 - Describe the mechanism, action and role of hormones on the human gastrointestinal and reproductive systems; ULO2 - Evaluate and explain how changes in the normal endocrine system may lead to disease; ULO3 - Perform physiology laboratory techniques including measurements of carbohydrate metabolites, and analyse experimental data quantitatively; ULO4 - Discuss and critically analyse physiology research papers; ULO5 - Collaborate effectively in a group to complete academic tasks; ULO6 - Communicate experimental physiology data via written practical reports.

ULO1 - Describe the fundamental mechanisms underlying neuronal communication and plasticity via synaptic and non-synaptic routes. ULO2 - Recognise molecular, cellular and neural circuit components contributing to higher brain function and disease. ULO3 - Describe the neural responses to brain injury, neurodegeneration, pain and ageing. ULO4 - Describe how knowledge of the functional operation of neural circuits can be used to devise novel therapeutic approaches targeting neurological disorders. ULO5 - Critically evaluate scientific information and communicate this in an oral or poster presentation. ULO6 - Work collaboratively and cohesively as a team.

ULO1 - Differentiate the energy pathways that power skeletal muscle activity, and how exercise training leads to adaptations in skeletal muscle structure and function; ULO2 - Identify and describe the factors that influence muscle fatigue and muscle repair. ULO3 - Outline and analyse how the cardiovascular, respiratory, sensory and endocrine systems respond to exercise in normal and extreme environments; ULO4 - Use standard physiological testing procedures to evaluate human subjects for exercise capacity and performance; ULO5 - Work effectively in a team in relation to the design and completion of a research project and communicate the results to a wider audience ULO6 - Critically evaluate the scientific literature of relevance to exercise physiology and metabolism.

ULO1 - Describe the chemical, energetic and physiological attributes of the major nutrient groups and use this knowledge to explain whole body energy balance and nutrient stores; ULO2 - Explain how peripheral and central mechanisms sense food intake and match this to body mass and energy stores; ULO3 - Evaluate theories for eating and body mass disorders (and their treatment); ULO4 - Critically evaluate the scientific literature and write scientific reports and essays; ULO5 - Demonstrate scientific laboratory skills, including dissection, data analysis and graphing.

ULO1 - Describe how sensory information is signalled by neurons from peripheral receptor organs to the brain areas processing sensory input; ULO2 - Compare and contrast how neuroscience techniques help scientists understand the structure and function of the central nervous system; ULO3 - Explain how the control of actions and perceptions change according to the context of what sensory information is presented; ULO4 - Evaluate how damage to the nervous system might alter sensory functions and the associated behaviours; ULO5 - Work collaboratively to design and develop their own scientific research project; ULO6 - Critically evaluate the scientific literature, to test a hypothesis, construct a scientific report and demonstrate data analysis skills.

ULO1 - Describe the major cardiovascular diseases, including how they impact on the individual and society; ULO2 - Use specific example of cardiovascular physiology to explain how different body systems work together; ULO3 - Critically evaluate the cardiovascular research literature; ULO4 - Design and analyse a cardiovascular physiology experiment, using statistical analysis to help with the interpretation of the data; ULO5 - Present scientific data in oral and written formats.

ULO1 - Describe the structures and functions of the endocrine system in the body; ULO2 - Explain the hormonal and neuronal control of male and female reproductive function; ULO3 - Explain the consequences of abnormal reproductive physiology and the associated diseases or pathologies; ULO4 - Communicate scientific information via an oral presentation or a written report; ULO5 - Critically evaluate the scientific literature and orally present current reproductive physiology research; ULO6 - Demonstrate physiology laboratory skills, including dissection, histology, data analysis and graphing; ULO7 - Work in groups to complete experimental projects and written scientific documents.

ULO1 - Undertake a research project with regard to ethical and safety regulations; ULO2 - Demonstrate technical skills in experimental methods and the ability to collect, analyse and interpret data using methods relevant to the discipline of Physiology; ULO3 - Communicate appropriately and effectively with supervisors, laboratory staff and students; ULO4 - Maintain accurate and up-to-date records of experimental procedures, results and outcomes; ULO5 - Identify relevant published scientific literature and critically analyse and evaluate the content in the context of the discipline of Physiology; ULO6 - Construct written reports.

ULO1 - Analyse and evaluate historical aspects of psychiatry in the context of current day practice. ULO2 - Apply essential clinical practice skills of mental state examination and the psychiatric interview to a standard required for psychiatrists in training in mental health settings. ULO3 - Apply knowledge of the psychiatric interview, history taking and collateral history, phenomenology, mental state examination and use of structured instruments (e.g. MADRS, HONOS) and psychiatric risk assessment to the clinical setting. ULO4 - Use an evidence-based framework of psychodynamic concepts to conduct psychiatric interviews to probe and access underlying needs or issues. ULO5 - Critically analyse ethical principles and professionalism in psychiatry during psychiatric interviews with reference to the evidence baes, mental health law and legislations, peer review and supervision and personal reflection.? ULO6 - Apply knowledge in basic neurosciences in psychiatry (neuroanatomy, neurophysiology, neurochemistry, genetics and inheritance) to understand psychiatric disorders in clinical practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Clinical Sciences at Monash Health

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply knowledge of mental illness diagnosis, assessment and treatment to a standard required for psychiatrists in training in mental health settings ULO2 - Analyse and integrate an understanding of the biological, psychological, social and spiritual dimensions of people experiencing a mental illness ULO3 - Apply knowledge of the complex interaction between mental health, physical illness, medications, illicit substances, family and social systems impacting mental wellbeing of a person ULO4 - Critically evaluate the evidence base for treatment approaches such as psychopharmacology and psychotherapy for various psychiatric disorders
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Clinical Sciences at Monash Health

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Integrate an understanding of Mental Health Policy within an Australian and Global context, followed by an overview of the mental health system and service reforms. ULO2 - Address social aspects of psychiatry including power differential and collaborative practice, as well as responses from the community in terms of stigma and attitudes and discrimination. ULO3 - Explore the epidemiology of mental disorders in Australia with particular reference to the high prevalence disorders and the impact of psychotic illness (Survey of High Impact Psychosis - SHIP) and the measurement of disability as well as the impact of NDIS (National Disability Insurance Service) on mental health policy and practice and its impact for patients, families and carers. ULO4 - Implement cultural competency, with particular reference to the mental health needs of the indigenous people, as well as minorities and persons from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds. ULO5 - Distinguish normal from abnormal development across the life span of an individual and the mental health connotations of this. ULO6 - Evaluate various core psychological and personality theories in detail.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Clinical Sciences at Monash Health

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Appraise the history of psychosomatic medicine and theories of adaptation to illness, including the key determinants of personal, developmental, familial, and social factors in adjusting to medical illness within key theoretical frameworks, and resultant models of care across the developmental lifespan. ULO2 - Implement competent psychiatric assessment, interviewing and diagnostic investigation of the medically ill, attending to family, staff and systems issues with cultural sensitivity, professionalism, effective multidisciplinary teamwork and insight into complex ethical dimensions that exist in medical illness. ULO3 - Integrate complex understanding of the biological, psychological, social and spiritual dimensions of people with medical illness to enrich the formulation of their psychiatric disorders. ULO4 - Demonstrate an awareness of the complex interaction between mental health, physical illness and medications.? ULO5 - Examine existentially-oriented and psychotherapeutic principles of management of the patient, their family and multidisciplinary treatment team and distinguish different mental health interventions that can be applied to optimise wellbeing, foster effective communication and harness the therapeutic environment in a general hospital medical or surgical setting. ULO6 - Evaluate the evidence-base from research in the management of the medically ill and their families.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Clinical Sciences at Monash Health

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Appraise the history of child and adolescent psychiatry, including the key determinants of personal, developmental, familial, and social factors in influencing and contributing to mental health difficulties in young people within key theoretical frameworks, and resultant models of care across the developmental span between infancy to young adulthood. ULO2 - Implement competent psychiatric assessment, interviewing and diagnostic investigation of infants, children and adolescents, attending to family, school, out-of-home care and systems issues with cultural sensitivity, professionalism and insight into complex ethical dimensions that exist in child and adolescent psychiatry. ULO3 - Integrate complex understanding of the biological, psychological, social, cultural and spiritual dimensions of children and adolescents presenting with psychological distress to enrich and inform the formulation of their psychiatric disorders. ULO4 - Examine and apply developmentally appropriate and psychotherapeutic principles of management of the patient and their family. ULO5 - Distinguish different mental health interventions and the role of the multidisciplinary treatment team in child and adolescent psychiatry. ULO6 - Evaluate the evidence-base for management strategies or interventions with children, adolescents and their families presenting with mental health difficulties.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Clinical Sciences at Monash Health

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the most common mental health issues impacting individuals within the community and organisations, services, and resources that may assist recovery; ULO2 - Appreciate the biological, psychological, and social factors that influence the development of mental health issues, help-seeking behaviours, and recovery; ULO3 - Critique different approaches to mental health policy and promotion designed to assist recovery; ULO4 - Demonstrate a capacity for critical thinking in relation to topical social problems; and, ULO5 - Describe the challenges involved at interpersonal, community, and policy levels in ensuring good mental health.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain how core concepts and theories of Psychology relate to a variety of professional settings, in particular the setting to which the student is assigned ULO2 - Critically evaluate their own actions, leadership skills, and professional development since commencing their internship ULO3 - Explore how to effectively collaborate with co-workers and supervisors in a professional setting ULO4 - Communicate clearly and effectively the professional expectations of their assigned organisation, and the benefits and challenges of working in a professional environment ULO5 - Engage in peer discussion regarding appropriate conduct when dealing with core professional issues ULO6 - Exercise critical thinking and professional judgement within new workplace environments

UNIT_TITLE: Perioperative management of the cardiac patient
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Correlate the pathogenesis of coronary artery disease, cardiac failure, hypertension, valvular lesions and pulmonary hypertension with patient history and clinical examination. ULO2 - Critically appraise the perioperative management plan for a patient with pre-existing cardiovascular disease who is undergoing non-cardiac surgery. ULO3 - Use the findings from perioperative cardiac investigations to stratify a patient's perioperative cardiovascular risk. ULO4 - Perform a thorough examination of the cardiac patient and formulate a suitable/appropriate/feasible management plan. ULO5 - Organize an appropriate perioperative plan to maximize the patient's perioperative outcome. ULO6 - Work collaboratively as part of a multidisciplinary perioperative medicine team.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Diagnose and treat patients with a range of chronic medical diseases, with a focus on the perioperative period. ULO2 - Explain various ventilation strategies that assist in improving respiratory outcomes in the acute trauma patient, as well as the patient with chronic lung disease. ULO3 - Justify the rationale for using various fluids (including blood products) to maintain circulatory and nutritional support. ULO4 - Explain the pathophysiological processes that occur in a patient in the setting of acute trauma. ULO5 - Correlate the pathophysiological mechanisms in acute trauma with the patient's clinical signs and symptoms. ULO6 - Formulate a perioperative management plan for patients with complex respiratory conditions ULO7 - Critically review issues relating to retrieval of the acutely ill patient. ULO8 - With appropriate collaboration formulate a defensible/appropriate management plan for an acutely unwell perioperative patient.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the pathogenesis and pathophysiology of endocrine disorders including diabetes, obesity and sleep apnoea, and their impact on the perioperative patient ULO2 - Formulate an appropriate/effective/suitable/feasible perioperative management plan for patients with endocrine disorders and/or dysfunction ULO3 - Explain the impact of renal, hepatic and gastrointestinal dysfunction on the patient during the perioperative period ULO4 - Identify commonly used anticoagulant and antiplatelet agents, understand their pharmacology and justify their use in the perioperative period ULO5 - Justify the use of thromboprophylaxis during the perioperative period. ULO6 - Recognise the patient with acute, complex acute and chronic pain and correlate their condition to the underlying pathophysiology. ULO7 - Critically evaluate the use of commonly used analgesics and apply these to a management plan. ULO8 - Assess the relevance of the science of genomics to perioperative medicine. ULO9 - Describe the perioperative management of patients undergoing lung resection and the particular problems relating to malignancies in the mediastinum. ULO10 - Identify the key issues associated with Advanced Care Planning and develop a plan for discussing end of life care with patients and their families.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the impact of infectious diseases on the perioperative management of patients and formulate a perioperative management plan for these patients. ULO2 - Recognise the causes of high risk pregnancies and evaluate the rationale for optimum patient outcome for mother and child in these conditions. ULO3 - Explain the pathophysiology of neurological and neuromuscular disorders and formulate a management plan for the perioperative care of these patients ULO4 - Describe the changes of ageing and geriatric care on physiology and apply this knowledge to formulate a perioperative management plan which addresses these changes. ULO5 - Formulate a perioperative management plan that is appropriate for a patient with psychiatric disorders.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Outline the wide ranging, multidisciplinary nature of human factors engineering and discuss how lessons from other domains have been applied to health. ULO4 - Describe how risk perception is affected by psychological, cultural and personal experiences ULO5 - Explain the differences between safety culture and climate and why they are important in clinical settings ULO6 - Apply principles of reporting systems, accountability and organisational learning to the investigation of a failed clinical service.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the common classes of receptor and link this to an ability to define receptor agonists, antagonists, inverse agonists and allosteric modulators. In addition students will be able to cite examples of how compounds acting at receptors act as therapeutic agents; ULO2 - Describe various classes of enzymes by the reactions they catalyse and show an understanding of the kinetic properties of enzymes; ULO3 - Describe the utility of substrate analogues, transition state analogues, and irreversibly binding compounds as enzyme inhibitors. This will also be linked to an ability to understand how enzyme inhibitors act as therapeutic agents; ULO4 - Describe the role of metal ions in enzymatic processes; ULO5 - Show how ligands can recognize and modify DNA tertiary structure and link this with an ability to cite examples of how compounds acting at oligonucleotides function as therapeutics; ULO6 - Distinguish ligand-based design, structure-based design and mechanism-based design strategies; ULO7 - Understand the principles governing the generation of small molecule structure activity relationships; ULO8 - Understand approaches to peptidomimetic design; ULO9 - Acquire skills in researching information and to present the findings in a structured, logical and fluent manner; ULO10 - Be proficient in chemical laboratory techniques and communicating the results in written form.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Analyse and interpret two dimensional spectra so as to identify the chemical structures of compounds; ULO2 - Define the term Nuclear Overhauser Enhancement (NOE) and account for the observation of NOEs in one-dimensional and two-dimensional NMR spectra of both small and large molecules; ULO3 - Analyse and interpret NOE data to determine the conformation of small molecules; ULO4 - Analyse and assign two-dimensional NMR spectra of small peptides; ULO5 - Describe quantitatively the relationship between enthalpy, entropy and free energy; ULO6 - Describe quantitatively the relationship between changes in free energy and equilibrium; ULO7 - Apply the concepts of this thermodynamics module to selected examples of biochemical energetics, protein-drug binding and drug-receptor interactions; ULO8 - Describe the principal NMR-based strategies for drug discovery and design; ULO9 - Detail the factors which govern photon-initiated electronic excitation, and describe the processes by which molecules can relax. In particular, to describe the phenomena and applications associated with fluorescence; ULO10 - Apply their knowledge of biophysical techniques including NMR spectroscopy, fluorescence spectroscopy, surface plasmon resonance and calorimetry to analyse experimental data describing drugs binding to their receptors ULO11 - Measure and record data relevant to the understanding of drug structure and and drug-receptor interactions; ULO12 - Perform numerical calculations based on experimental or theoretical data; ULO13 - Present written or oral results of experimental work.

OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Faculty of Pharmacy and Pharmaceutical Sciences

OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - In this unit, we will provide a broad view of interdisciplinary studies of the neuronal basis of consciousness. Throughout the unit, we will emphasise a triangulation approach: A) conscious experience per se (phenomenology), B) clinical and experimental facts about neuronal basis of consciousness and C) theories and models of consciousness that facilitate our understanding of A and B. While the lectures range from ones own perceptual experience (e.g., vision), loss of consciousness (e.g., deep sleep), cognitive processes (e.g., attention, working memory, decision making), the triangulation approach will unify the themes across the topics. By the end of the unit, you will be equipped with critical thinking skills, which are grounded by first-hand experience (to be provided by various first-person experience demonstrations in the lectures), supplemented by evidence-based rational thoughts.?? ULO2 - Describe the main experimental methods to study the neural correlates of consciousness. ULO3 - Examine ones own conscious experience carefully and test it through various demonstrations. ? ULO4 - Critically evaluate the contribution of contemporary research findings and theories in key areas of neuroscience. ULO5 - Describe and apply a range of research tools and paradigms used within different domains of neuroscientific research and link them to their own subjective experience. ULO6 - Design a creative and empirical way to build on previous research to study a particular aspect of consciousness, based on both their own subjective experience and theories/models taught. ULO7 - Peer review the work of other students and receive constructive feedback.?? ???????
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences
