ULO3 - Apply social psychology theories to a range of contemporary social questions, including belonging, identity, attraction, aggression, conflict and negotiation. ULO4 - Critically evaluate, and explain the origins and underlying assumptions of the psychoanalytic, humanistic, cognitive, learning, trait and biological theories of personality. ULO5 - Assess social psychology and personality theories and approaches in relation to gender, ethnicity and cultural diversity. ULO6 - Review and evaluate the practical applications, experimental procedures and research directions and goals associated with the above social psychology and personality theories.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Evaluate issues underpinning the relationship between brain processes and cognition and behaviour ULO2 - Synthesise contemporary research and theoretical issues in key areas of neuroscience ULO3 - Critically analyse the range of research tools and paradigms used within different domains of neuroscientific research, including the characterisation of neurological disease ULO4 - Demonstrate skills relating to research design and analysis of neuroscientific technologies that are incorporated across the graduate psychology program.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Statistics and Data Science for Psychology
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critique psychological science research data presentation and analysis steps. ULO2 - Identify an appropriate analysis technique for different types of data to answer question in psychological science. ULO3 - Apply software tools from data science to manage and explore data. ULO4 - Analyse data using modern software tools. ULO5 - Interpret results from statistical analyses.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Ethics, legal and professional issues in psychology
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand the purpose of legislation relating to the practice of psychology and how to comply with such legislation, appreciate the role of ethics in maintaining the integrity and cohesiveness of the profession. ULO2 - Become familiar with the ethical principles to be adhered to in psychological practice. ULO3 - Understand the psychologist's responsibilities in relation to clients. ULO4 - Develop an appreciation of appropriate professional behaviour in a number of potentially complex situations. ULO5 - Develop decision making strategies to assist in the maintenance of ethical conduct.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe and discuss theoretical bases for undertaking psychological tests, and the place of psychological assessment in various settings of psychological practice. ULO2 - Select, administer, score, and interpret psychological assessments, including common psychiatric conditions, neurocognitive abilities, and personality traits. ULO3 - Integrate and summarise information obtained during psychological assessments in the form of a professional report. ULO4 - Describe and discuss limitations of psychological assessment tools and how they can be misused, and assess the ethical considerations of administering, interpreting, and reporting of test results. ULO5 - Appraise approaches to psychological intervention from the theoretical and empirical evidence bases. ULO6 - Integrate assessment and intervention knowledge and skills for behavioural changes and symptom improvements.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Psychology research project: Statistics and research design for professional psychology
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe a range of methodological and philosophical principles in research design, analysis and interpretation; ULO2 - Describe, apply and evaluate research designs and analyses used by psychologists; ULO3 - Apply scientific research principles to data in practice; ULO4 - Critique data with a view to preparation, analysis and interpretation; ULO5 - Operate SPSS to analyse data for analysis; ULO6 - Critique and record decisions made in the process of research examples distinguishing between fact and inference in sets of analyses.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Psychology Research Project: Introduction and Project Planning
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain how their own research fits into a broader psychology research context ULO2 - Produce a testable proposal for research that will contribute to the development of knowledge in a particular area of psychology ULO3 - Develop and demonstrate high level skill in sourcing, reading and synthesising relevant psychological literature into a coherent research review ULO4 - Generate coherent and testable hypotheses or research question/s that will allow a contribution to the development of knowledge in a particular area of psychology ULO5 - Produce an explanatory statement outlining the research project to research participants, and detail recruitment and data collection procedures of your project, to a standard suitable for review by the appropriate ethics committee
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Psychology research project: Methodology and data collection
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain how their own research fits into a broader research context; ULO2 - Prepare a description of the research methods that will be used to appropriately answer the research project's research questions; ULO3 - Develop and demonstrate high level skill in writing up the research methods section of a research report; ULO4 - Acquire research data that can be appropriately analysed and used as the basis for answering research questions and testing research hypotheses; ULO5 - Select and justify the selection of appropriate statistical and other analysis methods; ULO6 - Communicate the processes involved in the design, development and implementation of a research project, and reflect on individual transferable skills and characteristics relevant to professional research
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Psychology research project: results and discussion
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Select, use and interpret results from statistical tests or qualitative analytic techniques appropriate to answering research questions and testing hypotheses within the context of psychology research ULO2 - Analyse and present results from statistical tests or qualitative analytic techniques in appropriate visual and written formats ULO3 - Produce research results relevant to a particular area of psychology ULO4 - Interpret, evaluate and appraise research results and appropriately relate them to research hypotheses or research questions ULO5 - Relate research results to existing research and identify further research that needs to be conducted to advance existing knowledge in a particular area of psychology ULO6 - Explain how data analyses and interpretation, and its relationship to existing research, will be informed by the need to advance existing knowledge in a particular area of psychology
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Ethical and professional issues in psychology

OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe and discuss theoretical bases for undertaking psychological tests, and the place of psychological assessment in various settings of psychological practice; ULO2 - Select, administer, score and interpret psychological assessments, including common psychiatric conditions, neurocognitive abilities, and personality traits; ULO3 - Integrate and summarise information obtained during psychological assessments in the form of a professional report; ULO4 - Describe and discuss limitations of psychological assessment tools and how they can be misused, and assess the ethical considerations of administering, interpreting, and reporting of test results; ULO5 - Appraise approaches to psychological intervention from the theoretical and empirical evidence bases; ULO6 - Integrate assessment and intervention knowledge and skills for behavioural changes and symptom improvements.

UNIT_TITLE: Psychology in industry: Pathways to employment
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply psychological knowledge, skills, and values in occupational pursuits, and communicate this effectively and creatively; ULO2 - Demonstrate insight and synthesise knowledge of their own behaviour and mental processes, and apply effective strategies for self-management and self-improvement; ULO3 - Identify, evaluate, consolidate and build on employability skills, such as communication, teamwork, and problem-solving skills; ULO4 - Critically evaluate the value of psychological knowledge in the general context of work and life; ULO5 - Identify the breadth of opportunity students have as graduates, as well as review and plan towards the specific routes into professional psychology.

UNIT_TITLE: Perspectives in clinical and developmental neuroscience

OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Discuss current and future research directions in a range of applied areas of psychology; ULO2 - Identify and discuss how psychological evidence informs and advances societal and individual change; ULO3 - Evaluate contemporary theories and review the evidence related to contemporary applied areas of psychology; ULO4 - Identify a problem or issue, locate and review relevant literature, and propose a psychological intervention strategy that address this problem of issue; ULO5 - Articulate and communicate complex knowledge and ideas; ULO6 - Describe how research in psychology can be translated into practice.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Conduct a psychiatric clinical interview and concurrent mental status examination. ULO7 - Effectively and appropriately contribute to case discussions regarding formulation and diagnoses. ULO8 - Understand the basic concepts of psychopharmacology with particular reference to recent advances in the fields of psychiatric medication, cognitive enhancers and neuro-protective agents, and substance abuse.

UNIT_TITLE: Legal and ethical principles in clinical psychology practice and research

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Theme 1: Personal and Professional Development  Identify the issues surrounding care and treatment of the patient with stable or progressive neurological disease; Demonstrate a range of strategies that enable effective communication with clients with stable or progressive neurological disease and their caregivers; Identify and explain the life-time burden imposed on people with chronic disability and their families; Distinguish and compare the roles and responsibilities of the physiotherapist and other members of the health care team in the management of the patient with stable or progressive neurological disease.  ULO2 - Theme 2: Population, Society and Health  Discuss and compare a range of health promotion theories of change ranging from an individual to population-wide focus; Summarise the medical, behavioural and socio-environmental approaches to health promotion; Devise strategies for integrating health promotion into a selected area of health and social care practice, and across a range of settings; Design and present a community-based health promotion program that addresses selected components of a health promotion model.  ULO3 - Theme 3: Fundamental Knowledge in Health Science  Explain the neuroanatomy and neurophysiology of the neurological systems; Describe pathology and mechanisms of recovery of central and peripheral nervous system diseases; Describe the principles of intervention for neurological disorders; Identify the principles of motor skill acquisition across the lifespan.  ULO4 - Theme 4: Applied Practice  Conduct an interview and physical examination of the patient with neurological dysfunction; Identify, evaluate and demonstrate appropriate management techniques relevant to the neurological patient across the lifespan; Analyse factors contributing to abnormal function in the person with neurological impairments; Demonstrate appropriate manual handling and positioning of self and client at all times, utilising principles of risk minimisation.  ULO5 - Theme 5: Research  Demonstrate key procedural steps required to conduct a systematic review in order to answer a review question; Describe common statistical methods used to report treatment effects; Perform key aspects of data synthesis (e.g. narrative / meta-analysis) using accessible statistical software; Describe the role of clinical practice guidelines in the delivery of evidence-based physiotherapy practice and methods used for their critical appraisal.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply knowledge of normal development across the spectrum of childhood, within the context of normal variations. ULO2 - Identify paediatric conditions and red flags areas of concern which are appropriate for physiotherapy intervention and recognise the scope of a comprehensive paediatric ULO3 - Synthesise the elements of a comprehensive paediatric physiotherapy assessment for children presenting with developmental, musculoskeletal or neurological conditions. ULO4 - Conduct prioritised systematic assessments using appropriate assessment tools for different paediatric conditions across the spectrum of childhood and adolescence. ULO5 - Identify and communicate the important findings of paediatric physiotherapy assessment that warrant further assessment and / or intervention and / or referral to other practitioners, especially areas of concern red flags. ULO6 - Identify and apply appropriate evidenced based or best practise interventions to specific paediatric conditions.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Advancing skills in paediatric physiotherapy: Cerebral palsy
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe relevant embryology in regards to the timing of cerebral insults that result in a diagnosis of cerebral palsy and an understanding of common risk factors leading to the diagnosis ULO2 - Identify and select appropriate outcome measures for children with cerebral palsy across the age span using the ICF model ULO3 - Identify and describe the principles of physiotherapy management in cerebral palsy ULO4 - Describe the advantages and disadvantages of burst versus ongoing therapy prescription across childhood in cerebral palsy within a multidisciplinary framework ULO5 - Summarise the complexity in equipment prescription in cerebral palsy across the life span ULO6 - Synthesise the complexities around transition from paediatric to adult services in adolescents with cerebral palsy using a multidisciplinary framework ULO7 - Demonstrate sensitive and appropriate communication at all times when working with children, their parents/carers ULO8 - Demonstrate appropriate and professional communication with other health care professionals, both internal and external to their own health care setting.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Advancing skills in paediatric physiotherapy: Neonates and infants
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the phases of neonatal neurological and respiratory development and the features of each developmental phase. ULO2 - Apply knowledge of typical neonatal and infant development to the clinical physiotherapy management of neonates and infants. ULO3 - Define the principles of developmental care and apply these to clinical practice with the neonatal population. ULO4 - Identify and analyse standardised outcome measures appropriate for assessment of the neonatal and infant population. ULO5 - Synthesise the multiple physiotherapy strategies available to address deviations from typical development in the neonatal and infant populations. ULO6 - Describe a comprehensive musculo-skeletal physiotherapy assessment of the newborn and the infant. ULO7 - Describe the management of common musculo-skeletal disorders of infancy ULO8 - Demonstrate sensitive and appropriate communication at all times when working with children, their parents/carers and other health care professionals.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify key milestones of motor development across infancy and childhood. ULO2 - Describe key elements of motor development during infancy. + Postural control + Transitions between postures + Acquisition of upper limb dexterity ULO3 - Identify and describe key elements of the acquisition of locomotion skill. ULO4 - Identify common causes of developmental motor delay. ULO5 - Critique some commonly applied tests of infant and child motor development. ULO6 - Analyse the key elements of family-centred practice. ULO7 - Describe key members of a multidisciplinary paediatric team and their roles. ULO8 - Formulate a treatment approach to facilitate motor skill acquisition in a child with developmental delay.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Advancing skills in paediatric physiotherapy: Complex and chronic conditions
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the aetiology and pathophysiology of progressive neuromuscular disorders, acquired brain injury, chronic pain and chronic fatigue syndrome in the paediatric population ULO2 - Critically analyse the key elements of physiotherapy assessment for chronic and complex conditions in the paediatric population. ULO3 - Identify and analyse standardised outcome measures appropriate for use in chronic and complex conditions in the paediatric population. ULO4 - Critically analyse the key elements of physiotherapy treatment for chronic and complex conditions in the paediatric population. ULO5 - Synthesise the evidence underpinning physiotherapy treatment selection for chronic and complex conditions in the paediatric population.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Advanced physiotherapy clinical skills and project
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify key performance characteristics of an advanced practice physiotherapist ULO2 - Interpret and relate theories supporting the physiotherapy management of relevant conditions. ULO3 - Critically evaluate the evidence underpinning relevant physiotherapy practice, including identification of levels of evidence, systematic and narrative reviews ULO4 - Demonstrate knowledge of multidisciplinary management in the context of client and/or family centred practice ULO5 - Formulate and answer a clinical question exploring an issue in advanced physiotherapy practice ULO6 - Develop and evaluate an intervention to address an issue in advanced physiotherapy practice ULO7 - Contribute and guide verbal and written discussion of individualised patient issues, with an advanced level of clinical reasoning ULO8 - Communicate effectively and supportively with the multidisciplinary team, patient and family/carers, both written and verbally
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify the key elements of the Australian health care system and the roles and responsibilities of the health care team; ULO2 - Articulate the attributes that define a profession and the conduct of professionalism ULO3 - Review and critique personal and community determinants of health, and develop, implement and evaluate a program of personal health enhancement; ULO4 - Compare and contrast a range of health promotion theories of change ranging from an individual to population-wide focus; ULO5 - Critique diverse definitions, concepts and interpretations of health and wellbeing, and how they apply to oneself and physiotherapy; ULO6 - Describe ATSI key concepts of health and wellbeing and the influence of culture, family and connection to country in health practice; ULO7 - Explain the biopsychosocial model and its relevance to pain, language, ones response to pain, and the impact of pain on ones life; ULO8 - Apply the principles of exercise programming and prescription to client needs; ULO9 - Apply knowledge of anatomy, physiology, biomechanics and kinesiology to the musculoskeletal system; ULO10 - Describe Evidence Based Practice in physiotherapy in the context of integrating the best research evidence with clinical expertise and the client's unique values and circumstances; ULO11 - Describe levels of research evidence, methods of study design and sources of bias in research and design electronic database searches to identify the best evidence.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Implement strategies to identify risk to self and others of physiotherapy practice ULO2 - Apply legal and ethical concepts to healthcare practice, clinical research and personal learning experiences; ULO3 - Demonstrate reflection and self-evaluation in order to support the development of communication and professional practice; ULO4 - Apply contemporary learning theories to self and others; ULO5 - Demonstrate a range of strategies to enable effective communication with clients in a simulated environment; ULO6 - Apply knowledge of anatomy, biomechanics, kinesiology and pathophysiology to musculoskeletal assessment and management; ULO7 - Describe the pathophysiology of the peripheral nervous system; ULO8 - Design and conduct a physical assessment of the musculoskeletal system, including determination of a clients short and long-term goals and medico-legal documentation of findings; ULO9 - Apply fundamental knowledge of health sciences to determine and perform appropriate musculoskeletal physiotherapy management, including monitoring its effectiveness and utilising re-assessment findings to inform practice; ULO10 - Apply knowledge of basic science of pain to client-centred assessment and management of pain; ULO11 - Demonstrate appropriate manual handling and positioning of self and client at all times, utilising principles of risk minimisation; ULO12 - Describe the reliability and validity of musculoskeletal assessment tools and methods
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Implement a range of strategies that enable effective communication with clients with stable or progressive neurological disease and their caregivers; ULO2 - Distinguish and compare the roles and responsibilities of the physiotherapist and other members of the health care team in the management of the client with stable or progressive neurological disease; ULO3 - Identify the policy and related funding issues surrounding care and treatment of the client with stable or progressive neurological disease; ULO4 - Apply anatomical knowledge to the function of the neurological system; ULO5 - Identify the principles of motor skill acquisition across the lifespan; ULO6 - Describe a range of pathophysiological disorders and mechanisms of recovery of neurological system and relate these to physiotherapy management; ULO7 - Analyse factors contributing to abnormal function in the person with neurological impairments; ULO8 - Design and conduct an appropriate, timely assessment of the neurological system, including determination of clients short and long-term goals and medico-legal documentation of findings; ULO9 - Apply knowledge of health sciences to determine and perform appropriate neurological physiotherapy management across the lifespan, including monitoring its effectiveness, discharge planning and utilising re-assessment findings to inform practice; ULO10 - Demonstrate appropriate, safe and effective manual handling and positioning of self and client at all times, utilising principles of risk minimisation; ULO11 - Explain evidence based physiotherapy interventions relevant to the management of the neurological client; ULO12 - Critically appraise clinical research using appropriate quality appraisal tools;
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Implement a range of strategies that enable effective communication with clients with cardiorespiratory disease and their caregivers; ULO2 - Communicate appropriate information to other health professionals involved in providing client care to optimize interprofessional management, including medical and surgical, behavioural and psychological, or pharmacological approaches; ULO3 - Identify the issues surrounding care and treatment of the client with acute or chronic cardiorespiratory conditions; ULO4 - Describe the anatomy of the cardiorespiratory system; ULO5 - Design and conduct a physiotherapy assessment of the cardiorespiratory system including determination of a clients short and long-term goals and medico-legal documentation of findings; ULO6 - Apply evidence based clinical reasoning to devise a client-centred problem list; ULO7 - Describe the pathophysiology of injury and disease of the cardiorespiratory system and relate this to physiotherapy management; ULO8 - Determine and perform appropriate cardiorespiratory physiotherapy management across the lifespan, including monitoring its effectiveness, discharge planning and utilising re-assessment findings to inform practice; ULO9 - Explain the principles of pharmacological management of cardiorespiratory disorders; ULO10 - Demonstrate appropriate manual handling and positioning of self and client at all times, utilising principles of risk minimisation; ULO11 - Explain evidence based physiotherapy interventions relevant to the management of the cardiorespiratory client; ULO12 - Calculate and interpret statistics to support clinical decision making in physiotherapy interventions;
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the role of the Australian Council on Healthcare Standards on safety and quality in health; ULO2 - Define and explain pain to others as a complex, multidimensional experience; ULO3 - Communicate appropriate information to other health professionals involved in providing client care to optimize interprofessional management, including medical and surgical, behavioural and psychological, or pharmacological approaches; ULO4 - Analyse strategies for successful management of stress and fatigue on physical and mental health; ULO5 - Compare the belief structures behind mainstream and complementary therapies, and their efficacy in therapy; ULO6 - Describe how ethnicity and culture influence health, healthcare and illness; ULO7 - Recognise common presentations of family violence in healthcare and describe best practice for management if encountered by a physiotherapist; ULO8 - Synthesise the pathophysiology of injury and disease from multiple systems and integrate knowledge into physiotherapy assessment and management; ULO9 - Apply knowledge of the anatomy and physiology of the endocrine, renal, reproductive and vestibular systems and their common pathologies to physiotherapy management and client care; ULO10 - Apply physiotherapy management in specialised areas of practice, including clients presenting with complaints relating to oncology, womens health, amputees, chronic pain, vestibular, falls, dementia and complex musculoskeletal conditions; ULO11 - Utilise data from imaging or investigation results to inform clinical reasoning; and ULO12 - Complete systematic review tasks in accordance with recommended methods such as those outlined in the Cochrane handbook

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate professional behaviour in client care and rights that is culturally sensitive and in accordance with legal requirements; ULO2 - Communicate appropriately and effectively across written and verbal mediums, with clients, staff, and other health care stakeholders; ULO3 - Reflect critically on practice and propose knowledge and skill gaps and methods for ongoing learning; ULO4 - Seek, reflect on and respond appropriately to feedback from others in the practice context; ULO5 - Tailor knowledge and skills to effectively assess client needs, including selection of relevant measures of health indicators and outcomes; ULO6 - Analyse and plan appropriate patient interactions, including patient-centred goal development, and the selection of appropriate interventions; ULO7 - Critically analyse risks and adverse events associated with client assessments and interventions; ULO8 - Describe and analyse a client's transition to a new context, referral for further physiotherapy and linkage to relevant clinical and non-clinical support services ULO9 - Identify, critically appraise and apply evidence-based practice to client care in physiotherapy; ULO10 - Analyse the ethical principles of conducting clinical-based physiotherapy research; ULO11 - Describe the steps required for an audit and design a survey for a research question; ULO12 - Describe purpose and main methods of qualitative research methods and their use within physiotherapy research

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate professional behaviour in client care and rights that is culturally sensitive and in accordance with legal requirements; ULO2 - Communicate appropriately and effectively across written and verbal mediums, with clients, staff, and other health care stakeholders; ULO3 - Reflect critically on practice and propose knowledge and skill gaps and methods to achieve them; ULO4 - Analyse the role of feedback in learning; ULO5 - Synthesise the input of other professions and the patient/ client/family to reach a shared vision of care plans; ULO6 - Describe and analyse the pharmacological management of common clinical cases; ULO7 - Tailor knowledge and skills to effectively assess client needs, including selection of relevant measures of health indicators and outcomes; ULO8 - Analyse and plan appropriate patient interactions, including patient-centred goal development, and the selection of appropriate interventions; ULO9 - Critically analyse risks and adverse events associated with client assessments and interventions; ULO10 - Identify, critically appraise and apply evidence-based practice to client care; ULO11 - Appraise clinical practice guidelines used in physiotherapy practice.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Evaluate, using a detailed knowledge of the statutory regulations governing the use of ionising radiation, and describe how regulatory agencies demand the safe use of medical imaging ionising radiation equipment; ULO2 - Discuss the response of organ systems to ionising radiation exposure, how x-radiation is monitored and measured and how personal monitoring is used, recorded and reported to enable safe practices in radiation areas for patient, staff and the general public; ULO3 - Calculate the energy content of an x-ray beam, integral dose, dose-area product and define dose and equivalent dose when x-rays are absorbed by living tissue, using correct units; ULO4 - Employ the principles learnt about kV, mAs and geometry of the x-ray beam that impact upon the four image quality factors of optical density, contrast, image detail and distortion to describe the characteristics of a radiograph; ULO5 - Review the theoretical principles underpinning the operation of automatic exposure systems and computed radiography systems, and where appropriate apply this in the clinical setting; ULO6 - Record and obtain information from individuals employing appropriate observation and interviewing skills, such that the information generated may be integrated with basic scientific theory and knowledge to provide quality levels of patient care; ULO7 - Recognise and adapt, in a professional manner, to the variety of social, cultural and ethical perspectives that may be encountered within clinical practice. ULO8 - Describe and justify the radiographic projections, body positions and the radiographic technique underpinning general radiographic examinations of the of the respiratory system, shoulder and pelvic girdles, the vertebral column, the bony thorax and plain abdomen; ULO9 - Position an adult patient, accounting for his/her clinical presentation, for the radiographic projections identified in the protocol, direct and align the central ray to an appropriate bony landmark, image receptor and ancillary equipment such as the bucky, grids and automatic exposure devices; ULO10 - Evaluate radiographs in terms of technical quality and positioning criteria and where necessary devise appropriate problem-solving strategies for less than optimal radiographic projections; ULO11 - Distinguish radiographic anatomical features and recognise associated common radiologic pathologies or traumatic appearances in terms of the clinical question being asked; ULO12 - In the light of the clinical problem, assess the appropriateness of supplementary projections, and where required position the patient for the required further images; ULO13 - Under supervision, safely conduct radiographic examinations of the respiratory system, pelvis, shoulder girdle, vertebral column, the bony thorax and plain abdomen of an adult patient.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the physical properties of atomic structure ULO2 - Discuss the fundamental principles of mechanics, electromagnetism and thermal physics relevant to the production and absorption of energy ULO3 - Explain the physical laws of interaction of particles and waves, including the mechanisms for absorption and scattering of energy at the atomic level ULO4 - Explain in quantitative terms the production of x-rays and the use of exposure factors that control x-ray intensity, penetration and dose ULO5 - Use quantitative measures for the absorption of x-rays and discuss why and how x-ray absorption coefficients vary with energy and atomic number and relate these ideas to the sharp depiction of contrast changes in x-ray images of patients; ULO6 - Explain the effects of ionizing radiation on cellular matter and the basic principles underlying radiation dose and radiation safety
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply the laws of physics, units of measurement and dimensions to solve numerical problems relating to radiation science. ULO2 - Describe how the interaction of x-rays, gamma rays, sound waves and magnetic fields with matter creates a detectable signal that can be captured to form a diagnostic image. ULO3 - Explain the design and image formation of imaging modality instrumentation including radiography, CT, Nuclear Medicine, PET, MRI and Ultrasound modalities. ULO4 - Discuss the safety considerations relating to imaging modality instrumentation and options for managing patient dose. ULO5 - Reflect on the applications of imaging in the radiation therapy field.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Connect how the biochemistry of molecules are integral in cellular functions ULO2 - Describe the physiological processes of cells, in particular membrane transport and genetic inheritance and group cells into 4 tissue types ULO3 - Relate anatomical terminology and osteology to the appendicular skeleton ULO4 - Discuss the soft tissues and bony structures that comprise the upper limb and how these structures enable the upper limb to function ULO5 - Discuss the soft tissues and bony structures that comprise the lower limb and how these structures enable the lower limb to function ULO6 - Recognise and describe the radiographic appearances of the upper and lower limbs and apply this knowledge to radiographic positioning for the upper and lower limbs
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe and apply within a professional standards and ethics context theories of the psychosocial impact on human behaviour, communication and occupational health and safety of the working environment; ULO2 - Record and obtain information from individuals employing appropriate observation and interviewing skills, such that the information generated may be integrated with basic scientific theory and knowledge to provide quality levels of patient care; ULO3 - Recognise and adapt, in a professional manner, to the variety of social, cultural and ethical perspectives that may legitimately be encountered within clinical practice; ULO4 - Describe and justify the radiographic projections, body positions and the radiographic exposure factors underpinning general radiographic examinations of the elbow, forearm, wrist, hand, fingers and thumb, knee, tibia and fibula, ankle, calcaneum, foot, toes and chest of an adult ambulant patient; ULO5 - Evaluate the radiographic request form, obtain a clinical history from a patient, select appropriate radiographic protocols consisting of radiographic projections positioning techniques and exposure factors to produce high quality projection(s) that will aid the diagnostic process; ULO6 - Evaluate radiographs in terms of technical quality and positioning criteria and where necessary devise appropriate problem-solving strategies for less than optimal radiographic projections; ULO7 - Distinguish anatomical features on radiographic images and recognise common radiologic pathologies or traumatic appearances in terms of the clinical question being asked; ULO8 - In the light of the clinical problem, assess the appropriateness of supplementary projections, and where required position the patient for the required further images; ULO9 - Under supervision safely conduct radiographic examinations of the elbow, forearm, wrist, hand, fingers and thumb, knee, tibia and fibula, ankle, calcaneum, foot, toes and chest of an adult ambulant patient; ULO10 - Position an adult patient, accounting for his/her clinical presentation, for the radiographic projections identified in the protocol, direct and align the central ray to an appropriate bony landmark and image receptor.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe fundamental mathematics and physics concepts relevant to medical radiation physics, focussing on mechanics, waves and particles, thermal physics, electricity, magnetism and electromagnetism ULO2 - Explain the principles and properties of atomic structure, radioactivity, the processes of radiation interactions with matter and the production, absorption and scattering of energy ULO3 - Describe the instrumentation used for the production of x-rays including the Diagnostic X-ray Tube and the Medical Linear Accelerator ULO4 - Discuss the principles of radiation detection and dosimetry relevant to medical radiation physics ULO5 - Describe the effects of ionising radiation on cellular matter and examine the principles of radiation safety and radiation protection that apply to the use of medical radiations ULO6 - Communicate and analyse laboratory findings with demonstrated conceptual learning and quantitative analysis
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify fundamental principles of pathology and apply this knowledge to specific cases, in particular the musculoskeletal and respiratory systems; ULO2 - Evaluate the effect of environment and nutrition on the health of an individual or community; ULO3 - Describe the anatomy of the vertebral column, spinal cord and thoracic cage and thoracic contents; ULO4 - Identify normal and abnormal anatomy on radiographic images of the vertebral column & thorax abdomen and musculoskeletal system ULO5 - Describe the basic physiology of respiration and the nervous system; ULO6 - List major stages that occur in embryology and extrapolate how congenital abnormalities can occur
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 -  Describe the general characteristics of the modern X-ray system used in clinical practice, including scientific principles, and production of the digital image.  ULO2 -  Identify the key features of the use of radiation, how it produces the image, and its safe use in diagnostic radiographic practice.  ULO3 - Employ radiographic positioning skills and protocols to produce images of a representative section of the axial skeleton and musculoskeletal system. ULO4 - Describe radiographic positioning skills and protocols to produce images of the thorax, abdomen and pelvis. ULO5 - Distinguish the anatomical features and recognise associated common radiographic pathologies of the axial skeleton and musculoskeletal system, the thorax, abdomen and pelvis.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Differentiate between the bony and soft tissue elements and joints which comprise the upper and lower limbs on digital planar radiographic and computed tomography images. ULO2 - Name and identify the anatomical and soft tissue structures represented on digital planar radiographic images ULO3 - Describe and differentiate the basic computed tomography radiographic representation of the primary organs comprising cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, urinary, & reproductive systems both with and without contrast enhancement ULO4 - Describe and differentiate the magnetic resonance radiographic representation of commonly performed MRI regions: magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP), brain & spine. ULO5 - Name and identify the primary anatomical structures of the head, neck and spine as represented on computed tomography images. ULO6 - Discriminate between the osseous, soft tissue components and primary muscles of the shoulder, hip, knee & spine on MR images.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe basic principles of radiation protection with regard to the use of unsealed sources justifying the need for a regulatory framework governing their use ULO2 - Explain the characteristics of radiopharmaceuticals used diagnostic imaging and for therapeutic purposes; ULO3 - Describe and explain physical principles and instrumentation used in nuclear medicine in the context of image acquisition, quality control and radiopharmaceutical administration techniques ULO4 - Evaluate the usefulness of nuclear medicine procedures/techniques in the context of specific patient diagnoses and communicate these findings to their peers ULO5 - Identify patient contra-indications to nuclear medicine procedures ULO6 - Describe hybrid imaging and discuss its application and advantages in medical radiation practice
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Discuss basic principles of pathology including cell response to stress, inflammation, infection neoplasia and multifocal disease as well as environmental and nutritional influences ULO2 - Describe important stages in embryonic development and correlate how disruptions in these processes can result in congenital abnormalities ULO3 - Apply principles of pathophysiology to the disease processes that occur in the musculo-skeletal system ULO4 - Apply principles of pathophysiology to the disease processes that occur in the respiratory system ULO5 - Identify pathologies of the musculo-skeletal and respiratory systems on a range of medical images
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe psychological theory relating to human development and learning, behaviour and personality ULO2 - Discuss socio-cultural issues related to health care delivery focussing on patients attending the radiology, radiation therapy and nuclear medicine departments. ULO3 - Identify issues and strategies for diagnosing, treating and preventing disease and illness in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander clients ULO4 - Develop practical skills required for implementing equity in healthcare ULO5 - Evaluate the barriers and enablers of effective patient and family centred and Inter-disciplinary collaborative care
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Relate knowledge of the normal gross and regional anatomy of the haematological, respiratory, cardiovascular, endocrine, reproductive, renal and gastrointestinal tract systems to understanding the impact of disease processes affecting these systems. ULO2 - Describe the key histological features of the haematological, respiratory, cardiovascular, endocrine, reproductive, renal and gastrointestinal tract systems. ULO3 - Apply knowledge of the principles of pathophysiology to the disease processes within the haematological, central nervous, cardiovascular, endocrine, reproductive, renal and gastrointestinal tract systems. ULO4 - Identify the radiographic representation of disease processes associated with the haematological, central nervous, cardiovascular, endocrine, reproductive, renal and gastrointestinal tract systems. ULO5 - Describe how pathological imaging is used in the radiation therapy context
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the legal and ethical concepts related to health care practice, including professional regulation of medical radiation practitioners ULO2 - Describe occupational health and safety (and radiation safety) considerations in the context of the medical radiation practice professions and clinical environment ULO3 - Describe and apply communication theory, cultural competence and reflective practice theory ULO4 - Evaluate the challenges associated with managing patients with a range of different needs including the elderly, children, patients with physical disability or mental impairment. ULO5 - Analyse and reflect on inter-professional practice in the context of the medical radiation practice professions ULO6 - Discuss the specific health needs and barriers for vulnerable patient populations
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain and apply the scientific principles, technological characteristics and relevant applications of digital imaging systems; ULO2 - Explain the general applications of information technology in medical imaging and its relationship to digital based imaging systems; ULO3 - Implement a range of basic digital image processing routines in general or digital vascular imaging and discuss how the application of these tools enables quantitative and qualitative image analysis; ULO4 - Implement and evaluate quality assurance principles in digital imaging systems; ULO5 - Discuss the use of radiological and other medications and their administration, the control of infection, the maintenance of surgical asepsis and monitoring of vital signs; ULO6 - Apply radiographic criteria and a problem-solving perspective to angiography; ULO7 - Develop, modify and adapt radiographic skills required to perform angiography; ULO8 - Critically apply ethical concepts, and knowledge of the Australian medico- legal framework to the practice of radiography; ULO9 - Apply evidence-based practice (EBP) to radiographic practice and identify how a range of research methods and the critique of reported research benefits medical radiation sciences; ULO10 - Critically evaluate the ethical and legal implications of research within medical radiation science; ULO11 - Identify personal learning goals in respect to the development of professional expertise and demonstrate an understanding of the multidisciplinary approach to the clinical management of patients in the intensive care units and accident and emergency situations; ULO12 - Modify and adapt basic radiographic methods, techniques and protection strategies for adult, elderly and paediatric patients undergoing radiographic examinations.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the physical principles underpinning mobile x-ray systems and apply them in clinical situations to produce and evaluate imaging; ULO2 - Explain the physical principles underpinning digital fluoroscopic imaging systems and the physics of fluid flow, image intensifiers and planar conventional tomography and apply them in clinical situations to produce and evaluate images of the vascular, gastrointestinal, genito-urinary and hepatobiliary systems; ULO3 - Implement and evaluate appropriate quality control measures in relation to mobile x-ray systems and digital fluoroscopic imaging systems; ULO4 - Implement and evaluate appropriate radiation safety strategies and radiation protection measures in the context of mobile and fluoroscopic examinations; ULO5 - Evaluate the effectiveness of exposure protocols for all general and contrast radiographic imaging in terms of image quality and radiation protection for patients; ULO6 - Develop radiographic skills required for imaging of vascular, gastrointestinal, genito-urinary and hepato-biliary systems and head; ULO7 - Distinguish between normal abnormal radiographic images of these body regions; ULO8 - Develop, modify and adapt radiographic skills required and techniques for paediatric and adult patients, particularly in emergency and mobile examinations; ULO9 - Evaluate imaging of the gastrointestinal, genito-urinary and hepatobiliary systems in terms of the patient presentation the anatomy and image quality; ULO10 - Appraise the professional challenges posed by patients with special needs to provide effective and safe care to them while they undergo imaging examinations.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the anatomy & physiology of the haematological, respiratory, cardiovascular, respiratory, endocrine, reproductive, urinary and gastrointestinal systems and the significance for medical imaging examinations ULO2 - Discuss pathological processes associated with haematological, respiratory, cardiovascular, respiratory, endocrine, reproductive, urinary and gastrointestinal systems ULO3 - Demonstrate an understanding of the fundamental concepts of pharmacology, pharmacokinetics and toxicology; ULO4 - Explain the general principles, risks, classification, structure and properties of radiographic contrast media; ULO5 - Describe the prevention, treatment and support for contrast media reactions; and the characteristics of other drugs used in the clinical setting, general and local anaesthesia and their implications for patient care during diagnostic imaging examinations; ULO6 - Identify and describe the radiographic representation of the organs comprising cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, urinary, endocrine, reproductive systems; ULO7 - Identify and describe the radiographic appearances of pathologies affecting the cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, urinary, endocrine and reproductive systems; ULO8 - Identify and describe the angiographic representation of normal anatomy
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the basic components, structure and function of the central nervous system including the special senses; ULO2 - Describe the anatomy of the skull, brain and associated structures; ULO3 - Describe important pathological processes affecting the central nervous system including the special senses; ULO4 - Distinguish between normal and abnormal pathophysiological processes affecting the central nervous system and its blood supply as they appear on CT, MR and DSA images; ULO5 - Name and identify the anatomy of the skull and central nervous system as seen on sectional computed tomography and magnetic resonance images; ULO6 - Compare and contrast the CT, MR and DSA appearances of the vascular supply of the head and neck; ULO7 - Discriminate between the osseous and soft tissue components, important muscles and blood vessels of the chest, abdomen, pelvis, spine, and limbs on CT and MR images.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Medical imaging science: Computed tomography and digital image processing
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the scientific principles underpinning modern multi-slice computed tomographic scanners; ULO2 - Articulate the technological characteristics and the relevant applications of multi-slice computed tomography medical imaging systems; ULO3 - Apply a range of radiation protection measures applicable to CT in simulated situations; ULO4 - Critically evaluate basic clinical scanning protocols, digital image processing techniques and equipment, image display and reconstruction routines used in CT ULO5 - Describe and interpret positioning and methods employed in CT examinations of the head, chest, abdomen/pelvis, and spine. ULO6 - Identify the key anatomical and pathological appearances in CT images of the head, chest, abdomen/pelvis and spine.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply principles of evidence-based health care practice to MRI imaging in the clinical context ULO2 - Explain the role played by the practitioner/researcher in the application of safety principles within the MRI suite. ULO3 - Describe a range of indications, participant presentations, participant preparation and positioning methods for MRI studies of the brain. ULO4 - Select the appropriate MRI protocol and post processing techniques for MRI studies of the brain structure and function from within an evidence-based framework. ULO5 - Use brain images to apply analytical theory and methods supporting the investigation of brain structure and function. ULO6 - Apply the principles of quality assurance and quality control to MRI imaging in the context of neuroimaging research.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Perform and evaluate correct patient preparation and sonographic imaging methods employed in examinations of the upper abdomen. ULO2 - Identify and interpret normal structures, function and common pathological appearances in abdominal ultrasound images. ULO3 - Evaluate the function, application and potential pitfalls of ultrasound instrumentation used in abdominal ultrasound scanning. ULO4 - Analyse clinical best practice with respect to the safe operation of MRI imaging systems and patient preparation with respect to MRI. ULO5 - Justify the appropriate introductory MRI imaging sequences for given clinical indications across key body areas. ULO6 - Appraise advanced radiographic techniques and radiation protection strategies in professional practice. ULO7 - Analyse the biological effects of ultrasound and ionising radiation, radio-sensitivity of specific organ systems and describe the relevant theories of radiation damage and repair mechanisms. ULO8 - Evaluate data collection methodologies, perform basic statistical analyses, report on accuracy and precision of outcomes using p-value, t-tests, Pearson correlations and other appropriate quantifiers. ULO9 - Evaluate advances in instrumentation, quality assurance techniques, relevant protocols and methods employed in breast imaging including medical ultrasound. ULO10 - Apply the concepts of Monte-Carlo calculations, depth-dose curves, interaction cross-sections, tissue conversion tables and beam quality parameterisations to perform numerical dose calculations for a variety of radiographic imaging protocols. ULO11 - Evaluate mammographic technique and the psycho-social elements of breast imaging. Correlate each of these elements to comprehend best practice mammography. ULO12 - Identify personal learning goals with patient-focussed clinical decision making in general radiography including contrast, trauma, fluoroscopic, paediatric and mobile imaging with various patients, encompassing the broader healthcare team. ULO13 - Perform general radiographic examinations of adult patients at the level of competent student radiographer. ULO14 - Perform general radiographic examinations of paediatric and complex adult patients at the level of advanced beginner student radiographer.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the scientific principles underpinning computed tomography; ULO2 - Describe and represent the physical configuration of axial, helical and multislice CT systems; ULO3 - Explain and distinguish between the various data acquisition and image reconstruction processes used in CT and their characteristics; ULO4 - Identify common CT artefacts, explain their cause and suggest methods to correct for them; ULO5 - Apply radiation protection and dosimetry principles to the practice of CT; ULO6 - Describe the principles underpinning advanced digital image processing, image distribution, data transfer and storage options used in medical imaging (including the DICOM standard and PACS and RIS infrastructure). ULO7 - Explain the clinical rationale for the selection of CT scanning protocols, image display and reconstruction methods for CT examinations of the head, chest, abdomen and spine; ULO8 - Implement and evaluate positioning methods, scanning protocols, image display and reconstruction routines for CT examinations of the head, chest, abdomen and spine; ULO9 - Identify the CT appearances of the anatomical structures comprising the head, chest, abdomen and spine and distinguish between normal and abnormal structures as shown on CT; ULO10 - Distinguish between normal and abnormal anatomical and pathological structures as shown on CT images displayed in a variety of relevant formats including MPRs, MIPs, SSDs and volume renderings. ULO11 - Reach the level of competent student radiographer in general radiography including contrast, trauma, paediatric and mobile imaging; ULO12 - Apply evidence based inquiry principles developed in second year to an advanced radiographic practice clinical issue. ULO13 - Apply radiographic techniques and radiation protection strategies within an ethical and appropriate medico-legal framework in professional practice. ULO14 - Perform a range of CT scans at the level of Advanced Beginner.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the function, application and potential pitfalls of ultrasound instrumentation used in abdominal ultrasound scanning, including B- mode, spectral Doppler and imaging artefacts. ULO2 - Discuss the likely bio-effects and bio-hazards of diagnostic ultrasound. ULO3 - Describe patient preparation and sonographic imaging methods employed in ultrasound examinations of the upper abdomen. ULO4 - Recognise and describe normal structures, function and common pathological appearances of abdominal structures in ultrasound images. ULO5 - Demonstrate the integration of theoretical knowledge of anatomy, physiology and ultrasound instrumentation in abdominal ultrasound scanning to a beginner sonographer level.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Present a comprehensive and critical description of the complementary nature of MRI relative to other imaging modalities ULO2 - Enumerate and be able to justify the physical design and operational requirements for a typical clinical MRI system ULO3 - Understand and explain the imaging parameters that define the contrast sensitivity in MRI ULO4 - Understand and explain the imaging parameters that define the SNR and spatial resolution of MRI ULO5 - Reconcile through a critical evaluation the advantages and disadvantages of gradient and spin echo recovery techniques ULO6 - List in detail and justify the reasons for precautions that are taken in MRI to assure staff and patient safety ULO7 - Explain use and development of the broader applications of MRI, including spectroscopic, dynamic and functional imaging ULO8 - Use problem solving skills to define appropriate strategies to meet the needs of clinical imaging through MRI techniques, and to recognize deficiencies in images, such as reconstruction artifacts, and be able to identify the cause of such problems.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Radiography and medical imaging work experience
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate competency as a radiography student across the domains of practice and be able to assume an independent role as a radiographer and modelling professionalism within the role. ULO2 - Synergise image appearances and health assessments using appropriate terminology and critically evaluate medical images with reference to the clinical presentation; ULO3 - Implement multislice CT imaging methods and protocols and related interventional procedures (CT and DSA) including dose reduction strategies in a problem-solving capacity across a diverse range of clinical settings and patients; ULO4 - Conduct pre-scanning screening of MRI patients and provide clear instructions of the procedure prior to performing MRI scans to the beginner stage of professional development, whilst being cognisant of safety issues including the use of contrast agents; ULO5 - Critically reflect upon advanced radiographic practice and identify on-going professional development needs especially in relation to CT and MRI scanning, and advanced radiographic patient management.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Present a comprehensive and critical description of the scientific research process; ULO2 - Present a comprehensive and critical evaluation of the scientific literature; ULO3 - Critically differentiate between a qualitative research design and a quantitative experimental design and justify the application of quantitative or qualitative research methodology within clinical medical imaging; ULO4 - Create a literature review based on a selected topic within medical imaging which reflects a critical awareness of the current ideas and methods of practice; ULO5 - Create a detailed research proposal based on a selected research topic within medical imaging which reflects a critical awareness of sound scientific approach including ethical responsibilities; ULO6 - Demonstrate a critical awareness of the moral, ethical and legal responsibilities of scientific investigation and research conduct; ULO7 - Describe the physical, psychological, social and economic ethical issues as well as solutions to ethical issues associated with a research scenario; ULO8 - Demonstrate ability to integrate research findings into the current evidence base practice related to medical imaging; ULO9 - Collect and enter data related to the research project; ULO10 - Carry out appropriate statistical analyses using appropriate software; ULO11 - Synthesise the findings of the collection and analysis phase of the project through the development of a written piece of scientific writing in the format of a peer reviewed journal article; ULO12 - Communicate the findings of the research project via a peer-reviewed oral presentation;
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically review the scientific research process in light of an understanding of the moral, ethical and legal responsibilities; ULO2 - Critically differentiate between a qualitative and quantitative research design and justify their application within clinical medical imaging; ULO3 - Describe the physical, psychological, social and economic ethical issues as well as solutions to ethical issues associated with a research scenario; ULO4 - Search the scientific literature to obtain related information, and critically review and communicate this literature; ULO5 - Review the literature based on a selected topic within medical imaging which reflects a critical awareness of the current ideas and methods of practice; ULO6 - Critically analyse the role of research in radiography, reflecting on experiences in clinical practice; ULO7 - Communicate the findings of the literature review via a peer-reviewed oral presentation; ULO8 - Describe and explain the philosophical and scientific concepts associated with the medical imaging topic chosen for in-depth study; ULO9 - Critically review the range of advanced procedural and or practical approaches which can be utilised in the clinical setting within the medical imaging topic chosen for in-depth study; ULO10 - Describe relevant professional and occupational health and safety standards which are associated with the medical imaging topic chosen for in-depth study; ULO11 - Analyse current and future trends associated with the medical imaging topic chosen for in-depth study; ULO12 - Critically discuss principles of quality assurance and imaging artefacts associated with the medical imaging topic chosen for in-depth study; ULO13 - Explain the advanced physical principles associated with the medical imaging topic chosen for in-depth study including PET/CT hybridisation; ULO14 - Describe appropriate imaging sequences and post-processing reconstruction associated with the medical imaging topic chosen for in-depth study; ULO15 - Explain the importance of CT imaging in the diagnosis of human disease and injury associated with the CT imaging topic chosen for in-depth study; ULO16 - Evaluate CT diagnostic images to recognise and describe relevant anatomy and pathophysiology to include a variety of body areas associated with the CT imaging topic chosen for in-depth study; ULO17 - Identify relevant anatomy and pathophysiology contributing to cardio-vascular disease associated with the MRI imaging topic chosen for in-depth study; ULO18 - Critique the Doppler modes (spectral, colour and power) used in diagnostic ultrasound to image vascular flow associated with the Ultrasound imaging topic chosen for in-depth study; ULO19 - Analyse the advances in harmonic imaging, the use of ultrasonic contrast agents and identify future trends in transducer technologies, associated with the Ultrasound imaging topic chosen for in-depth study.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply the principles of evidence-based health care practice to the delivery of MSCT and MRI imaging in the clinical context. ULO2 - Evaluate CT and MRI clinical images to recognise and describe the appearance of anatomical structures displayed in cross sectional imaging and identify abnormal appearances and common pathologies to include a variety of body areas. ULO3 - Accurately implement the principles of quality assurance measures and quality control relevant to MSCT and MRI imaging and artefacts. ULO4 - Comprehensively describe MSCT Methods and protocols and related interventional, vascular and cardiac procedures. ULO5 - Determine the radiation dose for a CT examination and how best to optimise it to produce a diagnostic image while limiting radiation dose in various CT examinations and body areas. ULO6 - Explain the physical and mathematical principles of CT image reconstruction and processing techniques. ULO7 - Select the appropriate MSCT protocol and post processing techniques for core and fine needle biopsies; angiographic studies and virtual colonoscopies from within an evidence - based framework. ULO8 - Explain how advanced CT imaging techniques can incorporate data from other imaging modalities, e.g. PET-CT, to enhance diagnostic outcome. ULO9 - Explain the role played by the radiographer in the application of safety and quality assurance and quality control principles within the MRI suite, including comprehensively and critically describing pre-scanning screening of MRI patients, and safety issues involved in the use of gadolinium-based contrast agents. ULO10 - Correlate the appropriate equipment, advanced MRI imaging sequence and post processing techniques with the clinical indications, patient preparation and positioning methods to include a variety of body areas. ULO11 - Outline and describe the principles of advanced MRI specialist techniques and parameter selection and those of MR-PET, and recognise the implications this has on image quality (+/- Signal and contrast to noise ratio, image resolution and scan time). ULO12 - Distinguish between sensitivity, specificity, accuracy, search error, detection error and interpretation error in relation to the interpretation of general radiographic images. ULO13 - Critically apply the knowledge of psychophysics of vision to patterns seen in radiographic imaging. ULO14 - Apply a logical method to the radiographic evaluation of bones, soft tissues and joints of the skeletal system, chest and abdomen. ULO15 - Recognise the characteristics of the radiographic representation of radiographic anatomy and common pathologies affecting the skeletal system, chest and abdomen ULO16 - Exercise professional judgement in respect of providing a series of evidence-based radiographic comments related to the interpretation of general radiographic through the use of a radiographer opinion form.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: MRI imaging and evidence based practice
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply the principles of evidence-based health care practice to the delivery of MRI imaging in the clinical context. ULO2 - Explain the role played by the radiographer in the application of safety principles within the MRI suite. ULO3 - Describe a range of clinical indications, patient presentations, patient preparation and positioning methods for MRI studies of the brain, spine, upper abdomen, pelvis, the knee and shoulder. ULO4 - Select the appropriate MRI protocol and post processing techniques for MRI studies of the brain, spine, upper abdomen, pelvis, the knee and shoulder from within an evidence-based framework. ULO5 - Recognise the characteristics of the MRI representation of common pathologies affecting the brain, spine, upper abdomen, pelvis, the knee and shoulder. ULO6 - Accurately apply the principles of quality assurance and quality control to MRI imaging in the clinical context.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply a systematic approach to the evaluation of x-ray images. ULO2 - Reduce interpretation errors through an understanding of the psychophysics of visual perception and the phenomenon of pattern recognition. ULO3 - Distinguish between sensitivity, specificity, accuracy and interpretation error when evaluating x-ray images. ULO4 - Identify normal radiographic anatomy and normal variants and apply this knowledge to x-ray images of the musculoskeletal system, chest and abdomen. ULO5 - Critically evaluate the quality of x-ray images to ensure diagnostic accuracy.? ULO6 - Implement appropriate interprofessional communication strategies when determining x-ray findings.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Physical foundations of magnetic resonance imaging
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Justify the physical design and operational requirements for a typical clinical MRI system ULO2 - Explain the imaging parameters that define the contrast sensitivity in MRI ULO3 - Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of gradient and spin echo recovery techniques ULO4 - Present logical arguments for use of different contrast agents in clinical practice ULO5 - Justify the reasons for precautions that are taken in MRI to ensure staff and patient safety ULO6 - Recognise deficiencies in images, such as reconstruction artefacts, identify the cause of such problems, and implement strategies to correct or attenuate image artefacts
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Compare and contrast benign and malignant musculoskeletal pathology and comment on their radiographic characteristics. ULO2 - Correlate x-ray images of the thorax with underlying pathology such as neoplasia, thrombotic episodes and septic emboli and analyse associated physiological processes ULO3 - Critically evaluate clinical presentations indicating an acute abdomen and correlate pathologies with diagnostic tests including radiographic images ULO4 - Relate the anatomy and physiology of the pancreas and liver with diagnostic procedures to determine pathology? ULO5 - Compare characteristics of CNS pathology, in particular focal lesions caused by neoplasia or infection and evaluate how the clinical presentation and radiographic imaging aids in diagnosis
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically evaluate how the different combinations of the individual imaging protocols within hybrid imaging can be utilised to enhance disease diagnosis. The protocols of particular relevance include CT, MRI, Ultrasound, SPECT and PET. ULO2 - Differentiate between hybrid and multi-modal imaging and explain the challenges that arise in trying to align images both temporally and spatially. ULO3 - Explain the physical and mathematical principles of image registration, segmentation and partitioning. ULO4 - Identify and implement the appropriate multi-modal protocols to combine anatomical and functional imaging modalities for cardiovascular and oncological conditions within an evidence based framework. ULO5 - Accurately apply the principles of quality assurance and quality control to hybrid imaging.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Relate mechanisms of injury and the clinical signs or symptoms of injury with the abnormal x-ray appearances of the shoulder girdle, upper limbs and the cervical spine. ULO2 - Apply a systematic and logical approach to the radiographic evaluation of bones, soft tissues and joints of the shoulder girdle, upper limbs and the cervical spine. ULO3 - Identify and evaluate x-ray images related to trauma, sport injuries, and arthritic conditions affecting the shoulder girdle, upper limbs and the cervical spine of adult and paediatric patients. ULO4 - Apply knowledge of sensitivity, specificity, accuracy and search error in the interpretation of x-ray images of the shoulder girdle, upper limbs and the cervical spine of adult and paediatric patients. ULO5 - Describe the major features of x-ray images related to trauma, sport injuries, and arthritic conditions affecting the shoulder girdle, upper limbs and the cervical spine of adult and paediatric patients. ULO6 - Communicate using appropriate terminology the presence of x-ray appearances affecting the shoulder girdle, upper limbs and the cervical spine to other members of the health care team.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Relate mechanisms of injury and the clinical signs or symptoms of injury with the abnormal x-ray appearances of the pelvic girdle, lower limbs and thoracic and lumbar spine. ULO2 - Apply a systematic and logical approach to the radiographic evaluation of bones, soft tissues and joints of the pelvic girdle, lower limbs and thoracic and lumbar spine. ULO3 - Identify and evaluate x-ray images related to trauma, sport injuries, and arthritic conditions affecting the pelvic girdle, lower limbs and thoracic and lumbar spine of adult and paediatric patients. ULO4 - Apply knowledge of sensitivity, specificity, accuracy and search error in the interpretation of x-ray images of the pelvic girdle, lower limbs and thoracic and lumbar spine of adult and paediatric patients. ULO5 - Describe the major features of x-ray images related to trauma, sport injuries, and arthritic conditions affecting the pelvic girdle, lower limbs and thoracic and lumbar spine of adult and paediatric patients. ULO6 - Communicate using appropriate terminology the presence of x-ray appearances affecting the pelvic girdle, lower limbs and thoracic and lumbar spine to other members of the health care team.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Advanced CT and clinical decision making 1
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Communicate an informed understanding of the principles of CT radiation dose, including CTDI, DLP and effective dose ULO2 - Implement dose minimisation techniques/strategies in clinical CT practice ; ULO3 - Critically apply knowledge of pharmacological principles of intravenous iodinated contrast media ULO4 - Critically assess risk factors and contraindications to the use of intravenous iodinated contrast media in advanced CT practice ULO5 - Analyse and refine CT pre-examination patient questionnaires ULO6 - Implement evidence based CT imaging protocols for brain and body perfusion studies based on clinical indications ULO7 - Provide  high quality patient care while managing health service resources ULO8 - Produce and critically evaluate high quality diagnostic multi-planar and 3D images from cerebral, neck, thoracic, abdominal, and extremity arteries CTA studies through the competent use of advanced workstations ULO9 - Communicate the CT appearances of a range of common vascular disorders ULO10 - Foster inter-professional collaboration through communication of CT risks, methodology and CT appearance of common pathology
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Advanced CT and clinical decision making 2
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically evaluate aspects of scanner design, techniques and protocols for imaging for the paediatric patient in an adult medical imaging setting. ULO2 - Apply the principles of CT radiation dose, including CTDI, DLP and effective dose and implement potential dose minimisation techniques/strategies in clinical CT practice in relation to CAD CT, cardiac studies, paediatric CT, Dual Energy CT and musculoskeletal CT ULO3 - Inform the inter-professional health care team of risks and benefits associated with radiographic contrast media in paediatric, trauma, cardiac and Dual Energy CT examinations. ULO4 - Implement evidence based CT imaging protocols for trauma, lung analysis, cardiac studies and musculo-skeletal examinations taking into account intravenous contrast requirement, clinical indications, patient care, healthcare resources and inter-professional collaboration. ULO5 - Produce and critically evaluate high quality diagnostic multi-planar and 3D images from cardiac, and musculo-skeletal studies through the competent use of advanced workstations. ULO6 - Communicate the CT appearances of common musculo-skeletal and lung disorders.

ULO1 - Analyse the life cycle of a mining project and understand the fundamentals of systems engineering.
