ULO1 - Identify and interpret the biggest challenges faced by modern society from an evolutionary perspective; ULO2 - Describe the fundamentals of evolution, and how these shape the diversity of life on the planet; ULO3 - Articulate how evolutionary processes have affected and continue to affect the environment in which we live, as well as human health and behaviour; ULO4 - Differentiate between evidence, interpretation, opinion and fact in evaluating evolutionary perspectives and concepts applied to the development of modern human society. ULO5 - Effectively synthesise and communicate findings of articles, blogs, book chapters and books written on these issues for the general educated public.

UNIT_TITLE: Climate change: From science to society
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand the basic scientific concepts underpinning natural climate change, anthropogenic climate change and responses; ULO2 - Critically evaluate information on climate change, climate change impacts and responses from a variety of sources including scientific reports, blogs and the media; ULO3 - Develop, apply, integrate and generate knowledge to analyse and solve problems in climate change, its impacts and the options for possible societal responses; ULO4 - Demonstrate competence in information technology, data handling, problem solving, communication skills and team work; ULO5 - Convey the basic concepts of climate change, its impacts and possible responses to diverse audiences.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: School of Earth, Atmosphere and Environment

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Compose arguments reflecting the key themes of adaptive leadership whilst demonstrating critical thinking skills; ULO2 - Construct a persuasive presentation demonstrating leadership presence though improvisation, storytelling and other speakership techniques; ULO3 - Demonstrate and reflect upon how to build and work in functional teams; ULO4 - Develop a digital presence demonstrating authenticity, personal values and ethical frameworks that have been identified through leadership development. ULO5 - Plan and take action on a personal leadership quest.

ULO1 - Critique the key tools of adaptive leadership demonstrating critical thinking capacity; ULO2 - Apply leadership skills and experiment with interventions in complex systems; ULO3 - Analyse and synthesise major global challenges using scientific evidence; ULO4 - Demonstrate and reflect upon how to build and work in functional teams; ULO5 - Produce a mentoring plan that reflects the development of self-awareness and leadership aspirations.

ULO1 - Demonstrate an understanding of the concept of sustainability and sustainable development; ULO2 - Demonstrate knowledge of the Earth's physical, chemical and biological resources and their role in human survival; ULO3 - Demonstrate understanding of the ethical responsibility and impact of humans on the Earth's resources; ULO4 - Critically evaluate research into human impacts and sustainability and demonstrate knowledge and develop ideas as to how the impacts can be reversed or ameliorated; ULO5 - Design, analyse and communicate a research project relating to sustainability of the Earth; ULO6 - Demonstrate competence in information technology, scientific writing, problem solving, communication skills and team work.

ULO1 - Describe how science works and the regulatory mechanisms for ensuring ethical scientific practice ULO2 - Acquire, critically analyse and communicate complex scientific ideas and information. ULO3 - Apply core strategies to effectively communicate science with diverse audiences, across various modes. ULO4 - Conceptualise and refine a research topic using the scientific process. ULO5 - Adapt your practices and communication to address the rise of misinformation in a changing landscape.

UNIT_TITLE: Indigenous science: Science through the eyes of Australias first peoples
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify science found within traditional Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander practices; ULO2 - Communicate science found within traditional Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander practices; ULO3 - Reflect on their intercultural competence and how that can impact how people value other peoples knowledge and traditions; ULO4 - Identify and communicate key events post-colonisation which have impacted Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders ability to use their traditional practices for the good of their communities, and to recognise the importance of these changes ULO5 - Design a culturally appropriate science communication piece in lines with a need in an Indigenous community or, to communicate Indigenous science to a non-indigenous audience.

ULO1 - Use a range of tools to identify and evaluate entrepreneurial venture opportunities; ULO2 - Differentiate between entrepreneurial business types; ULO3 - Articulate strategies for establishing entrepreneurial businesses; ULO4 - Evaluate appropriate financing opportunities for entrepreneurial ventures; ULO5 - Demonstrate teamwork capacity and knowledge of leadership by using a case-study approach to examine the entrepreneurial life cycle.

ULO1 - Develop a comprehensive business plan for an original idea, taking into account opportunity and risk; ULO2 - Work with others to critically evaluate business plans, and integrate feedback from peers/mentors to make improvements in planning; ULO3 - Articulate the core concept of their business plan in a pitch; ULO4 - Demonstrate teamwork capacity and knowledge of leadership by using a case-study approach to examine the entrepreneurial life cycle; ULO5 - Develop a plan for their first internship.

ULO1 - Illustrate an understanding of various concepts of sustainable biodiversity management ULO2 - Critically assessed various in situ conservation ecology and biodiversity projects in the field ULO3 - Apply diversity sampling methods in the field ULO4 - Apply community shadowing technique to understand stakeholder roles and challenges in local conservation project ULO5 - Construct and analyse human ecology through actor network theory (ANT)

ULO1 - Demonstrate leadership, an entrepreneurial mindset, cultural intelligence and networking skills by identifying and liaising with individual or organisations to develop an internship plan. ULO2 - Execute an internship project with a high degree of independence, professionalism and accountability. ULO3 - Apply and reflect upon knowledge and skills gained in the Impact Through Science units within a professional context. ULO4 - Actively seek out and act upon constructive feedback. ULO5 - Identify and convey the knowledge, skills and attributes required for the professional workplace in the global world.

ULO1 - Apply project management skills to develop, implement and deliver the specified project. ULO2 - Undertake independent research to demonstrate an understanding of the current scientific, social, corporate and/or political contexts of the projects. ULO3 - Articulate the importance of disruptive and innovative thinking to achieve impact through science. ULO4 - Refine teamwork capabilities and identify areas for improvement. ULO5 - Demonstrate critical thinking and persuasive communication through written reports and oral presentation.

ULO1 - Discuss selected issues in managing a scientific laboratory; ULO2 - Describe their obligations under the Occupational Health and Safety Act and related legislation; ULO3 - Recognise hazards associated with chemical and biological materials, instruments and ionising radiation and the risks they impose; ULO4 - Undertake a risk assessment and recommend safe working procedures; ULO5 - Outline their legislated obligations in recycling and disposal of hazardous materials; ULO6 - Apply the principles of chemistry, biology, microbiology and physical science to the treatment of hazardous materials; ULO7 - Discuss the effects of waste materials on the environment; ULO8 - Recommend procedures for the analysis and treatment of hazardous wastes before disposal to the environment.

ULO1 - Application of the knowledge and skills acquired during their academic studies to the practical requirements of the workplace; ULO2 - A positive contribution to the organisation; ULO3 - A capacity to work effectively as a member of a team through well-developed skills in job planning, time management, problem solving, critical thinking and the organisation of work; ULO4 - A sound understanding of the requirements of working with others in a position of responsibility; ULO5 - Effective and appropriate communication skills; ULO6 - Awareness of OHS issues and demonstrate application of safe practices in a workplace environment; ULO7 - An ability to set personal goals and to pursue these goals in a manner appropriate to the workplace.

ULO1 - Review scientific literature, with particular reference to the identification of key information; access information databases in an efficient manner; ULO2 - Practice careful and discriminating information retrieval; ULO3 - Present concise oral reports, with a strong emphasis on the provision of good quality audio-visual material; ULO4 - Construct clear written reports, both brief and extensive; ULO5 - Plan and undertake a minor research or investigative project, and adjust the project progressively as events and results dictate; ULO6 - Meet deadlines; conduct an appropriate statistical analysis of results, if appropriate perform the routine measurements and manipulations of a minor scientific project; ULO7 - Operate with a significant degree of independence, whilst maintaining an efficient and meaningful dialogue with a project supervisor; ULO8 - Act as a constructive member of a seminar audience; ULO9 - Interact with others as part of a team in a work environment.

UNIT_TITLE: Material transformations: glass and sculptural forming

UNIT_TITLE: Folio and reflection for spatial design

OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_TITLE: Physics of medical ultrasound and instrumentation
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Ultrasound production, propagation and tissue interactions and the focusing and steering of ultrasound beams; ULO2 - The instrumentation, performance and use of A-mode, real-time B-mode and M-mode scanning in ultrasound practice; ULO3 - The Doppler effect and Doppler modes used in diagnostic ultrasound to image vascular flow including spectral, colour and power modes; ULO4 - Image quality, relevant image processing, the recognition of artefacts and instrument calibration; ULO5 - Safety issues in medical ultrasound, bio-effects and potential bio-hazards; ULO6 - Advances in harmonic imaging the use of contrast agents and future trends on transducer technologies.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe and explain the major stages of embryology, and the specific embryonic development of the digestive, genitourinary, and central nervous system; ULO2 - Describe and identify the normal structure and function of the vascular system, and explain common vascular pathologies such as atherosclerosis and deep vein thrombosis and their risk factors and symptoms; ULO3 - Describe the musculoskeletal system in general, explain the anatomy and relevant pathophysiology of the shoulder and knee in detail, and identify normal anatomy; ULO4 - Identify regional abdominal anatomy, including cross-sectional anatomy, and explain the pathophysiology of the hepatobiliary system and pancreas; ULO5 - Describe the normal anatomy, physiology and common pathologies of the thyroid and breast, and identify normal anatomy; ULO6 - Identify regional pelvic anatomy, including cross-sectional anatomy, and explain the pathophysiology of the urinary and reproductive systems.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Gain greater insight into the worthiness of the ultrasound and medical literature and the veracity of new knowledge as it applies to clinical practice; ULO2 - Gain experience in identifying research problems in medical ultrasound and developing a research plan that will assist in the resolution of the research question; ULO3 - Develop knowledge and understanding of the practical, technical and management issues associated with the design and conduct of a research project; ULO4 - Gain experience in identifying ethical aspects of a research project and the subsequent process of gaining Ethics Approval; ULO5 - Develop skills in applying a particular research method to the resolution of a research question; ULO6 - Develop skills in logical and critical thought and analysis; ULO7 - Develop skills in the process whereby the development of new knowledge and understanding can be communicated in a coherent manner to a wider professional audience; ULO8 - Gain skills in self organisation in terms of the completion of a project within a set time frame; and ULO9 - Develop the capacity to extend the critical, ethical and creative stance to the clinical setting.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Sonographic professional skills and sonography of the breast and thyroid
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Interpret, compare and explain the key principles of medical law, medical ethics and the control of infection; ULO2 - Identify and describe potential medico-legal and ethical situations arising from sonographic practice and the communication of sonographic findings to patients, radiologists or sonologists and referring medical practitioners; ULO3 - Apply information gathering techniques, summarize information and record a clinical history; ULO4 - Perform routine sonographic examinations of the breast and thyroid safely and to a standard and ethical conduct expected of a competent sonographer; ULO5 - Identify and describe normal and abnormal sonographic appearances of the breast and thyroid and related artefacts; ULO6 - Recognise when modifications to routine scanning approaches are required and describe the limitations of ultrasound in regards to imaging the breast and thyroid.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify, describe and justify the selection of protocols, imaging parameters, equipment and transducers for sonographic examinations of the upper abdomen; ULO2 - Perform routine sonographic examinations of the upper abdomen safely and to a standard and ethical conduct expected of a competent sonographer: ULO3 - Identify and describe normal and abnormal sonographic appearances of the organs and structures in the upper abdomen and related artefacts; ULO4 - Recognise when modifications to routine scanning approaches are required and describe the limitations of ultrasound in regards to imaging the upper abdomen; ULO5 - Implement Spectral, Colour and Power Doppler techniques where appropriate in upper abdominal ultrasound imaging; ULO6 - Explain the application of contrast agents and tissue harmonic imaging in abdominal sonography, and describe and implement quality assurance principles in abdominal imaging.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Sonographic imaging of the reproductive system
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify, describe and justify the selection of imaging parameters, equipment and transducers, infection control measures and consent protocols for sonographic examinations of the female pelvis and the scrotum; ULO2 - Perform routine transabdominal and transvaginal scanning of the female pelvis and routine sonographic examinations of the scrotum safely and to a standard and ethical conduct expected of a competent sonographer; ULO3 - Identify and describe the normal and abnormal sonographic appearances of the male and female reproductive systems and related artefacts; ULO4 - Recognise when modifications to routine scanning approaches are required and describe the limitations of ultrasound in regards to imaging the male and female reproductive systems; ULO5 - Implement Spectral, Colour and Power Doppler techniques where appropriate in ultrasound imaging of the male and female reproductive systems; ULO6 - Describe and implement quality assurance principles to sonographic imaging of the male and female reproductive systems.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify, describe and explain fetal and placental development, circulation and anomalies; ULO2 - Describe and explain the genetics, indications and use of ultrasound in the prenatal diagnosis of congenital anomalies and the application of ethics in obstetric ultrasound examinations; ULO3 - Describe and explain appropriate sonographic imaging techniques to demonstrate normal embryonic processes and pathology visible in the first trimester, including ectopic pregnancy, normal and abnormal feto-placental anatomy; ULO4 - Assess gestational age and growth in the second and third trimesters and growth disorders in the third trimester; ULO5 - Implement the knowledge and interpretative skills gained in this unit to perform routine transabdominal, transvaginal and transperineal sonographic examinations involving the 1st, 2nd and 3rd trimesters in both single and multiple pregnancies safely and to a standard and ethical conduct expected of a competent sonographer* ULO6 - Recognise and describe placental abnormalities and foetal death, normal embryonic processes and pathology visible in the first, second and third trimesters. * The level of the competency obtained will be dependent on access to obstetric ultrasound clinical experience. There is provision to perform to a lower standard (advanced beginner) as many students now have limited or restricted access to ultrasound practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify, describe and justify the selection of imaging parameters, equipment and transducers, infection control measures and consent protocols for sonographic examinations of the musculoskeletal system, neonatal brain, hips and abdomen; ULO2 - Perform routine sonographic examinations of the shoulder and/or paediatric kidneys safely and to a standard and ethical conduct expected of a competent sonographer; ULO3 - Identify and describe the normal and abnormal sonographic appearances of the musculoskeletal system, neonatal brain, hips and abdomen and related artefacts; ULO4 - Recognise when modifications to routine scanning approaches are required and explain the limitations of ultrasound in regards to imaging the musculoskeletal system, neonatal brain, hips and abdomen; ULO5 - Implement Spectral, Colour and Power Doppler techniques where appropriate in musculoskeletal and paediatric ultrasound imaging; ULO6 - Describe and implement patient care and quality assurance principles to sonographic imaging.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify, describe and justify the selection of imaging parameters, and equipment, as well as patient care and quality assurance principles for vascular, transplant and postoperative ultrasound examinations; ULO2 - Perform routine vascular ultrasound examinations, including functional measurements of selected vessels of the cardiovascular system to a standard and ethical conduct expected of a competent sonographer; ULO3 - Identify and describe the normal and abnormal sonographic appearances of the upper and lower limb venous and arterial systems and carotid and vertebral arteries on ultrasound images and related artefacts; ULO4 - Recognise when modifications to routine scanning approaches are required and explain the limitations of ultrasound in regards to vascular and transplant imaging; ULO5 - Explain, justify and implement the use of Spectral, Colour and Power Doppler techniques in vascular imaging and the assessment of blood flow and organ perfusion; ULO6 - Describe and explain the gross structure and pathophysiological processes including organ rejection associated with the cardiovascular and immune systems.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Health and health care planning for communities
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify and describe the characteristics of different types of communities. ULO2 - Locate and review data sources to inform evidence based planning for health services. ULO3 - Analyse the characteristics of 'community' and describe the health advantages and risks associated with them. ULO4 - Examine the notion of 'Burden of Disease' (BoD) as it relates to different communities. ULO5 - Develop a community health services profile. ULO6 - Identify gaps in available health services and make recommendations based on health needs of the community.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Discriminate between research methods and determine their applicability to health care research ULO2 - Formulate research questions that are congruent with differing research methodologies ULO3 - Develop a research project that will answer and is methodically congruent with the research question ULO4 - Analyse and critique research reports related to health care ULO5 - Implement a literature search strategy
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically differentiate between research traditions and methods; ULO2 - Undertake a search and synthesis of the research literature and critically appraise the findings; ULO3 - Formulate a research question that addresses an evidence gap in the health care literature; ULO4 - Articulate the ethical considerations in promoting ethical conduct in health research; ULO5 - Design a research project that includes a method appropriate to the research question; ULO6 - Formulate a research protocol that is rigorous and feasible; ULO7 - Communicate the use of research as a basis for decision-making in health care policy & practice; ULO8 - Explain and apply the principles of academic integrity when conducting research.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Communicate an understanding of the use of research as a basis for decision making in the health care policy and clinical arena particularly in its application to health care practice; ULO2 - Formulate a research question that addresses an evidence gap in health care; ULO3 - Undertake a critical analysis of the research literature in response to the proposed research question; ULO4 - Develop a research proposal which explains the selection of appropriate research questions, designs and implementation plans within a health or community setting; ULO5 - Articulate the ethical considerations in promoting ethical conduct in research.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand the key steps of the scientific method and how it can be applied to real problems that involve data analysis and interpretation; ULO2 - Appreciate how statistical data is collected, analysed and stored; ULO3 - Understand the meaning of population parameters such as mean, standard deviation, and median; ULO4 - Understand the importance of statistical techniques in the analysis of data; ULO5 - Present and interpret data graphically; ULO6 - Determine confidence intervals for population parameters, and distinguish between a population parameter and a sample statistic; ULO7 - Determine the appropriate statistical technique for a given context; ULO8 - Perform simple statistical operations using Excel; ULO9 - Take a random sample from a population and determine whether data fits a statistical hypothesis; ULO10 - Prepare and write a scientific report.

ULO1 - Recognise the requirements for design of an effective experiment and the nature of data arising from these situations; ULO2 - Demonstrate an understanding of some of the important parametric and non-parametric methods of statistical data analysis, including analysis of variance, multiple linear regression and logistic regression; ULO3 - Identify and apply an appropriate statistical technique for analysing a given design/ data set; ULO4 - Formulate a model relating a response variable to a number of given independent variables; ULO5 - Use a statistical package for applying statistical techniques covered in the unit.

ULO1 - Identify the various methods and fields of Human Services practice ULO2 - Articulate the importance of research, policy and evaluation on practice ULO3 - Describe the historical and contemporary issues that influence Human Services practice ULO4 - Recognise the impact of self on practice ULO5 - Demonstrate how human services knowledge, values and ethics impact on the development of a human services practitioner identity.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Planning for supervised professional practice placement 1
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Communicate and conduct yourself professionally through participation in tutorials and briefings. ULO2 - Identify and differentiate between the roles and responsibilities of those involved in supervised professional practice placement - the university, the student, and the host organisation by participating in tutorial/briefing activities ULO3 - Transmit knowledge of the service system within Australia with particular reference to Medicare and Centrelink. ULO4 - Analyse and evaluate the importance of supervision when undertaking supervised professional practice placement. ULO5 - Prepare for supervised professional practice placement, by completing tutorial/briefings, and mandatory Faculty and Departmental compliance requirements for placement.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply the AASW Code of Ethics to the practice context. ULO2 - Identify the placement provider's legal and political context within the health and human services field. ULO3 - Explain the legislation and social policies that influence the field of practice. ULO4 - Articulate the theories and methods relevant to the placement context and critically reflect on their use and application. ULO5 - Apply effective communication skills within the placement context. ULO6 - Assume responsibility for self-learning and professional development while on placement. ULO7 - Critically apply knowledge of assessment, intervention and referral skills to the field of practice. ULO8 - Critically analyse different types of social research and their application to social work in the context of the placement setting. ULO9 - Interpret and adapt knowledge of cultural diversity in order to work in a culturally responsive and inclusive manner in a social work context. Students must also provide evidence of completion of at least 500 hours of field placement.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Human rights, legal and ethics knowledge for social work practice
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe how international human rights regimes have evolved; ULO2 - Identify relevant human rights documents, and apply them in social work practice situations; ULO3 - Demonstrate a working knowledge of the Australian Legal System, its international context, and the importance of legal knowledge to competent social work practice, including record keeping and report writing; ULO4 - Find, read, consider, apply, and critically evaluate legislation, and how it informs and impacts social work practice; ULO5 - Identify, describe and critically reflect upon legal and ethical issues and dilemmas; ULO6 - Implement ethical decision making processes in social work practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Develop the ability to critically reflect on their own values and how this impacts on social work practice. ULO2 - Develop an understanding and appreciation of the depth and complexity of use of self in professional practice. ULO3 - Develop an understanding of complexity in areas such as but not limited to ageing, cultural and linguistic diversity, class, family dysfunction, violence, poverty and disability. ULO4 - Develop an understanding of theoretical approaches and models of practice to be able to respond to the complexity of diversity in social work practice. ULO5 - Develop a framework for dealing with complexity in social work and the ability to develop appropriate strategies and interventions.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically reflect on their own values and how this impacts on social work practice ULO2 - Articulate the depth and complexity of use of self in professional practice ULO3 - Identify complexity in areas such as but not limited to ageing, cultural and linguistic diversity, class, family dysfunction, violence, poverty and disability ULO4 - Respond to the complexity of diversity in social work practice based on an understanding of theoretical approaches and models of practice ULO5 - Develop frameworks for dealing with complexity in social work and the ability to develop appropriate strategies and interventions.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Planning for supervised professional practice placement 2
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply knowledge and skills which demonstrate judgement and defined responsibility in relation to Faculty and department compliance and readiness for placement ULO2 - Synthesise knowledge and skills building on learning achieved in Supervised Professional Practice 1 through participation in tutorials/briefings ULO3 - Analyse and evaluate the roles and responsibilities of those involved in supervised professional practice placement - the university, the student, and the host organisation by participating in tutorial/ briefing activities ULO4 - Integrate theory for social work practice by refining, expanding, and consolidating learning achieved through first placement in preparation for final placement, through participation in tutorials/briefings ULO5 - Analyse, generalise and transmit the importance of supervision when undertaking supervised professional practice placement through participation in tutorials/briefings ULO6 - Apply knowledge to prepare effectively for supervised professional practice placement, by completing preparation for placement mandatory requirements such as Faculty and Departmental compliance documentation, and by participating in tutorials/briefing.

UNIT_TITLE: Critical social work 3: Group work and community engagement (context and practice)
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply the stages of group development to the student group project ULO2 - Analyse the impact of different group leadership styles and processes ULO3 - Demonstrate a beginning level of competence in group problem-solving strategies relevant to a range of social work contexts ULO4 - Critically analyse all aspects of their own group experience through engaging in critical reflection ULO5 - Engage effectively with professionals in a community group or organisation through the use of community engagement processes ULO6 - Articulate the features of an effective community engagement process ULO7 - Examine the group and project processes and outcomes through application of evaluation methods appropriate to a range of groupwork interventions.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Critical social work 4: Individual, health and society (context and practice)
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify appropriate competencies for the practice domains that intersect with mental health, including legal and statutory responsibilities; ULO2 - Demonstrate key communication and assessment skills necessary for effective practice with a range of clients in diverse health settings; ULO3 - Reflect critically on their practice - specifically the integration of theory and practice in challenging client situations; ULO4 - Describe specific health problems, recognise the social and psychological components, causes and consequences of ill-health, and have a critical awareness of the socio-economic dimension of health problems; ULO5 - Demonstrate knowledge of the practice and policy frameworks that animate health and mental health and consumer services in Australia; ULO6 - Articulate the factors that influence health and mental health needs of clients and propose distinct and distinctive responses to these; ULO7 - Assess the nature of health and mental health issues and the contributions made by the wide range of professional groups who work with individuals experiencing mental illness; ULO8 - Identify key issues and demonstrate skills in working effectively with clients in health and mental health settings; ULO9 - Structure and present a report on a substantive health issue.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Appraise the meaning and nature of social policy, from different theoretical and practical points of view; ULO2 - Explain the key trends and philosophies underlying the positions of major Australian political parties; ULO3 - Analyse the impact of social structure and social policy on welfare service users; ULO4 - Explain the role of social policy implementations upon their everyday social work practice in keeping with the expectations of the Australian Association of Social Workers Practice Standards for Social Workers ULO5 - Apply marxist, feminist, neoliberal and other ideological critiques of the welfare state, and their implications for particular policy areas; ULO6 - Critique the roles, strategies, and effectiveness of a range of NGO and consumer advocacy/lobby groups in social policy debates;
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Social policy and social justice: Honours
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe the meaning and nature of social policy, from different theoretical and practical points of view; ULO2 - Describe the key trends and philosophies underlying the positions of major political parties; ULO3 - Apply key theories and ideological perspectives in social policy to selected fields; and to learn how understanding different philosophical perspectives helps both to explain the nature of current policies influenced by particular philosophies, and to increase the options for policy development and change; ULO4 - Describe the impact of social structure and social policy on welfare service users; ULO5 - Discuss the role of social policy implementations upon their everyday social work practice as required by the Australian Association of Social Workers Practice Standards for Social Workers which require social workers to "promote and implement policies and practices which would achieve a fair, equitable and effective allocation of social resources; and identify inappropriate or equitable policy goals and outcomes"; ULO6 - Debate marxist, feminist, neoliberal and other ideological critiques of the welfare state, and their implications for particular policy areas; ULO7 - Critique the roles, strategies, and effectiveness of a range of NGO and consumer advocacy/lobby groups in social policy debates; ULO8 - Articulate the link between local and global welfare trends.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture pre-colonisation to the present ULO2 - Identify and describe core fields of contemporary social work practice: this may include social work practice across various settings such as health and mental health, child protection or family violence or working with specific client groups such as individuals living with a disability, the LGBTIQ+ community or Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander clients. ULO3 - Explain the historical and contemporary role of social work across various fields of practice and settings. ULO4 - Distinguish between the law, legislation and legal processes which shape the delivery of contemporary social work practice. ULO5 - Differentiate between key legal obligations and social work ethics as articulated within the Australian Association of Social Workers Code of Ethics
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Critical social work 1: Frameworks for practice with children and families
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe and identify the specific biopsychosocial developmental needs that arise in childhood, adolescence and adulthood to inform direct social work practice with individuals and families. ULO2 - Explain how risk and protective factors may enhance or impede the development of resilience in childhood, adolescence and adulthood and consider how to apply this knowledge in working with individuals and families. ULO3 - Assess the biopsychosocial development of a child, adolescent and adult using a social work framework and analyse the structural factors that have impacted on the client's biopsychosocial development. ULO4 - Critically evaluate the values and assumptions underpinning various theoretical approaches to human development. ULO5 - Synthesise the key evidence in relation to the effectiveness of different theories, frameworks and models applied approaches to direct social work practice. ULO6 - Analyse critically the elements of social work processes including assessment, engagement, the worker/client relationship and referral for the purpose of improving practice. ULO7 - Research and apply key principles in working with children and families from diverse and Indigenous cultures. ULO8 - Demonstrate appropriate and reflexive use of 'self' in the professional helping relationship, based on an awareness of self and others, including assessment of familial, social and cultural contexts.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply the AASW Code of Ethics to the practice context. ULO2 - Articulate the impact of your personal values and biases in the context of the social work assessments and interventions. ULO3 - Identify and articulate the application of theory to social work practice situations experienced on placement. ULO4 - Use a range of social work assessment and intervention methods and techniques appropriate to the area of practice. ULO5 - Explain the legislative and social policy frameworks that influence the area of practice and or agency. ULO6 - Adapt knowledge of cultural diversity and apply principles of culturally responsive practice. ULO7 - Apply effective written and verbal engagement skills with clients, staff, and/or relevant stakeholders; ULO8 - Effectively participate in supervision and use feedback to inform and improve practice and professional development. ULO5 - Negotiate, manage and document the planning and completion of a group activity.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Analyse the meaning and nature of social policy, and to be able to hypothesize the ways it can be understood from different theoretical and practical points of view. ULO2 - Compare and contrast the way political parties deal with social policy issues, and evaluate the key trends and philosophies underlying the positions of major political parties. ULO3 - Construct the link between social policy and the goals and values of social work. ULO4 - Analyse the impact of social structure and social policy on welfare service users. ULO5 - Analyse the role of community practice in social work settings. ULO6 - Apply a range of roles and strategies in community practice.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Leadership in social work and human services
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe leadership within a professional social work framework through analysis of historical and current leadership examples from the human services sector. ULO2 - Critically analyse theories of leadership for the human services in Australia. ULO3 - Contrast leadership theories with selected leaders' experiences and identify and analyse the differences. ULO4 - Articulate where leadership opportunities and responsibilities exist within the human services sector. ULO5 - Identify the components of leadership in the humanservices sector and the distinguishing features of leadership in the human services field.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Create practical and applied research questions related to social work, which can be answered using scholarly and grey literature. ULO2 - Prepare and implement appropriate search strategies to locate relevant evidence. ULO3 - Appraise the quality and applicability of evidence to guide social work interventions or assessment, and research. ULO4 - Interpret and synthesise evidence to provide guidance for effective decision making. ULO5 - Distinguish between the range of data collection and analytic methods, so as to be able to select approaches relevant to the practice issue ULO6 - Design a social work practice research project that is methodologically rigorous, feasible and ethical. ULO7 - Identify the ethical issues relevant to the conduct of research for social work practice, and devise appropriate strategies to manage these concerns, balancing promoting rights and protections. ULO8 - Effectively communicate findings to peers and relevant professionals
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Critical social work 3: Group work and social work leadership
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe and critically analyse the processes of group development and group dynamics, including the role of leadership, in effective and ineffective groups ULO2 - Apply the principles of group development and group dynamics, including the role of leadership, to the development, facilitation and evaluation of a group project ULO3 - Describe and critique leadership within a professional social work framework ULO4 - Critically analyse historical and current theories of leadership for and within the human services sector ULO5 - Formulate and critically assess a procedure for leading a change process as a social worker in a human services context ULO6 - Critically reflect on their ability to work in groups and engage in a leadership role
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Implement ?a person-centred, non-judgemental approach to direct practice social work with ?individuals and families ULO2 - Develop a therapeutic alliance with clients in direct practice from the beginning phases of engagement.? ULO3 - Demonstrate competence in the application of the micro skills common to effective social work practice across a range of diverse service contexts and fields of practice ULO4 - Articulate and justify the adoption of explanatory theories, practice tools or therapeutic framework applied to case conceptualisations across contexts ULO5 - Critically analyse personal values, experiences and assumptions that align with or diverge from the Australian Association of Social Workers Code of Ethics. ULO6 - Demonstrate an awareness of self as a practitioner and its potential impact on the professional helping relationship
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe and identify the specific biopsychosocial developmental needs that arise in childhood, adolescence and adulthood to inform direct social work practice with individuals and families. ULO2 - Draw on theory and evidenced frameworks to explain the manifestation of social problems, assess risk and protective factors that influence individuals and families to inform effective intervention ULO3 - Undertake a biopsychosocial assessment identifying the risk and protective factors that impact on the client's development and reinforce the continuation of presenting issues. ULO4 - Critically analyse the elements of effective social work practice in assessment and intervention including the different types of assessment, engagement techniques, decision making processes, the worker/client relationship qualities and referral for the purpose of improving practice. ULO5 - Explain the ways in which a cultures structures and values may function to maintain the status quo by marginalising or privileging particular ideas or groups of people and its influence on an assessment and how to redress these types of issues through effective interventions. ULO6 - Demonstrate knowledge and aptitude in documenting client assessments and recording details of the engagement demonstrating the AASW Code of Ethics and common agency protocols
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Assessment and intervention 1: Working with families
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Articulate the difference types of social work practice with families as a group, specifically between family work, family conferencing, child protection, case management, linkage referrals and family therapy. ULO2 - Devise and conduct a family assessment to ascertain the level of functioning and needs, values, circumstances, concerns and preferences of each family member and the family as a whole system. ULO3 - Evaluate strategies with families for family strengthening, safety and well-being with regard to risks and resilience, including relevant legislative, parenting skills and health knowledge and set goals. ULO4 - Conduct an evidence based, theory informed social work assessment and intervention plan with a family that includes assessment of risk, needs and resilience. ULO5 - Adapt and implement an intervention plan for families in ways that consider common practice barriers such as collusion, transference and counter-transference between family members, the social work and others involved with the family.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Recovery and trauma in social work  Health and mental practice
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Differentiate between various sub-specialities of social work practice in health and mental health. ULO2 - Devise and conduct a strengths-based and recovery-oriented assessment. ULO3 - Apply the social determinants of health framework to social work practice in health and mental health. ULO4 - Evaluate strategies for trauma-informed care and articulate how to implement these in practice with an individual and/or family. ULO5 - Conduct an evidence-based, theory-informed social work assessment and intervention plan. ULO6 - Adapt and implement an intervention plan that accounts for common practice challenges in the broader structural and cultural systems found in the contemporary Australian context including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander populations.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the nature and function of criminal justice organisations and networks in Australia; ULO2 - Analyse and interpret the meanings of competing and complex objectives underlying criminal justice policy and practice; ULO3 - Critically evaluate, assess and explain research findings in relation to effective interventions in criminal justice; ULO4 - Analyse and evaluate theory and research underlying risk assessment models; ULO5 - Critically analyse theories of criminal behaviour, and formulate hypotheses about their relevance to criminal justice policy and practice; ULO6 - Create a specific research question and formulate a response to this question by identifying, analysing and synthesising relevant published research; ULO7 - Demonstrate an understanding of at least one of the specialist programs directed towards offenders; ULO8 - Demonstrate the capacity to develop a coherent question or hypothesis which can guide an analysis of a specific corrections program or intervention.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically appraise the role of social work in criminal justice contexts. ULO2 - Analyse and evaluate the multiple and competing criminal justice aims and objectives. ULO3 - Assess and explain key research findings as they relate to effective practice and interventions in criminal justice contexts, including those targeted at reducing the overrepresentation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples in the criminal justice system. ULO4 - Analyse and evaluate theories of criminal behaviour and their relevance to criminal justice policies and interventions. ULO5 - Apply effective practice skills for working with involuntary clients to different simulated criminal justice practice contexts.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: The child in society: Promoting childrens well  being and responding to child maltreatment
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain the impact of sociocultural influences and personal biases on perceptions of children and the public policy, law and interventions intended to promote child safety and wellbeing. ULO2 - Identify Australian legislation and international agreements relating to the rights, development, wellbeing, best interests and protection of children. ULO3 - Critically reflect on the inherent tensions between rights and responsibilities of parents, the state, children and their interests ULO4 - Recognise social risk factors likely to impact family vulnerability and key indicators children may be at risk of harm, abuse or neglect? ULO5 - Assess situations where child wellbeing is compromised, assess key needs and consider collaborative, evidenced- based interventions that can improve outcomes. ULO6 - Describe the role of social work in managing responses to child wellbeing and safety in a context of completing societal expectations, legislative frameworks, client preferences and limited resources
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Contextualise social work practice in mental health care and service delivery, including contemporary debates about recovery-oriented practice and lived experience leadership. ULO2 - Critically evaluate concepts of mental illness and recovery using dimensions such as gender, class, diversity and spirituality. ULO3 - Assess the relevance of current and emerging theories of mental health and recovery to social work practice. ULO4 - Critically analyse the notion of risk and its implications for social work practice in mental health. ULO5 - Examine relevant social work policy and practice issues and assess their impact upon the population who experience severe and persistent mental illness.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Social work practice in post disaster sites
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify types of disasters and their impacts globally. ULO2 - Assess emerging global challenges that compound the impacts of disasters upon populations. ULO3 - Critically examine international and national policies in relation to disasters. ULO4 - Describe the nature of gender, vulnerability, adaptive capacity, resilience and social sustainability in the context of disasters.? ULO5 - Compare types of social work responses to historical, current and emerging social impacts of disasters in local, national and international contexts.? ULO6 - Describe social work theories and their applications to social workers attending disasters.?
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Social work practice in a hospital context
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Evaluate hospital and health care systems and identify the roles and skills of social workers in the hospital context. ULO2 - Assess the impact of current health care policies on social work practice in hospital contexts. ULO3 - Integrate research findings with practice interventions used by social workers in hospital contexts. ULO4 - Evaluate usefulness of social work theories and practice models in assessing patients' needs in hospital settings. ULO5 - Apply assessment frameworks in analysing patients' psychosocial needs in hospital settings.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Contextualise to social work practice, contemporary debates about life transitions with a focus on ageing. ULO2 - Critically evaluate concepts of ageing and longevity using dimensions such as gender, class, time, space and place. ULO3 - Assess the relevance of current and emerging theories of ageing to social work practice. ULO4 - Critically analyse the notion of risk and its implications for social work practice in aged care. ULO5 - Examine relevant social work policy and practice issues and their impact upon the ageing population.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Family violence and social work practice
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Analyse the gendered drivers and reinforcing factors associated with family violence from a variety of theoretical positions and practice-based frameworks. ULO2 - Identify and analyse the multiple and complex impacts of family violence on diverse populations, individuals, families and the broader community. ULO3 - Evaluate contemporary approaches to social work practice in responding to family violence, including risk assessment and case management. ULO4 - Critically examine the ways in which family violence legislation and policy shape family prevention strategies. ULO5 - Critically evaluate your personal views, values and assumptions about family violence.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Assessment and intervention 2: Working with communities and groups
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Contrast and compare the differences between individual case work, psychosocial education and therapeutic group work and community development interventions and the implications for social work practice. ULO2 - Devise and conduct an evidence based, theory informed social work assessment and intervention plan applicable to a psychosocial education group. ULO3 - Select and use appropriate group facilitation methods in the context of social work intervention with a psychosocial education group. ULO4 - Adapt and implement a community intervention in ways that consider common community development challenges, such as diversity and geography. ULO5 - Critically evaluate your role within a group setting and manage group dynamics.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Social work capstone: Contemporary issues in social work practice
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically evaluate the role of social work in ameliorating the impact of the major challenges facing vulnerable populations including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. ULO2 - Synthesise key research findings related to contemporary theory and practice within a field of social work practice. ULO3 - Identify a complex contemporary issue, challenge or problem within a field of social work practice with a particular emphasis upon Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. ULO4 - Formulate and communicate a creative and defensible response to an issue, challenge or problem within a field of social work practice. ULO5 - Implement team - based approaches to the creation of novel responses to social problems. ULO6 - Transition from a student social work practitioner to a reflexive social work practitioner.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Explain what is a drug and addictive behaviour as well as differentiate between types of drugs, their effects and presentations. ULO2 - Analyse the historical and contextual use of drugs, contrast and criticise distinct policies nationally and internationally. ULO3 - Explain and apply the social work framework stages of change to construct intervention plans, case management and referrals. ULO4 - Compare and contrast different interventions applying the concepts of harm minimisation, relapse prevention, clients self-determination and strengths-based approach. ULO5 - Justify potential psychosocial interventions distinguishing the different client groups and stages of change.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: The Australian welfare state and social policy
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Critically evaluate the link between social work goals and values and social policy analysis and advocacy ULO2 - Explore to what extent the provision of formal social rights within developed welfare states enhances social justice for disadvantaged groups with a particular emphasis upon Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples ULO3 - Apply an analytical framework to the evaluation of social policy that accounts for different theoretical and practical points of view ULO4 - Compare and contrast the way political parties deal with social policy issues, and evaluate the key trends and philosophies underlying the positions of major Australian political parties ULO5 - Appraise the impact of social structures and social policies on social welfare users ULO6 - Examine the impact of global welfare trends on local social policy debates
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Collect data in accordance with the accepted standards of scientific research, and within the boundaries of any ethics approval. ULO2 - Organise, analyse and interpret data according to accepted scientific research standards ULO3 - Synthesise critical arguments in relation to the existing literature about the topic. ULO4 - Create a written report that meets the academic standards associated with a research-informed investigation. ULO5 - Generate defensible conclusions in respect to the significance of any research findings. ULO6 - Effectively manage time and resources in a collaborative manner with a supervisor to achieve pre-determined goals. ULO7 - Appraise your personal role as a professional social work practitioner-researcher ULO8 - Orally communicate and defend research findings.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Ethical issues relating to research with humans; ULO2 - Issues relating to the place and role of different types of research in Social Work; ULO3 - The principles underlying qualitative and quantitative research; ULO4 - Research design, research questions and data collection methods; ULO5 - A range of statistical techniques and when it is appropriate to use them.  Students are also required to demonstrate their ability to develop a research proposal.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_TITLE: Social work in a hospital context
UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Analyse hospital and health care systems and identify the roles and skills of social workers in hospital context ULO2 - Describe and analyse the challenges and opportunities facing social workers in hospital context ULO3 - Critically analyse the health care system in relation to social work in hospital context ULO4 - Assess the impact of current health care policies on social work practice in hospital contexts ULO5 - Integrate research findings with practice interventions used by social workers in hospital contexts ULO6 - Evaluate usefulness of social work theories and practice models in assessing patients' needs in hospital settings ULO7 - Apply assessment frameworks in analysing patients' psychosocial needs in hospital settings
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Review contemporary debates about life transitions with a focus on ageing. ULO2 - Evaluate concepts of ageing and longevity using dimensions such as gender, class, time, space and place. ULO3 - Assess current and emerging theories of ageing and their relevance to social work. ULO4 - Critically analyse the notion of risk and its implications for social work practice in this area. ULO5 - Examine relevant social work policy and practice issues in longevity and ageing. ULO6 - Apply a multi-dimensional approach in a specific area of ageing.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Analyse the gendered drivers (particularly gender inequality) and reinforcing factors associated with family violence and do so from critical, feminist, intersectional and anti-oppressive theoretical positions and practice-based frameworks ULO2 - Critique the different and additional manifestations and impacts of family violence on diverse individuals and communities including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, refugee and immigrant women, LGBTIQ+ individuals, and women with disabilities. ULO3 - Compare emerging family violence/violence against women prevention strategies and initiatives ULO4 - Apply actions such as awareness-raising, advocacy, and community development in the development of family violence/violence against women prevention strategies. ULO5 - Critically reflect on personal values, assumptions and professional practice in family violence prevention practice
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Articulate mental health practice and policy frameworks in Australia. ULO2 - Explain historical, social and political factors that have contributed to contemporary mental health practice and policy. ULO3 - Identify appropriate competencies for practice in mental health including legal and statutory responsibilities. ULO4 - Determine specific factors that contribute to and influence client mental health challenges and needs. ULO5 - Articulate and synthesize the objectives and practice approaches in the service system constructed to meet these mental health challenges and needs. ULO6 - Critically reflect upon the inter-disciplinary roles and contributions made by the key professional groups working in mental health service delivery in clinical and community settings. ULO7 - Critically evaluate service programs, their objectives and practice models, in mental health settings. ULO8 - Critically evaluate the research approaches, paradigms and methods being used to answer practice-based questions in mental health. ULO9 - Analyse contemporary mental health issues, including service delivery gaps, innovation opportunities and political priorities.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Approach existing designs with a critical sense of their deeper social and aesthetic values as well as the popular connotations of their styles; ULO2 - Discern symbolic associations in design and express links with a historical vocabulary of images and metaphors which operate in traditional interpretations; ULO3 - Support your intuitive opinions either in favour of a design or against certain designs with reasoned argument and engage the language of criticism in debating the sense or the vanity of certain spaces and objects; ULO4 - Engage in the imaginative task of analysing design in ways which reveal its strengths and weaknesses; ULO5 - Project discriminating judgements with a sense of critical rigour which explores and challenges the existence of the principles of design; ULO6 - Feel comfortable with iconoclastic views of design classics wherever a coherent or poetic reason for disapproval seems justified.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate awareness of current discourses in a range of disciplines which bear on contemporary design; ULO2 - Pursue critical arguments with a sense of their relativity; ULO3 - Assess the bias of an investigative method, considering gender, class and ethnicity; ULO4 - Understand methodology as a critique of method and be able to practice criticism in your chosen field; ULO5 - Explain the basis of designs or art or craft objects not merely as the outcome of practical constraints but the expression of cultural values.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Be aware of current discourses in a range of disciplines which bear on contemporary design; ULO2 - Be able to pursue critical arguments with a sense of their ideological relativity; ULO3 - Assess the bias of an investigative method, considering gender, class and ethnicity; ULO4 - Understand methodology as a critique of method and be able to practice criticism in their chosen field; ULO5 - Be ready to explain the basis of designs or art works not merely as the outcome of practical constraints but the expression of cultural values.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate a secure grasp of certain key concepts in contemporary theory which have particular bearing on your field of design; ULO2 - Relate the terms of your practice to broader discourses; ULO3 - Candidly identify the values in your projects, especially related to gender, class and ethnicity and consider the possible case against the assumptions of your practice; ULO4 - Practice criticism in small forums, considering and conjecturing how aesthetic standards (such as style and taste) are the expression of non-absolute cultural values, and identifying critical questions of other people's practice; ULO5 - Sustain an exegetical defence of your work and its placement in current visual production; ULO6 - Outline the investigative and creative steps taken in the design process and have a critical understanding of how the chosen method fits alongside other paradigms of art, design and social inquiry.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Demonstrate that you have identified a conceptual framework for the research; ULO2 - Argue the logic of your research process; ULO3 - Situate the relevance of your research within a contemporary context; ULO4 - Engage with both your own practices and those of others in a critical manner that informs your work and demonstrates an awareness of the wider field; ULO5 - Demonstrate that you have translated an aspect of your enquiry into a relevant form of scholarship to the field of research (eg; academic poster, abstract, conference paper, journal article, research report);? ULO6 - Demonstrate that you are equipped to sustain an exegetical elaboration of your research.
OWNING_FACULTY: Faculty of Art, Design and Architecture

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Identify and describe the major movements of modernism in Design; ULO2 - Recognise and analyse key examples of practices in design; ULO3 - Discuss the legacy of the European avant-gardes and their lasting influence upon the social role of the designer; ULO4 - Translate basic theoretical contexts in to practice; ULO5 - Critique works of design, and articulate these analyses in both spoken and written form; ULO6 - Identify questions and consider ways to search for information.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Understand the history and the prehistory of communication design; ULO2 - Critically discuss different perspectives on the social significance of communication design; ULO3 - Recognise historical and theoretical references in contemporary works of communication design; ULO4 - Articulate an informed position in relation to key issues in communication design discourse; ULO5 - Analyse and discuss the social or disciplinary significance of works of communication design.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Investigate a range of current design research methods for design practice; ULO2 - Evaluate and apply design research methods to a design project, demonstrating a synthesis of complex theories, concepts and propositions; ULO3 - Communicate specific design strategies and approaches reflecting on the outcomes of design research in design practice; ULO4 - Clearly articulate a design methodology and its critical application to the discourse of a design practice.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe systems and systems engineering. ULO2 - Conduct the major tasks in system engineering: need analysis; requirement analysis; concept exploration; risk analysis; prototype test and evaluation; and verification and validation. ULO3 - Analyse the hierarchical structure of complex systems. ULO4 - Implement a System Development Life Cycle (SDLC). ULO5 - Design and analysis of mechanisms and control programs for mechatronic systems. ULO6 - Analyse and select sensors and actuators for mechatronic systems.

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Describe fundamental principles of kinematics of particles and rigid body motion in a plane. ULO2 - Describe fundamental principles of kinetics of particles and rigid body motion in a plane. ULO3 - Apply the principles of kinematics to solve questions of particles and rigid bodies. ULO4 - Apply the principles of kinetics to solve questions of particles and rigid bodies moving in a plane. ULO5 - Identify the key concepts of Mechanical of Materials (MOM). ULO6 - Apply concepts of MOM to bending and torsion, and combined stresses. ULO7 - Apply concepts of MOM to transformation of stresses, and failure theories.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Apply engineering fundamentals to design a mechatronics system. ULO2 - Design a complex mechatronics system that meets design requirements. ULO4 - Identify and use appropriate techniques, resources and modern engineering tools to achieve the design requirements. ULO5 - Justify technical details of a mechatronics solution(s) in written and oral forms. ULO6 - Demonstrate the ability to work effectively as a member or leader in a diverse team. ULO7 - Manage a project and drive it to successful completion. ULO8 - Demonstrate an understanding of the motivation for engineers to carry out mechatronics design.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Determine dynamic trajectories using kinematic approaches. ULO2 - Analyse the behaviour of a dynamic system using computational methods. ULO3 - Appraise the available mathematical approaches to model dynamic systems. ULO4 - Determine the equations of motion of a dynamic system using a range of fundamental approaches.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Appraise sensors in terms of their performance and characteristics, and apply transducer principles. ULO2 - Construct a complete sensory system including specifying the electronic components required. ULO3 - Describe sensory techniques as used in robotics and implement these concepts. ULO4 - Design, construct and debug a small microprocessor system that is capable of interfacing to a series of different inputs and outputs. ULO5 - Construct appropriate software and test processes to produce industry-ready products.
OWNING_ORG_UNIT: Department of Electrical and Computer Systems Engineering

UNIT_LEARNING_OUTCOME: ULO1 - Value the significance and relevance of systems and associated control in engineering ULO2 - Formulate linear dynamic mathematical models of various systems (mechanical, electrical, fluid, hydraulic and pneumatic) as well as graphical models (such as block diagrams and signal flow graphs) using time-domain, frequency-domain and state-space techniques together with the unified concept of resistance, capacitance and inertia/inductance ULO3 - Calculate the response of systems as a function of time using classical differential equation solution, Laplace transforms and state-space method ULO4 - Analyse the stability and dynamic performance of a system using root locus and Bode plot methods, and calculate system parameters to achieve the desired dynamic response ULO5 - Recognise the effects of non-linearity in systems and accept the limitations of the use of linear models as approximations ULO6 - Formulate solutions using computer-based techniques (such as Matlab).
